*"Sweeping the pavilion, I read with unwaning delight,
Beneath green shade, the clear day stretches leisurely.
Leaning on my staff, I pace the stream’s bridge,
Gazing upon the ten-mile hills south of the lake."*

**Dong Luoshi**
Master Dong Luoshi, styled Yun, was a native of Haining. Renowned among rivers and lakes for his poetic skill, at sixty he traveled to Kuaiji and met Yangming. Their conversation spanned days and nights, after which he begged to become his disciple. Yangming refused. Luoshi returned home and wove a bolt of silk as an offering, saying, *"My sincerity has accumulated like these threads."* Thereupon he bowed and joined Yangming’s circle. His disciples urged him, *"Why do you weary yourself so in old age?"* He replied, *"I follow only what I love."* Thus he named himself the *"Daoist Who Follows His Heart."*

**Wu Kangzhai**
The Recluse Master Wu Kangzhai, styled Yubi, was a native of Chongren. He journeyed to the capital and studied under Yang Pu, whereupon encountering the profound origins of the Lu-Wang school, he harbored the aspiration to befriend the sages of old. Taking the worthies as his certain teachers, he gathered in his body and mind and championed the illumination of principle. In the second year of Tianshun, an imperial summons brought him to the Hall of Literary Splendor, where he was appointed Left Attendant of the Eastern Palace and Left Instructor of the Heir Apparent. He declined the post. The emperor sought to compel him to serve, but he refused thrice.

He then claimed illness and returned home, where he shut his gates to lecture on learning, with followers numbering in the thousands. He styled himself the *"Kangzhai Recluse."*

**Lou Kezhen**
The Recluse Master Lou Kezhen, styled Liang, was a native of Shangrao. In his youth, he traveled in the company of Wu Kangzhai. His learning took the gathering of the scattered mind as the gateway to reverent attention, and *"neither deliberating nor scheming, neither forgetting nor forcing"* as its essential tenets. Wang Yangming once received instruction from him. He styled himself the *"Master of One Studio."*

**Chen Baisha**
The Perfected Master Chen Baisha, styled Xianzhang, was a native of Xinhui in Guangdong. Having passed the provincial examination, he immediately withdrew into seclusion. Upon hearing that Wu Kangzhai was lecturing on learning in Linchuan, he abandoned his former studies to follow him. In teaching others, he did not rely on words or texts, taking stillness as the foundation and recognizing Heavenly Principle in all circumstances, with the crucial point being *"neither forgetting nor forcing."* He further said, *"The scholar takes spontaneity as the宗, self-forgetting as the great, and desirelessness as the ultimate."* The Provincial Administration Commissioner Peng Shao and the Governor Zhu Ying, having heard of his reputation, jointly memorialized the throne to recommend him, petitioning for his recruitment with propriety. A certain Minister of Personnel argued that Xianzhang, by precedent, ought to be subject to selection and was no mere recluse—why employ recruitment? Summoned to the capital, he was ordered to take the Ministry of Personnel’s examination. Xianzhang pleaded illness and did not attend, begging leave to return home to serve his mother. He was then appointed Hanlin Academician. Thereafter, he repeatedly declined imperial summonses.

**Xue Jingxuan**

Scholar Xue Jingxuan, styled Dexian, was a native of Hejin in Shanxi. Having passed the imperial examinations, he served as Vice Minister of Rites. During the Tianshun era, he spent several months in the Grand Secretariat but, witnessing Shi Heng and others wielding power, sighed and said, *"The noble person perceives the subtle and acts—he does not idle away the day."* Thereupon, he resigned his post and returned home, retiring to seclusion in the Longmen Mountains. His learning took the recovery of original nature as its core, his self-cultivation profound and meticulous, his words and deeds all worthy of emulation. He authored *Records of Reading* in twenty volumes, which scholars revered as authoritative.

**Zhang Haiguan**
Recluse Zhang Haiguan, styled Xishi, was a native of Qiantang. In the renwu year of the Tianshun era, he passed the provincial examinations but failed to succeed in the metropolitan examination, whereupon he was appointed Instructor of Shanyin. Soon after, he retired to the forests and springs. At home, he had several bamboo stalks, within which he built a pavilion named *"Curing the Vulgar."* He also wrote a preface in praise of it, which read in part: *"My desire for leisure having proven incurable, I hung my official cap at the Gate of Divine Might, nearly twenty years ago. Later, I became an old gardener at home, planting several hundred clumps of bamboo, each standing tall with stalks like whips and nodes like staffs. Amidst them, I built a small pavilion with six pillars, thatched with straw, embodying the essence of rustic simplicity. Seated in this pavilion, the clear sounds of bamboo chime like jade, curing the ears of clamor; the delicate fragrance soothes the nose of coppery stench; the clustered leaves, lush and green, cleanse the eyes of dust and haze; the bamboo shoots serve as tea and dishes, curing the mouth of gluttony; and the hollow heart and unyielding nodes may yet cure those who are self-satisfied and lose their integrity. Thus, I borrowed a line from the old poet Su [Shi] and named it the *Pavilion for Curing the Vulgar.* Alas! If there are those who dwell in lofty halls with painted beams yet remain vulgar in spirit, why not visit this pavilion even once?"*

**Jin Yuanyu**
Recluse Jin Yuanyu, styled Cong, was a native of Shangyuan. He once traveled to Chicheng Mountain in Zhejiang, lingering there and unwilling to leave, whereupon he styled himself *"Farmer of Chicheng Mountain."* In his dwelling, he often let out long, carefree whistles and gazed into the distance, leaving others unable to fathom him. In his personal conduct and interactions with others, he was lofty, unassuming, pure, and refined. Together with Shi Chiweng, he was known as one of the *"Two Recluses of Jinling."* Chiweng, whose given name was Zhong, was of a bold and uninhibited nature, refusing to serve the powerful. He styled himself *"Chiweng"* and named his residence *"Tower of Reclining Madness."*

**Tang Bohu**
Scholar Tang Bohu, styled Boyan, was a native of Wu. He ranked first in the southern provincial examinations but was later unjustly implicated and barred from office, whereupon he indulged in a life of unfettered wandering—yet his spirit moved between heaven and earth. When Chen Hao admired and sought to employ him, Bohu, discerning Hao’s rebellious intentions, feigned madness to escape. His extraordinary spirit overflowed, sometimes expressed in poetry, sometimes in painting. His literary brilliance and romantic charm illuminated the lands south of the Yangtze, and a stone was inscribed in his honor proclaiming him *"The Foremost Romantic Talent of Jiangnan."* In his later years, he turned to the Buddhist path and styled himself *"Resident of the Six As."*

**Luo Dafu**
Scholar Luo Dafu, styled Hongxian, was a native of Jishui.

Sir Luo Dafu, having ranked first in the metropolitan examinations, was appointed as *Zan Shan* in the court. He memorialized the throne to establish rites for the Eastern Palace in advance, but this offended the emperor’s will, and he was stripped of his post and returned home. There, he secluded himself, refusing to emerge. He carved out a stone grotto to dwell in, fashioned a half-couch, and sat in silent meditation for three years, able to foresee events before they occurred. He once said: *"One must not mistake fleeting visions for true attainment. Daily, one must gather and refine the self, lest the habitual tendencies of acquired nature seize the moment to arise anew—only then will a lifetime not have been lived in vain."*

**Zhao Huaixian**
Recluse Zhao Huaixian, styled Jin, was a commoner of Wucheng. During the Zhengde era, he was summoned by imperial decree but refused to answer. Those who sought his door found themselves led into deep ravines and secluded gorges. He would often sit in a small skiff, drifting upon rivers and lakes, content in solitary joy. The two ministers Nanyuan and Ruoxi formed the Jian Mountain Society and came to his hut to invite him to join, but he declined. Throughout his life, he cultivated tranquility and nurtured serenity. At the age of ninety, he composed his own funeral elegy and passed without illness.

**Shen Zideng**
Recluse Shen Zideng, styled Shi, was a native of Hangzhou and the son of Shen Rui, Vice Minister of Justice in the Ming court. Though born into nobility, his heart yearned for purity and truth.

Clad in rustic garb amidst the mountains, he would let forth long, resonant whistles. He styled himself "Green Gate Mountain Man," setting this example to admonish the worldly clans enamored of fleeting splendor.

**Chen Qiwei**
Recluse Chen Qiwei, styled Tiwen, was a native of Jiangyin. He built a thatched cottage west of the city outskirts, where he tilled several dozen *mu* of land to sustain himself. Whenever guests arrived, he would invariably prepare wine, and when the wine flowed freely, he would compose poems. One of his verses reads:

*When fish is caught, then wine is bought;*
*With wine at hand, guests are detained.*
*Such is joy—why pine for wealth?*
*Without fish or wine, the host fares best;*
*The guest fares ill—so let him rest.*
*Thus lying abed, why fear the dawn’s delay?*

Truly the words of one who has attained understanding. Among his contemporaries were the "Five Peaks" and "Ten Peaks" mountain recluses, most of whom aped the airs of the gentry in coarse cloth, a most contemptible affectation. Amidst the fields, he alone preserved his unfeigned nature.

**Gu Yingyu**
Eccentric Gu Yingyu, styled Liyu, was a native of Shangyuan. Having risen to the rank of Vice Commissioner, he promptly retired to seclusion in Baixia. Some questioned his early retirement, asking how he could sustain his integrity in retreat. He replied, *"Were my official purse filled, that would hardly be the way to nurture purity."* He dwelt in a small attic, which he inscribed with the name *"Cold Pine."* He once taught young students to support himself. When Minister Huo Weiya sought to bestow upon him a hundred *mu* of abandoned temple fields, he firmly declined. Such was his steadfast resolve in poverty.

**Zhu Junzuo**

**Zhu Junzuo**
Eccentric Master Zhu Junzuo, styled Jian, was a native of Yueqing in Wenzhou. Having risen to the rank of Vice Commissioner, he promptly resigned his post and returned home. He built a hermitage in the Yandang Mountains, where he dwelled with the untroubled air of one beyond the dust of the world. When some urged him to reenter official life, he replied, *"How could I trade my five treasures for five pecks of grain!"* The five treasures were Dragon Abyss tea, Singing Bamboo, Gold Star herb, mountain yam, and mandarin fish—all native to Yandang. Such were the gifts of the mountain he cherished.

**Master Xu**
Eccentric Master Xu Chang was a native of Chong’an in Min. He devoted himself to the study of principle and served as Instructor in Ming Classics in Putian. After mourning his parents’ passing, he returned home and, once the mourning period ended, refused to take office again. When urged to resume his career, Xu wept and said, *"I sought official stipends only to support my parents. Now that they are gone, what use is office to me?"* He built a retreat in the Wuyi Mountains and remained in seclusion, never emerging.

**Lai Yixian**
Eccentric Master Lai Qutang, styled Yixian, was a native of Liangshan in Shu. Renowned for his perfect conduct, he passed the provincial examination during the Jiajing era but declined to take office, choosing instead to care for his parents. His learning took the extension of knowledge as its foundation and the cultivation of human relationships as its essence.

Officials memorialized his virtues and recommended him for appointment as a Hanlin Academy Attendant, but he declined to assume the post. Throughout his life, his writings were vast, yet only his *Commentary on the Book of Changes* consumed his utmost effort. He first studied the *Changes* at Fushan Thatched Hall, yet after six years could not even glimpse its gateway. Thereupon he journeyed as a distant sojourner into the depths of Qutang’s mountains in Wan County, immersing himself in deep reflection, forgetting food and sleep. After a long time, enlightenment suddenly dawned, and only after twenty-nine years did he complete the work. Thereafter, in observing heaven and earth and examining the workings of creation, he moved without friction among things, abiding in effortless self-possession.

**Luo Zheng’an**
Recluse Master Luo Zheng’an, named Qinshun and styled Yunsheng, was a native of Taihe in Jiangxi. Though the court repeatedly summoned him, he never accepted office. During the Jiajing era, he was again nominated for Minister of Personnel, but firmly declined. At that time, when [Zhang] Cong and [Feng] E held power, Zheng’an dwelt in seclusion among the cliffs, shutting his gate to devote himself to the investigation of things and the extension of knowledge. He once said, *"To establish oneself and act in the world, one must first break through the barrier between rightness and profit—otherwise, one will remain forever entangled."* His writings include *Records of Knowledge Painfully Acquired*.

**Xie Zipei**
Eccentric Master Xie Zipei, named Yan, was a native of Fushun. A Jiajing-era *jinshi*, he served as Assistant Magistrate in Zhejiang, then returned home to care for his parents and never reemerged. In the early Wanli era, Provincial Governor Zeng Xingwu memorialized that Yan had lived in seclusion for thirty years, delighting in the Dao through writing, and deserved a capital-rank appointment to encourage recluses in the mountains and forests. An edict was issued to confer the title of Vice Minister of the Court of the Imperial Stud at his home. Contemporaries called him *"The Vice Minister in the Mountains."*

**Lu Zichuan**
Eccentric Master Lu Zichuan, named Shidao, was a native of Changzhou. He passed the *jinshi* examination during the Jiajing era. Having just begun his official career in the Ministry of Rites, he immediately resigned to care for his parents—this when he was not yet thirty.

Du shut his gate and swept no paths for over thirty years, hand-copying several thousand volumes of classical texts. Refined and erudite, he was revered by the world, yet his purity and devotion to the Dao surpassed all others.

**Li Yinnan**
Recluse Li Yinnan, styled Ziji, was a native of Macheng in Huanggang. During the Wanli era, when the age favored harsh strictures, he became an old gardener and never emerged. At the time, taxes in the two Guang provinces were repeatedly increased, and people across the south and north often bore the pallor of starvation. Yinnan composed *The Old Gardener’s Lament*, saying:

*"Alas, my garden—you and I endure still;
Alas, you worms—do not gnaw my vegetable roots.
Mince and porridge, mince and porridge—
Such is the fare of those above,
Not meet for rustics like me."*

Those who heard it all sighed in sorrow. Once, while hoeing, he unearthed a statue of a dragon deity and venerated it morning and night with utmost reverence. Suddenly, he dreamed of a figure in golden armor with a jade-green face who spoke with him briefly. Thereafter, his predictions of future events proved as swift and sure as an echo. One day, he told his younger brother and son: *"Now the three great bandits of Shu have been pacified. The worthy withdraw from the world; the next best withdraw to another place."* Then, turning his back on the deity, he vanished into the Sichuan wilderness.

**Yu Changru**

The scholar Yu Changru, styled Chunxi, was a native of Qiantang. A *Wanli* era *jinshi*, he served as a secretary in the Ministry of Personnel. After resigning his post, he found solace in the scenic beauty of Ge Hill and Qixia, wandering through mist in wooden clogs, ever content. Huang Yunyong recorded of him: *"He embodied Confucian conduct, cultivated the mysterious as his practice, took Chan as his refuge, entrusted himself to mountains and rivers, and made literary arts his play."* Truly, this encapsulates his life.

The scholar An Wosu, styled Xifan, was a native of Wuxi. He too served as a secretary in the Ministry of Personnel but was dismissed for his outspoken views. Upon returning home, he shut his door and never ventured out—when he did, it was aboard a single boat, where he painted the likenesses of Tao Yuanming, Zhang Jiying, Su Dongpo, Mi Nan’gong, and other renowned worthies upon the windows, making them his companions amidst mist and water. He roamed freely, delighting in his wanderings and forgetting to return.

The scholar Yao Gongshou, styled Shou, was a native of Jiashan. Rising from the post of censor to become prefect of Benning, he resigned and returned home, where he built the *"Rainbow Moon on Azure River"* boat. Sailing between Wu and Yue, those who glimpsed him took him for a transcendent being. At home, he constructed pavilions and halls, naming them *"Red Mound"*—people thus called him *"Master of Red Mound."*

The recluse Zhou Shuda, styled Yi, was a native of Jinchi in Dian. From childhood, he was remarkably precocious, and as he grew, his demeanor deepened in gravity. His learning took *"knowing when to stop"* as its ultimate principle. He tilled the land to support his mother, untouched by the allure of power or profit.

Once, he encountered a Daoist alchemist who wished to teach him his arts. Yi replied, *"What use is gold in abundance? Inner elixirs—how do they compare to few desires? Outer elixirs—how do they compare to frugal use? Desist! I am a Daoist of the Confucian gate, and my path of refining essence for grand use has long been established."*

The scholar Lu Siduan, styled Chengyuan, was a native of Pinghu. A *jinshi* of the Tianqi reign’s *yichou* year, he served as a vice-director before being sidelined for refusing to align with the Donglin faction. In his memorial, he wrote: *"I willingly stand alone, a petty man of stubborn integrity, and will never cling to the grass or lean on trees like those ambiguous gentlemen."* Thus, he incurred the Donglin faction’s enmity and was fiercely opposed. Dismissed from office, he returned home with a long whistle, embodying the spirit of the ancient *kuang* and *juān* recluses. Whenever he saw riverside households with small bridges and flowing streams, he would linger for ages, unable to tear himself away.

The recluse Wen Yinlin, styled Long, was a native of Yin County. With lofty aspirations, he dwelled in a humble thatched hut, savoring the rustic charm whenever wind rustled the bamboo or clouds chilled the pine roots. Some compared his poetry to riverside cottages—crooked tables, sparse windows—ever playing with the hues of water and clouds. I say his very nature was the same.

The recluse Chen Zhongchun, styled Meigong, was a native of Huating. While still in his prime, he abandoned fame to practice reclusion. He built a hut on the southern slope of Little Kun Mountain, ferried his books by boat, and styled himself the *"Nameless Angler."* On frosty nights when the moon cast its cold light and the iron flute’s notes rang clear, he felt Zhang Zhihe and Lu Tian sui were not far removed from his own time.

The recluse Yin Fangshu, styled Zhongchun, was a native of Xiushui. He tilled the fields in Nancun of Yongle, content in his solitude. He was the very man Chen Zhongchun described: *"Yet I envy old Yin the recluse, who plows alone amid the cooing of turtledoves."* His thatched walls and reed fences offered scant shelter from wind and rain. Admiring Wang Ji’s character, he also styled himself *"Master of Eastern Mound."* In his leisure from farming, he practiced medicine. With the money he earned, he would enter the market to buy tattered books and read them.

The recluse Zhu Baimin, styled Lu, was a native of Wu. Endowed with an extraordinary spirit, he once traveled alone to Mount Huang, journeying far to seek the peaks of Song and Hua. In the early Chongzhen reign, he rode a donkey to the capital, intending to present rhapsodies and eulogies, but left without success. He built a hut at the foot of Lotus Seed Peak on Mount Hua west of the prefecture, drawing water and grinding grain himself, unwilling to meet the powerful and wealthy. At times, he was grouped with Wang Jie’an and Zhao Fanfu as the *"Three Eminences of Wu,"* with Baimin foremost among them.

The scholar Li Yinzhong, styled Tianzhi, was a native of Pinghu. A *juren* of the Chongzhen reign’s *guiyou* year, he later changed his name to Que and styled himself Qianfu. He lived in seclusion on Dragon Abyss Mountain, beside Ten Thousand Pines Terrace, in a single thatched hut.

People praised him for his lofty retreat and distant withdrawal, his poetry resonant with the sound of limpid rivers and jade-green peaks.

**Xie Huixian**
The eminent scholar Xie Huixian, styled Lin, was a native of Yixing. A *juren* of the Chongzhen reign’s *guiyou* year, he concealed his traces at home, tending a single plot of vegetables, never entering the prefectural city. Chen Qinian’s poem in remembrance reads:
*"Half an acre of ox-palace encircles the vegetable field,
Hoeing rows and drawing water, alone in serene ease.
A pair of straw sandals worth a thousand gold—
Yet for ten years more, he treads not the city’s streets."*

**Lu Maoqu**
The lay scholar Lu Maoqu, styled Lian (also written as *Lian*), was a native of Wu County. Twice successful in the military examinations, after the *jiashen* year he shaved his head to become a monk, dwelling at the foot of Lotus Seed Peak. Amid wisteria’s graceful vines, he set his couch within the cliffside, ten thousand peaks facing his door, a single stream winding past his gate. He styled himself *"Liaoyuan Daoist"* and left behind *The Maple River Posthumous Manuscripts*.

**Li Zuoyan**
The eminent scholar Li Zuoyan, styled Yuankuan, was a native of Nanchang. Passing the Chongzhen *jinshi* examination, he served as Vice Commissioner of Education in Zhejiang, but was dismissed for offending Wen Tiren and returned home. There, he built a thatched hut on Deer Valley Isle.

With his disciples he discoursed on learning, maintaining a serene and unassuming demeanor. At the beginning of the Shunzhi reign, when recommended for office, he firmly declined on account of his aged mother and never emerged again in his lifetime.

**Fang Mizhi**
The eminent scholar Fang Mizhi, styled Yizhi, was a native of Tongcheng. Passing the Chongzhen *jinshi* examination, he served as Compiler, his reputation resounding throughout the realm. After the fall of the Ming, he shaved his head, changed his name to Hongzhi, styled himself *Wuke*, and took the sobriquet *"Yaodi Monk."* He wandered through famous mountains and never returned. His writings include *Illustrations of the Zhouyi*, *The Record of Snow-Boiling*, and *The Complete Works of Floating Mountain.*

**Liu Nianting**
The eminent scholar Liu Nianting, styled Boyuan, was a native of Cixi. Rising from the *jinshi* degree to the rank of Vice Surveillance Commissioner, he retired on grounds of illness and lived to over a hundred years. The Master had taken office in the fifth year of the Longqing reign, returned home in the sixteenth year of the Wanli reign, and by the eleventh year of the Chongzhen reign, he was already eighty. Amid perilous times and dynastic upheaval, the recluse endured, his resolve evident in his poem *"Self-Mockery at Eighty":*
*"They say I retired early—
Had I not, what good would have come?
How many longed to return but could not,
Their regrets deep as the yellow dog at the eastern gate."*
Those who heard it held him in high esteem. Later, he changed his name to *Tuokongzi* and vanished into the depths of the mountains, never to be seen again.

**Zhang Haodong**
The eminent scholar Zhang Haodong, styled Ruoxi, was a native of Huating. A *jinshi* of the Chongzhen *guiwei* year, after the *jiashen* year he concealed himself in the countryside, personally tending his garden.

Old friends who sought him out would find him hoeing the earth, straw hat upon his brow, exchanging bows amidst the purple gourds and white amaranth. His thatched cottage, a few rafters only, stood in quiet simplicity. At times, he called himself *"Master Cold Pine."*

**Wei Shuzi**
The reclusive scholar Wei Shuzi Xi, a native of Ningdu in Jiangxi, was a *xiucai* of the late Ming. With his younger brother Li, he built a hut on Mount Cuiwei in Jinhua, where they lived in seclusion together. Though high officials, hearing of his reputation, all wished to meet him, he never went. Li, styled Jizi, traveled widely among the famous mountains of the land, yet returned to dwell with Shuzi on Cuiwei, where a pair of cranes often came to keep them company.

**Liu Qiner**
The eminent scholar Liu Qiner Yongsui, a native of Wei County in Daming, was a *xiaolian* of the Chongzhen reign and appointed instructor of Changzhou. After the fall of the Ming, he concealed himself by Yangcheng Lake. When the provincial governor sought to recommend him for office, he firmly declined on grounds of illness. Though his family was poor and at times lacked even food and clothing, he remained composed. Often, he would take up the oars himself, rowing out to midstream to sing, returning only when the song was done. At dusk, he would linger alone beneath the mist-laden trees, watching the sun sink behind the mountains.

**Xia Yuanzhen**
The eminent scholar Xia Yuanzhen Dao, a native of Daming.

Liu Qiner had passed the *xiaolian* examination of the Chongzhen reign and immediately renounced all thought of official advancement. After the fall of the Ming, he led his wife and children into the mountains, tilling and weaving to sustain themselves. At times, he would take up the axe to craft spinning wheels for sale; people admired their sturdiness and refinement, all vying to purchase them. Clad in short robes, he would walk singing, his voice shaking the trees. Occasionally, he composed poetry and prose, but once the draft was complete, he would discard it. His sons were taught only to recognize characters and keep accounts; as they grew older, they herded cattle and carried firewood, their traces lost amid mist and clouds.

**Lin Mingjun**
The eminent scholar Lin Wei Mingjun, a native of Pingdu, was a man of ardent resolve who from youth excelled in poetry and ancient-style prose. When Sichuan fell in the Chongzhen reign’s *jiashen* year, Minister of War Wang Yingxiong received the imperial mandate to suppress the rebels. Lin was recommended as the foremost candidate and appointed Director in the Bureau of Operations of the Ministry of War. After the fall of the Ming, he refused to serve. During the Shunzhi era, he was nominated as Vice Prefect but declined on grounds of illness. Later, he was also nominated for the *Boxue Hongci* examination but did not attend. He built a hut beneath parasol trees, living in serene accord with the Dao, and remained in reclusion for over thirty years. Once, in Pingdu, he invited a spirit-writing séance; I happened to take up the planchette, and the spirit bestowed upon him the four characters *tie gan shi dan* ("iron liver and stone gall"). His extant works include *The Collected Writings of Danyuan Hall*, *The Poetry of Baziyuan*, and *Recent Works from Wutong Residence*.

**Huang Taichong** of the Qing dynasty.

The Recluse Master Huang Taichong Zongxi was a native of Yuyao. He studied under the Ming Confucian Liu Niantai, delving deeply into the teachings of former worthies, and thus his followers grew daily. In the eighteenth year of the Kangxi era, the Censor-in-Chief Xu Yuanwen specially recommended him to the court, but Taichong declined on grounds of illness. He purified his mind and sat in solemn stillness, striving to sweep away all external distractions. His writings spanned the ages, penetrating the myriad discourses, and he mastered all texts—from those on celestial offices and terrestrial records to the books of the Three Teachings and the Nine Schools. Scholars honored him as "Master Lizhou."

The Eminent Gentleman Qiu Zhi’ji
The Eminent Gentleman Qiu Zhi’ji, styled Zhaoaao and named Zhi’ji, was a native of Yin. In his youth, he studied the profound learning of human nature and destiny under Huang Zongxi. As a student of the Imperial Academy, he enjoyed great renown. Later, he served as Vice Minister of the Ministry of Rites but soon retired, citing illness. He engaged in deep inquiry into the secret principles of self-cultivation with Tao Cuncun of Kuaiji. Over time, his countenance became like pine and crane, radiating brilliance through the mountains and forests—truly one who had attained the vast and unshakable. His extant works include *Concise Explanations of the Four Books*, *Detailed Commentaries on Du Fu’s Poetry*, and *Insights into the Yellow Emperor and Laozi*.

The Recluse Tao Cuncun
The Recluse Tao Cuncun, styled Susi and originally named Shiyu, was a native of Kuaiji. In his youth, he traveled among the waters and mountains of Yue and the imperial palaces of Yan, and his literary brilliance flourished ever more. He passed the imperial examination in the Kangxi era but soon retired to reside in Shanyin.

He frequented the immortal realms of Huotong Grotto-Heaven, where he encountered transcendents from beyond the world who transmitted to him the secret methods of self-cultivation. Thereupon, he burned his examination essays. He composed *Five Daoist Sayings*, *Collected Commentaries*, and *Miscellaneous Principles of the Elixir School* to guide later disciples. Qiu Zhiji praised him, saying, "He roams carefree through forests and springs, delighting in Heaven and fulfilling his destiny." Truly discerning words. He styled himself "Layman of the Pure and Tranquil Heart" and also "Master of Penetrating the Subtle."

The Recluse Yan Qinming
The eminent scholar Yan Qinming, a native of Ronglu, passed the provincial examination in the Kangxi *bingwu* year. He delved deeply into the study of classics and history. When Wu Sangui occupied Shu, many scholar-officials were coerced into service, but Qinming alone upheld his integrity and refused to emerge. After Shu was pacified, he built a dwelling at the foot of Yuchan Mountain and spent his life without ever setting foot in the cities.

The Recluse Shen Yuexi
The reclusive scholar Shen Yuexi, styled Juru, was a native of Wan County. Embracing lofty ideals, he retreated into the mountains, styling himself "Wild Man of West Stream." Li Peizhi, the governor-general of Sichuan, knowing of his long-standing scholarship, urged him to enter officialdom, but he declined. He constructed a hall of several bays, declaring, "I find joy in cold amusement; all who gaze upon my countenance regard me as Chao Fu or Xu You."

The Eminent Scholar Cheng Wuqiao
The eminent scholar Cheng Wuqiao, styled Mengxing, was a native of Jiangdu. He passed the metropolitan examination in the Kangxi era and was appointed Compiler. After returning home due to mourning, he never reemerged, for he was one indifferent to profit.

He built the Bamboo Grove Garden and the Southern Ripple Villa, where he composed verses and reclined in leisure. Whenever jade-green bamboo swayed in the emerald rain or clouds drifted over the lake’s shade, he would brew tea and share cakes with secluded scholars and refined guests, composing poems inspired by the scene. Those who beheld him saw nothing less than the image of a solitary cloud or a wild crane.

The Eminent Scholar Zhang Huanhua
The eminent scholar Zhang Yishan, styled Liang, was a native of Lou County. Having passed the metropolitan examination in the Kangxi era, he promptly retired to seclusion at West Stream. There he constructed the Pavilion of Preserved Leisure, featuring ten scenic vistas replete with the finest waters, bamboos, flowers, and herbs. Yishan was skilled at playing the zither; whenever he encountered secluded landscapes or moments of perfect wind and moonlight, he would settle the strings and strike up a melody, causing even the chariots of immortals to pause in midair. Though his sons and nephews all attained high office, and some urged him to emerge from reclusion—assuring him that prestigious posts could be swiftly secured—he would only smile without reply. Having attained enlightenment as if passing an examination with an empty mind, he devoted himself wholly to Chan cultivation, styling himself "Daoist of Illusory Blossoms."

The Recluse Jin Shoumen
The reclusive scholar Jin Shoumen, styled Nong, was a commoner of Qiantang. His nature was aloof and unyielding, untouched by the trends of the age. In his later years, he pursued only the joy of others being busy while he remained at leisure.

In the final days of the twelfth lunar month, he would bring out his family’s home-brewed wine, inviting the village elders to gather, laughing and discoursing on the recluses and true gentlemen of past and present—truly a lofty scholar. In middle age, he embarked on a carefree journey, traveling extensively through Qi, Lu, Yan, Zhao, Qin, Jin, Chu, and Min before returning home. He once wished to roam a thousand *li* a day like the ragged Daoist, and again to strike the bell and sweep the ground like the attendant of Clear Cool Mountain. During the Qianlong era, he sojourned in Yangzhou, concealing himself amid painting and calligraphy.

The Recluse Li Keshan
The reclusive scholar Li Keshan, styled Guo, was a commoner of Changzhou. He savored the Dao in his reading, secluding himself on South Ridge, reciting scriptures through hunger, his gate marked by two wooden boards. At times, when firewood ran short, he remained untroubled. He once remarked, *"Wealth and rank may bring joy, but they are not so fine as the immortals; the bustle of court and market may be lived in, but they are not so fine as the forests and springs."* During the Qianlong era, Governor Ya sought him out upon hearing his name, but he avoided the meeting—truly a lofty scholar of Wu.

The Accomplished Zhao Oubai
The accomplished scholar Zhao Oubai, also known as Oubei, styled Yun Song, was a native of Yanghu. In the twenty-sixth year of the Qianlong reign, he placed third in the imperial examination. He served as an official in Guixi.

Having petitioned to care for his aged mother, he never again took office. With Oubai’s early retirement, his travels grew leisurely. He once wandered the peaks of Tiantai, Yandang, and Wuyi, his spirit soaring as if roaming with immortals. Passing Mount Fuquan in Guizhou, he lingered in the Ritual Northern Dipper Pavilion and copied the *Song of Sitting in Meditation* before departing. In his later years, after meals he practiced the *Free and Easy Wandering* method, thus attaining great longevity, presiding over forests and ponds for several decades.

**Yin Guoyuan**
The reclusive scholar Yin Guoyuan, styled Rumei, was a native of Yuanhe. Content in poverty and devoted to the Dao, his secluded integrity remained steadfast. When visitors sought him out, they found a winding stream beside his gate, marked by two wooden boards, nestled among sparse willows by a crooked bridge—his bamboo basket and gourd dipper often empty, yet he remained unperturbed. He once inscribed a couplet: *"Lying in the woods, one truly forgets the years; with a tranquil heart, one need not shame the immortals."* In my spiritual wanderings, I encountered this and judged him a true recluse.

**Wu Zhuqiao**
The accomplished scholar Wu Zhuqiao, styled Weiguang, was a native of Zhaowen. Having passed the imperial examination in the Qianlong era, he served as a secretary in the Ministry of Rites, then transferred to the Ministry of Ceremonies upon entering the Hanlin Academy. Yearning for misty mountains, he resigned from his lucrative post, his aspiration for a life among birds and clouds as deep as the purity of the Jishui and Ying rivers. Roaming the hills in carefree song, he delved into history and literature, collecting rare steles. His uninhibited ways with zither and wine were admired by all, yet I alone esteemed his lofty reclusion.

**Luo Yufeng**
The reclusive scholar Luo Yufeng, styled Pin, was a commoner of She County who later settled in Yangzhou. He once studied under Shoumen, his brushwork imbued with extraordinary spirit, particularly fond of painting ghosts and spirits. Whatever he encountered, he recorded in long scrolls, compiling the *Ghost Amusements*. In my spiritual wanderings through Yufeng’s studio, the ghosts all rose to bow—truly a marvel. Beyond painting, he excelled in poetry, delighted in mountain travels, and favored Chan Buddhism. He composed the *Record of Awakening Faith*, resolving the doubts of both Chan and Pure Land schools.

**Weng Dansheng**
The reclusive scholar Weng Dansheng, styled Chun, was a commoner of Huating. His nature was pure and untrammeled, his poetic style serene and leisurely—even Xu Yonghui and Luo Zhaojian could not surpass him. His friend prefaced his collected works, writing: *"He delighted in tranquility, embraced solitude, served his mother with beans and water, farmed, studied, and taught his younger brother. Unmarried at forty, he never sat for official examinations. His poetry was like the sparse strings of a zither, one chant evoking three sighs."* These eight lines capture Dansheng entirely.

Weng inscribed a poem on the wall while traveling in Yangzhou, with the lines:
*"Two parts of moonlight, shadowing the passes and mountains in dreams,
One surge of waves, voicing ancient and modern sorrows."*

I, Hua Lao Dao, happened to be wandering leisurely at the time and found the words *"dreams"* and *"sorrows"* unsuitable for a reclusive scholar. I altered *"dreams"* to *"shared"* and *"sorrows"* to *"flow,"* drawing from the meaning of *"Together we share this single moon, as the blue river flows without end."* When Weng passed by again and saw the changes, he bowed deeply in reverence, saying: *"Only

Here begins *On the Great Dao*, Upper Scroll

Compiled by Li Xiyue of Hanjia, the Recluse of Changyi Mountain
Respectfully inscribed by Zhang Daoyuan, styled Zishi
Carved in Langzhong by Zhu Daosheng, styled Wanchengzi
Collated by nephew Ying Chuncheng and Zhu Zan, styled Suyuan
Proofread by son Huang Panxi

What is the Dao? It encompasses the generation of Heaven, Earth, humanity, and all things, bearing the mechanism of yin-yang and movement-stillness, possessing the profound principles of creation and transformation. It unites the Wuji and gives rise to the Taiji.

The Wuji is the Unnamed—what is unnamed is the beginning of Heaven and Earth.
The Taiji is the Named—what is named is the mother of the myriad things.
From the Unnamed comes the Named, and thus Heaven is born, Earth is born, humanity is born, and all things are born.

Now, speaking specifically of human birth:
Before father and mother conceived, there was but a vast emptiness, serene and boundless—this was the time of Wuji.
The Wuji is yin stillness; when yin is still, yang is also still.
At the moment of conception by father and mother, a wisp of numinous qi entered the womb—this was the time of Taiji.
The Taiji is yang movement; when yang moves, yin also moves.
From this, yin and yang interact, hardness and softness grind, the Eight Trigrams surge, and thus the Qian Dao forms the male, the Kun Dao forms the female.

At the outset of male-female union, the man’s essence and the woman’s blood blend into one—this is the root of the human body.
Thereafter, the father’s essence is stored in the kidneys, the mother’s blood in the heart; heart and kidneys are linked by meridians, following the mother’s breath. After ten months, the form is complete, and the child emerges from the mother’s womb.
At this moment, the nature is submerged in unawareness, with the Wuji concealing its spirit; the life-force depends on existence, with the Taiji nurturing its qi.
When the qi and meridians are still and the primordial spirit is inwardly stored, this is called true nature.
When the spirit’s thoughts are still and the primordial qi grows within, this is called true destiny.
In this undifferentiated, childlike state, what is present is precisely the Heavenly Nature and Heavenly Destiny.
If one can follow this Heavenly Nature to restore one’s Heavenly Destiny, this is what may be called the Dao—how then could the cultivation of the Dao fail to attain the Dao?

Alas, as consciousness sharpens and awareness deepens, blood and qi nourish growth, and the years pass. The Seven Emotions and Six Desires arise in endless profusion, ceaseless day and night.
The heart, long stirred, wearies the spirit; essence, much depleted, exhausts the qi. Birth and aging press close, and the afflictions of sickness and death take shape. Without replenishment, consumptive illnesses arise frequently, and to long preserve the body becomes difficult.

Observing this path of life and death, people regard it as ordinary—truly a pity! Yet when illness befalls the body, they seek physicians to regulate and heal, hoping to rise from deep affliction and prolong their years. At such times, though the will to live exists, of what use is it?

Witnessing the common aversion to death, I sought the wondrous art of longevity. After years of toil, I came to know the Immortal Dao.
The Immortal Dao is the Dao of long life, yet世人 often dismiss it as heterodoxy.
Yet what the Yellow Emperor and Laozi transmitted is none other than the principle of rectifying the heart, cultivating the body, governing the state, and bringing peace to the world—why then marvel at it as heterodoxy?

If one can cultivate the uprightness of body and heart, true essence and true spirit will gather within, and great talent and great virtue will emerge from within.
The *Classic* says: *"Only when at peace can one deliberate."* How profound the words!
I have long pondered this.

Just as Zhang Liang of Xiapei found tranquility before aiding the Han to avenge Han, and Zhuge Liang rested in Nanyang before assisting Shu to campaign against Wei; as Li Guang of the Tang nourished himself on Mount Heng before reviving the Tang and vanquishing the barbarians—so too did Ge Zhichuan govern Gou Lou, Zhao Qingyuan administer Jia Zhou, and Master Xu of Jingyang preside over his domain: all these attained the Dao and abided in the world, serving in office to bring peace to the people. Could their hearts not have been filled with the benevolence and righteousness of sovereign and father?

Confucius despised reclusion and the bizarre; Mencius rejected Yang Zhu and Mo Di. Yet reclusion here refers to the apocryphal prophecies and works like the *Feng Shan Shu*, while the bizarre denotes figures like Weisheng Gao and Chen Zhongzi. The Immortals’ way is not thus. When Master Changchun was summoned to court, his audience embodied the ancient virtue of cherishing the people and loving all things; when Master Xiyi retired to the mountains, he carried the integrity of lofty purity—where in this lies reclusion or the bizarre?

Yang Zhu’s self-centeredness and Mo Di’s disregard for kin are foreign to the Immortals’ way. Among the three thousand meritorious deeds, aiding others and benefiting the world take precedence; among the twenty-four exemplars of filial piety, Wu Meng and Ding Lan were both Immortal guests—how could they be equated with Yang and Mo?

Confucius spoke of "seeking the will," Mencius of "esteeming the will." What will is this? It is nothing other than *ren* (benevolence) and *yi* (righteousness). *Ren* pertains to Wood, which conceals Fire within—its great function is to nurture and illuminate, hence *ren*. *Yi* pertains to Metal, which generates Water—its great function is to regulate and circulate, hence *yi*. The Immortals’ mercury and lead are the seeds of *ren* and *yi*. When Metal and Wood intermingle, Water and Fire nurture one another, then through reclusion one seeks the will, esteems the will, and thereafter mercury and lead arise, the elixir congeals. The will encompasses *ren* and *yi*, mercury and lead, and unites the Four Symbols of Metal, Wood, Water, and Fire. To seek and esteem this is to act with sincerity; when sincerity and Earth unite, the Five Phases are complete. The great Dao’s affairs are thus fulfilled.

In their time, Confucius and Mencius only refuted reclusion, the bizarre, Yang, and Mo, yet never heard of them rejecting Buddhism or Daoism. From the Tang and Song dynasties onward, however, the two worthies Han [Yu] and Zhu [Xi] vigorously attacked the two teachings, and many great Confucians echoed them. Lesser scholars, picking up their scraps, sought to attach themselves to their tails—yet where, in the end, did they strike? Instead, they only drew smiles from the World-Honored One and sighs from the Most High.

These lesser scholars merely blew idle flutes, lacking the insight of Han and Zhu. Why say so? When Han and Zhu attacked the two teachings, they targeted those who were neither true Buddhists nor true Daoists—not those who genuinely studied Buddhism or Daoism. Otherwise, why would the *Collected Poems of Han Changli* contain so many exchanges with followers of the two teachings? There are poems sending off Daoist Master Zhang, poems sending off the Great Master Dian, and poems for Masters Hui and Ling. Some claim he used others to voice his critiques, as when he wrote of Master Hui: *"I detest the idle and indolent, / Pitying your foolishness and simplicity,"* or of Master Ling: *"I would gather the Way, / And crown your head with it,"* seeming to mock them. Yet why does he offer no disparaging words for Daoist Master Zhang, nor any dismissive remarks for Master Dian? For these two masters were true disciples of Immortals and Buddhas. Master Zhang, an unappointed minister, returned to the Real; Master Dian, with his wisdom and prajna, mastered Chan. Even Han Changli could not bring himself to attack or slander them.

Moreover, his family later produced Han Xiang, the Immortal Uncle, whose snowbound encounter at Blue Pass revealed his awareness that the distant traveler was no ordinary man. In his youth, Master Zhu [Xi] also dallied with the two teachings, but failing to find the gate, he was misled by false adherents. Thus he suspected their teachings of emptiness, absurdity, and desolation, turning back to oppose them. Yet in his later years, his learning deepened, and he grew fond of reading the *Cantong Qi*, even stating: *"The *Cantong Qi* was not written to elucidate the *Book of Changes*; it merely borrows this to convey the timing of advancing and retreating in practice."* In another letter, he wrote: *"Recently, on the road, I carried no other books, and at last grew familiar with the *Cantong Qi*,"* showing his newfound relish for the Immortals’ way. Thus, Han and Zhu only attacked those who were neither true Buddhists nor true Daoists—not those who genuinely studied Buddhism or Daoism. Otherwise, their own words would contradict themselves, rendering the two worthies laughable.

Though untalented, I have perused the hundred schools and synthesized the principles of the Three Teachings, recognizing that all three share this one Dao. Confucianism apart from this Dao is no Confucianism; Buddhism apart from this Dao is no Buddhism; Daoism apart from this Dao is no Daoism. Yet Daoism is uniquely called the Gate of the Dao, taking the Dao as its charge—what more need be said?

In fair assessment: *"Confucianism is for acting to benefit the times; Buddhism is for awakening to the Dao and enlightening the world; Daoism is for concealing the Dao and delivering people."* Each expounds its own wonders; together, they harmonize beautifully. Why engage in verbal disputes?

The Dao is nothing other than exhausting principle, fulfilling one’s nature, and arriving at destiny. Confucius rarely spoke of it; the Immortals expound it freely, illustrating it with metaphors. Though their terminology is abundant, the Dao’s meaning is subtle, so people fail to grasp it. Humans are nurtured by Heaven and Earth and born of father and mother. Following the natural course, descendants continue the ancestral line; reversing it, true Immortals and supreme sages emerge in succession—the principle is the same.

The *Wuzhen Pian* states: *"The practice of cultivating the body is not limited by gender. This great elixir of golden cinnabar, though grasped by the foolish and rustic, instantly elevates one to Immortal rank."*

Regardless of noble or base, wise or foolish, old and frail or young and strong—so long as one accumulates hidden virtue, practices benevolence and compassion, and fulfills loyalty, filial piety, trustworthiness, and sincerity in the human Dao, the Dao of Immortality is naturally not far away. One must also thoroughly understand yin and yang, deeply fathom the workings of creation, discern truth from falsehood, obtain the correct qi of yin and yang, and seek the true origin of lead and mercury. Only then can one transform the bones and attain longevity, dwell in the celestial realm of unending light, enjoy the scenery of eternal spring, and endure as long as Heaven and Earth, shining as brightly as the sun and moon—this is truly the proper affair of a great man.

As for heterodox paths and deviant practices—such as controlling women to absorb yin essence, refining the Three Yellows, or ingesting the Eight Minerals—these are all fruitless side doors. Some advocate massage and daoyin exercises, exhalation and inhalation techniques, or the cultivation and consumption of medicinal herbs as methods of nurturing life. Though these may temporarily dispel illness, they cannot escape the inevitable decline of old age and the exhaustion of destiny, and will only be ridiculed by the enlightened. Master Boduan said: *"The method of breath retention, if one can forget all scheming and extinguish all thoughts, may also lead to samadhi and spirit departure."* Yet essence, qi, and spirit belong to yin, and their dwelling is difficult to secure, often subject to the suffering of displacement. There are also techniques claiming to replenish qi and blood through inhalation, known as methods of "drawing and adding to extend life." These may help avoid illness and prolong years, preserving health and vigor, but if one seeks to ingest and nurture the embryonic Immortal, they will surely fail. All other heterodox paths and deviant practices are truly heresies within our Dao—what are they worth?

Some argue that human life and death are all predetermined by fate, and that none can defy destiny to escape death. Yet they fail to consider that fortune is sought by the self, destiny is forged by the self, and hidden merit can extend one’s years. Those who study longevity need only take hidden virtue as the foundation and the Golden Elixir as the application—thus even destiny may be escaped.

I reverently recall our Most High Dao Ancestor and the successive Perfected Saints, who, moved by a heart of loving-kindness and a vow to broadly deliver all beings, expansively inaugurated the Mysterious Teachings and secretly transmitted the Immortal formula known as the Golden Elixir. From beginning to end, they thereby fully revealed the celestial mechanisms and greatly disclosed the primordial mysteries. Within it, the wondrous practices of conduct—three periods and three barriers, nine zithers and nine swords, medicinal materials and ritual implements, fire phases and talismanic charts—have all been elaborated in full. Each should diligently study the various scriptures to return to the root of one’s nature and destiny.

Though my discourse is common, its principles are most refined—what is said is true and not false. If one obtains this without doubt or suspicion, one may proceed with practice and begin cultivation. Even without encountering an enlightened teacher or good friend, upon obtaining this text, it is as if the teacher or friend stands before you, enabling sudden awakening to the supreme Dao. Compared to other circulating elixir scriptures, all align with the same principle, leaving nothing obscure.

Truly, this is the compassionate vessel across the sea of suffering and the luminous torch guiding the lost. Though the path may be arduous, one must not fear difficulty and settle for ease. Furthermore, after embracing the Golden Elixir, one should retreat to secluded grotto-heavens and conceal oneself in blessed lands. Do not flaunt alchemical gold and silver before the court, becoming a forerunner for false adepts. Conceal or reveal yourself to deliver beings, awaiting the celestial decree to ascend in broad daylight. Only by not displaying one’s talents can one become a supreme Perfected of the highest rank—one who endures through ten thousand kalpas without decay.

Later fellow practitioners, ponder and take heed.

This grand and expansive work first explores the source of the Great Dao, then expounds the principles of human life and the causes of birth, aging, sickness, and death, guiding others to turn their heads toward the Dao, rectify their conduct, and govern with peace—just as the heroic immortals of antiquity, who cultivated both fame and the body, achieving loyalty and filial piety, unlike the heretical teachings of Yang Zhu, Mo Di, or the recluses and eccentrics. It makes clear that this Dao is also the Confucian Dao, where nurturing mercury and cultivating lead differ not from dwelling in benevolence and following righteousness.

Han Yu and Zhu Xi refuted the two schools (Buddhism and Daoism), but they only rejected the false disciples of those traditions; here, a more comprehensive discussion is offered. It sweeps aside heterodox paths and deviant byways, returning wholly to the Dao of exhausting principle, fulfilling nature, and attaining destiny—a resounding call that awakens the deaf and a monumental text that orders heaven and earth.

**Middle Section**
Between heaven and earth, the most numinous and noble is humanity; the most fleeting and swift is time; and that which can be vast and enduring is the Golden Elixir. Yet most people drown in the pursuit of fame, wealth, and power, or entangle themselves in love, desire, and worldly attachments, endlessly greedy like wolves or ceaselessly drawn like moths to flame. When the great limit arrives, how can regret avail them then? They resign themselves to awaiting death, knowing nothing of the method for longevity and agelessness, nor the wondrous efficacy of the Golden Elixir’s divine medicine. How lamentable!

This Golden Elixir’s divine medicine is not something absent from the world, nor is it unattainable in the heavens. It is sought only among its kind—an innate substance of the living body. Simple and easy, near rather than distant. I once composed a *Rhapsody on the Golden Elixir* to record it, its verses luminous and resonant. Now recalling its lines:

*"To forge the Golden Elixir,
First borrow heaven and earth as the Mysterious Female,
Learn the transformations of yin and yang.
Recognize the correspondence of the two eights,
Know the mutual concealment of Kan and Li.
Await the fullness of the metal qi,
Listen to the vastness of the tidal waters.
Then observe the lead blossoms after Gui,
Admire the moonlit evening in the Geng direction.
Wield the knife and spatula in an instant,
Cease the battlefield of dragon and tiger.
Summon the Metal Lord to return home,
Pair the Jade Maiden in the chamber."*

If one truly masters this Dao, even the foolish will become wise, and the weak will grow strong. As the former Confucians said: *"The sage does not speak of ease, lest it confuse people; nor does he speak of difficulty, lest it deter their progress."* If one pursues it with intent and cultivates diligently, one will surely enter sagehood, transcend the mundane, ascend to the realm of longevity, and eternally enjoy boundless joy—how could this be a small benefit?

Moreover, in the pursuit of fame, wealth, and power, some endure extreme hardship before success. If one redirects the heart that labors for such things toward cultivation, one will soon hold the Ninefold Return in hand, preserve the spirit through ten thousand kalpas, and compare this to fame and wealth—how short the one, how long the other!

Confucius said: *"Wealth and honor gained through unrighteousness are to me like floating clouds."* He also said: *"To practice benevolence is to prevent the unbenevolent from affecting one’s person."* Nothing is more unbenevolent or unrighteous than reckless greed and delusion. Master Hu said: *"One who is devoted to the Dao is not burdened by external things."* *Awakening to Reality* states: *"If one understands the mechanism of killing and its reversals, one knows that harm gives rise to grace."* Thus, to seek the Returned Elixir, one must first sever desire. To sever desire, one must diligently wield the mechanism of killing—keeping the spiritual sword ever at hand. When external desires arise, swiftly invoke the killing mechanism, never indulging the mind. With long practice, one becomes indifferent to circumstances and can proceed on the path of returning to the root and reverting to the origin.

The *Wings of the Book of Changes* says: *"All day long, acting with vigor—this is the Dao of reversal."* The Dao of reversal is the fruition of attaining longevity. Why do people not strive to practice it? Even the myriad things, like the grasses and trees, can return to the root and revert to the origin, enduring through the seasons. Humans, the most numinous of the myriad things, move toward death—are they not then inferior to grasses and trees? Can one not feel shame?

This path of returning to the root and reverting to the origin is no heterodox byway or deviant path. The world values virtue and conduct first, with hidden merit as the foundation. One examines the mechanisms of yin-yang transformation, seeks the wonders of the Mysterious Female and heaven-earth, distinguishes the substances of the two eights and Kan-Li, determines the timing of golden blossoms and water-moon, and deploys the power of subduing the dragon and taming the tiger. By clarifying the place where life and destiny are established, and through emptying the self and guarding stillness—where the other is host and the self is guest—with the radiance of sun and moon intersecting and the earthly branches Wu and Ji in use, the Elixir is completed as easily as turning the palm.

The *Book of Changes* says: *"When male and female unite their essence, the myriad things are transformed and born."* Humans receive this body from their parents—without them, how could one exist? Thus, the method of making the Golden Elixir is the same as the process of birth, except that following the natural course produces a human, while reversing it produces an immortal. Between following and reversing, heaven and earth stand far apart. One need only reverse the use of yin and yang, and success comes naturally—this is no heterodox byway or deviant path.

What I have discussed here boldly reveals the true mechanism, all drawn from the oral transmissions and heart-to-heart instructions of the successive sages. If one acts accordingly, one can seize the mysterious power of heaven and earth, plumb the unfathomable depths of ghosts and spirits—this is truly the oral formula of the Golden Elixir. Beyond this, there is no other transmission.

The former worthies said: *"Before the sages were born, the Dao resided in heaven and earth; after the sages passed, the Dao was recorded in the Six Classics."* Though my humble discourse does not dare compare to the sacred scriptures, it may serve as the proper path for seeking the Dao—like parting the clouds and mist to see the blue sky, or cutting through the brambles to find the great road. It is open and unobstructed, suddenly revealing a gateway. If scholars devote themselves to its study, they will naturally and silently align with the karmic conditions of immortality. Do not regard it lightly.

It is worth more than ten thousand gold, rarer than a hundred treasures. Do not show it to the unworthy—cherish it well.

*The Awakening to Reality* states: *"To learn immortality, one must learn celestial immortality—only the Golden Elixir is most certain."* This text focuses on the external medicine of the Golden Elixir, while the internal medicine of the Golden Liquid is also encompassed within it. Repeatedly and earnestly, it urges people to awaken in time, refine the self, and seek the Lead. Its compassion for the world is as if inscribed on the spirit tablet—an old admonition, yet every line is a secret oral instruction. Those with aspiration may further seek the oral instruction within the oral instruction, and the Returned Elixir will not be difficult to attain.

---

**The Following Section**

That which is called "one yin, one yang" is the Dao. Those who cultivate the Dao cultivate this Dao of yin and yang. One yin and one yang are nothing other than one nature and one life. *The Doctrine of the Mean* says: *"To cultivate the Dao is called teaching."* The sages of the Three Teachings all based their teachings on this Dao. This Dao originates in nature and is rooted in life.

Life is like a decree: heaven bestows upon humans its mandate as a command. Nature is principle: humans follow heaven’s principle through their nature. If one wishes to follow this principle, then externally fulfilling ethical norms is its principle, and internally practicing vigilant solitude is its principle. Loyalty, filial piety, friendliness, and reverence reside within, yet their radiance shines outwardly. Joy, anger, sorrow, and delight manifest externally, yet when guarded before they arise, they remain within. The sky is bright and clear, the earth is lively and free—fulfilling one’s nature, the internal elixir is accomplished.

To fully preserve one’s mandate, the diligent care given to it is this mandate, and the method of employing it is this mandate. Cultivating the mind and nurturing nature is the diligent labor of preserving life. Accumulating righteousness to generate qi is the method of employing the mandate. Refining qi to transform spirit, refining spirit to return to heaven—restoring one’s nature and simultaneously restoring one’s life, the external elixir is achieved.

I wish for those who come after to cultivate this true Dao, and so I speak plainly. In cultivating the Dao, cultivating the body is paramount, yet to cultivate the body, one must first rectify the mind and make the intent sincere. When intent is sincere and the mind is rectified, all worldly desires are eliminated. Only then can one discuss establishing the foundation: qi as the agent, spirit as the master.

At the outset of practice, scholars must recognize the moment when the first yang stirs and the time when true Lead begins to emerge. Its qi is swift as lightning, unable to long abide in the prenatal state. In an instant, it generates Water of Gui; in a moment, it transforms into flowing channels. By the time it takes form and materializes, it already belongs to the postnatal and is no longer usable.

Above Kunlun, there is a mysterious gate, its aperture exceedingly small. When yin and yang unite, no movement is permitted. One must wait for their emotions and nature to resonate, and naturally, self and other will communicate. All that has form cannot ascend into the aperture—only the true qi, like a bellows, can enter within. Thus, the sage directly points to the prenatal qi, surging to open this aperture.

It is also said: *"The path of cultivation can extend life and prolong years, refining the true to preserve the whole. It is without coming or going, without birth or extinction."* Yet today’s foolish people, upon hearing of the method that employs the yang of life, instead practice the deceptive arts of bedroom techniques. This is like wearing hemp to fight fire or a moth flying into a flame—coveting beauty, they indulge recklessly. By day, they exert themselves and labor excessively; by night, they indulge in passion and lust, causing their spirit to dull and qi to scatter, their marrow to deplete and essence to wither. Still, they do not awaken, willingly awaiting their end.

The worthies of old were not like this. They fulfilled both loyalty and filial piety, broadly practiced benevolence and righteousness, secretly performed kind deeds, and silently accumulated hidden merits. They regarded life and death as their sole concern, never allowing fame or profit to occupy their minds. By day, they minimized thoughts and worries; by night, they purified their minds and reduced desires. Thus, their spirit remained whole, their qi robust, their marrow full, and their essence abundant.

They often lamented the mortal body as fire within stone or bubbles upon water. Those who have not heard the Dao should urgently seek a teacher; those who have heard it should urgently seek the medicine. They should broadly study and widely adopt, faithfully receive and practice, seeking the great medicine of the prenatal and searching for the elixir formula of transcendence. They should hasten to begin practice, ever fearful that time waits for no one.

The Dao is not some minor technique of side doors—it is the wondrous Dao of the Golden Liquid Returned Elixir, transmitted orally and received in the heart. It is not the method of the Two Vehicles of fixed breathing, but the supreme Dao of the One Vehicle. Through effort, one enters effortlessness; through external medicine, one refines internal medicine. With the self, one seeks the other; with yin, one matches yang; with Lead, one joins Mercury; with qi, one unites spirit.

Effortlessness is not the method of guarding against danger or holding the city, nor the practice of warm nurturing or icy bathing. It is the work of shedding the embryo and transforming the spirit after obtaining the elixir. Effort is not the techniques of sexual arts or the methods of ninefold movement. It is the Dao of tranquil emptiness, guarding the feminine without aggression, still and unmoving, yet responsive when stimulated. This is the task of refining the self and establishing the foundation before obtaining the elixir.

Effort and effortlessness mark the beginning and end of substance and function, as has been shown here. Internal medicine and external medicine are the methods of origin and manifestation, further detailed elsewhere.

External medicine is born within the womb of creation; internal medicine is produced within one’s own body. Internal medicine is essence; external medicine is qi. Internal medicine nurtures nature; external medicine establishes life. Only when nature and life are cultivated together does one accord with the Dao of immortality.

Great cultivators who seek the prenatal external medicine must refine the self to await the arising of yang. They use spirit and qi to forge the sword of wisdom, gathering the Water of Metal and harmonizing softness and hardness. The ancients, in gathering medicine and advancing fire, relied entirely on this.

Eliminate the afflictions of the seven emotions and dispel the harms of the five thieves. Without refining the self to remove the harms of thieves, one cannot constantly respond and remain still. How can the hun and po be controlled? How can emotions and desires not interfere?

If one wishes to enter the chamber and apply the work, to approach the furnace and begin practice, then although the external fire moves, the internal tally does not respond.

Only because hardness and softness remain unbalanced, the sword of wisdom lacks its edge, and demonic forces wreak havoc, disturbing the heart and spirit, giving rise to scattered desires. Thus, one drifts with circumstances, causing mercury and fire to scatter, and the sacred embryo fails to form.

If self-refinement is mastered, the heart harbors no stray thoughts, the body becomes like the Great Void—unstained by a single speck of dust, all concerns dissolved. When the heart dies, the spirit lives; when the body is empty, qi circulates. Only then may one seek the Dao of the first yang and the work of the two celestial periods.

Returning the elixir is easy; refining the self is most difficult! Rely on the sword of wisdom to cleave open the primordial chaos, wield the craftsman’s hand to chisel through the undifferentiated. Then employ the method of inverting yin and yang, the Dao of harmonizing water and fire, so that earth and heaven unite in harmony. Let yang dwell below, and fire will naturally rise; let yin rest above, and water will naturally descend. Only through enduring hardship and practicing forbearance, keeping body and mind unmoved—when one’s nature abides, the other’s qi will return of itself.

If one can do this, one attains the effect of guarding the feminine without striving, remaining still and serene, responsive yet unobstructed. At the moment before the Supreme Ultimate divides, stillness reaches its extreme yet has not yet given way to movement. Yang first revives but has not yet parted from yin. Await the descent of this true prenatal qi, then use the method to gather and guide it into the Yellow Court. Daily, refine one’s mercury, enclosing it securely. As mercury qi gradually accumulates and lead qi gradually disperses, the elixir coalesces within the crucible.

One must then regulate the true breath, circulating it through the six voids, until sound fades and intent unites—only then do qi harmonize and pulses settle, and the elixir begins to congeal. Wait until the sacred embryo’s qi is full, the ten-month work complete, the embryo transformed and the infant born. Nurture it with skill, so that its comings and goings are unobstructed, and it remains unswayed by demonic temptations. Only after the ninefold transmutation is perfected and the time of wall-facing arrives—refining essence into qi, refining spirit into emptiness—do form and spirit become wondrously one, merging with the true Dao. This is the moment when the great man’s work is accomplished and his name established.

This Dao was not transmitted by the ancients to the world, for fools lack steadfast belief and diligent practice, and instead slander it. Thus, it was kept secret. Since encountering the perfected one, I have set forth these essentials of self-cultivation to awaken later learners. Let those of like mind exert themselves together and ascend the immortal’s capital.

This text exhausts the truth of nature and life, revealing the principles of sages, immortals, and buddhas—rooted in origins, clear as commentary. It distinguishes the sequence of action and non-action, the division of internal and external medicine, the subtleties of nurturing and delivering the embryo, all laid out in these pages. Nothing more need be added.

The profound mechanism is directly expounded here, as the patriarch revised earlier works to instruct others. Thus, it is appended to the complete collection as two essays on the firing times of elixir refinement.

In beginning the work, one must not cling to action, for action belongs to the postnatal. Many in today’s Daoist circles fall into this error, hence few in the world attain authenticity. Nor should one fixate on non-action, for non-action leads to stagnant emptiness. Many in today’s Buddhist circles succumb to this flaw, hence few in the world become true disciples of the Buddha. The failure of this Dao to spread lies in its obscurity.

The initial work lies in extinguishing emotional attachments and sweeping away stray thoughts. Removing stray thoughts is the first step in laying the foundation and refining the self. Once the human heart is cleared, the celestial heart returns; once human desires are purified, celestial principle abides. Each day, first still the mind for a time, until body and mind are settled, breath and qi harmonized. Then gently close the eyes, lower the gaze, and inwardly observe the space one inch and three fen between the heart below and the kidneys above. Only by finding the place where qi stirs can one avoid falling into emptiness or clinging to stagnation—neither grasping nor abandoning, neither forgetting nor forcing. All thoughts vanish, and only the solitary spirit remains: this is called right mindfulness.

At this time, within this mindfulness, be lively and free; within that qi, be leisurely and unhurried. Exhale to the upper, but not so far as to disturb the heart; inhale to the lower, but not so far as to disturb the kidneys. With each opening and closing, each coming and going, practice for one or two weeks, and naturally the two kidneys will steam with fire, the qi of the cinnabar field will warm. Breath need not be regulated, for it regulates itself; qi need not be refined, for it refines itself. Once qi and breath harmonize, they naturally neither exit nor enter, neither come nor go in the upper, middle, or lower—this is called embryonic breathing, spiritual breathing, the true bellows and furnace, the return to the root and revival of life, the mysterious female’s gate, the root of heaven and earth.

At this stage, qi is like a flower just budding, like an embryo just forming. Naturally, true qi steams and nourishes the constructive and protective energies, ascending from the coccyx, piercing the spine, rising to the mud-pill palace. Descending the magpie bridge, passing the multi-storied tower, it reaches the Crimson Palace and settles in the middle cinnabar field—this is the initial stirring of the river chariot. But though qi arrives, spirit is not yet complete; this is not the true stirring, so do not attend to it. Simply maintain gentle inward focus, guarding the central palace, and boundless vitality will arise. This is what is meant by nurturing the bud.

After one or two months of practice, the spirit becomes ever more still. With prolonged stillness, qi increasingly generates—this is the work of spirit generating qi and qi generating spirit. After a hundred days or more, vitality flourishes, true qi gradually fills, and with the gentlest firing, blood and water become abundant. Naturally, kan and li unite in marriage, qian and kun converge, spirit merges with qi, and in an instant, true qi blends as one. Suddenly, a whirlwind rises, surging through the hundred channels—this is the true stirring of the river chariot. If a single point of numinous light is felt in the cinnabar field, it is the mysterious pearl beneath the water, the yellow sprout within the earth.

At this time, the first yang revives, like the red sun rising over the vast sea.

Like mist, like smoke—now hidden, now visible—then lead-fire is born. When qian and kun, kan and li have yet to unite, in utter emptiness and quiescence, spirit congeals within. With unbroken effort, all is forged into one mass—this is the harmonizing of the Five Phases.

When water and fire merge, the second stage of gathering begins; the river chariot reverses its course, and in the fourth stage, the medicine is obtained. Spirit dwells within, the radiance of the elixir never departs—this is called the Great Celestial Cycle, the practice of the Ninefold Great Return.

At this time, a single point of utmost yang essence congeals within, concealed in moments of desire stilled and passion quelled. It takes on form and shape. Having reached this stage, breath abides in the embryo, nurtured within and without without the slightest lapse—this is also called the ten-month work.

Moreover, within a single moment of stillness, there lies the work of refining essence into qi, refining qi into spirit, and refining spirit to return to emptiness—not only in ten months. Even within an hour, a day, a month, or a year, it is the same. Sitting with eyes closed, concentrating spirit, calming the heart and regulating breath—this is the work of refining essence into qi. Turning the light inward, focusing spirit in the cinnabar field, allowing true breath to come and go, stillness within reaching its extreme and stirring, movement reaching its extreme and returning to stillness—this is the work of refining qi into spirit.

Thus, true qi returns to the origin, yin and yang revolve and repeat, uniting once more. Naturally, wind subsides and waves grow calm. At this moment, I fix my right mindfulness upon the cinnabar field—this is sealing the firing process. Practicing these three stages of work over months, days, and hours, one does not merely enter the ten-month enclosure.

Thus it is said: In a single moment of circulation, there is a Celestial Cycle for that moment; in an hour, a day, a month, or a year of circulation, there is a Celestial Cycle for that hour, day, month, or year. Yet within a single moment, the first half is warmth, advancing fire, the waxing moon, the upper crescent, the dawn of *zhun*, spring and summer; the latter half is coolness, retreating tally, the waning moon, the lower crescent, the dusk of *meng*, autumn and winter. An hour is divided into the first four moments and the last four, and so too are a day, a month, and a year. This is called gathering and clustering yin and yang, the Five Phases—within a single moment’s work, seizing a year’s qi and seasons.

Having reached this point, it is true emptiness, true stillness. After one or two years, or ten or a hundred, shattering the void to become one with the Great Void—this is the work of refining spirit to return to emptiness.

Once the ten-month work is complete, one must constantly tend to the infant. Step by step, mile by mile, gradually emerging—if one is careless or unrestrained, one may become lost and never return. The immortal scriptures say: *"Spirit enters, qi forms the embryo; qi returns, spirit coalesces into the elixir"*—this is what is meant by *"a single point falls into the Yellow Court."*

Yet those with fewer distracting thoughts attain the elixir sooner, while those with many attain it later. This method is simple, yet people lack the courage to persevere. If one can practice with constancy, one will surely pierce metal and stone, tread water and walk through fire, ascend to heaven and descend to earth. With further accumulation of merit and cultivation of conduct, refining the great medicine of spirit and elixir, one will attain perfection of both form and spirit, ascending in broad daylight with one’s entire household. This depends on the depth of one’s merit.

If one does not refine the spirit elixir but only allows the yang spirit to ascend, looking back at one’s old body as but a heap of dust—even so, one may take wing in broad daylight, enduring for ten thousand kalpas, coeval with the cosmos in eternal spring.

**On the Verification of the Return**

The method of the Seven Returns and Nine Reversions begins with work. First, the true yin within the upper yang orifice is drawn into the inner golden crucible of the qi sea, where it unites with the true yang of the lower orifice. The true yin within yang is one’s own original spirit, belonging to the three *hun*; the true yang of the lower orifice is the original qi within the body, belonging to the seven *po*. When these two qi merge, kan and li naturally unite, *hun* and *po* blend, spirit and qi congeal, and embryonic breathing stabilizes. Each day, like the joy of conjugal union, one must not cling to it—water and fire naturally achieve harmony, circulating through the four limbs like an external fire kindling into flame.
