Only when water and fire are balanced is this the Small Celestial Cycle.

When the firing process is harmonized and steaming, breath reverses course back to the original sea—then external yang naturally enters within, true fire naturally surges upward, the whole body softens with boundless bliss, and within the abdomen, a living dragon stirs, ascending and descending with countless transformations in a single day. The infant boy and maiden girl naturally unite—this is the stage of gathering yin to supplement yang.

Refining the jade liquid and returning the elixir is the foundation of refining the self, accumulating inner dharmic wealth. One abides in carefree ease, luminous day and night—this is the first step toward longevity and eternal vision. Ordinary people rely on the five grains to sustain life; going without food for days, they perish from qi hunger. If one is aged, with the lower origin depleted and marrow empty, unable to bear the qi of the five grains, then the five grains can nourish but also kill.

If one masters the inner and outer union, achieving harmony of water and fire, the reversal of qi and blood, the convergence of the five viscera’s qi, and the opening of the spleen and stomach—then food entering the abdomen can also transform into qi, generate essence, and nourish spirit. If one truly grasps the celestial mechanism of beginning, waiting until the marrow is full and the navel swells like a pregnant woman’s—though there is no actual fetal form, only qi full, essence abundant, and spirit complete—then with these three in fullness, one proceeds to true refinement, regulating spirit and refining emptiness. This is the time of a great man’s achievement and fulfillment.

I urge students to seek out a lineage master, earnestly pursue the perfected ones, and uncover the celestial mechanisms within and without the body. Clearly understand the swift method of beginning practice, refine the self and await the moment, and wait for the arrival of the first yang.

Select a secluded chamber and refine this Dragon-Tiger Great Elixir. It must be a place of profound stillness where no cock crows nor dog barks, and outside, only trusted fellow Daoists should be present—no idle or unfamiliar person may approach, lest the primordial spirit be startled and dispersed.

Earlier I spoke of harmonizing with the world, yet now I speak of seclusion—why? To refine the self amid worldly dust and nurture qi within mountain forests is the moment to enter the chamber and commence practice. To transcend the mundane and enter sainthood—how could this be a trifling matter? One must be unstained by a single speck of dust, free from all cares, utterly unencumbered, cutting all ties as if severing with a blade, forever a wanderer in a foreign land, with no thought of retreat or regret.

Hold emptiness to refine spirit, guard the void to refine nature. Let the five viscera, sinews, bones, qi, and blood of the entire body transform into azure qi. With single-minded devotion, cultivate spirit to perfection, shaping it to obey command. As stars revolve and the Dipper turns, it will change at will. Nurture it until the body bears no wrinkles, like a spider’s form, with the seven orifices radiating light, luminous day and night. When the body becomes like the Great Void, only then is it the proper time to seek the Dao of immortality.

This verifies that qi is full and spirit complete, with abundant dharma wealth—only then can the Great Elixir be refined, and one may truly be called an alchemist. When the work is accomplished, the time will naturally arrive. The seven orifices shine with light, the Three Yangs flourish, and the spirit-sword takes form. Seizing the moment like sailing with wind and tide, one ignites the fire with thunderous roars and lightning flashes, capturing the celestial mechanism beyond the body. At the outset, one seizes and grasps, gathering the true lead from beyond the self, marrying the Dragon to the Tiger, driving the Tiger to join the Dragon.

If one knows how to gather and concentrate without missing the proper moment, the golden essence from the sea-bottom is suddenly drawn up, opening the spine’s passage to ascend to the Mud Pill Palace, then descending into the Crystal Palace, where it unites with the Wood Mercury. In less than half a moment, the gathering is complete, and true fire surges into the four limbs. The entire body’s bones and flesh feel as if scorched by fire or sliced by a blade—this is most difficult to endure. Even the bravest, at this point, will have no control.

Guard against danger and peril, bathing body and mind in ice. When water and fire achieve harmony, in an instant the whole body crackles like roasting beans, bursting open all at once. The body’s qi and blood coalesce into form and speech, clamoring as if gathered in a throng.

Beneath the tongue lie two cavities: the left is the Elixir Well, the right the Stone Spring—this is precisely the Lianquan point. As the bone meridians open, kidney water surges upward like an external spring, impossible to swallow completely, its taste strange and unlike sugar or honey.

Yet the most wondrous moment comes at the outset of tending the furnace: the earth yields its golden lotus, and heaven bestows its precious dew. Suddenly, a drop of true mercury descends, piercing the heart like ice. One then directs a spark of spirit-fire to gather and concentrate it within the Chamber of Union. All at once, it resounds like a thousand drums in battle, roars like ten thousand thunders—yet this is merely the transformation of the body’s hundred meridians, qi, and blood. Do not be alarmed. One must tread the Dipper’s steps, wield the sword, and clasp the seal. Here lies the most perilous point. Three revolutions, nine turns—summoning generals and subduing marshals. With such vigilance, one may witness in the void the Dragon and Tiger in union, heaven and earth in harmony, the sun and moon conjoined. One may see hosts of immortals and buddhas. When the work reaches this stage, myriad visions appear—do not mistake them, lest external demons take hold.

Once the primordial spirit is recognized and mercury and lead unite, after three days the Great Medicine is born. These three days are the most difficult to endure. The entire world becomes a realm of demonic illusions: wailing spirits on all sides, murderous vapors and war smoke in every direction. This is the great opening of the passes. Nine out of ten are terrified to death at this stage. The heart must remain fearless. Though the self has transformed into spirit, it is still yin spirit—yin spirit is most cunning, capable of infinite transformations, and myriad visions may assail. How could it willingly submit? As the ancients said: *"Only when you master the six penetrations can you escape birth and death; if you do not master the six penetrations, do not dream of attaining the Dao in primordial chaos."*

After thirty hours—two and a half days—qi flows unimpeded, reaching its fullness. Suddenly, the living pearl of the Greater Yang reverses its course, leaping from its shell into the mouth. A hundred thousand dragon spirits are struck with awe. This is the true yang elixir of primordial yang. Only upon tasting it does one realize that *"my fate is not ruled by heaven."*

The ancient immortals said: *"Only after this great death does one truly live,"* and *"With one battle, the world is pacified."* This is that very stage—the harmony of heaven and earth, the union of sun and moon. When the true yang medicine enters the mouth, in an instant the fire of the celestial cycle blazes forth. The skeletal frame melts into a mass of flesh, and the yang spirit departs the body, free and unobstructed. With single-minded devotion, hold to emptiness and nurture the void, using emptiness to nourish spirit, the void to nourish the heart, allowing the heart to transform spirit at will.

All things under heaven are born of me; all spirits pay homage and submit as guests. Weary of dwelling in the dusty world, one roams the Peng Isle at leisure. Three thousand jade maidens attend, and daily one feasts at the Peach Assembly, drinking immortal wine, wearing immortal flowers. The four great elements intoxicate, the entire body becomes utterly translucent. The tortoise and snake of the sea-bottom emerge, and ten thousand spirits obey command. Only now are true lead and true mercury inverted, the body enveloped in purple mist and radiant beams—a thousand auspicious vapors. This is the Great Hibernation of the Five Dragons.

After a hundred days of refinement, the Mysterious Pass opens of itself, the infant manifests, and the tortoise and snake appear, naturally entwined. Only at this stage may the adept gather external mercury. After six months of refinement, the body becomes like silver paste, blood transforms into white nectar, and the entire being exudes a fragrant aura. The breath from the mouth forms clouds. This is the maturation of the numinous elixir—a lump of dry mercury. Whoever consumes it will never die and can even revive the dead.

After ten months of refinement, the yang spirit departs the body, and one body can transform into a thousand or ten thousand. Only after twelve months does it seize the full tally of Heaven and Earth, the yang spirit now perfected. The entire body moves in and out as fourteen thousand yang spirits, stepping through sun and moon without shadow, entering metal and stone without obstruction, entering water without drowning, entering fire without burning. Blades and weapons cannot harm it, ghosts and spirits cannot fathom it. Its transformations are boundless—it has become a true person.

The entire body’s qi and signs are nothing but true medicine. A chicken that eats it becomes a phoenix, a dog that consumes it becomes a dragon. This principle is so profound even ghosts and spirits struggle to comprehend it. Without having encountered such words, one would surely not believe in the great medicine of the golden elixir.

The work of creation and transformation undergoes three revolutions and nine cycles. Seven returns and eight reversions—fire timing is subtle. The oral instructions for gathering and assembling take only three to five days to overturn Heaven and Earth entirely. All is natural; the yin and yang of the human body’s creation are also natural. Only by embodying the creation of Heaven and Earth can one achieve success.

The matter must be personally experienced and tested until it reaches the state of naturalness. Though the work spans a year, the subtle fire timing lies within a hundred days, and the critical moments of movement and stillness, danger and ferocity, occur within just a few days. In an instant, internal and external forces converge, and in a moment, clarity arises—the sacred embryo is accomplished. It produces a pearl like a grain of millet, which, when swallowed, completes the fire of the celestial cycle. Shedding the husk and changing the bones requires only maintaining emptiness and nurturing the void; the rest unfolds naturally.

If one truly receives guidance from an enlightened teacher, one first refines the self amid the dust of the world, accumulating lead in the marketplace. Gathering years into months, months into days, days into hours—within the great stillness, it all occurs in a single instant, no more than half an hour, overturning Heaven and Earth. After ten months of firing, one embodies the natural law of Heaven and Earth. If one cannot seek life within death, how can one escape the three great calamities?

**On the Consumption of the Great Elixir**
The emoluments of the Three Pure Ones, the provisions of the Jade Emperor—how could those who are not sages and worthies receive them? Like Xu Jingyang, Master Ge, Yin Zhenjun, and over eight hundred others, all attained the Dao before refining and consuming the elixir to deliver the deluded.

The immortals say: *"When the inner elixir is complete, the outer elixir manifests."* This is the true transmission of the ancients. First, accumulate essence and amass qi, gathering the inner and outer dharmic wealth. When the qi is full and the spirit complete, golden light appears, shining day and night without cease. Only then is the inner elixir of one’s body complete, and the outer elixir of one’s body also manifests.

One must not read books by matching them to diagrams like seeking a steed. Only when the medicine sprouts during the time of unceasing brightness day and night may the adept gather the outer medicine of the body, pairing it with the inner yin and yang to obtain the golden elixir. When it enters the mouth, the fire of the celestial cycle ignites, and in an instant, clarity arises—releasing the hand without obstruction. This is the golden cicada shedding its husk, silently ascending to the Emperor on High, encountering immortal ascension, receiving celestial emoluments. Ten thousand spirits pay homage, able to mend Heaven and patch Earth, pluck stars and grasp the moon, command thunder and turn the Dipper, summon wind and call rain. With a single thought, ten thousand spirits obey, making Heaven and Earth appear as one’s palm. This fortune surpasses that of three generations of emperors, this wisdom exceeds that of seven generations of top scholars. Only at this stage may one refine and consume the golden elixir.

This elixir, like a grain of millet, when dropped to the ground, illuminates the sky with golden light—only then is it called the divine elixir. Without spiritual attainment, how dare one speak of consuming the outer elixir! This principle is profound, the celestial mechanism deep and distant. Gold begets gold, silver begets silver—there is no other numinous spirit beyond this. This art of the yellow and white is not the gold and silver of the mortal world. As the mother restrains qi, if one truly receives the correct transmission, one can produce the primordial great medicine. Recognizing the yellow sprout and white snow—this is the yellow and white, the mother that restrains qi to refine the divine elixir. However, all gold, silver, water, and medicine belong to the postnatal realm. Without knowing the true yin and true yang of the same kind, success is utterly impossible.

Alas, scholars of the world cannot distinguish truth from falsehood and do not encounter true masters. They are all blindly cultivating and recklessly refining. Those who truly cultivate life and destiny, if they have not yet met an authentic teacher, should quietly study the texts.

The *Great Auspicious Scripture of the Divine Elixir* does not utter a single empty word or a single false sentence. It is only that later generations fail to recognize orthodoxy and heterodoxy, unaware that the words of sages and worthies are all hidden metaphors. They encounter mediocre teachers, cling to side doors, and let poisonous doctrines enter their hearts without adaptability. Seeming right but wrong, they are self-important and self-righteous, their voices and expressions repelling others from a thousand miles away. Thus, the lofty depart in disdain—how much more so the immortals and sages!

Before encountering a true master, the scholar should be humble and cautious, accumulating merit and virtue. When facing demons, do not retreat; when slandered, do not grow angry. Value the Dao and disdain wealth. Upon meeting a true master, devote oneself wholeheartedly to seeking, swiftly breaking through the two true mechanisms within and without. Suddenly, one awakens to all the texts and is no longer deluded by others.

If one is a gentleman of great aspiration, sincerely devoted to life and destiny, sweeping aside side doors, firmly settling the mind-monkey, resolutely establishing will and qi, humbling the heart and lowering the intent—enduring demonic trials and hardships, earnestly seeking an enlightened teacher—one must exhaustively pursue the origin of the qi received at birth. The origin is the primordial ancestral qi, which unites with a single point of true yang and true yin.

True yang and true yin are born before Heaven and Earth, at the beginning of the primordial chaos. This luminous pearl, like a grain of millet, hangs in the void, radiant and resplendent. Yet without an enlightened teacher to point it out, one remains as if in a drunken dream. Departing from this, all is heterodoxy. This luminous pearl in the void contains all phenomena, conceals all existence, and gives rise to all things—all is this.

A grain of millet—
In the Daoist tradition, this is likened to true lead and true mercury.
Once truly attained, it must not be sought in Heaven and Earth, sun and moon, or male and female,
but only within one’s own body, setting up the furnace and establishing the crucible,
refining the self and upholding the heart.
When principle is illuminated and nature is perceived,
gathering the fire in an instant, within half a moment,
the mysterious pearl of the millet-grain appears above the winding river.
With a single dose taken, in an instant one aperture opens and a hundred meridians align;
the sinews and bones of the entire body, the five viscera and flesh,
all transform into qi, resembling external mercury.
At this stage, a hundred days of firing effort bring forth numinous wonders—
once attained, it is forever held, with no return.
Abiding in the world while preserving form,
refining spirit to return to emptiness,
one becomes one with the Dao.

In the Buddhist tradition, this is called true emptiness and the wondrous awakened nature.
The proper method begins with refining demons to perceive nature;
in a brief moment, the true fire of samadhi arises,
returning to the origin and restoring the root,
unifying all in a single vision.
The great earth becomes treasure,
radiant with ten thousand rays of rosy light,
the five eyes and six penetrations manifest,
and the indestructible vajra-body is forged,
completing the unfathomable mystery beyond ghosts and spirits.

In the Confucian tradition, this is spoken of as the Supreme Ultimate emerging from the Non-Ultimate.
Considering the external Heaven and Earth,
the Non-Ultimate is the vast expanse surrounding Heaven and Earth,
before the separation of sun and moon,
the four directions and above and below,
a state of primordial chaos like yin mist and watery qi.
Only when the time arrives and qi fills to the point of mutual excitation does the Supreme Ultimate arise.
At that moment, sun and moon are born,
clear and turbid separate—
above becomes Heaven, below becomes Earth.
Heaven’s clear qi is pure yang,
Earth’s turbid qi is pure yin.
Rain and dew descend from Heaven—yang generates yin;
the myriad things arise from Earth—yin generates yang.
Heaven and Earth are but emptiness,
encompassing the boundless and infinite.
The stars and deities of Heaven move and turn in their fixed positions;
the myriad things of Earth follow the four seasons and eight solar terms,
naturally arising—
all, in essence, is but emptiness.
The sun and moon are the essence of Heaven and Earth,
illuminating the thirty-three heavens above and the nine abysses and ten thousand springs below,
revolving east and west, ascending and descending,
the cycle of cold and heat.
The sun is the body of pure yang,
containing within a single point of true yin essence—
associated with the Azure Dragon, the Maiden, Wood of Jia, mercury, the Golden Horse, and the three hun-souls, which are external.
The moon is the body of pure yin,
containing within a single point of true yang qi—
associated with the White Tiger, the Infant, Metal of Geng, cinnabar, the Jade Hare, and the seven po-souls, which are internal.

The workings of the human body mirror those of Heaven and Earth;
thus, the human body also possesses true sun and moon.
The Dao is near—why seek it afar?

The three hun-souls pertain to nature, which resides at the edge of Heaven;
the seven po-souls pertain to destiny, which lies at the bottom of the sea.
The interplay of internal and external gives rise to the two words: *nature* and *destiny*—
comprehending these, the myriad volumes of alchemical texts are resolved.
Nature pertains to spirit and is yin;
destiny pertains to qi and is yang.
Thus it is said: “The Dao is called the unity of yin and yang.”
The thousand scriptures and ten thousand volumes are but different names for this.
Yet true nature and destiny, along with illusory phenomena,
remain unknowable without true transmission.

The immortals say:
“The four great elements of the body all belong to yin—
what, then, is yang essence?”
And again:
“Tears, saliva, essence, fluids, qi, blood, and marrow—
these seven numinous substances all belong to yin,”
for they are the turbid yin of acquired dregs, not true yin.
True yin stands opposite true yang—
if true yin is unknown, how can true yang be known?
Scholars today not only fail to know true yang,
but also remain ignorant of true yin.
Yet if one knows true yin, one must also know true yang.
Without encountering an enlightened teacher, how can one fathom this?

Scholars must exhaustively seek the wonders of the three talents—Heaven, Earth, and Humanity—within their own bodies,
discern the proper furnace and crucible within and without,
and grasp the true workings of yin and yang within and without.
Without attaining the essential teaching,
upon seeing the varied names in texts, the mind lacks certainty,
clinging to heterodox paths without discernment.
Failing to comprehend principle, the heart remains unilluminated;
with an unilluminated heart, one cannot perceive nature;
without perceiving nature, how can one attain destiny?
The ancients said:
*“Only because the golden elixir lacks oral transmission,
how can you be taught where to congeal the numinous embryo?”*
This is the *Guide to Ascending Heaven, Dispelling Delusion*.

The Dao/Way gives birth to Heaven and Earth, nurtures the myriad things—when released, it encompasses the vastness of empty space; when gathered, it retreats into profound concealment. The Two Modes, sun and moon, and the Five Phases are but the transformations within the Dao/Way. Each thing possesses a Supreme Ultimate, which is the Dao/Way. Within every person’s heart lies the primordial, which is also the Dao/Way. The Five Phases flow in sequence to give rise to humans and beings; when reversed, they produce immortals and buddhas. Thus it is said: *“When the Five Phases flow in sequence, the dharma-realm becomes a fiery pit; when reversed, the great earth yields its seven treasures.”* The essence of the Five Phases is hidden in the secret place of the four great elements—neither within nor without—yet people use it daily without awareness.

The people may be made to follow it, for this is the sequential flow; they cannot be made to know it, for this is the reversed flow. Fish dwell in water yet do not know it as water; humans reside within qi yet do not know it as qi. This analogy demands deep contemplation: turn the light inward, illuminate the heart, and perceive nature—how then could attaining the fruition of immortals or buddhas be difficult? Yet today’s Dao-seekers, each claiming cleverness, boasting of wit, and styling themselves as adepts, never attain true awakening. There are also those of shallow roots and blind eyes who, upon hearing the sages speak of external yin-yang, external furnaces and crucibles, and external medicines, cling to the delusion that women are the crucibles—how pitiful indeed!

I have observed those who ardently pursue the furnace and fire, yet a hundred fail to achieve one success. Some cite the Yellow Emperor’s casting of nine tripods to attain the Dao/Way, mistakenly believing that nine women must be used as crucibles—how utterly misguided! I have seen those who have progressed through five or seven crucibles yet still achieve nothing. Moreover, the moment a thought arises, primordial simplicity scatters; once the primordial is lost, even if the posterior remains, what benefit does it bring to body and heart? It merely sustains the four great elements. Such fools know nothing of Heaven’s silent operation—how the four seasons proceed and the hundred things flourish!

The human body’s transformations mirror those of Heaven and Earth, yet who knows how Heaven attained its singular clarity or Earth its singular stability? And who governs these transformations? If one can take stillness as the body, stability as the foundation, the celestial heart as the master, and the primordial spirit as the function—skillfully employing the mechanism of reversal to restore primordial truth, return to the root, and recover destiny—how could one not ascend to the sacred rank of Heaven and Earth?

As for the matter of employing a literary crucible, there is no such principle. If a person of karmic affinity encounters a true teacher, they should first practice the *jade liquid return to the elixir*, refine the self, harmonize the light, and cultivate through introspection—this is the work of perceiving nature and illuminating the heart. Having perceived nature, one may then seek the higher work: the *golden liquid return to the elixir*, where emotions return to nature, until reaching the state of true emptiness, where great function manifests. The Dragon Girl offers a single precious pearl, and golden light appears—only then is there an attainment that endures.

At the juncture of *hai* and *zi*, between *bo* and *fu*, when the first stirring of the Great Yang arises, one reaches into the moon’s cavern with the hand and treads upon the celestial root with the foot, merging the returning wind—from this arises the wondrous efficacy of a hundred days’ work. This is the *golden liquid return to the elixir*, the great Dao/Way of yin-yang and the Five Phases. Apart from the dual cultivation of nature and destiny through the *jade liquid* and *golden liquid*, and the Dao/Way of stillness and spontaneity, all else are but side doors and lesser methods.

I have established the furnace and crucible within and without my own body, mastered the oral instructions on gathering and refining, and understood the subtleties of medicine, fire, and timing. Yet, unaware of the celestial principles, I entered seclusion to undertake the great work of ingesting the external medicine and kindling the fire. At the secret juncture, when the empty space of the myriad spirits pays homage and celestial music plays above the crown, this matter is beyond even the comprehension of gods and ghosts. Alas, because I had not refined myself amidst the dust of the world, nor accumulated lead in the marketplace, my qi and vessels were not yet fully stabilized, and my foundation was not yet complete. Though principle was harmonized, nature remained unseen. Thus, myriad perils arose, the heart and spirit grew distracted, and I could not maintain control. Without a knowing companion to guard and protect me externally, the slightest sensory disturbance startled my primordial spirit, overturning the crucible and disturbing the furnace. The restless mind-monkey and wayward intent-horse fled, the spirit failed to guard its abode, and qi did not return to the origin—plunging me into the realm of yin demons.

What are yin demons? I shall not elaborate, for later learners would not understand. It is because the true yang scatters and yin qi takes control that, day and night within the body, spirits and ghosts wreak havoc. Whether eyes are open or closed, one sees ghosts and spirits coming and going; even in the ears, one hears their clamor. By day, idle moments are bearable, but at night, it becomes unbearable—one cannot remain still for even a moment. The life-master at the sea of qi in the body, the *dui*-metal’s *wu*-earth, surges upward, and the five viscera’s qi and blood follow, rising beyond control. The body cannot be subdued, and life is forfeit—truly the work of ghostly hands.

I temporarily abandoned my previous efforts, following my teacher’s guidance to conceal myself in the marketplace, accumulate lead amidst worldly dust, gather emotions back to nature, and reverse the mechanism of destruction. From youth to old age, the primordial truth stolen by Heaven, Earth, and beings—I now sought to reclaim it from the emptiness within worldly dust and return it to my celestial nature. Only then were the three treasures—primordial essence, primordial qi, and primordial spirit—complete. At last, the heart was illuminated, principle harmonized, nature perceived, the body and heart stabilized, and the Five Phases gathered. Only then could I proceed to the higher work and complete the great Dao/Way.

Reflecting on the sages of former times, many abandoned their practice midway, for they had not refined the self or stabilized the heart, nor had they returned metal to nature. Thus, when they obtained the medicine in the second phase and proceeded to the fourth phase of firing, unaware of the celestial principles and acting with carelessness, even the White Jade Toad lamented *“cutting the autumn bamboo again.”* Who realizes the subtlety, peril, and ferocity of the empty space’s workings? If one cannot seize and subdue it, it will surely not spare them.

If the practitioner discerns the two true workings—within and without the body—with perfect clarity and no obstruction, then they may proceed to nurture and refine, shedding selfishness and restoring the celestial principle. Thus, the work of returning the elixir becomes most simple and effortless. All day, one gathers the Yellow Sprout beyond the body, awaiting the primordial Jade Liquor—this is precisely the wondrous awakening of "drinking wine and wearing flowers" to attain immortality.

As for the state of primordial undifferentiation, there is no intention, no insistence, no fixation, no self; whether living or dying, one forgets both people and things. Like an idler who neglects livelihood, wandering streets and alleys, delighting in sights and soothing the heart, lingering in brothels and taverns, sitting in wordless oblivion—how could this not astonish and perplex the world? To gather the environment and accumulate lead, employing both method and wealth—how could this not invite the ridicule and slander of the vulgar?

Therefore, one must rely on powerful families in great metropolises for external protection, perceiving the Dao in plain sight while concealing one’s light and obscuring one’s traces. The immortals say: *"To covet the treasure of heaven, one must use the wealth of the world."* The treasure of heaven does not refer to the sky above but to the dwelling of the Nine Yang Cauldron within the body—thus did the Yellow Emperor cast the Nine Tripods and ascend. Yet deluded fools, upon hearing the words *"treasure of heaven,"* fixate on the sun and moon in the sky, taking the moon’s emergence in the *geng* direction as true water and true lead, using their eyes to measure degrees and gather it; or at the sun’s rise in the *mao* hour, they likewise employ their eyes to gather it as true fire and true mercury.

The heavens above and earth below, *qian* and *kun*, *kan* and *li*, the inner and outer furnaces of male and female—these are all metaphors for the inner and outer yin and yang of one’s own body, without any actual form of male or female. The immortals say: *"Whatever has form is all delusion."* The returning elixir has no substance—how profound are these words!

Those in the world who cultivate goodness never engage in harming others for personal gain. What men and women in the cosmos rely upon to live without dying is none other than this single point of yang essence. How could one who seeks immortality steal a woman’s essence to benefit their own body? How does this differ from those who kill? Moreover, the ancient sages spoke of *"that household’s male and female,"* *"the two families,"* *"the two nations,"* and *"the inner and outer furnaces"*—if one does not receive the correct transmission, how few will avoid misinterpretation?

I once encountered an enlightened teacher who, through direct instruction and personal guidance, revealed the two true workings within and beyond the empty space. Daring not keep this secret for myself, I transgressed the prohibitions to pass it on. The creation of heaven, earth, and humanity; the scriptures of the Three Teachings; the medicines and firing times; the union of sun and moon; the measures of waxing and waning—all these I have fully disclosed, not through written words but through true speech, so that practitioners may avoid the errors of misguided cultivation. Wherever this book resides, spiritual beings guard it. If one without affinity chances upon it, it will be no more than the blind singing empty verses.

The Great Way of the Golden Elixir is rarely encountered even in ten thousand kalpas—*"tramping in straw sandals yet finding nowhere to seek, yet gaining it without effort."* If the practitioner can nurture this square inch of the heart amidst haste, turmoil, displacement, and hardship, preserving it without loss, then the celestial principle is restored. Once the celestial principle is restored, one may then seek the higher work of ingesting the external medicine, and in an instant, become serene, shedding the mortal coil and transforming the bones, merging entirely into a single golden light, transmuting the great earth into treasure.

The body generates another body beyond itself; the yang spirit departs the form, embracing emptiness and nurturing the void—this is the Great Hibernation of the Five Dragons, attaining boundless freedom and transcending the three kalpas of wind, water, and fire, no longer subject to birth, aging, sickness, death, or suffering. Yet people today do not cultivate the Way but instead covet external elixirs and alchemical concoctions—this is the height of delusion.

This chapter is the concluding section of *Mysterious Essentials*, a general discourse on the sentiments of the Dao. *"Guiding the Lost to Ascend Heaven"* is the overarching title for the verses on the Dao’s sentiments. The closing line—*"if seen by the unworthy, it is but the blind singing empty verses"*—makes clear that this is a general discourse on the Dao’s sentiments.

**Commentary on the *Nine Augusts’ Elixir Canon: Dragon-Tiger Lead-Mercury Treatise***

The Daoist Lord’s discourse on the extraction and replenishment of dragon-tiger lead and mercury is intended for those of the future with roots and affinity to begin their practice here. Though it is said, *"Only immortals can become immortals,"* I insist that *"even mortals can become immortals."* The only fear is not understanding the principle of the Golden Elixir—then one truly enters hell to become a beast.

This dragon pertains to yang; once yang is lost, all becomes yin. This tiger pertains to yin; within yin lies the treasure, which is a single yang. The dragon is the mysterious pass of the self; the tiger is the mysterious gate of the other. The dragon is lustful, yet I do not leak—adding a drop of water to a bit of earth forms the character *yao* (瑶), becoming the supreme treasure of Jade Liquor. The tiger is voracious, yet I do not leak—adding the true fire to the character *jian* (柬) forms *lian* (炼), gathering the supreme treasure of Golden Liquor.

Tiger, tiger, tiger—fear not your gaping maw and fanged jaws, striking terror into hearts and souls. I possess the hand of the tiger-tamer, reducing you to emptiness within form and form within emptiness. With the dragon’s playful touch, I make you the meeting of dragon and tiger amidst wind and clouds, unafraid that you will not yield your tiger cub from the tiger’s den, entering my Three Fields.

Dragon, dragon, dragon—though you are a creature of lust and desire, I possess the hand of the dragon-subduer. Fear not your endless transformations—I use Nezha’s vajra ring to bind you, extracting your sinews to fashion a golden belt for nurturing nature and connecting life, worn always. How could you not then approach the True One of the Great Ultimate to request the unparalleled Dharma-door of the True One, merging with me into the Great Way of primordial unity?

Lead is the lead of the two bowstrings, mercury is the mercury of heaven and earth within my body. With the radiance of sun and moon, heaven and earth become "Earth-Heaven Peace" rather than "Heaven-Earth Obstruction." Since birth from parents, the human body originally possesses one mercury and one lead—the principle of male-female union. Thus it is said: *"Qian is father, Kun is mother; male and female unite in essence, and the myriad things transform into purity."* *"The Changes are the Primordial Ultimate of pre-heaven."*

Yet people fail to grasp this principle: they only cast mercury into lead, begetting sons and daughters, rather than casting lead into mercury to become buddhas and immortals. This iron mantou can shatter all obstacles—how could one not become the Three Abundances within Three Abundance?

**Annotation on Lüzu’s *Hundred-Character Stele*:**
*Nurture qi, forget words, and guard the One.*
All cultivators must first nurture qi. The method lies in forgetting words and guarding the One. Forgetting words prevents qi from scattering; guarding the One keeps spirit from departing. The secret says: *"Seal the tongue, still the mind; embrace spirit, settle the heart."*

*Subdue the heart to refrain from action.*
The human heart is ceaselessly restless. For cultivators seeking stillness, mastery lies in subduing the two eyes. The eyes are the gates of the heart—lower the lids, seal the orifices. Treat all matters as if the heart were a sword: deem worldly affairs profitless, sever them with blazing resolve, and never cling. The secret says: *"Gaze from eyes to nose, from nose to navel; upper and lower align, heart and breath interdepend. Focus intent on the Mysterious Pass—thus thoughts are subdued."*

*In movement and stillness, know the Ancestral Origin.*
Movement and stillness are the interplay of yin and yang. The Ancestral Origin is the source of embodied life. Cultivators must recognize the state before parents’ birth—this is the Mysterious Transformation. Where the body’s Qian and Kun, the Eight Trigrams, the Five Phases, and the Four Images converge is the state before heaven and earth divided, formed from a single luminous spark—the Great Ultimate. Below the heart and above the kidneys, within the nebulous center where thoughts arise without cease—this is the Ancestral Origin. Movement and stillness mean harmonizing true qi and stabilizing true essence. Inhaling connects to the Root of Heaven; exhaling connects to the Root of Earth—closing the gate is Kun, opening the gate is Qian. Exhalation makes the dragon chant and clouds rise; inhalation makes the tiger roar and winds stir. With each opening and closing, movement and stillness, the key is to keep the heart-mind unmoved, allowing true breath to flow naturally, continuous and unbroken. Refine breath to the breathless breath, forging it into oneness—thus spirit congeals, and the elixir is achieved.

*If no affairs arise, who else is there to seek?*
If one can nurture qi, forget words, and guard the One, subduing body and mind so spirit returns to the qi-cavern, intent fixed within the compass, merging into a single qi—like a hen brooding an egg, like a dragon nurturing a pearl, ever-present and unwavering—then with time and deep practice, the millet-grain pearl will naturally manifest, radiant as the sun. Silently transforming the primordial spirit, its numinous clarity is unfathomable—this is the Way.

*The True Constant must respond to phenomena; responding to phenomena requires non-delusion.*
This Dao is the True Constant. Yet engaging with affairs easily leads to confusion, so one must not be deluded by worldly matters. If one refuses all engagement, one falls into hollow emptiness. Instead, respond when matters arise, then let them go without attachment. Radiant and upright—this is non-delusion. True nature is pure; primordial spirit congeals. The secret says: *"Intent misplaced leads to error; non-action falls into void. When nature is undeluded, it abides; when nature abides, qi naturally returns."*

The human nature is fiery and volatile—joy, anger, sorrow, and pleasure; love, aversion, desire, and hatred—ever-changing, stirred by the slightest touch, giving rise to delusive thoughts that disrupt stillness. One must truly quell anger to descend fire, truly diminish desire to ascend water. When the body is unmoving, it is *refining essence*—refining essence makes the tiger roar, and primordial spirit solidifies. When the heart is unmoving, it is *refining qi*—refining qi makes the dragon chant, and primordial qi is preserved. When intent is unmoving, it is *refining spirit*—refining spirit makes the two qi merge, the Three Origins blend, and primordial qi naturally returns. The Three Origins are essence, qi, and spirit; the two qi are yin and yang. When cultivators respond to phenomena without delusion, primordial spirit returns of itself, and true nature abides. When nature abides, the body’s pre-heaven qi returns, life is restored to its root—what difficulty remains?

The secret says: *"Turn light inward, reflect within the heart; inner thoughts do not stray, outer thoughts do not enter. When qi returns, the elixir forms of itself; within the crucible, Kan and Li unite."*

When cultivators are undeluded by worldly affairs, qi returns of itself. Then the two qi ascend and descend in the Central Palace, yin and yang unite in the elixir crucible. Suddenly, a wisp of warm qi from the kidneys surges into the heart’s palace—emotion returns to nature, like husband and wife in union, enraptured and intoxicated. The two qi intertwine, forming the elixir’s substance. Within the qi-cavern, water and fire intermingle in ceaseless circulation—spirit rides qi, qi stabilizes form, and without extraneous techniques, one attains longevity. The secret says: *"The three treasures—ears, eyes, mouth—seal them, do not let them leak. The true person lurks in the deep abyss, floating and wandering, guarding the compass."* Until the elixir field is full and the knife-point elixir forms.

*Yin and yang generate reversal; universal transformation sounds as a single thunderclap.*
At this stage, spirit does not stray outward, qi does not leak, spirit returns to the qi-cavern, Kan and Li have united. With ever-greater vigor and dedication, reaching the utmost emptiness and profound stillness, the body rests in the boundless dark, the heart settles in the realm of nothingness—then true breath abides of itself, the hundred vessels cease, sun and moon pause in their course, the celestial pivot halts. The Great Ultimate is still yet generates movement; yang arises in Kun of the southwest. Kun is the abdomen, also called the Winding River.

Suddenly, a single spark of numinous light appears, no larger than a millet grain—this is the sign of the elixir’s birth. With a blazing radiance piercing through, the two kidneys seethe like boiling water, the bladder scorches as if roasted by fire. Within the abdomen, a roar like a howling gale arises; within the belly, a sound like rolling thunder resounds—this is the revelation of the *Heavenly Root* in the *Returning* hexagram.

As the Heavenly Root manifests, stabilize the heart-king and assist it with spirit, so that the qi, like fire pressing metal, ascends, piercing through the *Weilü* gate. Gently guide it, silently lift it—a harmonious mass of qi, like thunder’s shock, rises to the *Mud Pill Palace*, surging through the entire body. This is the *Heavenly Wind* hexagram of *Encounter*. From the *Moon Cavern* to the space between the brows, the primordial light leaks forth—this is the Great Ultimate moving and generating yin. It transforms into divine water, sweet dew, within which a millet-grain pearl descends into the *Yellow Court*, touching my spirit-mercury within *Li*, coalescing into the sacred form. One cycle of the *Fire Times* of the *Celestial Circuit* is completed. Refine it, temper it, and the elixir will crystallize of itself.

White clouds gather at the crown; sweet dew sprinkles *Mount Sumeru*. At this stage, the elixir is attained. The two qi congeal into the knife-point elixir; the gates and cavities open and align. Fire descends, water ascends—one qi circulates throughout. From the movement of the Heavenly Root within the Great Ultimate, passing the *Mysterious Valley Pass*, ascending through the twenty-four joints of the spine to the *Heavenly Valley Pass*, yin arises in the *Moon Cavern*. A fragrant, sweet savor descends the *Double Towers*, ceaseless and unending—this is called *"Sweet Dew Sprinkles Mount Sumeru."*

The oral instruction states: When the mouth is full of sweet dew, guide it with the eyes, receive it with the mind, and send it down to the elixir cauldron to congeal and nurture the primordial qi. Drinking the *Elixir of Immortality* oneself, who could know of this carefree joy?

At this stage of nurturing qi, the joints of the bones have opened, the divine water flows without cease, circulating up and down, ceaselessly coming and going. Swallow it from time to time—this is called the *Elixir of Immortality*. The oral instruction states: *"Flowing pearls irrigate and nourish the numinous root-nature—does the cultivator know or not?"*

Sitting, one hears the music of the immortals, as if from strings unplucked, clearly penetrating the workings of creation. At this stage of practice, the ears perceive the melodies of the immortals, along with the rhythms of bells and drums. The five qi converge at the origin; the three flowers gather at the crown—like evening crows returning to roost. The field of the heart opens and brightens; wisdom arises of itself. The three teachings’ scriptures become clear; past lives’ roots are silently comprehended. Future fortunes and misfortunes are foreknown. Mountains and rivers of the great earth lie as if in the palm of one’s hand; the gaze spans ten thousand miles. The six penetrations’ wonders are attained—this is no mere illusion.

I have truly reached this stage in my practice. Were I to utter falsehoods and mislead later students, Heaven would surely punish me. To encounter this and not practice it is to incur Heaven’s condemnation. Without meeting a teacher, this matter is difficult to know.

In all, twenty lines—these are the true steps to Heaven’s ladder. From *"Nurturing Qi, Forgetting Words"* to these twenty lines, all are the authentic oral instructions of Ancestor Lü, without a trace of falsehood, the very staircase to ascension in cultivation. Those who awaken to this instruction and its commentary should hasten to practice it. Do not recklessly disclose it, nor show it to the unworthy, lest you incur Heaven’s punishment. Cherish and uphold it, and you will ascend to the Heavenly Palace.

Ancestor Lü embraced the vast vow to deliver all beings and transmitted this *Hundred-Character Stele*; Ancestor Zhang embraced the great vow to deliver all beings and annotated this *Hundred-Character Stele*. The heart of Ancestor Zhang is the heart of Ancestor Lü. Thus it is said: *Pure Yang* and *Three Peaks* are the eyes and ears among immortals.

Written in the tenth month.
The Dao speaks in simple terms.

The Dao, in its stages, must be understood through the three periods and three passes. In essence, it does not exceed these four phrases: *"After non-action, follow with action; after action, return again to non-action."* The practice of internal alchemy likewise has its lesser three periods: accumulating essence and amassing qi as the first, opening the passes and expanding the apertures as the second, and laying the foundation and refining the self as the third. To begin with the first period, one must generally calm the heart and reduce desires, first seal the outer Three Treasures to nurture the inner Three Treasures. As the *Xici* states: *"Exhaust principle and fulfill nature to reach destiny"*—this is the Daoist progression, a step-by-step practice. What is meant by exhausting principle? Study the true canon, seek the true instructions, observe the workings of creation, contemplate the *He-Luo*, seize moments of leisure to preserve qi, and guard the spirit to lay the foundation. While exhausting principle on one hand, fulfill nature on the other, thereby securing an indestructible body to pursue the wondrous medicine of immortality. Nature is internal, destiny is external; joining the internal with the external and uniting them as one, the Great Dao is accomplished. The phrase *"to reach"* clearly contains the oral instruction of establishing nature and destiny, and of returning from the postnatal to the prenatal—yet those without sincerity will seek further within the instructions to resolve it.

The eight characters *"concentrate the spirit and regulate the breath, regulate the breath and concentrate the spirit"* are the foundational practice. One must proceed with single-minded devotion, advancing through the stages without interruption. To concentrate the spirit is to gather the already-cleansed heart and enter within. When the heart is not yet clear, do not rashly close the eyes; first encourage and exhort oneself, and only when it returns, cool and tranquil, may one draw it into the qi cavity—this is called concentrating the spirit. Once the spirit is concentrated, one sits as upon a high mountain gazing over all peaks and rivers, or as a heavenly lamp illuminating the nine depths and nine obscurities—this is what is meant by *"concentrating the spirit in emptiness."*

Regulating the breath is not difficult: when the heart and spirit are still, the breath follows naturally. I merely guard its spontaneity, directing the light of spirit downward—this is regulating the breath. To regulate the breath is to harmonize the breath of the Yin Heel Vessel with the qi in the heart, meeting within the qi cavity. When the heart ascends to the region below the navel, it is called *"doubting the spirit"*; when qi returns to the region below the navel, it is called *"regulating the breath."* Spirit and breath depend on each other; guarding their natural purity is *"not forgetting,"* following their natural purity is *"not forcing."* Neither forgetting nor forcing, acting with silence and softness, the breath becomes lively and the heart at ease. Here, apply the *"boring"* technique: use emptiness as the dwelling place of the heart, and profound stillness as the homeland of spirit and breath. After repeated efforts, refining again and again, spirit and breath suddenly forget each other, and spirit and qi merge. Unawares, yang arises in a trance, and one feels as if intoxicated—this is the true sign, the moment when the Mysterious Pass appears.

All terms in the alchemical canon such as *"prenatal,"* *"true,"* and *"original"* emerge from the cauldron of yin and yang, born after the profound obscurity of deep stillness—like the sages and perfected beings at the dawn of the primordial chaos. Henceforth, when reading alchemical classics, one may infer by analogy.

Learning the Dao is most difficult; transmitting it is also not easy. If those who transmit the Dao are so diligent, can those who learn it be lazy?

Those who transmit the Dao must endure hardship—can those who learn it be impatient? If one’s study is not refined, effort not diligent, heart not pure, and spirit not true, entering the Dao by such means will yield not a single success in ten thousand attempts.

Confucius said, *"To know the incipient is to be divine."* He did not speak of thought or intention but of spirit—clearly, the subtlest movement of breath cannot be known except by spirit. Now let us distinguish: the subtlest movement is the incipient, while the overt movement is the direct. To know the incipient, employing heart, intention, or thought will never reveal it.

Spirit! Spirit! Only when spirit is truly spirit does it qualify as prenatal. True spirit is true thought, true heart, true intention. How to discern what is true? The secret lies in this: when the fire of the Mysterious Pass ignites and profound obscurity suddenly awakens, that solitary, luminous awareness—*that* is it.

The alchemical tradition says, *"A single thought arises from the compass of the rule"*—this is true spirit, true thought. It also says, *"Within the faintest glimmer, the light of the heart appears"*—this is true spirit, true heart. And again, *"Wisdom arises in stillness, a single intention governs"*—this is true spirit, true intention. True spirit is refined from what is not spirit; let the learner take note.

The student of the Dao must originally break through conventional patterns to guide the heart into principle. When the heart of fervor departs, the heart of coolness arrives; when the human heart is extinguished, the Dao-heart appears. This is why I abandon fame, power, and profit, forsake children, family, and home.

To truly learn the Dao, one must treat it as a rare commodity to be hoarded—only then will there be results. The Great Dao takes cultivating the heart and refining nature as its foundation. Nature resides within the heart, while the heart envelops nature. Nature is the master of settled principle; the heart is the dwelling where nature abides.

To cultivate the heart is to preserve it—fortifying the city walls so the house does not collapse, which is the work of laying the foundation. To refine nature is to nurture it—watering and tending the roots so the inner medicine matures, which is the work of self-cultivation. When the heart is bright and nature at peace, passions and desires do not intrude, thoughts and worries vanish, and heart and nature stand open within and without, free from vexation or distress—this is the effect of cultivating the heart and refining nature, the inner elixir.

Some study the Dao for months yet make no progress, for they lack a sincere heart turned toward the Dao. If one’s heart is set upon the Dao, naturally it will be untroubled by worldly affairs; if the heart values the Dao, naturally it will be light toward worldly matters; if the heart is deeply devoted to the Dao, naturally it will be indifferent to worldly concerns.

Guard your nature so it does not scatter; preserve your spirit so it does not grow dull—how then could drowsiness or stray thoughts disturb you?

Alas! When principle prevails over desire, one is preserved; when desire prevails over principle, one is lost.

Plunge the heart into the abyss, and spirit will not wander outward. When the heart is entangled in affairs, fire stirs within. When fire stirs within, essence is inevitably shaken. When the heart is still, breath naturally harmonizes; when stillness endures, the heart naturally settles.

Put the heart to death to nourish qi; still the mechanism of the mind to purify the heart. Essence, qi, and spirit are the three inner treasures; ear, eye, and mouth are the three outer treasures. Always ensure the inner three do not wander after external things, and the outer three do not penetrate within to disturb. Let breath be continuous and deep, entering the cinnabar field. Let breath be husband and wife, spirit and qi be mother and child—when mother, child, husband, and wife gather without parting, the heart does not stray outward, intention does not wander in thought, spirit does not roam, and essence does not move recklessly. Constantly steaming the four limbs, this is the orthodox lineage of the golden elixir.

The Great Dao enters through the character *"center."* This *"center"* has two aspects: one within the body, one beyond it. The work must proceed in two layers.

First, seek the center within the body. As Master Zhu said, *"Guard the center to control the external."* To guard the center, one must turn the light inward, return the gaze, and focus attention within the compass—at the point one inch and three-tenths below the navel, neither clinging nor departing. This is seeking the center within the body.

Second, seek the center beyond the body. The *Doctrine of the Mean* speaks of *"before joy, anger, sorrow, and pleasure arise."* At this unarisen moment, one neither hears nor sees, vigilantly guarding solitude. Naturally, nature settles and spirit clears; when spirit is clear, qi becomes wise. Only then does one see the original face. This is seeking the center beyond the body.

By using the center within the body to seek the center beyond it, human desires are easily purified, and heavenly principle is restored to brightness. The sages, immortals, and buddhas of all ages have taken this as the first step in their work.

In seated meditation, the most essential practice is to concentrate spirit and regulate breath—calm and composed, neither forcing nor forgetting. There is none who does not daily advance in skill.

To concentrate spirit and regulate breath, one need only make the heart level and qi harmonious. When the heart is level, spirit gathers; when qi is harmonious, breath is regulated. The character *"level"* in *"level heart"* is most wondrous. A heart without waves is level; a heart that holds to the center is level. *"Level"* resides in this center. When the heart is in this center, it does not stir waves. This center is the Mysterious Pass of the alchemical classics.

Without knowing the Mysterious Pass, no matter what else one does, it is like entering a dark room—where to begin? The Mysterious Pass is the qi cavern. The qi cavern is where spirit enters qi, as if dwelling in a deep cave. When spirit and qi long for each other, the substance of the Mysterious Pass is established.

The ancient immortals said, *"To regulate breath, regulate the true breath; to refine spirit, refine the spirit that is not spirit."* The true breath is the breath that breathes itself; the spirit that is not spirit is the spirit that is spirit itself.

Above all, eliminate the human heart and preserve the Dao-heart. Return this Dao-heart to emptiness and nothingness, dwelling in profound obscurity within the compass—only then can one nourish the true breath and attain the spirit that is not spirit.

Begin with the inner breath, for this is where one departs from the breath of parents and reestablishes the womb’s nurturing ground—here alone can merit be cultivated. As the mother breathes in, so do you; as she breathes out, so do you, as if reborn anew. In seated practice, embrace spirit with qi, bind intent to breath, and let them coil and drift within the cinnabar field, gathering without scattering. There, the inner qi and the qi drawn from without intertwine in the cinnabar field. Day by day, month by month, they flourish, extending to the four limbs, flowing through the hundred vessels, striking open the twin passes of the spine to ascend to the muddy pellet, then circling back down to the crimson palace and returning to the lower cinnabar field. Spirit and qi guard each other, breath upon breath interdependent—the path of the river chariot is open. At this stage, half the merit of laying the foundation is achieved; all that remains is to refine with diligent emptiness.

Regulate the breath by following the postnatal breath to seek the true person’s breath. As the ancients said: *"The postnatal breath stirs a gentle wind, which rouses the true person’s breath."* Yet in regulating the postnatal breath, one must let it regulate itself, for only then can the prenatal breath be awakened. I need only attain emptiness and preserve stillness. Once the true breath stirs, the Mysterious Pass is not far.

Proceed thus in practice, and the foundation may be attained with ease, not requiring a hundred days. The *Daodejing*’s lines *"Attain utmost emptiness, preserve profound stillness"* may be interpreted as a whole or parsed in detail. Taken as a whole, they simply instruct one in the practice of entering concentration. Parsed in detail: *emptiness* is the void, *utmost* is the central pole, *stillness* is tranquility, and *profound* is single-minded devotion. That is to say, guide one’s spirit into the space of the void and align it with the central pole, guard the spirit within tranquility, and devote oneself wholly to the work. The human heart is twofold—one true, one deluded. Thus, to seek the true heart, one must not generate deluded thoughts; this is the true heart. The true heart’s nature is most vast and luminous; its dwelling is most serene and unconstrained. With the true heart, one comprehends a thousand texts as one; with the true heart, one traces the myriad paths to their single source.

Yet if one wishes to employ the true heart in worldly affairs, one must first cultivate its strength and preserve its tranquility—only then can it labor without exhaustion and respond without disturbance. The alchemical verse says: *"When the heart wanders, draw it back; having drawn it back, release it. After use, seek stillness again; in stillness, awakening arises."* Who says one cannot attain stillness amid bustle? Wandering in cities or sitting in barren halls is not the Way. Yet if one does not wander through cities and mountains, one should let qi wander through the body’s passes and orifices; if one does not sit in hollow halls, one should let spirit sit within the body’s wondrous apertures.

The study of the Dao takes the foundation of the elixir as its root. Once the elixir foundation is solidified, one may return home to till the soil and care for parents, living as a refined scholar for some years before entering the mountains to seek a teacher and complete the great Dao. Those who abandon their families, forsake their wives, chant scriptures, and burn incense are merely idlers passing time—what worth do they have?

Preserving the body hinges on calming the heart and nourishing the kidneys. When the heart is calm, the fire of *li* does not flare outward; when the kidneys are nourished, the water of *kan* does not spill outward. If fire does not flare, there is no illness of spirit’s agitation, and the heart grows ever calmer; if water does not spill, there is no exhaustion of essence, and the kidneys grow ever clearer. When the kidneys are clear, the fire of life does not surge upward; when the heart is calm, the fire of spirit can shine downward. When spirit and essence congeal, one may ward off illness and speak of cultivation.

In nurturing spirit and qi, spirit serves as the master that gathers qi. Gather one part qi, and you gain one part treasure; gather ten parts qi, and you gain ten parts treasure. Qi is so precious that even a hundred taels of gold or jade cannot exchange for a single part. Why should a Daoist contend with the world for profit? Profit breeds resentment, resentment belongs to fire, and qi is also a kind of fire. When resentment arises, qi flees with it, and one cannot retain it. In severe cases, both mother and child scatter and vanish. Thus, in nurturing qi, nothing is more urgent than curbing resentment; to curb resentment, nothing is more urgent than nurturing the heart and spirit.

Rank and fame often arise unexpectedly—one must not harbor a mind set on official emolument. Confucius said: *"In learning, emolument lies within."* The same holds for cultivating the Dao: one must not greedily anticipate results. In every seated session, one must still the heart and congeal the spirit, not allowing the slightest thought of calculation or expectation to arise. Simply hold fast to the inner breath and work at it.

The method of refining the heart proceeds from small to great. In the scorching heat of the third *fu*, a single bowl of rice suffices—do not seek more; a slight coolness suffices—do not seek greater chill; a few mosquitoes are not to be feared—do not insist on their absence. From the minute to the vast, every moment presents an opportunity to refine the heart. Seeking sweetness in bitterness, life in death—this is the guiding principle of Daoist cultivation.

Though the Way of the golden elixir is said to be easy to know but hard to practice, one cannot refrain from seeking knowledge as the ground for practice. If knowledge is not upright, where can practice lead? If knowledge is not precise, where can practice enter? If knowledge is not yet mature, how can one speak of oral instructions?

Those who study the Dao must purify the heart and clear the mind to obtain the true medicine of clarity. Do not indulge the temperament’s nature, do not mobilize the spirit of thought, do not employ the qi of breathing, do not use the essence of intercourse. Yet when does true essence stir? Where is true spirit born? In what direction does true qi move? Where is true nature nurtured? These are matters that must be clearly distinguished and meticulously explained.

The qi of wisdom naturally clears the spirit, for qi is the temporal manifestation of the spirit within the human body—what difficulty is there in knowing this? The sole concern is that the heart is not still and settled. Drawing in qi is the first crucial step in cultivating the Dao; if one does not still the heart and investigate meticulously, one cannot know the end or the beginning—how then can one begin practice? To proceed in confusion, knowing this but not that, the heart grows ever more frantic, perpetually scattered and unable to gather. Thus, the originally unified heart divides into many, and how can one cultivate with a single heart? Those who study the Dao must be wholeheartedly sincere, striking with one decisive blow to avoid waging endless battles. Whenever beginning seated meditation, one must still both heart and spirit, empty and quiescent, such that even spirits and gods cannot perceive it. This practice should be self-examined and self-trusted, seeking self-realization. What is meant by "making the intent sincere" is to refrain from self-deception. Sincerity within naturally manifests without, which is why the noble person must be vigilant in solitude.

—Excerpts from Master Sanfeng’s Compiled Teachings—
The Master said: "The Azure Grotto Heaven has long been frequented by immortals and perfected beings, who have left behind elixir formulas—this too is the heart of awakening the world and delivering others. Why should those in the mountains seek other transcendent herbs or gather different immortal blossoms? This alone is the talisman of salvation, the medicine of longevity. Now, I have specially excerpted and preserved these teachings to share with those who cherish the Dao."

Master Baizi Qing’s *Formula for Regulating Breath* states: Regulating the breath involves method, implements, and firing times—these three interweave in subtle harmony. One must know them thoroughly, ponder them deeply, and then apply them with effortless mastery.

The firing times in breath regulation include:
- **Gathering breath**: One must be empty and humble, so that essence may enter the crucible—this is the method of "shrinking the earth."
- **Harvesting breath**: The spirit must remain unmoved and unshaken, so that the medicine naturally takes form—this is the "grasping clouds" technique.
- **Union breath**: One must attain the great stillness of the six extremes, with not a single thought arising.
- **Advancing fire breath**: The intent drives it forward—this is "arousing the Xun wind and moving the Kun fire."
- **Withdrawing tally breath**: The spirit gathers it in—this is "returning to the root and restoring life."
- **Mao-You bathing breath**: It is merely the soft character *rou*.

All these methods of breath regulation must be cross-referenced with the proper method, implements, and firing times. "Regulating" means adjusting and harmonizing them appropriately.

Master Zi Qing’s *Secret of the Mysterious Pass* states: The Mysterious Pass is the gateway to seeking the mysterious, the mechanism of the wondrous. It has both substance and function. What is meant by "substance"?

Still and unmoving.
What is meant by "function"?
Stimulated, it then penetrates.

There are times when it does not move.
At the first union of spirit and qi, subtle and interwoven, vast and boundless—this is one pass, the place where the Four Elements and Five Phases do not adhere.
At the moment of spirit and qi’s union, dim and silent, profound and obscure—this is another pass, the state of no sound or scent, no inside or outside.
When stillness reaches its extreme and movement arises, function then emerges: continuous and unbroken, rising and surging. True qi stirs within the compass—this is yet another pass, the place where the arising thought is the Mysterious Female.
When the thought arises, as if drunk and then sobered, a numinous awareness remains. In that instant, one awakens—this is another pass, the moment when timing meets spirit’s knowing.
Here, one employs this numinous awareness like a thread pulling a puppet: the mechanism moves, qi flows, and with the slightest urging, it passes through the Gate of Wei Lü—this is yet another pass, the time when the Dipper’s handle turns and the Northern Asterism is set aright.
Bathing at the Mao Gate is another pass.
Soaring to the Mud Pill Palace is another pass.

Returning to the root and reviving the mandate is another pass. Bathing at the You Gate is yet another pass. Great rest, great stillness—emptied and forgotten, returning to utmost quiescence is another pass.

Such is the substance and function of the Mysterious Pass. All the thousand scriptures and ten thousand treatises are contained herein.

Master Zi Qing’s *Lu Ding Jue* states: *"The Four Hundred Characters"* should be studied closely, especially the verse *"This aperture is no ordinary aperture,"* which exhausts the subtleties of the crucible and vessel.

The term *"this aperture"* may be viewed in two aspects: inner and outer. *"No ordinary"* is a word of praise. When Qian and Kun unite, it forms the outer aperture; when spirit and qi are concealed within, it becomes the inner aperture. When spirit and qi intermingle, Kan and Li arise; when Kan and Li intermingle, primordial essence is produced. This essence is no common essence—it is the supreme treasure of the White Tiger’s first meridian. Whoever attains it ascends instantly to the immortal realm. This pertains to the Reverted Elixir.

As for the minor elixir, one may explain to others thus: *"This aperture is no ordinary aperture, formed by the union of yin and yang. Named the Cavern of the Two Qi, within it true yang is born."* Thus may it be clearly understood.

The immortals’ three secrets are: fire timing, medicinal substance, and crucible-vessel. This poem encompasses the marvels of the crucible-vessel.

Master Zi Qing’s *Dong Ji Lun* states: Confucius said, *"The subtle is the incipient movement."* He also said, *"The Creative’s movement is straight."* Mencius spoke of *"nurturing with straightness"*—by cultivating the subtle movement of straightness until it becomes great, it fills the space between heaven and earth. Straightness is the qi of firmness, the first yang line of Qian, the initial nine, the *"one"* attained by Yanzi. Straightness and oneness are one. Movement resides within the human aperture, present in all twelve hours. The essential is to preserve it through stillness, then observe it through movement.

Within the flavorless, seek flavor; within the uneventful, seek event—is this not the way? Lu Qianxu, styled Xianhui, was transmitted the Way by Master Huian of the Jiajing era. His *Lun Tiao Xi Fa* states:

*What is *"not forgetting"*?*
*Abiding by nature.*

*What is *"not forcing"*?*
*Following nature.*

*How to abide?*
*By relying on the breath.*

*How to follow?*
*By equalizing the breath.*

Relying on the breath, the breath becomes unobstructed; equalizing the breath, the breath becomes even.

*Is *"abiding"* distinct from *"following"*? Or are they one?*
Knowing how to abide, one knows how to follow; knowing how to follow, one knows how to abide. Whether two or one, the principle is not amiss. From the broad, return to the essential—this lies solely in concentrating the spirit. Do not employ intention; if intention is used, it is not true intention. True intention arises from stillness, like the primordial separation of the great simplicity, free from attachment—only then can it be employed. Thus, one must die to know life; without knowing life, one does not know death. Life and death are the profound mechanism of movement and stillness.

Master Qianxu’s *You Lun Tiao Xi Fa* states: In regulating the breath to guide inhalation, one need only concentrate the spirit into the qi cavern. With the spirit dwelling in the qi cavern, silently focus on the yin heel vessel. Without seeking union, it unites of itself; without striving for connection, it connects of itself. As the ancient immortals aptly said: *"The principle of spirit conjoining across form is most detailed."* This is what is meant by *"the spirit leaving form to join qi"*—there is a separate oral transmission.

*"Men do not loosen their garments; women do not untie their sashes"*—revering as if before the divine, cherishing as one’s parents—all this is merely concentrating the spirit and gathering qi. Thus it is said: *"The Dao returns to nature."* The *Can Tong Qi* states: *"What nature does is not perverse conduct."* This is the meaning.

Master Qianxu’s *San Lun Tiao Xi Fa* states: Now, water unites with water, fire with fire, wind with wind, clouds with clouds—this is the constant principle. In regulating the breath, qi unites with qi—why force it? One need only concentrate the spirit into the qi cavern, letting the spirit’s light illuminate the yin heel vessel. Without expectation, they meet—this is the resonance of a single qi, naturally and spontaneously. The *Tun* hexagram says: *"The noble submits to the lowly, greatly gaining the people’s favor."* The *Xian* hexagram says: *"Cessation brings joy; the male submits to the female—thus there is free flow."* The *Book of Changes* has already spoken clearly of the way of union.

Yet the method of regulating the breath involves both technique and application; the alchemical path from beginning to end does not depart from it. The Master said: I discussed the seven reversions and nine refinements of the golden liquid great elixir with Hanxuzi. Hanxuzi replied: According to your words, these are all the wondrous functions of the medicinal spoon. Later, I saw Hanxuzi’s *Wu Ji Er Tu Pian*, which deeply accorded with the original intent, and so I recorded and transmitted it.

Those who seek to understand longevity cannot penetrate the numinous without this. Hanxuzi said: The *Wu Zhen Pian* states: *"If Kan and Li lack Wu and Ji, though they contain the four images, they cannot form the elixir. Only because each holds true earth does the golden elixir achieve reversion and return."* These four lines exhaust the marvels of harmonizing the elixir’s foundation.

For within fire, wood-mercury is born; within water, metal-lead is produced. Wood, fire, metal, and water contain the four images between Kan and Li. At this time, Li contains Ji, and Kan contains Wu—with the two earths as mediators, the four images may unite.

Some ask: Is true intention not earth? Earth has Wu and Ji—does this imply two intentions? It seems so, yet it is not. As intention, it is one; as earth, it is two. Taking one intention and dividing it into two yields the two earths, thus distinguishing inner and outer. Yet one must know movement and know stillness.

Originally, Wu earth is the external medicine, true yang within yin. Movement is primary, so one seizes Kan’s moment—only by detecting its movement. Knowing movement is intention; thus, the moment of knowing movement is one earth.

Ji earth is the internal medicine, true yin within yang. Stillness is primary, so after filling Li, one nurtures through stillness. Knowing stillness is intention; thus, the moment of knowing stillness is one earth. This one intention divides into two intentions, thereby acquiring the name of two earths. Yet when the two intentions merge into one, there is no longer any constraint of two earths, nor any fixation on inner or outer—only the capacity for both movement and stillness.

Originally, Ji earth is the internal elixir, yet it may transform into Wu earth: as the sun of Li reflects the moon of Kan, planting lead yields lead, and one sees only Wu without Ji—stillness enters into movement. Wu earth is the external elixir, yet it may shift into Ji earth: as the yang of Kan supplements the yin of Li, planting mercury yields mercury, and one sees only Ji without Wu—movement merges with stillness. These two intentions unite as one, unbound by the distinction of two earths.

Then do each of them harbor true earth, each holding one earth? Or do they together hold one earth? The perceptive and discerning will naturally understand.

The Dao of the golden elixir’s return cannot proceed without this true intention. Not only does it harmonize the four images, but it also commands them. Why? Within wood, fire is concealed; cast into the realm of water, fire ignites. Wood carries metal upward, mercury departs and returns. Fire, meeting metal, reverses its course. Within water, metal is born; refined by the work of fire, water boils. Metal follows wood upward, lead departs and returns. Metal, meeting fire, completes its cycle.

The art of metal and fire’s return is none other than the great elixir of seven reversals and nine returns. If one seeks the accomplishment of the great elixir, how can it be achieved apart from this true intention?

Master Ziyang said:
*"The red dragon and black tiger part east and west,
The four images intertwine within Wu and Ji."*

Immortal Tao observed:
*"The dragon emerges from fire, the green dragon transforms into the red dragon;
The tiger arises from water, the white tiger is renamed the black tiger."*
These four characters—*dragon, tiger, red, black*—already embody the four images.

*"Intertwine"* means to gather and cluster. In my humble view, those who practice elixir-making, desiring the four images to cluster, must ensure the five phases converge. The *"within Wu and Ji"* does not refer to the centers of Li and Kan, but rather to the central palace, the center. Though east and west are separated, the spatula unites them. Two substances transform into the four images; the four images coalesce into one village. One village assembles the five phases. When the five phases gather, the elixir congeals. Thus, the following lines state:
*"From this, Reunion and Encounter may be applied,
Who says the golden elixir cannot succeed?"*

Reunion and Encounter signify the fire tally of the tenth month. Advancing fire in Reunion, retreating the tally in Encounter, adjusting through addition and subtraction—naturally attaining the proper measure, the golden elixir may then be accomplished.

Elixir masters take *"Wu Ji"* as *"blade"* and *"two earths"* as *"spatula,"* structuring the characters to resemble their forms, precisely indicating the intent of forging and uniting. While the two earths as spatula are widely understood, *"Wu Ji"* as blade is less known.

Master Qianxu remarked: *"A scholar, grasping the meaning, interpreted the character '㇗' as the sound 'nie,' representing the top of 'Ji,' and '丿' as the sound 'pie,' representing the side of 'Wu.'"* Though lacking prior basis, this seems apt.

Master Hanxu countered: *"It is not without basis. In qin tablature, numbers are assembled to form a character, each stroke drawn from a single note. The method of plucking left and right is fully contained within one character—this is the very basis of qin tablature. '㇗' is the head of 'Ji,' '丿' is the side of 'Wu.' The two earths, Wu and Ji, are combined in the two characters 'blade' and 'spatula,' urging one to merge the two earths of Li’s Ji and Kan’s Wu into one place."*

Such is the nature of immortals’ veiled language.
