Facing the wall for nine years, alone revealing the true essence,
Only then becoming an immortal beyond the world in Penglai’s paradise.

Following the ancestral masters’ lyrics and melodies,
No prior notation exists—only to elucidate the Dao’s intent.
Yet these notations were all created by the ancients;
Why not innovate from our own antiquity?
*"Ascending the High Terrace"* takes its name from the *Cantong qi*,
Fittingly harmonizing with the profound sound’s elegant title.
Some say the theme is ingenious but the divisions too numerous,
Unaware that in lyric forms like *"The Whistling Patrol"* or *"Oriole’s Song Sequence,"*
Three or four divisions are common—what harm in four here?
One must not be constrained by *ling*, *man*, single, or double forms.

*The Celestial Immortal* was vulgarly rendered as *"Southern Palace Lyrics,"*
Its original name being *The Celestial Immortal’s Lure*.
As the *Wuzhen pian* states: *"To learn immortality, one must learn celestial immortality;
Only the golden elixir is most authentic,"* whence the original name was drawn,
Imploring deep reflection.
The latter four tunes differ slightly,
Yet by lyricists’ standards of division, this piece stands as the first form.

Seeking heaven within earth,
Chasing lightning amidst clouds.
Moment by moment, rein in the galloping mind-horse,
Instant by instant, lock the restless heart-ape.
Day and night without sleep,
Refining the self’s work without pause,
Holding fast to the will with ever-greater firmness.
Guard the Three Treasures within, abiding in the deep abyss,
Seize the Five Thieves without, observing the celestial gardens.
Let self and other rest in suchness and stability,
Make yin and yang invert and overturn.
Repelling all demons with the sword of wisdom,
Gathering the Black Tortoise’s incipient qi,
Drawing from the White Tiger’s first crescent.
Erect the Heavenly Root,
Suspend the Moon’s Hollow.
Display divine powers by planting lotuses in fierce flames,
Wield the craftsman’s hand to pole a boat on weak waters.
Sweep clean to still the heart and quiet the mind,
Nurture to fill the essence and complete the qi.
No envy for lovely, delicate flowers,
Only awaiting the sweet path of nectar and springs,
Causing the passionless to relinquish their mortal guise.
Assault the divine continent, breach the crimson realm,
Seize the golden essence and carefully lead it,
Escort it into the cinnabar field.
Guard against peril, dispel distractions,
Stabilize the breath, calm the spirit, sever delusive ties,
Bathe and cleanse the heart, cease all strife—
The sacred embryo emerges unobstructed.
Facing the wall for nine years,
Refining spirit to return to emptiness,
Thus is our work’s course complete.

**Second Form**
Behold the *Returning to the Root and Restoring Life* chapter,
Observe the *Nurturing Nature and Cultivating Truth* scroll.
Only then know water within metal,
Only then recognize heaven within earth.
Subtle and wondrous, wondrously subtle—
Life and death are but a thread apart,
Dragon and Tiger concealed in the two crescents.
Expound the mysterious female in the *Dao and Virtue* immortal scriptures,
Plumb the *Wuzhen* sagely canon’s *wu* and *ji*.
Discuss the *geng* direction where metal is born,
Speak of the *dui* position where medicine’s river flows,
Pointing clearly to the crimson realm.
Like dew, like lightning,
Like mist, like smoke—
Only awaiting the Black Tortoise’s exhalation,
The White Tiger’s spittle.
Slay the Three Corpses, extinguish the demon’s lair,
Capture the Five Thieves, still the horse, lull the ape to sleep.
Pursue the spirit-qi into the returning sea,
Circulate the true qi through the bubbling spring,
Gather the golden essence into the cinnabar field.
Naturally penetrating,
Flowing through every joint of the body.
Heart like fire,
Intent like lightning—
Nurturing the golden elixir,
Mercury gradually added, closing *dui* and forgetting speech.
Nine years facing the wall, work unceasing,
The Great Ultimate’s spirit roams the boundless,
The sevenfold infant naturally appears.
Six Thieves vanish,
Five Phases complete their numbers,
The world’s people know to return to Penglai’s paradise.

**Third Form**
First regulate the breath evenly,
Then unite metal and wood.
Lead-essence concealed in the female’s gate,
Mercury-fluid hidden in the mysterious portal—
The root of creation.
In the profound and obscure, there is trust;
In the indistinct and imperceptible, no sight or sound.
Nurture the medicine’s sprout, ever keeping the furnace whole,
Pluck the yellow sprout, never letting the tripod be damaged.
Let the original spirit not stray from the square inch,
Seek the golden water to irrigate Kunlun.
Wield the sword of wisdom to pursue and press the demon horde,
Guard the Three Treasures, hold the heart and intent with care,
Seize the Five Thieves, diligently refine the self,
Sever greed and wrath, dispel ten thousand cares,
Encounter scenes without staining a single dust.
I only await:
At Qujiang’s shore, the moon spits forth *gengshen*,
On Xingshan’s peaks, treading snow to seek spring.
Gather the golden essence as it departs the crimson waters,
Harmonize the true breath to circulate through the body,
Circulate one’s own mercury to envelop the yang essence.
The furnace fire ever warm,
Moment by moment, ceaselessly advancing.
Like the foolish, like the dull,
Silently sitting, forgetting speech,
Guarding poverty to preserve the whole truth.
I turn to the deep mountains, facing the wall where none inquire,
In the quiet chamber, with ashen heart, only I am intimate.
Regulate the spirit-breath,
Rely on our teachings—
Not speaking of ten months’ gestation,
Only nine years’ toil,
Today, the work complete, the merit round, one verifies the origin.

**Fourth Form**
Leisurely perusing the *Dragon-Tiger Classic*,
Quietly savoring the *Entering the Medicine Mirror*—
Originally, lead is but one flavor,
Falsely given many names.
It lurks in the water’s depths,
Bestowed upon the crown of the reclusive,
Residing in the alchemical pit.
Scarlet, it hides in sweet springs,
Densely packed, it conceals itself in the cinnabar well.
I only await:
At the winter solstice, when the first yang stirs,
At the autumn equinox, when the second qi ascends.
The Flowery Pond’s trustworthy pearl bursts forth,
Acting with benevolence, establishing virtue,
Setting up justice, preparing punishments,
Guarding against deceit,
Drawing forth joyful passions.
Observe the divine continent’s qi flourishing, yang surging,
See the crimson realm’s *gui* stirring, lead arising.
Scarlet, the Dragon’s head erects,
Crimson, the Tortoise’s eye rounds,
Black, the Tiger’s mouth roars.
Contending to display their powers,
Making yin and yang invert,
Uniting metal and wood.
Seize the northern Dark Warrior’s tortoise essence,
Lock it in the Yellow Court.
Bathe and constantly sweep the Three Fields clean,
Temper and nurture, ensuring the ninefold transmutation’s numinosity.
Accumulate eight hundred deeds of hidden virtue,
Name inscribed in the Upper Clarity,
Spirit ascends to Jade Capital,
Feasting concludes, drunk on the peaches of immortality.

**Fifth Form**
No indulgence for the galloping mind-horse,
How could the restless heart-ape be released?
Three Corpses unperturbed,
Six Thieves all subdued.
Demon realms all forgotten,
Preserving robust spirit,
Harmonizing strong qi and blood.

All cares forgotten, leaving behind greed and wrath,
Myriad entanglements cease—no false thoughts arise.
I dispatch the divine maiden to tend the furnace and forge the sword,
Pairing metal and water to balance soft and hard.
Relying on the smith’s hands, I seize and capture as easily as turning a palm,
Unlocking the elixir’s gate, loosing the Dragon and Tiger’s bonds.
I drink the wine of extended years,
Savor the nectar of prolonged life.
The elixir enters my belly, fragrance suffuses my body,
Passion yields to nature, bones transform, yang revives.
Still the heart’s landscape, seal the earthen crucible tight,
Extinguish the mind’s spring, close the chamber deep.
Far from sound and color, I guard the true constant,
Vigilant against harm—should I encounter indulgence, I do not lightly lose myself.
After ten months, the infant descends,
Nurtured to full numinosity, meeting the spirit, I stride alone through the immortal realm.
Who knows that within stillness, heaven and earth are vast?
I love the long days and months within the gourd.
Let the world’s slander and praise be as they may—
Clad in cloud-robes and crane-feathered cloak,
Holding the cinnabar script and jade tablet,
The immortals of the Purple Palace all celebrate.

This tune, *"Heavenly Immortal’s Invitation,"* was composed by the Patriarch,
Its name’s meaning most refined and proper.
For it must be thus—this is the great Dao of the Golden Elixir.
Were it taken as a *Nangong* lyric, it would be diminished.
The *Nangong* belongs to the talismanic school,
Distinct from the Golden Elixir.
Those who reach the *Nangong* still face rebirth before attaining the Way.
As the *Supreme Scripture for Salvation* states:
*"Those of shallow learning, whose immortal rank is unfulfilled,
When their destined end arrives, their bodies pass through the Great Yin.
At the hour of passage, fellow students and perfected ones
Burn incense and recite the scripture ten times to deliver the corpse.
By this method, the hun-soul ascends directly to the Nangong,
Where, according to their merit, they await rebirth,
Turning the wheel without annihilation before achieving immortality."*
Thus, the *Nangong* stream consists of those who seize bodies and transmigrate.
How could the sublime purport of Heavenly Immortals be named after the *Nangong*?

This lyric must not be divided arbitrarily.
Here, it is split into two parts where division is possible.
The Zhang-Deng edition divides it into three:
The first part as *"Magpie Bridge,"*
The second as *"Jade Maiden Shakes the Immortal’s Girdle-Pendants,"*
The third as *"Coda,"*—likely arranged for *Daoist ballads*.
Yet *"Magpie Bridge"* and *"Jade Maiden"* are ancient tune names.
Since the Patriarch’s composition does not rigidly follow old melodies,
Such reckless naming lacks meaning.
Here, I follow the Wang edition.
*"A Branch of Flowers"* is also titled *"Fair Golden Flower."*
As Elder Yuchan’s *"Song of Joy"* says:
*"At midnight, a branch of spring in the yellow sprout,"*
And this collection’s *"After the Fifth Watch"* reads:
*"A branch of spring’s hue, the golden flower’s beauty,"*
Thus, this tune’s name is taken from these lines.

The lyrics follow the Peng Haogu selection, the Zhang-Deng edition,
And *The Mirror of Immortals* for collation.

**First Stanza**
Cultivating the work of creation,
At the outset, harmonizing primordial qi.
Since receiving the master’s transmission,
I alone guard non-action.
The Jade Fluid ever refined,
Original qi returns to its true seat.
Piercing the Three Passes,
Passing the Tail Gate,
Reversing the River Chariot to ascend Mud Pill.
Striking Kunlun, thunder shakes the earth,
Sweet springs well forth, fragrant as honey.
Entering the Jade Pool, it transforms into Golden Fluid,
Freely drinking the sweet dew that drips down.
Descending the Twelve-Storied Tower’s steps,
Firmly sealed and guarded, I hold fast—
Originally, these are the three: essence, qi, and spirit.
Returning to the root, restoring life,
Originally, these are the five: metal, wood, water, fire, and earth, gathered in confluence.
Within the mysterious, the deathless Reverted Elixir;
Within the wondrous, the root of life-extension.
Who does not practice? Who does not comprehend? Who does not act?
All lies in failing to grasp the precelestial aperture—
How could one dare to act recklessly?
I, too, amidst the flowers,
Drum the bamboo, play the zither, my heart like still water.
From now on, I fathom the true message,
Forgetting things, forgetting form.
Before midnight and after noon, I persist;
At dawn and dusk, the hours of bathing.
What need to speak of the wheel of birth and death?
What need to speak of the Girl and Infant?
All is but the gathering of that single grain of millet from uncarved chaos.

**Second Stanza**
The heart like a lotus rising from water,
The mind like lightning flashing through clouds.
Last night, over a trifle,
I strayed into the Pleasure Garden.
Hour by hour, I rein in the mind-horse,
Moment by moment, I lock the heart-ape.
Day and night without sleep,
Refining the self, my work unceasing.
Sealing the Three Treasures within the Yellow Chamber,
Capturing the Five Thieves, I gaze outward upon the Upper Court.
Commanding self and other to be thus—steady, unshaken,
Making yin and yang invert, overturn.
Brandishing the keen-edged sword, I drive back the hordes of demons,
Daring to pluck those fresh blossoms beyond the wall.
I don my iron face, born of my mother,
Leaving them not the slightest room to stir.
Lovely celestial forms, delicate ten fingers—
None can sway my mind-horse or heart-ape.
I am a touchstone—truth or falsehood instantly revealed;
A steel steamed bun—hard to bite;
A sea of purity—untouched by a speck of dust;
A luminous pearl—ever suspended in emptiness.
The Dao firm, my resolve distant,
From youth, I tempered body and heart.
Cutting off fame and profit, refusing greed,
Seizing the Three Corpses, searing them in the crucible.
My heart is steadfast,
My mastery of creation unseen by others.
I grieve only that my work remains unfinished, my name unmade,
Time wasted in vain;
I grieve that days and months race like shuttles, youth fleeting.
One day, I shall turn the Celestial Gate,
Soaring midair—
Only then will I expound the cold, aloof teachings of the Daoist school.

**Third Stanza**
First, comprehend heaven and earth’s mechanism,
Next, pair yin and yang.
Heaven existed before the Mother,
Without the Mother, there would be no heaven—
This is the root of Daoist teaching.
Counting the celestial cycles from the beginning,
Reversing and settling qian and kun.
The moon’s fullness depends on oral transmission,
The hour of midnight’s wonder lies in heart-to-heart teaching.
Raising my sword, keen and bladeless,
I fear only the rushing rapids where the boat is hard to moor.
I am moved by the Yellow Dame’s guidance,
I await the Maiden’s unfolding lotus—
This matter is hard to speak of.

Five thousand days—count them with steadfast resolve,
Thirty hours—silent reckoning in the dark.
I raise the dragon’s head upright,
He suspends the moon’s cavern in empty space.
Manifesting divine power, planting lotus in fierce flames,
Wielding the craftsman’s hand to pole a boat against the current.
I do not envy the beauty of delicate blossoms,
I await only the sweet dew and nectarous spring.
Assaulting the divine realm, shattering the crimson land,
Seizing the golden essence to lead it carefully,
Guiding it into the cinnabar field.
Guarding against peril, dispelling stray thoughts,
Bathing in nature’s purity.
Facing the wall for nine years,
Only then does one become an immortal of Penglai beyond the mortal world.

**Fourth Stanza**
In seeking the profound Dao,
I traversed the ends of the earth.
Forsaking fame, power, and profit,
Abandoning home, estate, and fields.
Through myriad hardships,
Clothes tattered, shoes worn—yet the master remained unseen.
I grieve that sixty or seventy years of light pass so swiftly,
Entering Zhongnan, moved to receive the Fire Dragon’s oral transmission.
Commanded to descend the mountain, to seek companions and hunt for lead.
Visiting renowned sages far and wide,
Only to find them scheming, miserly, and thieving the mysterious Dao.
Yet it was my destined karmic cause to transcend the world,
Fortunate to meet Shen Wansan, who upheld righteousness and scorned wealth.
Alas, his strength was too meager to fulfill the task,
So I had no choice but to tend the furnace and refine the elixir.
After nine cycles were complete,
I entered the Pleasure Garden to gather herbs and enact talismans,
Spending five years on Mount Wudang.
Facing the wall to harmonize the spirit for another nine years,
Suddenly, the imperial summons arrived.
Though I wished to avoid the sovereign’s gaze,
I feared for Minister Hu’s life.
Riding clouds straight to the Chaoyang Hall,
The emperor rejoiced, his dragon countenance beaming.
I longed to transmit the teachings mouth-to-mouth,
But feared defying the Jade Emperor’s decree—
Thus, I mounted the phoenix and soared to the nine heavens.

*Ode to the Hibernating Dragon*
*Fisherman’s Song*

The Hibernation Method is soundless yet resounds,
Its voice and speech heard only by the inner heart.
The spirit silent, the qi obscure,
The hibernating dragon, though asleep, remains awake.

*Hibernating Dragon’s Chant*
Sleeping immortal, sleeping immortal,
High upon stone roots, years forgotten in repose,
The Three Lights sink, yet nature remains whole.
Qi by qi returns to the Mysterious Cavity,
Breath by breath follows nature’s course.
Do not scatter, must remain serene,
Nurturing mercury’s nature to perfection,
Waiting for lead’s blossom to appear.
No loss, no negligence,
True firing times, operated within.
Seven returns, no hardship,
Nine refinements, why lament?
Quietly observe the battlefield of dragon and tiger,
Secretly invert yin and yang.
People call me a drowsy fool,
Yet I sleep—yet sleep not.
Mastered, true reclining meditation,
Cultivated, the true primordial embryo.
When the hibernating dragon stirs, it ascends to heaven.
This hibernation method—who transmitted it?
Folding arms for a pillow, from Mount Ni’s self,
Joy lies within, unknown to others.
Five dragons leap from the deep abyss,
Heaven bestowed this method to Tu Nan.
Who in Tu Nan’s lineage could inherit?
The slovenly Daoist Zhang Fengxian.

*Two Odes to Beautiful Golden Flower*
**Note on Title:** As *Cantong Qi* states: *"Ancient records title it* Dragon and Tiger*, the Yellow Emperor praises* Golden Flower.*"* *Dragon and Tiger* and *Golden Flower* are both ancient scriptures left by sages. Alchemists compare the golden flower to true lead, hence the *Contract* says: *"At last obtaining the golden flower, turning and interdependent. The flower is white liquid, congealing into utmost hardness."* This speaks of mercury transformed by true lead into liquid, entering the Yellow Court to become the supreme treasure. It also says: *"Lead’s body is black without, yet harbors the golden flower within."* Thus, in elixir-making, white gold is extracted from black lead, refining the earth of wu and xu. Named *"Beautiful Golden Flower,"* the golden flower’s value is thus supreme. The tune’s name is taken from this.

Golden flowers bloom fresh,
Without wealth, cultivation is difficult.
Dare not speak to others,
Each calculates their own means.
Seeking external protection, yet no worthy master met,
Holding fast to heaven’s mechanism for years.
Testing briefly, wonders grow more profound,
Relying on the sword of wisdom to gather the primordial.
Only now do I know the Dao lies before me,
At last believing the golden elixir has a true transmission.
Blowing the flute without holes,
Plucking the stringless zither.
Delighting in yellow sprouts and white snow,
Cherishing the first scripture’s red lead.
Drinking the wine of life extension,
Ingesting the soul-returning elixir.
Engaged in the work within the pot,
Playing with the golden toad at the sea’s bottom.
Seizing sun and moon to refine in the furnace,
Seizing heaven and earth to simmer in the crucible.
This is my true cultivation secret,
A layman’s guise.
Regretting that in the past, I had no wealth,
Day and night pleading to heaven, pitiful indeed.
Now, at last, fortune turns,
Awaiting only the completion of my work and the perfection of merit,
Then casting off to become an immortal beyond the world.

*Again*
Golden flower, jade bud fresh,
The world finds it hard to discern.
For longevity, one must subdue qi,
For grafting, true lead is needed.
Laying the foundation, refining the self,
After gathering, the postnatal jade liquid returns as elixir.
Even if one attains longevity in this world,
One must still seek the nine refinements of golden liquid.
Alas, those who study immortality,
Each and all blindly cultivate and recklessly refine,
Step by step, who understands true investigation?
Throughout heaven and earth, yellow sprouts grow everywhere,
Across the cosmos, white flowers bloom in full,
All awaiting the moment when water is exhausted, gold is born, and the moon is full.
Here, I wield the precious sword upon Southern Mountain,
Slaying the seven emotions and six desires,
Severing the entanglements of love and affection,
Sweeping away the floating clouds of ten thousand li,
Not a speck of dust remains.
Startling the five ghosts and three corpses, their hearts turn cold.
I invert yin and yang,
Employing divine strategy to silently harmonize the Zhou Tian,
Guarding body and mind against danger and peril.
Gently shaking the earth’s axis,
Slowly turning the heavenly gate,
A thunderclap resounds beyond the heavens.

*The Heavenly Mechanism in a Single Secret*
As *The Song of Knocking on the Hexagrams* says: *"People of this age do not grasp the principle within the flower, a single secret of heaven’s mechanism is worth ten thousand gold."* The tune’s name is taken from this.

I tell you the true oral secret,
Point to the moon at heaven’s edge.
When the moon is full, the jade bud appears,
When the moon wanes, the golden flower falls.
Three and five follow the seasons,
Old and young carefully distinguished.
Sent to the Yellow Dame’s abode,
Never let it leak or escape.
Grafting, grafting,
The spirit turtle drinks the Golden Crow’s blood to the last drop.
Resolute, resolute,
Become a guest of Penglai’s three isles.

*The Song of the Mysterious Pass’s Union*
The Great Dao is beyond words,
Its wondrous principle hard to exhaust,
The Mysterious Pass—a single secret of Damo.
Above, to Kunlun’s Niwan peak,
Below, to the deep abyss of Yongquan’s cave.
Lead as mother, mercury as father,
The leaves of lead and mercury—yin and yang—unite as one,
The maiden and infant rest together.

*The Song of Yin-Yang Union*
Inverting Kan within Li,
Dragon and tiger meet in wind and cloud.
A wondrous point encompasses heaven and earth,
Its minute size unknown to men,
Returning three and revolving five to penetrate heaven’s mechanism.
Li returns to Kan, Kan returns to Li,
Kan and Li’s water and fire move east and west,
Infant and maiden become husband and wife.
Yin steals yang’s essence to take Kan’s reality,
Yang subdues yin’s spirit to fill Li’s emptiness,
Three threes and six sixes divide heaven and earth.
These practices are not easy,
Transforming heaven and earth, leaking primordial qi.

*Pure Chant of the Grotto-Heaven (Six Refrains)*
From Qiu Zu’s *Song of the Azure Sky*: *"Day and night, the pure youth fills the grotto-heaven,"* referring to the moment when the solitary truth is fully revealed. The tune’s name is taken from this.

**First Refrain**
I only await to cleave open the chaos and embrace the primordial,
To split asunder the vast emptiness and reveal the aperture.
I only await to find a single drop of life-continuing nectar,
To seek a sprig of soul-returning herb.
I but see the tiger’s roar summon the tide of qi,
The stirring of *gui* sprouts the medicine’s shoot.
When the Yellow Dame teaches the zither’s harmony,
And the Metal Duke strikes the bamboo clappers,
Unawares, the cinnabar field burns hot—
The life-treasure has returned to the Yellow Way.
At that moment, regulate spirit and breath in even measure,
Silently witness water and fire commingle.

**Second Refrain**
I take up the bottomless basket, borne by another’s labor,
I cradle the stringless lute to my breast.
Gently I pluck the crimson phoenix’s head aright,
Stealthily I bore into the black turtle’s aperture.
Seizing yang qi, I cross the Magpie Bridge,
Wielding yin talismans, I swiftly enfold.
Suddenly, the mud-pill palace boils like broth,
The cinnabar field blazes like fire.
Setting up *zhun* and *meng*, I forget dawn and dusk,
Permeating the four limbs, the warmth steams through.
Should demonic visions beckon,
Here I remain—still, thus, unshaken.

**Third Refrain**
Refining the self, I pacify the five thieves,
Transforming the scene, I merge the seven emotions.
Subduing the six desires, I bring them to quiescence,
Sweeping clean the three fields, I leave them pristine.
Nature settled, it naturally attains numinosity,
The heart emptied, inner illumination shines.
Harmonizing firm and yielding,
Metal and water in concord ascend to meet yin and yang,
Reversing their course.
Once the *jiji* work is complete,
The ten thousand spirits all heed command.
Hearing the summons, I ascend in flight—
My name is already inscribed on the steps of the Cinnabar Terrace.

**Fourth Refrain**
I only await to conceal myself in the marketplace, silently cultivating the work...

I await only to choose a propitious place for my practice;
I await only to wield the sword of wisdom, nurturing the white snow,
Relying on the craftsman’s hand to plant the yellow sprout;
I await only to stir the fire and refine true emptiness,
Seeking the light to shatter primordial chaos;
I await only to gather the two qi into the Li chamber,
Harvesting the single yang to enter the Zhen palace.
Following Master Jingyang’s footsteps, I ascend on wings of cinnabar phoenix;
Emulating the divine prowess of the Yellow Emperor, I soar astride a fiery dragon.

**Fifth Refrain**
Gather the essence of lead, pair it with the sprout of mercury,
Erect the furnace and tripod, cultivate the mystery’s essentials.
Seize the mechanism of heaven and earth’s creation,
Comprehend the wondrous waxing and waning of sun and moon.
Unite water and fire, kindling left and right,
Commanding hun and po to intermingle in exchange.
Follow the four seasons without missing their sequence,
Align with the eight nodes, responding to the trigrams’ lines.
Discern dawn and dusk, clarify growth and decline,
Observe the celestial Dao—twelve circuits of the celestial sphere must be completed.

**Sixth Refrain**
The seven-return great pearl illumines the nature,
The nine-return golden liquid completes the great elixir.
With a thunderous clap, the true person emerges from the crown.

**Two Lyrics of the Pleasure Garden of Beautiful Spring**

In the Pleasure Garden of Beautiful Spring, the moon’s wheel hangs high,
Jade trees bloom anew, breaking the silence.
At midnight, the cinnabar furnace is opened,
At the third watch, the Dipper’s handle is turned.
Who has ever reached the Silver River of the Milky Way?
The Cowherd and Weaver Girl laugh from the edge of heaven.
In the Purple Palace, the assembly of immortals gathers—
Return, return! The dust of the mundane is washed away.

Again,
In the Pleasure Garden of Beautiful Spring, the sun’s radiance is clear,
The golden liquid and returned elixir are already refined.
To make emotion return to nature,
One must merge nature with emotion.
Wealth, honor, and fame—ask no more,
The infant boy and maiden girl are most enchanting.
The furnace and tripod radiate light—
From here, one journeys to the summit of Kunlun.

**West River Moon**
The Dao resides in the mysterious pass, a single aperture,
The aperture embraces primordial qi and primordial essence.
Primordial essence and primordial qi nourish the primordial spirit,
When the spirit is full, movement and stillness arise naturally.
In movement and stillness, three revolutions and nine transformations,
Circulating through the changes of heaven and earth.
Heaven and earth inverted, planting the flower’s root—
The root blossoms, and the West River Moon shines true.

**Two Lyrics on the "Rootless Tree"**

**To the Tune of "Partridge Sky"**
*(Note: The fifth and sixth lines are three-character phrases, rhyming as one, following the "Partridge Sky" form. One version reads "Difficult / To debate with worldly folk," combining two lines into one, resembling "Auspicious Partridge." Both versions are preserved here.)*

The Dao’s methods flow with orthodoxy and heterodoxy,
Those who enter heterodoxy and turn from orthodoxy fill the earth.
Rarely seen are phoenixes soaring through the clouds,
Many are those who drown, becoming well-frogs.
Difficult to debate,
Amid the clamor,
All take red earth for cinnabar.
To know the true path to the mysterious,
Study closely the flower beneath the rootless tree.

**To the Tune of "Selling Flowers"**
Beneath the rootless tree, the eternal constant is spoken,
The six paths unite in spirit, sharing one light.
Comprehending matters before and after the sound of majesty,
Originally without coming or going, bearing a dignified form.

**Twenty-Four Daoist Songs on the "Rootless Tree"**
*(In the world, there are two interpretations of the "Rootless Tree," elucidating the primordial mystery without omission. Those with aspiration for the Dao should peruse them.)*

**Topic Explanation:**
The "rootless tree" refers to the lead qi within the human body.
Within the realm of emptiness, the alchemist nurtures a rootstock—both precelestial and postcelestial arise from nothing into being. Thus it is said: *"Though spoken of as rootless, it indeed has roots."*

Those refining the postcelestial must enter nothingness to seek being, then cast being into nothingness;
Those refining the precelestial must enter being into nothingness, then return from nothingness to being.
The cultivation of the root and foundation is thus.

All twenty-four songs urge one to study closely the immortal flower beneath the rootless tree. The subtleties of medicinal substances, celestial timing, grafting, and harvesting are fully contained within—these are the immortal verses of Daoist songs.

---
The rootless tree, its flower now secluded,
Who in this red dust would cultivate?
Floating life’s affairs are a boat on the bitter sea,
Tossed to and fro, never free.
Boundless and shore-less, hard to moor,
Ever sailing through the perils of dragons and fish.
If you would turn your head, it is the shore—
Do not wait for the winds and waves to wreck your boat.

Again,
The rootless tree, its flower now faint,
The old tree renewed by grafting tender branches.
Peach grafted onto willow, mulberry onto pear,
Passed down as a model for those who cultivate the true.
Since ancient times, the immortals’ method of grafting—
Even the aged can be healed with medicine.
Seek a bright teacher, inquire of the method,
Begin swiftly—even then, it may be too late.

Again,
The rootless tree, its flower now verdant,
From ancient times to now, flower-wine immortals abound.
In the brothel’s camp, within the wine’s forest,
Avoiding meat and lewdness, avoiding lust.
Lust forfeits the treasure of long life,
Meat and wine pass through the gut, yet the Dao resides in the heart.
Open the door, I tell you:
Without wine and flowers, the Dao cannot be achieved.

Again,
The rootless tree, its flower now solitary,
I ask: does yin and yang find its kind?
A hen’s egg cannot hatch a chick,
Turning from the furnace of yin and yang’s creation.
A woman without a husband is a resentful maiden,
A man without a wife is a widowed bachelor.
Alas, the deluded ones, so muddled—
Sitting in solitude, refining qi until it withers.

Again,
The rootless tree, its flower now askew,
Departing from yin and yang, the Dao is incomplete.
Gold separated from wood, mercury from lead,
Yang widowed, yin solitary—each to its own side.
In the world, yin and yang pair man with woman,
Bearing sons and grandsons, generation after generation.
Following the flow makes one mortal,
Reversing it makes one immortal—
It lies only in the inversion of the cheekbones.

Again,
The rootless tree, its flower now fresh,
Born in the Kun direction—Kun is human.
Pluck the flower, wear it,
Gather the flower’s heart,
Layer upon layer of the flower’s pistil, resplendent in spring’s beauty.
Worldly folk do not grasp the principle within the flower,
A single secret of heaven’s mechanism is worth ten thousand gold.
Borrow the flower’s name to make the flower’s body,
Every line of *"Knocking on the Trigrams"* speaks truly.

Again,
The rootless tree, its flower now lush,
Its smiling face and delicate features like powdered silk.
Guard against the monkey and horse, stubborn and unruly,
Hang up the iron face born of your mother.
Draw forth the true treasure sword of the Azure Dragon,
Pluck every blossom from the garden wall.
Hoist the sails to the wind, fully laden return—
How could one journey empty-handed to the mountain of treasure!

Again,
The rootless tree, its flowers now in flight,
Shedding to bloom again at fixed times.
When the lead-flower appears, as *gui* wanes,
Once more the Western Garden’s branches bloom full.
Just gathered beneath the moon, they’re mended at dawn—
Patching the robe in the morning sun.
This subtle mystery, rare in the world,
Must be pondered with immortals, carefully weighed.

Again,
The rootless tree, its flowers now in bloom,
Plucked from the crescent-moon furnace.
They lengthen years, lessen illness and woe,
Forming good bonds to prepare the dharma-wealth.
From this, the treasure of heaven may be wrought—
Let the deluded masses laugh at my folly.
I urge the wise: cease your cleverness,
Without a true master, do not force your guesses.

Again,
The rootless tree, its flowers now full,
Fruits ripened, their flavor complete.
Like crimson tangerines or pellets round,
Guard the embankments well—never idle.
Learn the method of plants: gathering at the head,
Returning life to the root, reverting to the origin.
Choose a sacred site, build a Daoist hut,
Unite with the primordial to complete the great return.

Again,
The rootless tree, its flowers now flourishing,
Spoken of as rootless, yet it has roots.
The three talents’ apertures, the two-five essences,
When heaven and earth unite, the ten thousand things are born.
When sun and moon conjoin, cold and heat align,
When man and woman unite, conception begins.
How clear this is, I tell you plainly—
Only fear we meet yet fail to recognize the truth.

Again,
The rootless tree, its flowers now fine,
Facing the scene, forgetting emotion, savoring moonlight.
Golden essence flourishes, dazzling the eye—
Do not pluck the wrong melon in the garden.
The five metals and eight stones are all false,
The ten thousand herbs and grasses all fall short.
The golden toad, the jade crow—
Recognize true lead, and you are the master.

Again,
The rootless tree, its flowers now many,
Blooming everywhere beyond the river of desire.
Hard to pluck, what can be done?
Step by step, tread the dragon-tiger’s den.
Returning with yellow blossoms to the cave,
Your name inscribed in the Purple Palace, never to fade.
Laughing heartily, oh white clouds,
Prepare the celestial ladder to ascend the Great Loft.

Again,
The rootless tree, its flowers now fragrant,
The lead cauldron warm, revealing its treasure’s glow.
On the golden bridge, gazing toward the winding river,
In the moon, the sun is clearly seen.
Swallow the black liver and hare’s marrow,
Replace the old dust-laden intestines.
The realm of fame and profit, the land of love and attachment—
Never again turn back, vainly busy.

Again,
The rootless tree, its flowers now fresh,
Talisman fire sears mercury and lead.
At the furnace’s edge, the scene appears—
Gathering depends entirely on the dharma-boat.
A master craftsman, strong and steady, holds the helm,
Though the vast sea’s waves churn beneath.
Pass the three barriers, pierce the mud-pill,
Early on, open the nine apertures of the body.

Again,
The rootless tree, its flowers now lush,
Recognize true lead as the primal ancestor.
Essence, qi, and spirit refined in one crucible,
The woman transforms to man, the old to youth.
To capture the White Tiger in the west,
First subdue the Azure Dragon in the east.
Of like kind, work diligently—
When the outer medicine flows, the inner medicine flows.

Again,
The rootless tree, its flowers now fair,
Heaven responds with stars, earth with tides.
The dragon-slaying sword, the tiger-binding rope,
Revolving the celestial stem, turning the Dipper’s handle.
Forging a furnace of true sun and moon,
Sweeping away the three thousand six hundred paths.
Treading the clouds, free and unfettered,
All sins and worldly dust vanish with a stroke.

Again,
The rootless tree, its flowers now lofty,
Ocean waves surge as the moon plays with the tide.
The Silver River’s path pierces the nine heavens,
The raft’s shadow spans the void, moored to the Dipper’s handle.
Touching the Weaving Maid’s shuttle-stone,
Treading the Cowherd’s magpie bridge.
Meeting the immortals’ court, with bold spirit,
Stealing the Queen Mother’s peaches from Jasper Pool.

Again,
The rootless tree, its flowers now paired,
Dragon and tiger ascend the altar, locked in battle.
Lead enters mercury, matching yin and yin,
The dharma-image of the mysterious pearl, priceless.
This is the true seed of the homeland,
Returning the old to youth, life everlasting.
Ascend to heaven, to the realm of utmost bliss,
Spared from the wheel of rebirth and meeting King Yama.

Again,
The rootless tree, its flowers now wondrous,
Cultivated in the moon for but a moment.
Cloud-seizing hands, cloud-stepping ladder,
Plucking the first primordial branch.
Drinking wine with flowers, spirit refreshed,
Laughing at the drunken immortal, limp as mud.
Entrusting to a confidant, guarding with care,
Ever fearful the furnace’s fire may fly away.

The rootless tree, its flowers now golden,
Born in the central realm of wu and ji.
The eastern maiden, the western youth,
United as husband and wife in the bridal chamber.
Yellow Dame urges them to drink the ghee-like wine,
Daily intoxicated, ever drunk.
This immortal formula, this soul-returning nectar,
Raises the dead to life—truly the Medicine King.

Again,
The rootless tree, its flowers now radiant,
The moon’s essence pressing upon the sun’s soul.
The golden crow’s marrow, the jade hare’s essence,
These two seized and simmered in one vessel.
Yang fire and yin tally divide at midnight and noon,
Bathing rites added at dawn and dusk’s gates.
Guard the Yellow Court, nurture the Valley Spirit,
A man conceiving—how the world will laugh!

Again,
The rootless tree, its flowers now crimson.
Plucked bare, the red blossoms leave the tree empty.
Emptiness is form, form is emptiness,
Discerning true emptiness within form.
When true emptiness is fully realized, form vanishes,
Yet the dharma-form endures, never falling into void.
Named Perfect Penetration, called the Great Hero,
Nine generations ascend beyond the nine heavens.

Again,
The rootless tree, its flowers now formless,
Shadowless, shapeless—hard to depict.
Nameless, yet answering when called,
Seized and placed within the alchemical furnace.
Circulate the samadhi fire of the celestial cycle,
Temper true emptiness to return to the Great Void.
Visit the immortal capital, receive the heavenly tally,
Only then is one a true man of courage.

*Daoist Airs of the Four Seasons*
Spring’s hues delight the heart,
Peach and apricot blossoms renew the eye.
The mountain garden’s fresh scenes,
Seem to banish all cares.
The immortal’s joy is to wander spring’s grotto-realm,
Master Zi Jin plays his jade flute,
The jade flute’s notes for the knowing ear.
I thought it mere idle pastime—
Lighting a stick of incense,
Stroking a tune upon the zither.

Summer’s delight—the lotus pond,
A pair of mandarin ducks skims the water’s face.
Arranged in mirrored pairs,
They drift with the cool breeze beneath the moon.
The immortal’s joy is Lü Dongbin’s meeting with Zhongli,
The two elders leaving behind the land of longevity,
Riding clouds to ascend Mount Zhongnan.
I thought it mere idle pastime—
Lighting a stick of incense,
Playing a game of chess.

Autumn’s scene—sparse clouds,
Distant peaks turn russet, trees shed their leaves.
Night reveals the Silver River’s spread,
Where the Herdsman ferries the Weaver Maid across.
The immortal’s joy is the fortune-teller’s retreat in Chengdu,
Master Junping carrying his jade flask,
Earning a hundred coins each day to buy wine.
I thought it mere idle pastime—
Lighting a stick of incense,
Reading a scroll of scripture.

Winter’s sight—snow flies,
A thousand miles of passes and mountains like jade heaped.
He Jing hides in his hut to sleep,
The cold sky, a crane guards Solitary Mountain.
The immortal’s joy is Han Xiangzi’s salvation of Wen Gong,
Though he urged him to turn back, he would not,
Only meeting again on the road to Blue Pass.
I thought it mere idle pastime—
Lighting a stick of incense,
Painting a plum tree in bloom.

*Four Daoist Airs*—composed in reclusion on Mount Zhongnan, sung for my own pleasure.
Styled after the *Bamboo Branch* songs, each stanza a sharp pause,
Seeming disjointed, yet the wonder lies precisely in the unbroken thread of disjunction.
Self-inscribed.
Left at Green Goat Palace, *Four Daoist Airs*.

Seeking old friends across the ends of earth—none to be found,
I sigh at those lost fools who would learn to be immortals.
Some cling to stubborn emptiness,
With yin but no yang, their refining is solitary;
Some wield crucibles and vessels,
Abandoning life and death to prattle of "gathering and battle."
Each grasps but one corner,
The Mysterious Pass unknown to them all.
Do not dress up non-action as adornment—
All is but an empty facade.
How to find cloud companions and rosy friends,
To blend with the world and harmonize its light for a few years?

To seek the Dao, one must seek the Primordial,
For the Primordial is what immortals transmit mouth-to-mouth,
And immortals but slumber amidst the flowers.

Again—
To refine millet-grain elixirs, one must have both method and resources,
And for matters of the heart, one must entrust two or three as companions.
How to find a Zhang Huanwei to discourse on the mysterious,
Or a Ma Banzhou to cultivate refinement together?
Xue Daoguang once returned to the secular,
Wang Chongyang was fortunate to meet a good fate.
Old Master Boduan sought friends in Fufeng County,
Bodhidharma attained the Dao in the Pavilion of Eternal Spring.
Only then did I realize that even the willow lanes and flower streets are fit for Chan meditation—
No more talk of pure non-action and idle sitting in vain.

To seek the Dao, one must seek the Primordial,
For the Primordial is what immortals transmit mouth-to-mouth,
And immortals but slumber amidst the flowers.

Again—
Seeking a true master with utmost diligence, countless times,
All claim to have received authentic transmission,
Some immortal and their dharma kin.
One speaks of replenishing the Upper Field,
Another of benefiting the Lower Origin.
One says guarding the Central Yellow is the Dharma-eye,
While others mock the space between the two kidneys as the Mysterious Pass.
With such a thousand gates and ten thousand doors,
Atop a hundred-foot pole,
Countless worthies have been led astray.

To seek the Dao, one must seek the Primordial,
For the Primordial is what immortals transmit mouth-to-mouth,
And immortals but slumber amidst the flowers.

Again—
Let those who would learn immortality heed my words:
Never blindly cultivate or recklessly refine.
You must know the inner and outer yin and yang,
And what kind of thing their kindred is.
One must refine yin and yang according to yin and yang,
And refine the worldly according to worldly methods.
Following the flow, one becomes human;
Reversing it, one becomes immortal—
A single phrase transcends thousands upon thousands.
No more talk of pure non-action—
Without obtaining the Returned Elixir, all is in vain.

To seek the Dao, one must seek the Primordial,
For the Primordial is what immortals transmit mouth-to-mouth,
And immortals but slumber amidst the flowers.

*Five Watches Daoist Airs*
**Note on Meaning:** *"Five Watches"* must be lived—it signifies unceasing effort, not that the first watch is one watch’s effort, the second two, and so on. The rest follow by analogy.

**First Watch**
Alone I herd the green ox at the first watch’s beginning,
Never letting it run wild or wander idly.
Here I shift scenes and alter moods,
Plucking flowers and breaking willows,
Secretly refining and cultivating in seclusion.
Closing the six gates, I guard in non-action and stillness,
Capturing the five thieves with methodical restraint.
Matching hardness and softness,
Enduring through spring and autumn,
Qi flourishes, spirit complete—
What worry is there in gathering the medicine?

**Again**
In the second watch, matching and harmonizing,
Dispelling all yin, driving back the demon horde.
I only wish to summon the phoenix to nest,
Call the turtle back to its cave,
And guide the tiger home to its den.
When lead arises, know to guard it carefully,
And when the moon appears, recognize it truly.
Do not err in action,
Lest the distant hour pass—
The Red Waters merge with the pearl,
And creation dances in joy!

**Again**
In the third watch, as the first yang stirs,
The gates of the Red County open,
And true qi begins to rise.
At this moment, lead’s splendor is faintly revealed,
First containing the jade bud,
Half-spitting golden essence.
Lock the heart-ape—dragons chant in response to clouds,
Tether the mind-horse—tigers roar as the wind rises.
Gather a sprig of magic fungus,
Send it into the Yellow Court,
Seal it without worry—
A hundred days’ work bears efficacy.

**Again**
In the fourth watch, the last drops of ghee are drunk,
Riding a raft like Zhang Qian,
Laughing at the sight of Magu.
Relying on this drop to irrigate the Three Fields,
Fusing and opening the hundred channels,
Moistening skin and flesh.
Circulating through the sturdy cauldron’s earthen pot,
Ascending and descending—guard as at first.
All thoughts vanish,
All sounds and sights are cast away.
Nurturing the fetal immortal—
Ten months’ work.

**Again**
At the fifth watch’s end, adding mercury and drawing lead,
Changing the crucible, dividing the elixir,
Moving the elixir to the Upper Field.
From now on, yang grows and yin wanes,
Nature is perfected, life is complete,
Body is firm, form is solid.
Quietly harmonizing the spirit, it gradually expands,
Diligently facing the wall—nine years to return to the origin.
Work complete, merit fulfilled,
Eight hundred and three thousand—
Uniting with the Dao as true,
One becomes an immortal.

**Five Watches Daoist Airs**

**First Watch**
Lead and mercury complete,
The Three Corpses and Six Thieves all scatter.
Heart-ape and mind-horse firmly tethered,
The lead crucible warm and never cold,
No demon dares lift its head.
Calm the spirit, let nature take its course,
The dragon chants, the tiger rejoices.
Mastering this wondrous principle through practice,
Fire and water throughout the body pair as Li and Kan.
To become immortal or sage—what lament is there?
To achieve longevity is not difficult.
I recall the *Fire Dragon’s Direct Pointers* to the Returned Elixir,
Carefree and at ease—
At ease, an immortal.

**Again**
In the second watch, the elixir edict arrives,
Riding dragons and phoenixes beyond the spring clouds.
The Great Return is at hand—everyone cherishes it,
At last believing the golden elixir is fine medicine.
Mother sees her darling child in one embrace,
Peacefully asleep, feigning dullness.
In the realm of purity, unstained by dust,
From now on, all karmic debts are extinguished.
Becoming one who never ages,
Nurturing peach-cheeked and apricot-faced youth.

**Again**
In the third watch, the living Zi hour,
The immortal’s fair scene appears in the Flowery Pond.
The spirit turtle drinks the golden crow’s marrow,
The elixir phoenix brings the jade hare’s fat.
Mysterious bright wine—
Drunk as if mad,
All yin gone, the radiant yang season.
A branch of golden spring blossoms,
The fair one’s heart inclined, consenting,
The young lord delights in mutual play.
Having met the return to origin and reversion to root,
Lifespan equals heaven’s.

**Again**
In the fourth watch, the night watch deepens,
After lead arises from Gui, yin and yang part.
Just at the first string, the golden water is full,
Like the oriole and flowers of a second-month spring.
No greed for wealth,
No love for fame.

Drinking nectar of jade,
Listening to celestial music.
The azure sky merges with the pristine clear waves,
Before the Hall of Void-White, the steed of intent is tethered,
Beneath the shadowless tree, the monkey of the heart is locked.
Three cycles and nine revolutions—the true person appears,
Having met the primordial Great Dao,
Lifespan rivals heaven and earth.

**Again**
In the fifth watch, having gathered it,
Fame and fortune are all cast aside.
With whole heart longing for Penglai’s scene,
The Ten Isles and Three Mountains become home.
Free from the fire of desire,
Without entanglements,
This longevity
Lies within oneself.
Nurture gratitude for parental kindness, never falter,
Meet others without speaking of hardship,
Fear neither blade nor beast.
Though alluring beauty hangs her curtain,
Never again yearn for wayward blossoms or wall-side willows.

**Five Watches’ Daoist Songs**

**First Watch**
Entering the meditation chamber,
Body and mind in purity—no need for haste,
The heart’s monkey and intent’s steed must not be lightly released.
Guard the spirit terrace’s white jade light,
Within it hides the idle true person.
The master sits upright atop Kunlun,
The Yellow Dame leads into the bridal chamber.
Infant boy and maiden girl pair as one,
The three families meet by Qujiang’s winding shore.

**Again**
**Second Watch**
Ascending the meditation mat,
Contemplating parents before birth,
The original face ever appears.
Gathering the primordial to mend the later heaven,
The three passes revolve to the Mud Pill Palace.
Divine water of the Flowery Pond frequently swallowed,
Water and fire unite to warm the lower field.
Within the crescent moon crucible, the supreme treasure simmers,
Three cycles and nine revolutions refine the elixir.

**Again**
**Third Watch**
As the first yang arises,
Kan and Li consummate their marriage,
Free from entanglements, ever pure.
The mud ox from the sea’s depths surges straight upward,
Unbroken qi threads through Kunlun.
The gold-water couple comes to union,
White snow of immortality abides in the Yellow Court.
Having refined the golden elixir, the indestructible body,
Only then is the mystery of the mysterious pass fully known.

**Again**
**Fourth Watch**
Seeking the ancestral wind,
The great meaning from the West lies within,
Constantly applying effort.
The bright moon hangs in the sky, red to the crown,
Illuminating one’s own master.
Only then knowing lead cast into mercury within the crucible,
The true lineage appears within the exquisite pagoda.
The golden elixir refined, true emptiness achieved,
For a thousand years, ten thousand ages, the body remains unmoved.

**Again**
**Fifth Watch**
Aligning with heaven’s mechanism,
The aperture of the mysterious pass—few know it,
Who recognizes the realm of life and death?
All relies on wu-ji to birth the infant,
Golden light resplendent, the Muni appears.
The supreme treasure gathered within the cinnabar field,
Nurturing the spiritual root to equal heaven.
The yang spirit’s wondrous form merges with the Great Void,
A single grain of millet pearl encompasses heaven and earth.

**Five Watches’ Daoist Songs**
In stillness observing faces and images,
Searching for the root of the Dao’s aperture.
Within the Taiyi crucible, the celestial circuit revolves,
The true fire of samadhi forges and refines.
Arrows pierce the iron drum of the nine kings,
The three passes revolve to the Mud Pill Palace.
Grasping the precious moon to pair with the sun’s slumber,
At this moment, lead and mercury meet.

*To the tune of "Moon over the West River."*
This is an ancient immortal’s song, borrowed by the patriarch as the prelude to *Five Watches’ Daoist Songs*, hence preserved as is.

**First Watch**
The steed steady—let not the monkey leap.
Qi settled, spirit clear,
The heart’s ground naturally swept.
Guarding the Yellow Court,
Revolving the primordial Dao.
In tranquil leisure observing,
The mystery within the mystery revealed.
Seizing the moment when the heart is stilled,
Nature abides at heaven’s edge, life at the sea’s bottom—
Awakening to the bronze mirror.

Bronze mirror,
Formless, radiant, hard as iron.
Look at yourself,
Transforming heaven and earth,
Gathering the sun’s essence—
All heed
The Dharma King’s decree.

**Again**
**Second Watch**
Within the crucible, myriad lotus blossoms bloom.
The yellow sprout refined,
A single point descends from heaven.
Drawing life from death,
Formless yet possessing form.
Illuminating the ten directions,
Everywhere resplendent.
Behold the celestial channel, bright and gleaming,
Herding the flock, clapping hands in laughter,
Early leaping over Cloud Dream.

Leaping over Cloud Dream,
Feet stomping the spirit terrace, crying aloud.
Look at yourself,
Holding the golden tablet,
Inscribing your name—
Having attained
The effortless Dao.

**Again**
**Third Watch**
Regulating with towering stillness, utterly unmoved.

A lone pillow in solitary sleep,
Piercing the dream of millet’s golden steam.
The white crow arrives at dawn,
The Great Ultimate’s cavern radiant and bright.
The seas run dry,
Each pearl played in hand.
Purple Yang Palace stands alone, leafing through profit,
Wandering idly in the Crystal Palace’s halls.
What fine Nine-Ranked Land of No-Birth—
The Great Marshal’s hall lined with vajras.

Look at yourself,
Climbing heaven’s ladder—
How to know
The coral stone,
True lapis lazuli?

**Again**
**Fourth Watch**
With fierce courage, battling the demon king.
In the Formless Palace,
Wielding the double-tailed sword.
Vanquishing the demon king,
Ten thousand leagues become one expanse.
Body and form unbound,
Entering Penglai’s courts once more.
Who knows this news?
You ponder and laugh to yourself.
What wondrous mystery within the mystery—
A single set of chess pieces clamoring on the board.

Look at yourself,
Pawns and advisors,
Cannons arrayed,
Chariots and horses advancing,
Checkmate in sight.

**Again**
**Fifth Watch**
Just awakened, self-aware, the heart unfolds in realization.
Swiftly redouble efforts,
Advance another step beyond the peak.
Rushing to Purple Yang Palace,
Breaking through the Caoxi path.
These labors—
No need to speak of them lightly.
Lifting the golden visage, grasping the sword’s hilt,
Keep it sealed, let nothing leak.
Unleashing the dragons to wrestle,
Dragons wrestle—
Do not let the lambs grow hungry and thin.

Look at yourself,
Vigilant on the dike,
Thieves do not steal,
The guard has wandered off—
Awaiting the celestial cycle.

**Fifth Watch’s Daoist Ballad**
The Yellow River’s current reversed in a single flow,
Nurtured to tenderness, soft as an infant child.

If mortals ask of the path to longevity,
Laugh and point east to Penglai beyond the azure sea.

**First Watch**
Cultivation demands meticulous care—
Do not let the mind-steed gallop east and west,
Gallop east and west.
The gibbon is locked within the square inch of the heart,
While this old master rides the black ox.
One more phrase—
The rest follows likewise.
The golden elixir’s blossom is drawn as one,
The precious sword plunged into the furnace.
Dragon and tiger entwine,
Kan and Li unite,
Water and fire inverted to achieve completion.

The golden elixir’s blossom—joyful recitation:
Recite once the name of the Buddha,
*Namo* the Buddha of the primordial chaos,
*Namo* the blossom’s bloom, the leaf’s fall.
Blossom’s bloom, leaf’s fall—
The moment when yang arises and yin expires.
Were it a mundane flower,
The bloom would bring forth leaves as well.
The rest follows likewise.

**Again**
**First Watch**
Cultivation lifts the true thought,
At the crossroads, refine the golden elixir,
Refine the golden elixir.
No need for water, fire, or charcoal—
Only awakening through seated meditation.
The golden elixir’s blossom is drawn as two,
The Yellow Dame leads the infant away.
Ascend to the Mud Pill Palace,
Pierce the Mysterious Pass—
Infant and maiden unite in harmony.

The golden elixir’s blossom—joyful recitation:
Recite once the name of the Buddha,
*Namo* Śākyamuni Buddha,
*Namo* the blossom’s bloom, the leaf’s fall.

**Again**
**Second Watch**
Cultivation demands unity,
Maiden and infant stand on either side,
Stand on either side.
The Yellow Lord and Yellow Dame serve as matchmakers,
Binding the two families in karmic ties.
The golden elixir’s blossom is drawn as three,
Speaking of life and death is no difficulty—
Yet though it seems not difficult,
It lies not here but there.

The golden elixir’s blossom—joyful recitation:
Recite once the name of the Buddha,
*Namo* the Tathāgata of the Western Paradise,
*Namo* the blossom’s bloom, the leaf’s fall.

**Again**
**Second Watch**
Cultivation demands single-minded focus,
Hand gripping the shadowless sword,
The shadowless sword.

**Third Watch**
The Six Thieves rush to the Demon King’s hall,
The Three Corpses’ heads roll before one’s eyes.
The golden elixir’s blossom is drawn as four—
Now I meet my enlightened teacher,
Who points me down a single path,
Hour by hour, moment by moment, I apply the work.

The golden elixir’s blossom—joyful recitation:
Recite once the name of the Buddha,
*Namo* Maitreya, the Laughing Buddha,
*Namo* the blossom’s bloom, the leaf’s fall.

**Again**
**Third Watch**
Cultivation demands vigilance against peril,
Let not the Six Thieves sway you,
Sway you.
Gather qi, condense spirit—all sinks downward.
Burn paper money to send them away.

The golden elixir’s blossom is drawn as five—
Now I have mastered the work.
Gather the primordial,
Mend the later heaven,
Rolling forth beyond the Cloud Gate to the heavens beyond heavens.

The golden elixir’s blossom—joyful recitation:
Recite once the name of the Buddha,
*Namo* Cundi, the Guiding Buddha,
*Namo* the blossom’s bloom, the leaf’s fall.

**Again**
**Third Watch**
Cultivation must not leak the mechanism,
The Yellow River reverses its flow, ascending the heavenly ladder,
Ascending the heavenly ladder.
Stand firm at the Mysterious Pass on the Black Ox’s hoof,
Inverting and inverting, fill *li* with *kan*.

The golden elixir’s blossom is drawn as six—
The lion refines the fire monkey.
Now I think,
To wander the clouds,
Crossing the *jiazi* cycle to reach Yingzhou.

The golden elixir’s blossom—joyful recitation:
Recite once the name of the Buddha,
*Namo* the Eighteen Arhats,
*Namo* the blossom’s bloom, the leaf’s fall.

**Again**
**Fourth Watch**
Cultivation demands wholehearted devotion,
Light the lamp of wisdom in the twin trees’ grove,
Light the lamp of wisdom.
Illuminating the World-Honored One’s departure,
Wait for him before the gates of the Land of Ultimate Bliss.

The golden elixir’s blossom is drawn as seven—
Someone in the void lends a hand.
Ride the Black Ox,
Cross the Mysterious Pass,
Refining a golden elixir, round and whole.

The golden elixir’s blossom—joyful recitation:
Recite once the name of the Buddha,
*Namo* Dipamkara, the Ancient Buddha,
*Namo* the blossom’s bloom, the leaf’s fall.

**Again**
**Fourth Watch**
Cultivation demands diligence,
Watch for the *xun* wind rising from the southwest,
Rising from the southwest.
Water and fire in harmony, inverted in use,
The medicine and fire together enter the furnace.

The golden elixir’s blossom is drawn as eight—
The infant and maiden flourish in splendor.
The master,
Recognizing them,
Forge them into one—this is the true adept.

The golden elixir’s blossom—joyful recitation:
Recite once the name of the Buddha,
*Namo* Mahāpakṣa, the Golden-Winged Buddha,
*Namo* the blossom’s bloom, the leaf’s fall.

**Again**
**Fifth Watch**
Cultivation—the golden rooster crows,
The deluded do not walk this path,
This path.
The iron tree blooms, its pistils not few,
When complete, it naturally has root and branch.

The golden elixir’s blossom is drawn as nine—
Speaking of it, everyone possesses it.
Speaking of possession, yet it is not,
Speaking of absence, yet it is—
This debate never ends.

The golden elixir’s blossom—joyful recitation:
Recite once the name of the Buddha,
*Namo* Mahāmāyūrī, the Peacock Radiant Buddha,
*Namo* the blossom’s bloom, the leaf’s fall.

**Again**
**Fifth Watch**
Cultivation—the sun crimson,
Beware lest the fire-timing come to naught,
Come to naught.
A thousand rays of rosy light surge like golden lotuses,
When complete, success is natural.

The golden elixir’s blossom is drawn as ten—
Now I return home.
Seeing the master,
Smiling,
I ask, “Where is the true person?”

The golden elixir’s blossom—joyful recitation:
Recite once the name of the Buddha,
*Namo* Dīrgha-karṇa, the Long-Eared Buddha,
*Namo* the blossom’s bloom, the leaf’s fall.

The recitations of the five watches end at dawn,
In the east, the first blush of peach-red appears,
The first blush of peach-red.
East rising, west setting—hurrying mortals to old age,
Avoiding the three disasters to repay the teacher’s kindness.

The golden elixir’s blossom is drawn as eleven—
Now I come to the deep mountains.
Erect a thatched hut,
Taming dragons and subduing tigers—naturally at ease.

The golden elixir’s blossom—joyful recitation:
Recite once the name of the Buddha,
*Namo* Amitābha Buddha,
*Namo* the blossom’s bloom, the leaf’s fall.

The recitations of the five watches conclude in radiant clarity,
A single crimson light—this is the ultimate truth.
The Yellow Dragon pierces through the Three Passes’ summit,
Today, riding the crane, I ascend in flight.

The golden elixir’s twelve blossoms open as one,
The Jade Emperor’s cinnabar script arrives.
Donning immortal robes,
Transforming upon the lotus dais,
The golden body is refined—imperishable.

Recite, recite once the name of the Buddha,
*Namo* Amitāyus, the Buddha of Infinite Life,
*Namo* the blossom’s bloom, the leaf’s fall.

Though the *Nine Watches* are not nine in time,
This is named “Nine Watches” (*geng*, falling tone),
Speaking of the repeated refinement
To complete the nine revolutions’ count.

The gate that gives me life is the path that takes my death,
How many are truly awake? How many truly awaken?
Last night, the iron man reflected alone—
Long life and immortality are made by man.

This verse belongs to Ancestor Zhong,
Also cited by the Patriarch to begin the *Nine Watches*.

**First Watch**
Turn the heart toward goodness,
For life and death are truly arduous.
Since departing the ancient Vulture Peak,
At the primal chaos’ first division, descending to the world.
In the West, there was a root,
Abandoned, its origin lost.
Coming to the Eastern Land,
Nature and life fell into the mundane.
Lost was
The Old Mother’s state before birth.

**Second Watch**
In the years of growing to adulthood,
Roots and sprouts take hold in the city’s midst.
Hunger and thirst teach up from down,
Yet none know whence life and death arise!
Dwelling in the second chamber,
Truth and falsehood remain unrecognized.
No path of escape is cultivated,
Only the present moment is heeded.
Following the six thieves,
The master of the house is ruined.

**Third Watch**
Banish thoughts of lust and waywardness,
Firmly lock the intent-horse and mind-ape.
In streets of flowers and willows, curb desire,
Lest another’s wife or daughter become your kin.
All is broken precepts,
All is demonic entanglement.
Two ghosts come to beckon—
Dare not turn to look back.
Entering hell’s gates,
Then the Tathāgata’s face will be hard to see.

**Fourth Watch**
Wisdom and folly are hard to discern,
Only the awakened see through the snare.
Behold how worldly men do not endure,
A hundred years of light pass swift as arrows.
Turn back early,
For this is the prime of life.
Seek a radiant teacher,
Receive the oral transmission,
That you may be shown
The original face before your mother’s birth.

**Fifth Watch**
Take refuge in the Tathāgata,
Sever the bonds of love for life and death.
Seeing worldly affairs stirs sorrow,
Lest one incur the debt of rebirth.
Lock the mind-ape fast,
Lest it be harmed.
Raise the true thought,
Boundless and without limit.
Ride the fragrant breeze,
Return home in good time.

**Sixth Watch**
Examine closely your original lineage,
Confine the ape and monkey within the chamber.
Whether coming or going, do not relax,
Guard the deep palace day and night with sword in hand.
Lock the four gates,
Suppress the demonic winds.
See through the red dust,
All is but emptiness.
Master of the house,
Recite the true scripture ceaselessly.

**Seventh Watch**
To shed the dust of the world,
Rely on the guidance of the gracious teacher.
Uphold the Three Regulations and Five Precepts,
Vow resolutely never to break them.
Worldly matters are small,
The matter of life and death is great.
Sever the cycle of rebirth,
Become indestructible as vajra.
Amidst the surging waves,
A single white lotus appears.

**Eighth Watch**
Guard the true lead,
Amitābha sits inverted at the mysterious pass.
Inhalation and exhalation of primordial yang revolve up and down,
Three before and three behind, borne as one.
The Yellow River flows backward,
The mud ox plows the field.
The magpie’s nest crowns the head,
Golden lotuses rise from the earth.
Atop Mount Sumeru,
A ray of numinous light shines forth.

**Ninth Watch**
Refine the three families with bitter toil,
The furnace’s fire never errs.
Beneath the shadowless tree, golden flowers bloom,
The two words *nature* and *life* branch forth at both ends.
Three carts transport,
Zhaozhou pours the tea.
Journey to the West,
Pay homage to the Buddha’s family.
The little infant,
Laughs with joy upon seeing its mother.

**Seven Laments on Leaving the Household Life**
These seven *Laments on Leaving the Household Life* have often been appropriated by Daoist priests as their own, and some suspect them to be the work of Luo Hongxian—this is not so. The final piece states: *"Fifty-two lines of mystery within principle, / Clearly and plainly spoken for you,"* referring to the *Daoist Songs*. From this, it is evident they were undoubtedly transmitted by Master Feng. Further examination of Wang’s edition confirms this.

**First Lament**
Leaving the household—how strange!
Seeing through the world’s path, as distant as cloud and mud.
With a heart unstained by worldly affairs,
Let others chase fleeting fame and profit,
Let others cling to beloved children and fair wives.
Toil of form is not worth remaining—
How could I spend my days in ceaseless striving?
How could I waste my days in endless scheming?
In cultivation, one must resolve with soaring ambition,
Become a man of noble spirit,
Shatter the mechanism of life and death,
Free from vexation, sorrow, and care.

**Second Lament**
Leaving the household—how secluded!
Cutting off deluded thoughts and worries.
How can one live without worldly dust?
How could I seek profit and covet gain?
How could I idly give up?
Resolutely, I will not fall into impermanence’s grasp,
Vowing to seek a teacher,
Vowing to pursue true cultivation.
Naturally, there will come a day when the elixir is perfected,
Then I may ride a crane or sail a boat,
Then I may wander at leisure,
Who has fathomed the wondrous mystery of the true Dao?

**Third Lament**
Leaving the household—how profound!
Learning to borrow the false to refine the true.
In movement and stillness, sitting and walking, fix the true heart,
Cherishing the nurturing of qi and uplifting of spirit,
Delighting in wood descending and metal ascending.
The numinous light appears, round as a mirror,
In an instant, every aperture becomes spiritually attuned.
The Yellow River’s waters revolve around Kunlun,
Naturally, one recognizes the true transformation of mystery.

**Fourth Lament**
Leaving the household—how abstruse!
Seeing through seated meditation and Chan inquiry.
What thing is the master that appears?
Within the mystery, silently wordless,
In motion and stillness, adding mercury and drawing lead.
Like a fool, like a drunkard, yet the spirit never tires.
When stoking the fire, civil and martial contend,
When nurturing, after midnight and before noon,
Water and fire conjoin in mutual refinement.

**Fifth Lament**
Leaving the household—how refined!
Prepare as a mighty general and valiant soldier.

**Sixth Lament**
Guard against the Six Thieves’ pilfering,
Let them ride mists or soar on clouds,
Let them be battle-hardened and fierce in strife—
All are subdued by wondrous skill.
Raise the Eye of Wisdom, ten thousand steeds charge as one,
Grasp the Sword of Wisdom, sever demonic essence.
The Three Corpses yield, the Demon King submits,
Revealing a heart of red loyalty and devotion.
Naturally, one sees a prosperous nation and a peaceful people,
With a single battle, all is settled in tranquility.

**Seventh Lament**
Leaving the household—how lofty!
One learns a life of ease and carefree wandering,
Embracing reversal and inversion, penetrating the mysterious and wondrous.
A single meal—how much can one eat?
Three cups of wine, and the face blooms like a peach of immortality,
Laughing through the streets of flowers and willows.
A small gourd always hangs at the waist,
A few packets of the Ten-Thousand-Spirits Elixir carried along,
Everywhere offering convenience to others.
When fortune smiles, fine wine and delicacies,
When times are lean, water and a simple gourd.
Wealth and poverty, honor and lowliness—all shaped by Heaven.
Let others don purple robes,
Let others ride steeds adorned with golden sable.
In the blink of an eye, impermanence arrives,
A three-inch breath grows faint and fleeting,
A household wails and clamors—
What care is given to filial sons or worthy grandsons?
In the end, cultivating the Dao is supreme,
Prolonging life, dispelling illness, and dissolving calamities.
Free from worry, free from care, free from vexation,
Awaiting the hour to ascend on clouds,
To join the Eight Immortals and cross the Immortal Bridge,
Only then is the mystery within the mystery revealed.

**Eighth Lament**
Leaving the household—how true!
The source of the heart must be cleansed to purity.
Only then is the principle within the mystery made clear,
Yet who inquires into refining the true and nurturing nature?
I have traversed rugged mountains and towering peaks,
Wandered through prefectures, counties, and cities,
Blending with the bustle of markets and crowds.
Some avoid meat and abstain from lust,
Some bear insults with magnanimity, keeping wealth and principle distinct,
Honored as friends in the lands of the southwest.
Once, I too was drunk on the world’s ways, dazed and confused,
But with sober eyes, I see the four seas’ teeming multitudes,
The red dust churning, golden blossoms tender.
Who in this world truly recognizes the moon at the edge of the sky?
Which affair in this world is ever made clear?
Yet each clings to the aspiration of cultivating immortality.
Fifty-two verses of mystery within the mystery,
Spoken plainly and clearly for you.
Seek a radiant teacher, visit the lofty,
With earnest devotion, one may receive the gift of longevity.

**The Moon at the Edge of the Sky (Nine Songs of Daoist Sentiment, Taking "The Moon at the Edge of the Sky Emerges from Geng" as Its Meaning)**

**I**
The moon at the edge of the sky, its light bright,
Illuminating the world as if through an overturned basin,
How many enmities lie hidden beneath that overturned basin?
Through kalpas of cultivation, one gains a human form,
Lose it, and for ten thousand kalpas it is hard to find again,
Hard to find the Eight Jewels of True Suchness.
Clinging to wife and children, like sheep among wolves,
Boasting of wealth and power, bullying the poor.
Yet Heaven’s retribution awaits those who bully the poor—
Better to leap free of the red dust,
Seek a radiant teacher, and early embark on cultivation,
Only then will one have a share among the immortals.

**II**
The moon at the edge of the sky, its light dim,
Who would cease clinging to glory and splendor?
Without ceasing, how can the conditions for immortality converge?
Alas, worldly folk, moored to a lone boat,
Like bubbles afloat on water,
Once scattered, they are hard to reassemble.
Better to turn back early,
Seek a radiant teacher, reverse-ride the green ox,
Accumulate merit and deeds until the elixir is formed,
In times of steadfastness, wander the four seas,
In times of fulfillment, step onto Penglai Isle,
Only then will one’s name be inscribed on the golden memorial.

**III**
The moon at the edge of the sky, its light cold,
To become an immortal is not so difficult,
Not difficult—if one but slays the Three Corpses.
The Alms Bowl for Subduing Dragons, passed down through generations,
The Vessel for Taming Tigers, its wondrous secrets hard to speak,
Hard to speak—do not reveal them to the unworthy.
Great spiritual powers plant lotuses in fire,
A master craftsman poles a boat against the current,
Poles against the current—do not falter.
The master steers the sail,
Amidst crashing waves, gathers true lead,
Only then does one ascend to the Hall of Numinous Dawn.

**IV**
The moon at the edge of the sky, its light high,
An immortal crosses the Magpie Bridge,
Yet the Magpie Bridge’s path is perilous, hard to reach.
From the Palace of the Yellow Court, one gathers the sprouts of medicine,
Within the Silver River, the tides of water rise,
Only then is the mystery within the mystery revealed.
The Cowherd descends from the heavenly courts,
The Weaver Girl eagerly beckons,
Cowherd and Weaver Girl share their joy.
May Heaven bestow a Yellow Matron,
For a blessed union in the realm of the indistinct,
When merit is complete and deeds fulfilled, the celestial decree arrives.

**V**
The moon at the edge of the sky, its light solitary,
The cultivator—a true man.
Only a true man enters the path of cultivation,
The Immortal Maiden Zhang once paid homage to Ancestor Lü.
The Dragon Girl offered a precious pearl,
The pearl summoned the protection of Chang’e.
From the Palace of Muddy Pellet, nectar descends,
Like pearl-orange wine, the finest ghee,
Ghee that, upon the tongue, is like sweet dew.
Advance the fire of yang, retreat the tally of yin,
Enter the Cinnabar Field, seal it firmly,
Only then will the path to Heaven be opened.

**VI**
The moon at the edge of the sky, its light drifting,
An immortal plays a jade flute,
The jade flute’s notes open the heavenly apertures.
Heaven and Earth in harmony, unmoving and unshaken,
Inversion and reversal—one must raise the hand high,
Only then is the mystery within the mystery revealed.
White snow swirls up to the Ninth Heaven,
Yellow sprouts grow long into numinous shoots,
Who knows the subtleties of the primordial mystery?
The rolling pearl is hard to depict, hard to describe,
The Hall of Mañjuśrī stands firm and unyielding,
Only then does one repay the teacher’s kindness.

**VII**
The moon at the edge of the sky, its light low,
The eighteen disciples play with the Mañjuśrī,
Mañjuśrī enters the land of longevity.
The meaning of the Western Advent is like drunkenness, like folly,
Avalokiteśvara, pure and without action,
Yet from non-action arises wondrous function.
Lead merges with mercury, life spans match Heaven’s,
Water and fire conjoin, forever secure,
The Three Corpses cower, the Demon King flees.
The Elixir of Longevity needs no cup,
Sweet as honey, one drinks the measured dose,
Intoxicated, one departs for the Feast of Peaches.

**VIII**
The moon at the edge of the sky, its light full,
Beneath the ancient pine, one awakens to the true mystery,
The true mystery—only the self may see.
Phoenixes soar over lofty mountains,
Parrots sing, guarding the Muddy Pellet,
Within the Muddy Pellet, the Infant’s face appears.
Holding the moon’s essence, neither ahead nor behind,
Embracing the sun in slumber, without earth or sky.

The Heavenless becomes the Palace of Exquisite Clarity,
May Heaven bestow a wisp of pure mist,
Embracing millet grains to ascend the cloud’s edge,
Only then may one approach the Hall of Divine Radiance.

Again,
The moon at the edge of the sky, its light gone,
Formless and shapeless, hard to depict,
Depictions hard to enter the manuals of cultivation.
Nameless, yet one hears the call,
Formless, who discerns near and far?
The wondrous function of kinship remains wholly concealed.
In thoughtless moments, what need for effort?
In the absence of desire, the true nature is thus,
Only thus is the path of one’s birth mother.
In the formless realm lies the true Way,
In freedom from entanglement, the immortal capital,
Only then may one tread upon the colored clouds.

*Twelve Songs of the Sweeping Light*

The sweeping light,
Illuminating the true,
Clap—one’s breast brims with spring.
Jade is not treasure, pearls are not precious,
The road to Mount Bei Mang does not follow the body.
All that has form and shape is false,
Only the scentless and soundless is true.
The body is not the Dao, the Dao is not the mind,
Do not mistake body and mind for the true person.

Again,
The sweeping light,
Illuminating the lord,
Beneath flowers and moonlight, drunk and reeling.
Words are not script, learning is not literature,
The Lord of the East laughs at one’s meager knowledge.
Peach red, willow green, plum blossoms white,
Swept away in an instant, no need for reflection.
People bustle, things teem,
Yet none differ—one transcends the crowd.

Again,
The sweeping light,
Illuminating the emperor,
The mechanism of divine transformation suddenly aligns.
Fish leap of themselves, kites soar of themselves,
Creation’s calculations are never concealed!
Qi transforms, form arises from its primal sign,
A single point of harmonious balance returns to the root.
Encompassing emptiness, giving birth to Heaven and Earth,
At a glance, all matters become effortless.

Again,
The sweeping light,
Illuminating the master,
Suddenly, the path of arrival is seen with clarity.
By land, one rides a carriage; by water, a boat,
Yet without moving a step, one reaches paradise.
In an instant, the principle is most true,
Ascending to the sacred realm—no words are amiss.
Without peering through the window, without stepping beyond the door,
One grasps all under Heaven with certainty.

Again,
The sweeping light,
Illuminating life,
A single point of harmonious balance, the essence of the Two and Five.
Nature is principle, destiny is feeling,
The wondrous function of intermingling qi coalesces at once.
When deluded, seeking it leads to error at every turn,
Once awakened, grasping it makes every place divine.
Death follows death, life follows life,
Cultivation depends on planting, ruin on collapse.

Again,
The sweeping light,
Illuminating the numinous,
Morning roams, evening rests in the Pavilion of Exquisite Clarity.
Awake, one is at peace; asleep, one is at peace,
When spring arrives, no place is not verdant.
To attain wisdom, one need not listen to the zither,
To brighten the eyes, one must read the wordless scripture.
Neither vague nor obscure,
Ever at peace, ever still, ever vigilant.

Again,
The sweeping light,
Illuminating the One,
One penetrates, one completes, one returns to the One.
The sage is One, the worthy is One,
Heaven and Earth, the myriad things—none are not One.
The hundred cares of the world all converge in One,
The diverse paths of the world all return to the One.
The immortal is One, the ordinary is One,
One resolves all—naturally simple and easy.

Again,
The sweeping light,
Illuminating the heart,
Confucian texts, Buddhist scriptures, immortal classics.
All are superfluous growths, mere excrescences,
Each expounding its own Dao.
To devise diagrams and symbols is a vain effort,
Clever metaphors and roundabout explanations are but idle chatter.
Do not cling to traces, do not adhere to words,
Such is the person who embodies the spirit and illuminates it.

Again,
The sweeping light,
Illuminating clarity—
At the dawn of primordial chaos, where were the written words?
The Qin burned books, the Han annotated scriptures,
Annotations perished, burned books endured.
Transmission from heart to mouth, instruction through texts,
All stir up trouble where none need exist.
No robe, no bowl, no sword, no zither,
Only then is one a person unstained by even a speck of dust.

Again,
The sweeping light,
Illuminating immortals—
Know now that "penetration" is but a forced term.
