All day we sit facing each other behind lowered blinds,
Silent, colorless, speaking of karmic causes in the capital.

**The Radiant Terrace Study**
Tonight, all disciples gather in one hall,
The Daoist writes "Radiant Terrace" himself.
Not only do the disciples discuss wonders—
Even I boast of the brush’s divine inspiration.
Sea winds and sky breezes follow my elbow,
As I wield the brush, unaware of dragons and serpents dancing.
Shaking the Five Peaks, soaring over the blue isles,
The assembly joyfully claps and laughs.
Laughing, clapping hands—the calligraphy endures, the terrace never decays.

**The Immortals’ Joy in the Empty-Void Rhythm**
In the Azure Grotto, the Daoist’s home,
Tranquil, pure, far from the world’s clamor.
Waterfalls cascade like cinnabar cliff rain,
White lotuses idly planted in mountain ponds.
Wine in hand, the clear day passes among the woods,
On stone, the zither embraces the fading glow.
This is the perfect place for cultivating the true—
Why seek elixirs from sea or sacred peaks?

**Appendix: Original Poem**
On Penglai Isle, the ancient immortals’ abode,
Cultivating longevity, far from the world’s clamor.
Iron trees ever perch with thousand-year cranes,
Jade peaks smile as four-season flowers are plucked.
The sleeping dragon awakens to wander green cliffs,
The fierce tiger is ridden to reach crimson clouds.
A wisp of white cloud seals the cave,
A furnace of pure fire nurtures cinnabar.

**Old Immortal’s Portrait**
Eight hundred, three thousand—long since victorious,
Now the good fruit grows even more abundant.
Marvelous traces appear again and again,
With bamboo staff and palm-bark sandals, wandering everywhere.
Thousand-year elders all become old friends,
The ten-thousand-year calendar records long life.
In recent years, mingling in the mortal world,
I’ve learned to change my name like Fu Qiu.

**Appendix: Lüzu’s Response**
Long following the sun and moon, discerning emptiness and gain,
Yet to ascend the Jade Capital on cloud and mist.
The Five Elders should add a sixth to their seat,
The Eight Lords often see off the Ninth on his journey.
Among mountains, I often meet Red Pine,
In the world, I’m mistaken for White Stone Sage.
Past and present affairs all seen through—
The Ten Isles and Three Mountains are fully known.

**Appendix: Hanxu’s Response**
Last night, the flute-playing girl surnamed Ying
Yielded to the young man ascending the Celestial Capital.
Who in the world’s dust would know of my presence?
Alone, I soar through moonlit skies.
Early on, I learned to scatter like the world’s carefree,
Once studying under the ancient master of Gandhara.
Each meal of lingzhi and fuling suffices,
Roaming seas and peaks, I’ve earned a name for longevity.

**Appendix: Zangya’s Response**
Once following Laozi to flee Qin’s Ying,
A hundred generations’ years cannot compare.
Ancient temples, long beards flowing,
Through Three Mountains and Five Peaks, singing as I go.
I once refined the great elixir, inexhaustibly,
Again witnessing Fusang wither and revive.
A smile at Penglai’s shallow waters—
I’ve forgotten my surname and given name.

**Appendix: Panshan’s Response**
After consuming the divine elixir, qi flourishes,
Clouds and waters roam freely through the four capitals.
Flowing with heaven and earth, truly carefree,
Roaring across seas and mountains, wandering alone.
The old crane nurtures a doubly pregnant embryo,
Having eaten the peach of immortality, its fruit reblooms.
My simurgh-drawn carriage briefly visits Pengzu’s tomb—
I laugh at his breath exercises, vainly seeking fame.

**Old Recluse’s Portrait**
First entering Peach Blossom Spring to escape chaos,
Not following false recluses to pay court in the divine capital.
Moving my home to emerald peaks, my heart grows stiller,
Speaking of red dust, my feet grow weary of walking.
Embracing the urn, the old man calls me a dear friend,
Like Jieyu the madman, I bow to the master.
Children and grandchildren each tame simurghs and cranes,
Forgetting the world’s profit and fame.

**Appendix: Lüzu’s Response**
Transformed into simurghs and cranes, qi flourishing,
In recent years, nearing a hundred capitals in lifespan.
In grottoes, mist and clouds roar defiantly,
Among mountains, sun and moon flow naturally.
Planting melons unlike Donglingzi,
Escaping the world before Beiguo Sheng.
Peach blossoms by the stream separate from the mortal realm—
I’ve never heard of current affairs or names.

**Appendix: Hanxu’s Response**
Who knew Xiang Yu’s defeat would bring seclusion?
Together forgetting Liu Pi and the Han’s Western Capital.
Ten acres of lingzhi fields call forth dragon breeds,
A staff of goosefoot follows the deer’s path.
In ancient grottoes, the heart is empty, ever content,
After many years, fallen teeth regrow.
Wandering between green streams and white stones,
Always concealing or evading names.

**Appendix: Zangya’s Response**
Hand-planted green pines have grown tall,
Carefree, untroubled, avoiding the capital’s bustle.
With open heart, like the Ji and Ying rivers, embracing heaven and earth,
Accompanying Chaoyou, settling where I go.
Autumn gardens, spring fields, roaming ancient times,
Fishing mountains, woodcutting waters, passing a lifetime.
Uninvolved in the slightest worldly dust,
I simply take namelessness as my name.

**Appendix: Panshan’s Response**
Not learning the official recluse’s ways like Hou Ying,
Riding an ox, singing loudly, surpassing the capital’s splendor.
Among troops of apes and birds, I’ve transformed,
In depths of cloud and mist, I fly alone.
Plum blossoms for wife, cranes for children—my immortal kin,
Green temples, gray beard—my hair ever grows.
No wonder the old man’s lofty aspirations—
The pure wind long disdains glory and fame.

**South Peak**
Wandering mountains as I please, I love the mountains,
Within and beyond the mountains, returning with the clouds.
In green straw cloak and bamboo hat, walking the peak’s summit,
On the fifth night, the crescent moon just curved.

**Chaoyang Palace**
Cricket chirps clamor in the Buddha hall,
Most desolate places feel not desolate.
Idly chanting beyond the twelve balustrades,
Moonlight hazily reaches the upper realm.

**Night Gathering at the Mountain Study**
Cool winds gently blow beyond the woods,
A slender moon hangs on bamboo tips.
Tonight in the flower hall, sharing wine,
Discussing the Dao, clapping hands—all immortals.

**Wu Peak’s Summit**
The great river encircles the walled city,
Clearing skies, bright tiles open the tiled roofs.
Beyond, merchant sails drift with the clouds,
Within, the monastery nestles among bamboo.
Strange peaks rise straight, waves mighty,
Fresh air soars, mist and haze recede.
This place truly becomes a realm beyond the world—
Carrying wine, treading leaves, ascending the high terrace.

**Visiting Qingyi Mountain**
Newly clear, the mountain’s hues are fine,
Taking this chance to visit Qingyi.
The traveler adjusts cloud-piercing clogs,
Village taverns flutter wine-selling flags.
Carrying wine, treading the high summit,
Sweeping stone, discussing the Dao’s mysteries.
What place compares to this?
Nanjing’s Swallow Rock.

**Visiting Dizhu Mountain**
The path winds through groves of strange bamboo,
People walk atop the high peak’s summit.
Briefly sweeping moss flowers to sit and talk,
In osmanthus groves, the noon bell rings clear.
Beyond the pines, a hundred birds’ songs are heard,
Exploring the secluded, hand in hand, ascending the high ridge.

Here follows the translation:

---

Casually borrowing a line from the Cassia Palace,
A mountain breeze carries my quiet recitation.
On the Flower Festival, a hundred flowers fragrant,
Visiting the sublime, I carry wine to the heights above.

I love the wondrous seclusion of Wu You,
Where mist and rosy clouds embrace the ancient Wenchang.
Entering the emerald haze, then emerging from it,
In Wu You Mountain, white clouds drift.
Pine groves and bamboo isles entwine,
A long whistle—returning beyond the heavens.

**At Bamboo-Embraced Study, Listening to Disciple Yang Panshan Read *Cloud and Water Anthology***
Young Yang, tall and lean of form,
Loved my poems of cloud and water from years past.
In bamboo courtyard on a clear wind, moonlit night,
I hear him scratch his head, chanting slowly.

**At Listening-to-Tides Pavilion, Seeing Li Xilai Off to Langzhong**
Come back, then go again,
Go, but return soon.
Wine shared with one departing,
The pavilion opened for farewell.
Tide sounds drive distant shores,
Moonlight chills the empty cup.
Urging the guest, we set another feast,
Lingering by the pond together.

**Inscription for Bamboo-Embraced Study**
A winding path leads to seclusion far from worldly clamor,
The empty study leans half-hidden in a deep village.
Tower bells drift from beyond the clouds,
Balustrades encircle stone roots.
A thousand tall bamboos house avian friends,
A small pond nurtures fish progeny.
Most delightful after rain, gazing through the window—
Countless green mountains reach the temple gate.

**Ode to Flowers and Wine**
Flowers blooming bring joy, their fall sorrow,
Do not let cups of wine before them go unfilled.
Drinking wine while wearing flowers—spirit soars,
With flowers and wine, depart and return again.

**Inscription for Moon-Reflecting and Sun-Containing Pools**
Red railings mirror the Poet Immortal’s abode,
Deep blue waters cradle the Buddha’s dwelling.
Best to view beneath crape myrtle blossoms—
Branch by branch, tree shadows stand among the pond’s fish.

**Heavenly Gate Invitation (Two Poems)**
Stepping steadily through Heaven’s Gate, eyes smiling wide,
Palaces of gold, terraces of jade.
Mortals, do not gaze for the immortal chariot’s call—
Only those who mount the cloud ladder may ascend.

Where does the cloud ladder lead?
The cloud ladder lies within yourself.
If you know the wonders of refining qi and returning the elixir,
You may rise from the earth to the azure sky.

**At Poet Immortal’s Temple, Honoring Li Bai and Su Dongpo**
I often burn incense and bow to the poems of these two masters,
Their literary brilliance and grace guide later generations.
If their spirits across the ages could meet,
Together we would ride the moon to Mount Emei.

**On the Lantern Festival, Visiting Yang Zi’s Newly Built Panshan Thatched Cottage**
I am the Old Man of Three Peaks,
My gate framed by a mountain shaped like the character "one."
Tonight I come to your dwelling,
The scenery deeply resonant.
Spring’s breath arrives at the new house,
Woods and ponds enter the small bay.
The Yang family’s pure and noble estate,
Truly transcends the dusty world.

**Xuanran Terrace**
On Xuanran Terrace, the guest
Sits in stillness, far from worldly dust.
Tree shadows float on cinnabar cliffs,
Bell sounds strike the white clouds.
Three peaks of Emei stand in the void,
Nine summits divide in the distance.
Best is the Yangtze at nightfall,
Autumn tides heard in quiet.

**River Pavilion**
With spirit roaming seas and mountains,
A long whistle crosses river peaks.
Autumn’s breath fills the pavilion,
High windows sealed by clouds.
The world cannot be without bamboo—
Here, a realm apart unfolds.
Within the hut, sun and moon are stored,
Beyond the cliffs, forests and springs embrace.
Poetry and wine delight through the ages,
Heaven and earth entrusted to the seven-stringed zither.
Most cherished in fine scenery—
Lamp and moon illuminate the gate.

Wine abounds, poetry grows wilder,
Mountains still, the room grows clearer.
What night is this tonight?
Brush and Dao converse in feeling.
A thousand ancient characters on the desk,
A single lamp beyond the eaves.
Gaze afar at the village,
The host’s refined taste arises.

**Inscription for *The Eastern Transmission of the Dao and Its Virtue, with Orthodox Commentary***
Huiweng’s preface sets the definitive critique,
His introduction opens the Eight Virtues’ gate.
Again we see purple qi come from Guanzhong,
Truly behold the Mystic Descendant beneath Li’s tree.
Desiring to guide later generations to shared transcendence,
He makes the primordial Dao ever more revered.
How many commentators praise this edition—
A treasure case long guarded to stabilize Kunlun.

**Self-Immolation Verse Beneath a Painting**
Heavenly immortals do not cling to old forms,
How can a single brushstroke reveal the Dao?
In the radiance of fierce fire, I depart today,
Yang spirit scattered, filling empty space.

**Xuanran Terrace**
At dawn, roosters crow in deep white clouds,
The fifth watch heard in the bronze clepsydra.
Wild geese early pierce distant autumn frontiers,
Seven stars brightly reflect the pure altar.
Heaven and earth laugh boundlessly,
From isles, flying chants bear color and sound.
Best is the mountain tower’s jade flute,
Early autumn’s slanting moon crossing the river city.

**Matching Changyi’s Rhyme**
Dwelling in mountains, cease talk of soft red affairs,
Beyond the gate, the Brocade-Washing River flows long.
---

**Planting Life-Extending Herbs**
Everywhere roots are planted for life-extending herbs,
At every moment, a stake is driven to steady the heart.
I arrive at the ornate pavilion where wind stirs the seat,
As others chant the *Huangting* sutra, sunlight fills the window.
Most beloved is late autumn’s tender affection,
Where feathered immortals join in singing the feathered immortals’ tune.

**Most Desolate**
Alas! Worldly mortals never resolve their dust-bound passions,
Never dreaming of the carefree freedom beyond the world.
At home, they’ve lost their priceless treasure—
With what will they buy passage to the Three Isles?
Vainly aging, vainly aging!

**Matching Master Lü Chunyang’s Original Rhyme**
Harmonious sounds often played on the flute,
Refining qi never apart from the zither.
A message to the Perfect Yang Master:
You must know the great Dao’s sentiment.
Heaven opens with a solitary moon shining,
Clouds rise as ten thousand mountains sink.
On a distant isle, a leisurely recluse—
Why trouble to seek the great forest?

**Linked Verses with Immortals at Shuangqing Pavilion (Limited to Fifteen Rhymes in *Xian*)**
A modest feast set on Penglai Mountain,
Cool night enters the jade-green cliff.
Heaven and earth are the wanderer’s path,
Sky and land the scattered one’s domain.
A great cry from the crane in the clouds,
A distant call to the sail upon the sea.
Sala trees on the Three Isles,
Immortal geese seal autumn’s letters.
Straw hat bearing Yingzhou’s rain,
Mist-clad fire-washed robes.
Wind and flute play in rustling harmony,
Dragon chariots emerge from jagged peaks.
Folding notes to invite the bright moon,
Inscribing poems on vermilion scrolls.
Jade nectar arrayed in painted pavilions,
Treasure staffs leaning against star-lit pines.
This place is originally free of dust,
All transcendents wholly apart from the mortal realm.
Rainbow robes sing in the upper realms,
Magic herbs gathered on sacred cliffs.
Laughing words of the vicissitudes of time,
Spread out like stone tripods’ chime.
Raising my head to the empty azure,
Joining the rhyme in response to *Shao* and *Xian*.

**Cloud Pavilion: Winter Journey from Penglai to Shu**
With a soaring cry, I depart east of the sea gate,
Leaving Penglai once more to arrive here.
My belly brims with primordial essence, luminous and steadfast,
From the outset, wondrous hands move through emptiness.
Ten thousand lines of grass-script characters fall from twin brushes,
A thousand peaks of mist and glow blaze red along the way.
Behold the layered beauty of Shu’s mountains—
Most pitiful are the maple leaves fading from frost.

**Hearing Master Hanxu Play the Zither as Autumn Rain Clears and Geese Cross the Frontier**
After rain, the mountains are still, listening to the zither’s silk,
Silver lamps of sacred incense illuminate the pavilion.
Longing to merge with the Great Void,
Straightaway reducing all existence to emptiness.
The river’s distant sound answers the moon trembling on water,
Mist’s first settling as wind enters the pines.
Most beloved is the pure heart transmitted through fingertips—
No need to raise one’s gaze to send off the flying geese.

**Sharing a Verse with a Lay Practitioner**
Wind carries the rapids’ roar to the pavilion,
Clouds bring rain’s breath into the mountains.
On the western cliff, the sound of axes felling wood,
By the northern stream, the striking of poles to cast fishing lines.
I mingle my traces with fishermen and woodcutters—
Who knows the mountain and water conceal an immortal elder?
Laughing, I share this verse with the lay practitioner,
Beyond the world, a path may yet be found.

**Linked Verses**
Together in this fine wind and sunlight, Han Qingfu,
All transcendents join in song, Bai Ziqing.
A long chant through the empty world, Qiu Changchun,
A single laugh crosses the river tower, Sanfeng.
Qi merges with heaven and earth, Qingfu,
Heart one with the moon on water, Ziqing.
How many affairs through the ages, Changchun—
Forgotten in the grotto-heaven’s autumn, Sanfeng.

**Pure Chant**
Pure tea, pure fragrance, pure Dao-heart,
Pure fast, pure night, plucking the pure zither.
If one can avoid the turbid to speak of purity and stillness,
They leap into the cloudy mountains, nowhere to be found.

**Early Spring Outing with Li Changyi to Pan Mountain for a Small Feast**
The east wind is like a great elixir,
Reviving withered roots at its arrival.
Pathside grasses sprout thickly together,
Everywhere in gardens and groves.
Rapeseed flowers yellow as millet,
Village waters clearer than wiped glass.
Together we love the southern stream’s banks—
Green mountains’ qi and appearance are splendid.

**For Li Yuanyang**
Since relinquishing the seal and returning home,
If you again covet the mortal realm’s descent,
Simply nurture your nature’s celestial dawn and dusk,
Never let spirits and gods know your heart’s ground.
Heaven and earth vast, the zither’s three refrains,
Qi’s breath harmonized, a single flute’s branch.
To cultivate transcendence within yin and yang,
You must cultivate beyond yin and yang.

**Double Ninth Day: Outing to Mount Emei with Master Hui, Lan Yangsu, and Bai Yuchan**
After rain, we soar to great Emei,
Gazing down at the dusty world’s miasmic mists.
All transcendents gather in refined assembly,
Ten thousand miles of empty clarity, each singing freely.
Cranes cry into clouds, harmonizing with Lan’s clappers,
Phoenixes call through the heavens, Bai’s chariot passing.
Only old Lü remains without verse or melody—
Laughing, he cleaves the cliff with his sword.

**The Day After Double Ninth**
Misty villages, river trees, a vast scene,
Painting’s intent, poetry’s sentiment, stirring long interest.
A message to the mountain altar’s disciples:
No harm in enjoying the rain to make up for Double Ninth.

**Two Poems Inviting Disciples to Tour Qingcheng’s Grotto-Heaven**
Seeking the immortal’s abode to trace immortal footsteps,
We ascend Min Mountain’s first peak.
Tenth month’s minor yang, spring’s qi so fine,
In the grotto-heaven’s depths, we speak at leisure.

The immortal’s abode remains, unfolding jade-green windows,
Qingcheng’s subtle discourse—scenery unmatched.
A single clear chime from the cloud gate at dawn,
The mountain moon lingers by the pavilion, not yet crossing the river.

**Laojun Mountain in Xinjin**
Hand beckoning immortals to ascend the clouds,
Zhangzi comes to play the jade flute.
Who can recognize the Supreme Clarity’s wondrous realm?
Only within the heart’s vast emptiness.
*Ha-ha!* Hand in hand, carefree;
*He-he!* Striding the heavenly bridge together.
Two gourds brimming with fine wine,
All drunk, we visit Master Song and Qiao.

**Palace of Longevity**
Where emerald trees pierce the sky,
Clouds journey to this palace.

Beyond the yellow leaves on the winding path,
Mountains lie within the crimson walls of Chicheng.
A secluded courtyard hosts the returning elder,
Whose lingering radiance recalls Master Fan.
Come dawn, we’ll scale the loftiest peak,
Where vast qi rides the boundless sky.

**Pavilion Where Cranes Nest for Drinking**
The immortals’ modest feast atop the highest summit,
Precisely at the heart of Qingcheng’s emerald point.
Countless white clouds encircle the few seats,
Towering screens of sky-piercing peaks array east and west.

**Wooden Bridge at the Heavenly Master’s Grotto**
A wooden bridge spans the azure-clouded stream,
Where flowing waters murmur beneath low-hung green shadows.
Best where the two cliffs converge,
To hear the transcendent birds call across the forest.

**Linked Verses on Qingcheng Mountain**
Wu and the Daoist delight in long recitations of Lü Dongbin,
Soaring beyond the heavens, their steps tread jade-green peaks.
The mountain rejoices as the dragon reveals its grand visage—Liu Haichan,
Immortals pause their cranes to speak of shared hearts—Bai Ziqing.

Three terraces rise faintly through the mist—Zhongshan,
Nine chambers ascend layer upon layer into the deepening haze—Feng.
Still I recall the year I left the world’s net—Haichan,
Lightly treading the cloud-path, chanting beneath the pine’s shade—Ziqing.

**White Cloud and Green Cloud Streams**
Clouds drift on gentle winds,
Mountains hush as waters ripple.
Endless cool clarity,
All arises between spring and stone.

The Daoist blows his iron flute,
The old monk shuts his wicker gate.
Freely wandering east and west ravines,
Perfected beings come and go together.

**Crane-Crying Mountain**
When the Daoist arrives, the stone crane cries,
His spirit soars to the Heavenly Valley, where long life is inscribed.
Now the two streams murmur ceaselessly,
Aiding my dragon’s chant and tiger’s roar.

**Heavenly Valley Grotto**
The Heavenly Valley is where long life abides,
Its stone apertures resound with endless song.
To lodge the spirit, this is the place,
Where one sits and refines the great elixir to completion.

**To the Master of Changyi Mountain Dwelling**
Autumn rains for nights on end dispel the summer’s heat,
The fine eve of the Ghost Festival defies the painter’s art.
Stream winds and ridge moons—friends of immortals,
Beneath bean trellises and melon arbors lies the recluse’s hut.

Our company follows the old master’s teachings,
The mountain dweller can annotate Confucian classics.
Burning incense, we read the *Yi* and discourse on profound principles,
For Dao and Confucianism share a single source at heaven and earth’s dawn.

**Late Autumn at Yueyun Tower**
On the autumn river’s tower, gazing at autumn lamps,
Each autumn lamp glows bright upon the waters.
I have chanted my way here from the two lakes,
The vast sky’s expanse still echoes with lingering sound.

**Playfully Summoning Yuanyang from the Ethereal Mountain**
The Daoist hides himself in the misty peaks,
Where grotto winds whisper and waters ripple.
The white dragon slumbers in the cold jade pool,
The yellow crane returns at dusk to the pine’s tranquil summit.

Fingering auspicious blossoms by the stone table,
Shouldering an iron staff, he strides the heavenly pass.
You two, come early to visit,
Amid thirty-six peaks and twenty-four bends.

**Visiting Chaoyang Temple**
I come from the sea and mountains,
Bearing sea-clouds with me.
Fluttering my sleeves, I release the clouds to fly,
As they depart, they seal the mountain temple.

**Roaming Mount Luofu**
Playfully riding Luofu’s great butterfly,
My spirit wanders vividly through silent peaks.
Suddenly revealing my true form,
Once more a straw cloak and bamboo hat.

On Jade Toad Peak I linger,
Gazing afar as Haiqiong flies toward me.
The two of us clap hands and let out long cries,
How towering and rugged the green cliffs!

Green-haired immortal, yellow rustic,
Many transcendent beings hide and appear in these mountains.
Why not be the host here?
Sweep the stones, set out cups, and drink several rounds.

Sea winds gust from beyond the heavens,
Blowing forth Luofu’s wondrous realm.
How joyous! Truly joyous!
Hand in hand with Ziqing, we return to Penglai.

**After the Rain, Gazing at Mount Emei’s Slopes—Composed in the Immortal’s Style**
Emei’s emerald brush sweeps the rain-cleared sky,
My distant chanting spirit infuses each word with transcendence.
Gathering the mist’s glow into my brush,
Unleashing my bold qi before the tower.

Who can grasp the painting within the poem?
In stillness, free from sorrow, is the truest grace.
Enamored of these misty peaks spreading across half the sky,
My secluded inspiration fills the mountains and rivers.

**Ascending Wawu Mountain**
A great ridge looms high and distant, pressing upon Emei and Min,
At its summit, clouds part to reveal a fresh vista.
Ten thousand trees roar with tiger-like winds,
All peaks, after rain, emerge as dragon spirits.

Pizhi Cliff holds snow of a thousand autumns,
Maitreya’s Grotto knows not a speck of dust.
The earth’s rivers and mountains lie beneath my feet,
This western realm surpasses all others.

**Appended: Linked Verses on Pan Mountain**
Wawu Mountain’s height levels a single beam,
Where immortals fly into the city of transformed beings.
A fine radiance shines forth, cloud-light whitened,
A crisp qi gathers, stone-breath purified.

Ten thousand ravines’ pines and firs exhale distant echoes,
A thousand cliffs’ rain and dew fill the new clarity.
Ribbon after ribbon of silk cascades from the sky,
Pouring the Silver River with a resounding rush.

**Rising Yangtze**
Northwest rains, southeast clears,
The clear river suddenly swells with surging waves.
Children along the banks clap their hands in unison,
Mountains charge, waters stand—thunder roars.

With a sudden crash, rapids part the rocks,
Like horses, like oxen, their hooves race free.
An immortal descends from the void,
Only to see the river’s heart churn with flying snow-like waves.

Transformed into a drifting raft, it sways and drifts,
Following wind and wave to Penglai’s isles.

**Early Autumn Mountain Dwelling**
Plantains, rain-washed, gleam with natural verdure,
Lotus blossoms, wind-tossed, offer effortless cool.
Just right for discussing Chan by the waterside pavilion,
Where osmanthus fragrance lingers within.

**Viewing Fupeng Mountain in the Rain**
Middle Emei refuses to reveal her long brows,
Just as slanting winds and fine rains begin.
Fishermen before my eyes merge into a painting,
Ink-dark clouds overhead urgently summon verse.

The mountain, like an upturned canopy, is no small sight,
Peaks, in retreat, appear all the more wondrous.
Laughing at my straw cloak and bamboo hat,
I stand opposite you, both of us lost in mist.

**Birthday of Lord Zhang Huan of Han**
In Tang, he left his surname in Suiyang; in Song, his name as Martial Ancestor,
His ever-circling heroic qi props up the ages.
Slaying bandits with thunderous might, his troops were invincible,
His strategies pure as ice and snow, his wisdom unclouded.

At Dangyang, his battle cry struck Cao pale,
His inscribed war drum echoed the Han’s valor.
A general of both martial and civil prowess,
Drunk in Chengdu, he worshipped beneath his banner.

**Six-Character Lines on the Scene**
Sparse rain drips from parasol leaves,
Autumn winds turn willows pale yellow.
Chanting as I walk by smartweed blooms by the pool,
I see a painted scroll of watery homeland.

**Long Rain**
Wind and rain darken the new autumn,
An immortal clad in imperial qi treads the waters.
Temple bells beyond the clouds grow damp,
Sails on the river and sky fade into the mist.

Early on the jade altar, the moon departs from the Pleiades,
A jade flute’s long chant fills the wind-swept tower.

Seeking to summon the white dragon back to its cave,
Heaven’s heart and human affairs both stretch into the distant.

**The Night After Lantern Festival, Gathering with Disciples at Listening-to-the-Wind Pavilion**
Wind through bamboo, a rustling tune fills the tower,
Master and disciples converse deep into the night among the groves.
The Lantern Festival has passed—why dwell on it?
Do not let time slip away like flowing water.

**Two Quatrains for a Recluse**
Long have I known Tuanyang as a star of seclusion,
Beneath Mount Emei, nurturing the true spirit.
Leisurely inviting rustic scholars to speak of elixir arts,
Through the night’s cold mist, the door remains unlatched.

White clouds drift over deep paddy fields,
The song of rice-planters fades into emerald peaks.
Last night, the cuckoo’s cry never ceased;
This morning, a fine rain taps at the thatched eaves.

**Inscribed at Wang Sheng’s Residence, Ziping’s Abode**
Half a room’s mountain hues reflect the eaves,
Green bamboo casts deep shade upon the green gauze.
Here the old man’s joy runs deep—
A Peach Blossom Spring where ancients once dwelled.

**Two Quatrains on an Outing to Dragon Gorge with Disciples**
Within Dragon Gorge’s mouth, green mountains rise,
Bay after bay, one curve after another.
Come the clear, bright winds of Pure Brightness,
I’ll don cloud-clogs again to seek the heights.

Just as the mountain bell tolls the evening sky,
Disciples, please ascend the rush-woven mats.
I shall transform into a cloud immortal,
Roaming the pavilion, whistling through the dusk mist.

**Returning to Xuanran Terrace**
Tonight, my spirit descends from the Great Purity,
Heavenly winds carry the sound of jade flutes.
The cloud thoroughfares unfold, the Three Heavens still,
Snow and moon intertwine, illuminating ten thousand miles.

Await my descent, riding a crane with my whole being,
I leave you this word to await the cock’s crow.
On Green Robe Isle, beside the Clear Ripple Temple,
Pavilions rise in tiers, like a jade-green city.

**Late Spring**
Today, the weather is fine,
Spring winds stir the green willows.
Water follows the traveler’s path,
Flowers waft their fragrance across the stream.

Butterflies flutter among the grasses,
Mayflies dance over the wall.
I observe all these creations,
And turn my head, sighing at the vicissitudes.

**Lyrics of the Clear Stream Commandery**
Spring has departed for so long—
When the cuckoo cries at dawn, one must rise at the fifth watch.
Even birds are diligent;
Who among those on meditation mats can dispel this?
To make the spirit lively, the heart must first die—
The man of dead heart is the very seed of immortals.

**Scene Before Us, Shown to Disciples**
True friends have always been few,
Yet after rain, the mountains are abundant.
Clouds emerge, speck by speck, from the horizon,
Majestic peaks traverse the ridges.

Forests and springs, wind and sun at rest,
Wild temples, water and mist in harmony.
All things in the pond are alike—
Red lotuses mirror the green waves.

**Dispelling Summer Heat**
To dispel summer heat, ascend the ancient Buddha’s tower,
Where all mountains and rivers gather before your seat.
River winds fill your sleeves, cloud waves roar,
A single laugh, a long chant—vast qi flows.

**Two Poems on Xuanran Terrace at Summer’s End**
Roaring rapids reach the temple gate,
Ascending the tower, leaning on the pavilion, the four mountains darken.
Only a single red lamp remains,
Laughing with immortals, we raise our wine cups.

Wind and rain patter into the painted pavilion,
The mountain temple’s coolness nears autumn.
Across the river, wild trees entwine with cloud and mist,
As if gathered by Ni Zan’s brush.

**Early Autumn**
The Dipper’s handle spans the Milky Way,
Early autumn gradually points west.
Phoenix-tree winds suddenly rise,
Blowing the moon past the bridge’s embankment.

**Autumn Night Rain, Shown to Tuanyang and Ziping**
Speaking of discussing the Dao, years are not counted,
Carefree beyond the world, like the immortals of old.
Sweep away every speck of dust, root by root, until pure—
Only then may one attain our family’s highest Chan.

Autumn’s hues arrive from ten thousand miles west,
Phoenix-tree rain falls upon the green moss.
Smiling, I take up a few lines to inscribe on the mountain stone,
Reciting them with a graceful air, facing the wine cup.

**Autumn Night in a High Tower**
In the quiet of night, atop the high tower,
The autumn river reveals distant lamps.
Fisherfolk laugh and converse,
Sitting side by side, mending silk nets.

**Autumn Rain**
Rain from the leaking sky scatters,
On level ground, water and clouds arise.
Vast and dim, the three autumns darken,
A lone traveler in a straw cape wanders.

Who has seen the flying immortal’s shadow?
The incoming geese have not yet been heard.
I would ride a swan and depart,
Where misty isles meet the sea’s clarity.

**Hearing Geese on an Autumn Night**
Rain patters until the third watch,
The wild temple’s bell rings, exceptionally clear.
Just as the geese’s formation crosses the autumn frontier,
Wind and snow stretch across ten thousand miles of passes.

Where is the land of rice and millet?
I laugh as the wild geese fly south.
The vast azure vault of the night sky—
Immortals ride you to the Xiao and Xiang.

**Autumn Clear Skies, Shown to Tuanyang and Ziping**
August Heaven bestows good rain,
Ponds and embankments swell with autumn water.
Birds rejoice in the leftover red grain,
The immortal’s chariot soars on white clouds.

Each thing and self at ease,
Heaven and Earth follow their own return.
Roaming in spirit, I play with creation,
Qi gathers, knocking at the Chan gate.

Refined inspiration links the cinnabar peaks,
Lofty chants stir the emerald ridges.
New poems composed wherever I tread,
I scrape the wall to write on the mossy cloak.

**Ascending Xuanran Terrace on the Ninth Day**
Last year on this day, we gathered at the mountain pavilion,
Heaven specially granted clear skies for the Double Ninth.
This year, as before, follows this pattern—
The Daoist rings the noon bell, its clarity unbroken.

**Cold Dew**
On this day, Cold Dew arrives,
Deep in the night, white dew turns cold.
Cool autumn comes beyond the frontier,
Yellow leaves fall at the forest’s edge.

Distant peaks yield lamplight,
High clouds swirl with the geese’s calls.
Laughing, I blow my long flute and depart,
Leaning on the railing of the tower.

**Autumn Night at the Tower of Ten Thousand Views**
At will, I ascend to this place,
Heavenly winds, vast and surging, shake the tower.
Wielding my brush, I sweep away mist and rosy clouds,
Across the river, a fisherman’s lamp emerges from the water’s bend.

**Autumn Day at Dongpo Tower**
Seven-star flowers bloom before the tower,
Withering at dusk, opening at dawn—most pitiable.
Yet they possess a frost-defying heart,
Thus enhancing autumn’s beauty even more.

**Plum in a Vase**
In the cold, jade buds just contain their fragrance,
Cultivated in snow, their season endures.
Do not place them in a bronze vase for display—
Only then can their fragrance fill the courtyard.

**Evening Scene**
River clouds faintly outline the sandbar,
Again, the temple bell rings from the tower.
I long to ride the wind with a long whistle,
As flocks of crows caw, separated by mist.

**Facing the Scene**
Beyond the tower, the great river flows,
Green mountains open across the shore.
Peak after peak of clouds cannot obscure them—
I myself return from the sea’s summit.

**Autumn Day, Gathering with Disciples at Xuanran Terrace for Wine and Song**
Clapping hands, whistling in the wind,
Clear songs fill the hall.
Water’s light floats the railing white,
Mountain qi enters the tower green.

Raising wine, we discuss profound principles,
Before the window, we chant Daoist scriptures.

**The Heavens Should Laugh Heartily**
The master and disciples forget all formality—
Each lets go in joyful abandon.

**Autumn Night, Reassembling with Disciples at Xuanran Terrace**
Fine rain beyond the gauze window,
The chirring of insects—too poignant to bear.
Clouds seal a thousand trees in darkness,
The night still, a single lamp glows green.

Who can utter forbidden lines?
None before us have ever tried.
I pluck a banana leaf to write,
Grass-script forming dragon shapes.

Such joy is rare this year—
Tonight, let us not squander it.
Listening to wind, listening to rain,
Discussing the Dao, discussing poetry.

Each sings *"The Rootless Tree"*—
No need to boast of rhyme-bound verse.
Unfettered by rules of law,
We chant in carefree delight.

**Moonlit Rivers and Mountains**
Rivers and mountains in the moon—sought within a painting,
Leaning on the pavilion, opening the window to gather far and near.
Peaks press into the clouds, deepening into night,
Bamboo tips brushed by dew, autumn’s weight congealing.

Insects chirr-chirr on mossy steps,
Lamp’s glow flickers upon treetops.
Gazing afar, banyan shade cradles evening mist,
Vague, misty trees veil the high tower.

**Autumn Evening**
The Milky Way faint in the night,
Autumn wind stirs the osmanthus grove.
Cool clouds linger at dawn along three paths,
Cold dew invades the tower.

Bamboo shadows stir lofty thoughts,
Mountain dwelling deepens the Dao’s intent.
Of late, no other words—
Worldly distractions no longer trouble the heart.

**Lamentable**
Lamentable—people of the world do not study immortality,
Fearing illness’s clinging through all four seasons.
How could they know a single qi is matchless?
When qi fills the body, life may be prolonged.

**Laughing Heartily**
Laughing heartily, singing loudly,
Dancing drunkenly through mist and waves,
Donning a fisher’s straw cloak, roaming rocky slopes,
At day’s end, the rivers and mountains brim with joy.

I pass beyond the slanting sun’s village—
Who knows I dance drunk in bliss?

**With Disciples, Awaiting Rain**
Today, great rain sweeps the southeast,
Locust wind and plum rain deeply stir the heart.
Heaven does not explain clearly—
Within this, yin and yang form a single qi.

**Hall of Bamboo Love**
White rain, pure wind,
Washed clean from the Peng Palace.
Jade blossoms cover the ground, fragrance drifting,
Wafting onto the bamboo screen.

In this triple-heat season,
The mortal world drowns in vexing heat.
How unlike our immortal realm’s bliss—
A tumbleweed flying over the sea.

**Delighted by Guangyu’s Arrival at Yueyun Tower**
Bound by fate, a thousand miles bring us together,
Unburdened, one body roams afar.
I love Layman Li of Langzhou—
He drifts here to Yueyun Tower.

**Joy, Joy, Joy**
Speak, speak, speak—joy, joy, joy!
The wind stills, the moon not yet risen,
The shoals gleam clear, autumn’s air solemn.
I have a Dao of feeling,
To speak of it in depths and shallows.

If one can shed all worldly vulgarity,
The primordial true qi will often warm the body.
Unafraid of wind and cold,
Unscathed by pestilence,
Years may be prolonged, descendants continued.
All things arise from the spirit—
When the spirit acts, great fortune is gained.

No talismans, no medicine needed,
Simply sweep away all celestial calamities—
Joy, joy, joy!

**Dawn Chant**
Atop Sunrise Peak at dawn,
Suddenly, the mountain temple’s drum hastens the planting.
At Fusang’s summit, the celestial rooster still crows,
A band of red clouds unfurls the dawn’s light.

**Instructing Disciples Zhu and Li**
You two are rare in this ancient age,
Withdrawing far from the city’s clamor.
A settled mind suits few desires,
Cultivating qi shuns excess speech.

Parting from Lang’s waters a thousand miles,
Dwelling once among fine mountains.
From now on, seek your original nature—
Thus escape the world’s snare.

**Inscription for Clan Member Dexuan’s Tomb**
A household of filial piety and brotherly love, the Hall of a Hundred Endurances,
Cultivating ancestral virtue, fragrance flows naturally.
Dexuan rests peacefully beneath Square Mountain,
His estate producing nine fragrant lingzhi.

**Instructing Liu, Bai Jiu, and Li Yuxi**
White wine and fishing rod—guests of the rivers,
Green mountains and Daoist robes—wind of the recluses.
Both of you are laughable,
Youthful yet bearded like old men.

Beyond the world, mist and rosy clouds are ancient,
By the river, the atmosphere is empty.
Early study the principles of purity—
Amid a few wisps of white cloud.

**Seeking the Secluded**
Elegant waters, elegant mountains—seeking elegant scholars,
Fine mountains, fine waters—delighting in fine guests.
By chance hearing a green simurgh’s call beyond the clouds,
One knows a Penglai visitor has arrived at the gate.

**Early Autumn Affairs, in the Style of Master Hui**
After new autumn’s new rain,
The moon rises, tender coolness born.
River’s reflection holds the sky’s azure,
Starlight illuminates vast clarity.

Leaning on the tower, blowing a jade flute,
Riding a crane to cross the Jasper Capital.
Coming and going without fixed abode,
Whistling freely, treading Peng and Ying.

**Seeing Off Langquan and Langshan Returning to Langzhong, Linked Verse with Daoist Bicheng**
Cloud-water wanderers like wild geese, Sanfeng,
In early spring, northward to Bicheng.
A thousand miles of mountains and passes, far—Sanfeng,
A single body of virtue, plump—Bicheng.

Unasking of the pavilion’s length—Sanfeng,
Who knows the world’s right and wrong?—Bicheng!
Drifting, coming and going—Sanfeng,
Willows by the riverbank sway gently—Bicheng.

**Early Mid-Spring, Instructing Disciples**
One year never repeats another,
Years and months like arrows loosed from a bow.
Beneath the flowers, a fine spring feast,
Rouse the poetic spirit to sing in harmony.

**Soaring Chant**
Chanting clearly at Yunmeng’s dawn,
Soaring past Dongting’s spring.
Drifting without fixed abode,
Swinging my arms, entering Emei.

**Haha!**
Who else is as carefree and refined?
—The Returning Daoist.

**Inscription for the Painting *Maiden Xian Listening to Maiden He Play the Sheng***
Treading Peng Island, ascending clouded skies,
Seeking the immortal of Green Mist Cave.
A melody from the jade sheng—how cold its tones!
Since parting, Lang Garden has passed a thousand years.

**Volume Six of the Complete Works of Master Zhang Sanfeng**
*Recompiled by Li Xiyue of Hanjia, the Long Yi Mountain Scholar*
*Respectfully inscribed by Zhang Daoyuan, styled Shen Shi*
*Published by Zhu Daosheng of Langzhong, styled Latecomer*
*Collated by nephew Ying Chuncheng and Zhu Zan, styled Suyuan*
*Son Huang Panxi*

**The Heavenly Mouth Chapter**
The ancients said: *"The sage speaks for Heaven."*
I am no sage—how could I presume to speak in Heaven’s stead?
Yet it is only to uphold the August Supreme Emperor,
Whose hidden virtue aids the people below.
To rouse the deaf and awaken the blind—
This is the radiant intent of His illumination!
To exhort goodness and correct transgressions—
This is the true cause of universal deliverance.
Though my tongue stammers and falters,
I do not shirk my dull roots;
Though the world teems with multitudes,
I beg you to heed my words.
Thus I compose these didactic essays, numbering several,
And name them *The Heavenly Mouth*,
In gratitude for the venerable Biweng’s exalted praise.

**The Orthodox Teaching Chapter**
From ancient times to now, there have been two teachings—no third.
What are these two? The orthodox and the heterodox.
Why no third?
There is only the One, only the Dao.
How then does it divide?
How does it become three?
Since the advent of Kong, Lao, and Muni,
Even unto the present age of Kong, Lao, and Muni,
Though it seems there are Kong, Lao, and Muni,
In truth, there are no Kong, Lao, or Muni.
Kong was fundamentally a Confucian,
Lao fundamentally a Daoist,
Muni fundamentally a Buddhist—
Yet where they diverge, they ultimately do not diverge.
Because they do not diverge,
They must converge.
Thus, they are neither Kong nor Lao,
Neither Lao nor Muni.
Muni, Kong, and Lao—
All are called the Dao.
Kong’s "cutting off the four,"
Lao’s "embracing the One,"
Muni’s "emptying the five"—
All are self-cultivation.
Kong’s "benevolence toward the people,"
Lao’s "aiding the world,"
Muni’s "delivering from suffering"—
All are benefiting others.
Self-cultivation and benefiting others—
Their aim is one.
Those who distinguish Kong, Lao, and Muni
Do so because they see names but not reality,
Or forms but not principles.
To see them as Kong, Lao, and Muni
Is not to see Kong, Lao, and Muni.
Though not Kong, Lao, and Muni,
They remain Kong, Lao, and Muni.
Kong, Lao, and Muni—
All were ancient sages.
The sages’ teachings
Take orthodoxy as their foundation.
Anything not orthodox
Is called a heterodox teaching.
The Yangists and Mohists of the Confucians,
The fangshi of the Daoists,
The demonic monks of the Buddhists—
These too are the three teachings.
Though divided into three,
They are but one heterodoxy.
Thus, those who divide the three teachings are foolish;
Those who distinguish orthodoxy from heterodoxy are wise.

**The Confucian Canon Chapter**
Beyond the Six Classics,
Those whose words may serve as models
Must be sought among Kong’s disciples.
They did not discourse on transcending the world,
Nor expound on esoteric scriptures,
Fearing people would fall into perilous abysses
Without true practice.
Kong and Yan’s aspiration
Was only that people would retire to seek their will
And practice righteousness to attain the Dao.
The Dao lies in aiding others—
Mountains and forests are no different from court and market.
The Dao lies in self-cultivation—
Court and market are unstained by mountains and forests.
Thus, their words brim with profound meaning,
Yet those who grasp them are rare.
The second passage of the *Great Learning*—
This is Kongzi’s self-cultivation.
"For benevolence, employ the four restraints"—
This is Master Yan’s refinement of the self.
Before the work is perfected, one does not leave the humble lane;
Once the work is mature, one does not forget the state.
Thus, they sought action in reclusion,
And attained reclusion in action.
In reclusion, there were Kong and Yan;
In action, there were also Kong and Yan.
Even in neither action nor reclusion,
There were still Kong and Yan.
Spiritual illumination resides within me;
Transformations follow the heart—
This is the true Great Dao.
Kongzi transmitted to Zengzi,
Zengzi to Zisi.
The *Doctrine of the Mean*—
Its Dao is wondrous and luminous.
Those who awaken to the mystery
Steal it away to realize the truth.
Like the sands of the Ganges,
After Zisi, only Mencius is esteemed.
Holding the heart and nurturing qi,
Neither aiding nor forgetting,
Filling heaven and earth,
Utmost in greatness and firmness—
All may be delivered.
Silently drawing it forth,
The subtlety of *haoran* qi—
Its oral transmission is hard to express.
Refuting the heterodox and aiding the orthodox,
Yang and Mo were overthrown.
I wish for scholars and commoners alike:
Seek not the truth on the Three Isles,
But take it from the *Four Books*.
Regard Yan, Zeng, Si, and Meng as enlightened teachers,
Take the roles of subject, minister, disciple, and friend as your practices,
Regard body, heart, nature, and destiny as mercury and lead,
And the refinement of righteousness and benevolence as ascension.
When cultivating the Dao, do not covet its use;
When nurturing the Dao, do not hasten its practice;
When attaining the Dao, you may then manifest it.
If the Dao cannot be manifested,
Drift away and return,
Transmit it to the famous mountains—
Its source and flow will naturally endure.

**The Chan Essence Chapter**
What is meant by "Shi" in "Shijiamouni"?
*"I favor ‘Shi,’ so I use it to open the teaching,
Taking ‘Shi’ to mean severing the ten thousand conditions."*
What is meant by "Buddha"?
The Great Being said:
*"I favor ‘Buddha,’ so I employ it to establish the teaching,
Taking ‘Buddha’ to mean awakening sentient beings."*
Thus have I heard: the Master Shi departed the world;
Thus have I heard: the Master Buddha awakened the world.
The entire canon, hundreds of scriptures,
All aim to transcend worldly defilements
And awaken those sunk in delusion.
Thus, Muni is pure,
And the Great Being attains purity.
Muni encompasses purity,
The Great Being universalizes purity.
Not clinging to purity,
Not destroying purity,
Not begrudging purity—
Even to the point of no purity, not purity,
Not purity, yet purity—
This is great purity,
This is perfect purity.
If one can chant the tide-sound,
One will surely attain a pure heart,
A prajñā heart.
But attaining prajñā,
One forgets prajñā.
If prajñā is not forgotten,
It is not prajñā.
Since it is not prajñā,
It cannot be called prajñā.
Not not-prajñā—
This is prajñā.
One who attains prajñā
Is called a Shi;
This may become a Shi,
This has the Shi of Shi,
This Shi is not the having of Shi,
This Shi naturally has the Shi of Shi.

This is called the Buddha,
This may become the Buddha,
This has the Buddha of Buddha,
This Buddha is not the having of the Buddha of Buddha,
This Buddha naturally has the Buddha of Buddha.

Thus is Muni,
Thus is the Great Being,
Thus even the śramaṇa bhikṣu.

Can one become a Shi without this?
No.
Can one become a Buddha without this?
No.
Why?
This Shi is the Shi;
not-Shi is not the Shi.
This Buddha is the Buddha;
not-Buddha is not the Buddha.
Why?
Beyond the Shi there is no Shi;
grasping the Shi makes the Shi.
Beyond the Buddha there is no Buddha;
grasping the Buddha makes the Buddha.
Why?
The Shi of Shi, the intent of Shi—
when both are without Shi-intent,
then is true Shi-intent.
The Buddha of Buddha, the thought of Buddha—
when both are without Buddha-thought,
then is true Buddha-thought.

Not-Shi yet Shi is the supreme vehicle,
Not-Buddha yet Buddha is the Great Vehicle.
The scriptural treasury of Shi and Buddha—
it is through Shi and Buddha that the treasury is formed,
this is called the Treasury of the True Dharma Eye.

**Mystic Sound Chapter**
Mystic learning takes virtue and power as its essence,
the Golden Elixir as its function,
and only then can one become an immortal.
There are five ranks of immortals,
but in truth, only four.

First, the Human Immortal.
The Human Immortal refines primordial essence to replenish primordial qi,
having cultivated the foundation of immortality.
Yet they can only nurture health
and do not transcend birth and death—
these are immortals among humans.

Second, the Earth Immortal.
The Earth Immortal refines primordial qi to congeal the inner elixir,
free from the affliction of leakage.
Yet they may walk on land
and do not leave the dusty realm—
these are immortals among the earth.

Third, the Divine Immortal.
The Divine Immortal refines primordial qi to transform primordial spirit,
attaining the wondrous power of divine penetration.
Water and fire cannot harm them;
they are also called Water Immortals.
When spirit is refined to return to emptiness,
they become Heavenly Immortals.
Thus, below Heavenly Immortals are Divine Immortals,
below Divine Immortals are Earth Immortals,
below Earth Immortals are Human Immortals,
and below Human Immortals,
there are only ghosts, no immortals.

Ghosts are pure yin,
Immortals are pure yang.
Humans possess half yin and half yang,
thus they do not escape birth and death.
Severing the yin half makes an immortal,
severing the yang half makes a ghost.
Therefore, humans exist between the possibility of immortality and ghostliness,
momentarily suspended between the two.
To escape this in-between state,
one must abide in the ranks of Heavenly and Divine Immortals.

Turn back to recognize the shore,
let go and leave the dust.
The myriad words of elixir scriptures
all reside within oneself.
Mistaking the self for the other
is to fall into heterodox paths.

The legacy of former sages
must be skillfully pondered.
It is neither metal nor stone,
neither mercury nor lead,
neither furnace nor cauldron,
neither woman nor man,
neither sun nor moon,
neither kun nor qian,
neither father nor mother,
neither dragon nor tiger,
neither crow nor hare,
neither female nor male.

Where lies the mystery?
The mystery lies in the mysterious place.

Where lies the wonder?
The wonder lies in the wondrous place.
I possess true transmission,
yet dare not speak recklessly;
people possess true sincerity,
yet do not shut their doors.
To broadly accumulate hidden merits
is to first become an immortal of the highest rank;
to broadly practice convenience for others
is to first establish the foundation of immortality;
to broadly cultivate cause and effect
is to first plant the root of immortality.
If one finds such a person to seek my Dao,
I shall willingly expound the supreme Dharma,
pointing out subtle words,
as if parting clouds and mist to behold the azure sky,
then depart with a long whistle.

This chapter delineates the ranks of immortals,
clear and luminous.
I only hope that people will accumulate hidden merits to seek true transmission,
for the Dao of divine immortals is truly not difficult to attain.

**The Five Virtues Chapter**
Human life possesses five virtues,
which I have likened to the five phases of Heaven and Earth.
The five classics of the human body:
benevolence pertains to wood, the liver;
righteousness pertains to metal, the lungs;
propriety pertains to fire, the heart;
wisdom pertains to water, the kidneys;
trustworthiness pertains to earth, the spleen.
Thus, not one of the five virtues can be lacking,
just as not one of the five classics can be severed,
or one of the five phases cut off.
All say wood cannot be lacking,
yet why is there no benevolence?
Without benevolence, one must lack the thought of nurturing and fostering,
their liver already severed,
and wood withers and dries!
All say metal cannot be lacking,
yet why is there no righteousness?
Without righteousness, one must lack the consideration of expediency,
their lungs already severed,
and metal rusts and dulls!
All say fire cannot be lacking,
yet why is there no propriety?
Without propriety, one must lack the radiance of brightness,
their heart already severed,
and fire wanes and extinguishes!
All say water cannot be lacking,
yet why is there no wisdom?
Without wisdom, one must lack the clarity of purity,
their kidneys already severed,
and water darkens and dries!
All say earth cannot be lacking,
yet why is there no trustworthiness?
Without trustworthiness, one must lack the sentiment of mutual trust,
their spleen already severed,
and earth crumbles and collapses!

Thus, one who would be human
must first possess the five virtues of the heart,
and only then the five classics of the body.
Benevolence does not sever the liver, and its qi flourishes;
righteousness does not sever the lungs, and their qi is balanced;
propriety does not sever the heart, and its qi is luminous;
wisdom does not sever the kidneys, and their qi is numinous;
trustworthiness does not sever the spleen, and its qi is awakened.
Virtue envelops the body,
the body envelops the heart,
the body serves the heart’s use,
and the heart is illuminated by virtue.
This body is the heart,
this heart is the body,
these five virtues are the five classics.
When virtue is lost, the classics are lost;
when virtue is perfected, the body is perfected;
when the body is perfected, the classics are perfected,
and only then can one assist and harmonize with the five phases of Heaven and Earth.

**The Filial Conduct Chapter**
The osmanthus palace arrays its pillars with couplets,
and of a hundred deeds, filial piety comes first.
The cultured ancestor could practice filial piety,
his fragrance enduring for ten thousand myriad years.
Thus, in his own person,
attaining the Dao is attaining immortality,
attaining immortality is attaining sagehood,
attaining sagehood is attaining worthiness.
His radiance opens the sun and moon,
his love and longing connect Earth and Heaven.
If the people of the world desire to emulate filial piety,
filial piety is truly the origin of a hundred deeds.
Yu Shun ordered the hundred offices,
with filial piety foremost in illumination and exaltation.
King Wen of Zhou rectified the hundred measures,
with filial piety foremost in reputation and command.
Master Zeng valued the three ways,
yet serving parents was uniquely great.
Min Ziqian excelled in the four virtues,
yet serving his mother was uniquely earnest.
Since ancient times, there have been many filial children,
and I shall briefly expound a few.
Do not regard this as a mere classic of filial piety,
but observe it as a model of filial conduct.
Some carried rice on their backs,
some left behind savory broth,
some gazed at white clouds,
some wore patched robes,
some wept until their strength waned,
some cherished fresh tangerines,
some prayed and bamboo sprouted,
some moved stones to release springs,
some remembered the crow’s return to feed its parents,
some entreated fish to leap from the abyss,
some held the Anyang decree,
some set aside the *Liao’e* ode,
some thought of their parents and ceased feasting,
some served their parents and carved their cheeks—
these were all streams of worthies and sages,
how could they lack words of virtuous merit!
Yet among their hundred fine deeds,
none surpass the entanglement of filial piety.
Only filial piety can make one a friend,
shifting filial piety can become loyalty;
only filial piety molds one’s wife,
and through filial piety, one gains trust among friends.
One act of filial piety encompasses the five relationships,
and you must know that filial piety can be emulated.
Supreme filial piety lies in the heart,
love and longing reveal one’s true nature;
moderate filial piety lies in the body,
serving and nurturing should be earnest and diligent.
Though one may speak of filial piety with their mouth,
they must be able to act as they speak.
Though one may feign filial piety on their face,
they deceive both others and their kin.
The virtue of filial piety is boundless,
each thought gains a portion,
portion by portion and inch by inch,
inch by inch it reaches the heavenly spirits.
Filial piety upon filial piety,
sincerity upon sincerity,
I compose this *Classic of Filial Piety*,
the great classic within the classics.

**The Debauchery and Evil Chapter**
The osmanthus palace inscribes its pillars with verses,
and of ten thousand evils, debauchery is foremost.
Thus, the retributions for evil are many,
but none are as shameful as the retribution for debauchery.
Heaven’s punishments are each extraordinary,
Heaven’s penalties are each manifest.
Some seduce another’s wife,
and their own wife is seduced by another;
some embrace another’s daughter,
and their own daughter is embraced by another;
some are killed for their lewdness;
some are cut off from descendants for their lewdness;
some lose their family’s wealth and property;
some forfeit their official rank and longevity;
some bear base and ignoble descendants;
some follow deceit and fraud to their ruin—
the retributions for debauchery are endlessly tangled,
and brush and ink cannot fully recount them.
Who can this evil be spared?
Why do they not turn back!
Some say the debauched are full,
and only when their sins are complete does retribution arrive,
yet the moment one is debauched, retribution follows,
for Heaven’s mirror brooks no partiality.
One case of a lewd ghost
is truly lamentable, truly lamentable!
I exhort you, people of the world,
do not violate the precept against debauchery.
What you have not seen, do not think of;
what you have seen, do not act wantonly toward.
Do not jest with virgins,
do not trifle with chaste widows.
When you encounter another’s wife or concubine,
regard them as sisters.
Do not defile maidservants or slaves,
do not frequent prostitutes or actresses.
The rouge and powder of a moment are flowers,
but one’s spirit scatters in an instant.
To preserve the body, one must emerge from the pit;
to escape suffering, one must cross the shore.
Even with your own wife and concubines,
intimate passions should also be moderated.
If you desire to bear upright and dignified children,
you must establish respectful boundaries.

On occasions of sacred deities’ birthdays, solar or lunar eclipses, the appointed days for stove sacrifices, inauspicious anniversary dates, times of dark and gloomy convergence, or during swift thunder and lightning, one must separate quilts and beds, or even beds and chambers.

Heavenly spirits observe such reverence and bestow blessings of their own accord. Celestial immortals honor such conduct, and those who seek the Dao may attain it. If one further refrains from all evil, one becomes a true hero of greatness.

**The Chapter on Giving and Retribution**

For wealthy and noble families, accumulating goodness is easy, yet seeking good retribution is not. It is not that goodness goes unrewarded, but that retribution is measured by its weight. For poor and humble families, accumulating goodness is difficult, yet receiving good retribution is not. It is not only that goodness is rewarded, but that retribution is likewise measured by its weight. As for those who are neither rich nor noble, neither poor nor humble, their accumulation of goodness and receipt of retribution are also proportionally meted out.

In terms of monetary aid: for the wealthy and noble, a hundred taels yield ten merits; for the poor and humble, ten taels yield ten merits. In terms of aiding others: for the wealthy and noble, helping a hundred people yields ten virtues; for the poor and humble, helping ten people yields ten virtues. Those who are neither rich nor noble, neither poor nor humble, should naturally be judged by the standard of the common man.

For the wealthy and noble to claim the standard of the common man is improper; to claim the standard of the poor and humble is even more so. What one generation amasses, the next dissipates; what one generation strengthens, the next weakens. Nevertheless, if the wealthy and noble perform good deeds appropriately, even a few hundred taels will surely bring great retribution—one need only expand and fulfill it. For the poor and humble to forcibly imitate the common man is improper; to forcibly imitate the wealthy and noble is even more so. Extravagant support invites sin, while cold and hunger deepen the resentment of wife and children. Yet if the poor and humble perform good deeds appropriately, even as their household teeters on collapse, great retribution will surely follow—one need only weigh and apply it judiciously.

Heaven does not fail the good. Yet if one dwells in wealth and nobility but begrudges resources, expecting meager retribution for great goodness or delayed retribution for swift goodness, and thus neglects to cultivate virtue, calamity will inevitably strike, and misfortune will not be rare. A once-prominent clan may vanish in an instant like melting ice, and a lordly gate may crumble to ashes upon a second glance—all of this kind. If one dwells in poverty and humility yet boasts of merit and retribution, expecting scant reward for little goodness or delayed reward for delayed goodness, and thus treats virtue lightly, the calamities summoned will be stranger still, and the misfortunes encountered even more severe. Amid the desolation of war and the ravages of plague, all stem from this. Those who are neither rich nor noble, neither poor nor humble, follow the same principle.

Why is this so? Those who dwell in wealth and nobility possess the influence and authority to accumulate goodness. Even if one’s goodness goes unrewarded in this life, it is one’s due—clothed in abundance, fed in abundance, renowned and esteemed. To enjoy such peace and prosperity, passing it to one’s descendants, is itself a form of good retribution. Yet if one scorns goodness and refuses to act, expecting retribution while indulging in reckless greed, Heaven will transfer one’s authority to the virtuous without the slightest hesitation.

Those who dwell in poverty and humility lack the influence and authority to accumulate goodness. For such a person to perform even small acts of kindness is no extraordinary feat—cherishing words and objects, loving others and all things. If one consistently cultivates such habits, piling earth into mountains and gathering water into seas, good retribution will surely follow. Yet if one neglects goodness and refuses to act, expecting retribution while dulling one’s heart and will, Heaven will deepen one’s hardship to punish the wicked, showing no trace of partiality.

Thus is good retribution; thus is evil retribution. Those who are neither rich nor noble, neither poor nor humble, may observe this. You who are rich or noble, you who are poor or humble, reflect upon it.

Alas! The principle of giving and retribution is seen most clearly by sages and worthies, and handled most profoundly by immortals and buddhas. Even the chivalrous may sometimes exceed proper bounds, yet if the common people could but emulate such chivalry, it would suffice.

In my youth, I delighted in giving, and by good fortune ascended to the Nine Heavens. Thus, I have thoroughly discerned the retribution between Heaven and humanity. How could this be mere abstruse theory? Even the heart of Heaven operates thus. Yet what does Heaven say?

**The Chapter on Fullness and Decline**

The affairs of the world and the state are ever subject to waxing and waning, obscurity and clarity, fullness and decline. The common people attribute this to the workings of Heaven, while the enlightened ascribe it to the human heart. The principle is sound, the words pure—what need have I to expound further? Yet in this world, there are those who decline before reaching fullness, or who, though poised to decline, do not. The reasons for this I shall earnestly elucidate to admonish the world.

The momentum of a state’s power, secure at its height, may yet face peril in a single generation, and sigh over its impending ruin in the next. What holds true for the state may be applied to the individual. If this is decline, why do some revive through restoration? If this is not fullness, why do great crises suddenly arise, only to halt at a certain point?

For it is this: failing to draw near to worthy talent allows treacherous villains to corrupt governance; neglecting the cultivation of poetry and ritual leads descendants into extravagance and recklessness. In times of peace and prosperity, one must remain mindful of treading perilous paths. Anticipating danger and taking precautions, the noble person should remain vigilant to fulfill Heaven’s allotted span. Yet Heaven has no fixed span—if one daily maintains fullness, even ten thousand years may be attained.

The vital energy of a state, chaotic at its nadir, may yet revive as its fortune wanes and waxes anew, its power declining only to rise again. If this is not decline, why does it teeter like eggs stacked precariously? If it has already declined, why does it once more enjoy stability and peace?

For it is this: reining in the reins at the edge of a cliff may avert disaster; turning back upon witnessing the scene may extend the dynasty’s legacy. Even in the smallest pleasures of feasting and drinking, one cannot expect unending joy. Extrapolating from the minor to the major, the noble person should awaken sharply to avert Heaven’s predestined calamities. Yet Heaven has no fixed calamities—if one daily guards against decline, even the mediocre may endure.

Ah! The heart of Heaven resides in human affairs—why then do people not strive toward goodness?

**On Praise and Blame**
Why do others blame me? Why do they praise me? Why do they blame others? Why do they praise others? One who craves praise yet falls short of merit invites blame; one who guards against blame and corrects their faults earns praise. Thus, those who blame or praise me do so without cause, while I bring blame or praise upon myself with cause. Those who blame or praise others do so without reason, while others invite blame or praise with reason.

I love that all under Heaven seek no praise yet act in ways worthy of praise; I despise that all under Heaven fear no blame yet indulge in conduct that invites it. I am ashamed that all under Heaven, unaware of praise and blame, fade into obscurity. To fade into obscurity is to self-destruct without others’ blame.

Those who, in life, self-destruct through their faults will surely be praised by others; those who, in life, self-aggrandize through their merits will surely be blamed by others. Yet if praise exceeds reality, the wind of mutual flattery will arise; if blame exceeds reality, those who demand perfection deserve condemnation. Let the world take heed and be warned.

**On Longevity and Shortness**
Who is fated for long life? Who for short? The August One gazes below—no separate eye discerns. To teach all beings to live long, the great earth must teem with life. Thus, benevolence brings longevity, wickedness invites calamity; merit brings longevity, faults shorten life; nurturing brings longevity, dissipation scatters one’s essence.

Even immortals, Buddhas, sages, and worthies cannot escape kalpas—singing as speech, they summon the lost to return.

**On Prosperity and Adversity**
The prosperous know no endless sorrow; the sorrowful lack cultivated virtue. Flourishing and withering are but spring and autumn—yet I dwell in both, free in concealment or display. Life rushes past like an arrow—why rejoice in prosperity? Why sigh at adversity?

Circumstances may bind, but not the hero; fate may be endured, so play idly. Reading to cultivate the Dao, one’s noble qi coils like a dragon. With Yan Hui’s gourd and Zengzi’s zither, Confucius would approve; with Fu Yue’s zither and Mi Heng’s robe, I too may follow.

The dragon in the hut soars to the clouds; the donkey by the lake roams carefree. Clouds emerge to bring timely rain; streams recede to visit the pine and peach immortals. Or, without ambition for office, one may lean on a staff like Wang Zhi—why torment oneself to death in the weeds?

**On Character**
The boundaries of human character must be clearly discerned. Some possess an upright qi, standing apart from the crowd—others call them arrogant, but I call them resolute. Some dwell in humble light, indistinguishable from the world—others call them fickle, but I call them harmonious. Some roam freely, following their nature—others call them lazy, but I call them at ease. Some chant and sing as they please, following Heaven’s decree—others call them mad, but I call them enlightened. Some hold themselves with solemn dignity, their bearing stern—others call them haughty, but I call them dignified. Some establish themselves with simplicity, their nature steadfast—others call them dull, but I call them unadorned. Some distinguish right from profit, free of self-interest—others call them affected, but I call them principled. Some possess lofty aspirations, untouched by dust—others call them eccentric, but I call them noble. Some exude warmth and harmony, though unversed in letters—others call them vulgar, but I call them refined. Some embrace purity as their bond, ignorant of scriptures and repentance—others call them foolish, but I call them awakened. Some eat and drink no differently, untouched by cold or heat—others call them strange, but I call them immortal.

In the mingling of worthy and unworthy, some appear similar yet differ in essence—one must observe closely.

Do not thin others’ hearts while thickening your own, belittle others’ hearts while prizing your own, deny others’ hearts while clinging to your own—then the spirit of the perfected will emerge. Shun lived in the mountains, differing little from others, yet upon hearing a single good word or seeing a single good deed, he shone like a crimson beacon in the sky.

**On Joyful Living**
An old man from Ancheng said to Lord Weicheng: “I hear that to live in an age of peace, one must be a man of peace—neither above nor below, dwelling in ease and benevolence. Do you know the joys of such a life? Let me compose a brief ode to describe them.

Red dust rolls, the bitter sea surges.
Follow my path, guard my conduct;
Nurture my vastness, preserve my loftiness.
Preserve great harmony, dispel worldly cares;
Quell strife, temper restless qi.
Endure cold to deepen learning and cultivation;
Forget desires, dwell in the grove.
As an official, avoid transgressions;
As a scholar, escape resentment.
Teach children to shun debauchery and gambling;
Instruct women to keep the household solemn.
Farming yields no shortage for taxes;
Study neglects no moral garden.
Drink communal wine to cure deafness,
Become the great toe of the people.
Dignified in bearing, ancient in appearance;
Unfettered in spirit, whole in essence.
Amid the clamor of right and wrong,
All grievances vanish.
Able to release life and abstain from killing,
One nurtures nature and prolongs years.
Discuss maxims with village elders;
Teach the young to weigh deeds and faults.
Perfect yourself to perfect others,
Transforming thousands, ten thousand faces.
Spread a mat in the thatched hall,
Seat the mountain elder as guest of honor.
Plant lotuses in the pond, the gentleman’s flower;
Cultivate chrysanthemums by the fence, as Tao Yuanming did.
Let plum blossoms perfume the mountain soil;
Fill the ravine with the recluse’s bamboo.
Content wherever one is—
Is this not joy beyond joy?

Now you, sir, wear a double frown, a heart of stagnant blood.
Your feet tread the marketplace,
Your body cast aside the springs and rocks.”

Entering yet finding no peace, departing yet gaining no benefit.
Greedy for gain and fond of strife,
Ever scheming, ever gluttonous.
Grinding against the dusty marketplace,
Watching the sunset fade to nothing.”

The man of Dangerous City then sighed deeply: “Alas!
The immortal elder’s teaching has brought me to this point!
I humbly receive his instruction.”
With a deep bow, he withdrew.

**The Chapter on Yielding**

In a chamber of harmony, a family of accumulated virtue,
West wall and east hall—fit places for inscribed maxims.
Take, for instance, the matter of enduring loss:
Most men find it unjust.
Yet if we can practice forbearance,
We nurture harmony for ourselves
And lay up virtue for our children and grandchildren.
Here, I distill the profound sayings of sages, worthies, and wise men
Into a few lines, to exhort others.

Some say:
*“What benefits others benefits oneself,
What suits others suits oneself.
If I benefit others at my own expense,
If I suit others at my own cost.”*

Some say:
*“Those who endure loss enjoy abundant fortune,
Those who profit excessively always lose in the end.”*

Some say:
*“If everyone must win,
Who in the world is left to bear the loss?”*

Some say:
*“Heaven and earth are governed by the law of fullness and emptiness;
When one has endured every loss, the calamity is exhausted.”*

I, too, have a saying:
*“When I have endured much loss, Heaven cannot bear it—
Old Heaven will surely grant me advantage.”*

Disciples, take heed!
Those who endure loss never truly suffer it.

**The Chapter on Loyalty and Empathy**

Loyalty and empathy—these are the single thread transmitted by the Proclaimed Sage.
What is this “single thread”?
Loyalty is the essence, empathy the application.
“Loyalty” (*zhong*) means centering the heart;
“Empathy” (*shu*) means treating others as one would oneself.
Does not the meaning of “establishing oneself to establish others” lie herein?

Loyalty permeates empathy.
To practice empathy as the Way of benevolence (*ren*)
Is to refrain from imposing what one does not desire—
Thus the Heavenly heart remains undisturbed by human desires.
To practice empathy in the world
Is to endure offense without retaliation—
Thus the human heart remains free from violent opposition.
To practice empathy in governance
Is to refrain from imposing what one detests—
Thus the minister’s heart avoids cruel policies.

The principles of sages and worthies flow back to their source,
Truly fit to be practiced throughout one’s life.

If one desires only to follow one’s own heart
And not the hearts of others,
Then the heart will surely generate
A bias for oneself and against others,
A preference for oneself and disregard for others,
A concern for oneself and indifference to others,
A pursuit of self-interest at others’ expense,
A drive to succeed at others’ failure.
Such a heart is not the heart of others—
And if it is not the heart of others,
How can it be one’s own heart?
Though one may desire to follow one’s own heart,
Greed harms it;
Though one may not desire to follow one’s own heart,
Resentment corrupts it.
When the heart is corrupted, it is lost.
When the heart is lost, there is no center.
When the center is gone, the root of benevolence dies—
No wonder such a heart lacks empathy.

Thus, those who are disloyal also fail to grasp the thread.
I urge you, scholars,
To seek the intent of this single thread,
To preserve its truth—
Then you will not be traitors to the gate of Confucius.

**The Chapter on Emptiness and Nothingness**

Emptiness and nothingness—this is the shared teaching of Laozi and the Buddha.
What is emptiness?
An empty heart.
When the heart is empty, the spirit is clear;
When the spirit is clear, nature is wise.
From this arise great liberation and profound awakening.

What is nothingness?
No-self.
When there is no self, there are no others;
When there are no others, there are no desires.
From this arise great purity and boundless joy.

Now, my two disciples,
You do not understand emptiness and nothingness,
But only probe into “solid existence.”
The term “solid existence” may sound fine,
Yet in the end, how many are led astray by it!
Daily seeking the tangible, discoursing on gold and stone—
Nothing is gained.
Daily seeking the existent, pondering Chan verses—
The six senses are defiled.
Of the infinite sands of the Ganges,
Who attains the first *paramita*?

I pity your ignorance and open your wisdom.
Observe how an empty heart leads to wisdom—
Know that emptiness can grasp the real.
Observe how no-self leads to no desire—
Know that nothingness can encompass being.

Confucius abandoned the self,
Yan Hui purified his heart—
Even the Confucians valued this.
How much more should you?

**The Chapter on Nurturing Life**

Of all human desires, none surpasses the desire for life.
To attain life, one must value it;
To value life, one must never treat it lightly.
Sacrificing oneself to fulfill benevolence,
Offering one’s life in peril—
This is not treating life lightly.
Preserving life in ordinary times,
Using it in such moments—
This is not vain existence.
Though one may die, one yet lives.
Only those who value life can become
Loyal ministers, righteous scholars,
Chaste women, steadfast maidens.

If one lives in times of peace,
Encounters an age of prosperity,
Whether noble or humble,
Fulfills filial piety and loyalty,
Becomes a venerable elder of the state,
A paragon among men—
Then one who cherishes life must know how to nurture it.

The discourse on nurturing life differs from that of cultivating the true.
Cultivating the true can escape calamity—this is the Dao.
Nurturing life can prolong years—this is technique.
Yet without understanding the principles of Heaven, Earth, and humanity,
Past and present,
One will never find a verified method.

The people of antiquity,
With their unadorned customs,
Few in cares, few in thoughts,
Few in words, few in laughter,
Few in sights, few in sounds,
Clothed in coarse garments, eating simple fare,
Unknowing and unperceiving—
Thus they preserved their true nature
And lived long lives.

The people of today,
With their growing vanity,
Many in cares, many in thoughts,
Many in words, many in laughter,
Many in sights, many in sounds,
Clothed in finery, eating rich foods,
Their wills and spirits dissipated—
Thus they harm their natures
And meet early deaths.

The harmony of Heaven’s Way lies in return:
The sun, though slanting, returns to noon;
The moon, though waning, returns to fullness;
The rain, though ceasing, returns to clarity;
The thunder, though roaring, returns to hibernation.
Thus it retains its inexhaustible spirit,
Perpetuating the celestial cycle in constant renewal.

The disharmony of the human way lies in excessive depletion:
Essence is spent in dissipation,
Qi is lost in deficiency,
The spirit’s movement never ceases,
The body’s form cannot be preserved.
Thus it is difficult to restore an exhausted self,
And one lingers in the world but a brief morning and evening.

Thus, in nurturing life,
Medicine and diet come after,
Preservation comes first—
One may learn from Heaven’s Way,
Or one may learn from the ancients.

**Five Kalpas Chapter**
Alas, how sorrowful!
All humans are bound to the Five Kalpas.
What are the Five Kalpas?
Birth, aging, sickness, death, and suffering.
Must one not be born?
One should be born upright, born justly,
