Not born in delusion.
To be born as a sage or worthy—even if one dies young—is still to have lived,
With radiant spirit in the world,
A name that endures,
A fragrance that lingers—
How is this different from immortals or buddhas?
Yet there are those born in evil,
Born in violence,
Born in cruelty:
After one life, they shall not be born again,
Or rather, they *will* be born,
But born into kalpa after kalpa,
All falling into evil destinies,
Enduring the uninterrupted torments of hell.
Though they wish not to be born, they cannot escape.

Birth is the first kalpa.
Thus, sinking into the world,
Struggling in the human realm,
Unknowing of repentance,
Unmindful of change—
Leisurely, one ages:
This is the second kalpa.
Thus, essence depleted, form withered,
Spirit gone, qi exhausted,
Medicine cannot restore,
Nurture cannot revive—
Weakly, one falls ill:
This is the third kalpa.
Thus, impermanence arrives suddenly,
The final hour has come,
Where is one’s home? Who are one’s wife and children?
Hastily, one dies:
This is the fourth kalpa.
Thus, evil must be repaid,
Transgressions must be repaid,
One drifts through the netherworld,
Weeping and wailing in anguish—
This is the utmost suffering:
The fifth kalpa.
Fortunate if rebirth comes one day,
Yet one’s fate may bear the blade of war,
Or the disasters of water and fire,
Or the afflictions of myriad illnesses,
Or the hardships of endless poverty—
Still one will wander within the Five Kalpas without end,
Not to mention the knife mountains and hells.
Those who fall into this kalpa
Cannot dissolve their sins through karma or merit.
Thus, in this one life,
One must cultivate goodness and accumulate blessings,
Return to the root and restore the origin—
Only then may one ascend to the Terrace of Spring,
Or together enter the Land of Ultimate Bliss.
To be born is to attain long life,
To attain long life is to transcend birth,
To transcend birth is to be unborn,
To be unborn is to be undying,
To be undying is to achieve liberation.
Let all people take heed!

**Revering the Divine Chapter**
The divine—how wondrously it moves all things!
The Supreme Lord established teachings through the divine way,
Thus the divine truly governs good and evil.
All who are wise, bright, upright,
Are entrusted with the divine’s authority.
Heavenly spirits are *shen*,
Presiding over the guiding of all things;
Earthly spirits are *qi*,
Presiding over the sustaining of all things.
Such is the vast virtue of the divine—
The people receive it daily yet remain unaware.
Only by fully exhausting the human to align with Heaven and Earth
May one be deemed sufficient.

As for the sacred peaks and rivers, suburban altars,
Temples and shrines—
Those who erect steles and carve statues
Do so to revive the ancient spirits.
With towering halls and resplendent majesty,
All who gaze upon them cannot but stand in solemn reverence.
Yet when incense burns brightly, those who pray for blessings multiply;
When supplications grow frequent, those who seek fortune arrive—
How could the divine be deceived by mortals?
The origins of the divine are not uniform,
But all arise from the upright *qi*.

As the *Lu Yu* states:
*“The sage kings established sacrifices:
Those who enacted laws for the people were sacrificed to,
Those who died in service were sacrificed to,
Those who labored to stabilize the state were sacrificed to,
Those who averted great disasters were sacrificed to,
Those who warded off great calamities were sacrificed to.”*
Moreover, mountains, rivers, and the altars of soil and grain
All rendered great merits to the people.

For *“enacting laws for the people”*—
Originally, no repayment was expected;
*“Dying in service”*—
Originally, no gratitude was hoped for;
*“Laboring to stabilize the state”*—
Originally, no favor was sought;
*“Averting great disasters,” “warding off great calamities”*—
Originally, no entreaty was awaited;
Spreading merit and virtue among the people—
Originally, no prayers were required.
Even in the solemn rites of spring and autumn,
Or frequent fasts and offerings,
The ancestral temple’s purpose is but to pray to the divine
To protect our lord and state—
Yet this concerns not the self;
Or to pray to the divine
To protect our parents—
Yet this concerns not the self;
Or to pray to the divine
To bless the people and all things—
Yet this concerns not the self;
Or to pray to the divine
To deliver the lingering souls of the departed—
Yet this concerns not the self.
Moreover, one purifies the body,
Cleanses the mind,
Calms the thoughts,
Purifies the heart and liver,
Reveres the heart to revere the divine—
Thus, without seeking blessings, one naturally attains them.
Therefore, revering the divine
Is not as wondrous as revering one’s own heart.
The human heart is the divine,
The divine is the heart.
Only without shame in the heart
Can one be without shame before the divine.
One may face the divine,
And still face the heart—
Yet the divine is not separate from the heart.
It dwells in your chamber,
It dwells in your heart.
Just as the divine of Heaven abides in the sun,
Wherever the sunlight reaches, what place is not illuminated?
The divine of the human heart abides in the eyes—
Wherever the gaze falls, what thing is not seen?
Yet people seek to flatter the divine,
Hoping to erase their sins—
How could this be possible?

Beware:
The way of revering the divine has two paths—
The obsequious flattery of the vulgar is not among them.
The superior person maintains a heart of uprightness and magnanimity,
Establishes merit and conduct with profound sincerity.
In all places of dwelling,
They fear the divine’s scrutiny.
Blessings and felicity
Still arise from divine thought—
Such a person,
Though they never burn incense or hold candles,
Nor bow reverently at temple gates,
Has already attained the great way of revering the divine.
The middling person maintains a heart of caution and respect,
Speaking of the divine with trembling reverence.
When good thoughts arise,
They are spurred by the divine’s encouragement.
With merit and virtue,
Their heart bears the divine’s protection—
Such a person,
Though they may fast, bathe, and pay homage to bodhisattvas,
May be said to have grasped the lesser way of revering the divine.
As for those who outwardly feign humility
While inwardly harboring great wickedness,
Rushing about on the first and fifteenth days—
The divine will say:
*“You have come at last—
I have been seeking you!”*

"Do not flatter Me, do not profane Me—if you offer Me incense, I shall bind you in chains. Return and reform your heart; perhaps then it may yet be acceptable!"

**On Loving Others**
Of all things that live, none is more spiritually endowed than humankind. Having been granted such spiritual endowment over other beings, one must cherish life. Do not ensnare others with schemes, do not harm others with weapons, do not poison others with drugs, do not oppress others with power. Those who ensnare, harm, poison, or oppress others will face the visible punishments of the state and the invisible retribution of Heaven—none shall escape.

Consider how even creatures that fly and speak or dance, plants that bear fragrance or color, animals that can be tamed or delighted in, and hidden beings that can be nurtured or amused are still cherished by people. How much more precious, then, is a human life! Now I exhort you, people of the world: live together in harmony, do not oppress one another. In all your comings and goings, reflect upon the virtue of loving others, the merit of completing others, the deeds of loving others, the deeds of completing others, the benefits of loving others, the benefits of completing others. For in completing another’s name, you complete your own name; in completing another’s merit, you complete your own merit; in completing another’s deeds, you complete your own deeds; in completing another’s benefit, you complete your own benefit—all is love.

In completing another’s name and merit, deeds and benefit, do not obscure the loyalty of loyal ministers, do not usurp the achievements of meritorious officials, do not slander the chastity of women of integrity, do not defame the purity of young maidens, do not envy another’s ability nor falsely claim it as your own, do not resent another’s talent nor conceal it, do not hide another’s goodness nor steal it, do not spread another’s evil nor imitate it, do not secretly obstruct another’s advancement, do not recklessly erase another’s writings, do not ruin another’s grand undertakings, do not undermine another’s good deeds, do not sabotage another’s noble plans, do not diminish another’s wealth or longevity, do not seize another’s land, do not meddle with another’s property, do not aid villains in seizing the geomantic blessings of the virtuous, do not ally with petty men to lead astray the descendants of the noble. The compassion of universal kinship is too vast to enumerate fully.

Thus, the Everlasting Heavenly Worthy tirelessly admonishes: do not humiliate the good and upright, do not deceive the poor and destitute, do not separate father and child, do not divide flesh and blood, do not break marriages, do not mock the deaf and blind. Furthermore, rescue those in peril, aid those in urgent need, pity the orphaned, tolerate others’ faults, relieve suffering, provide for the hungry and cold, support your kin, assist neighbors and friends, show compassion to the orphaned and widowed, respect the elderly, and care for the poor—all these are acts of loving others.

Alas! Heaven has created countless beings to serve as the ground for the benevolent to practice benevolence and the virtuous to accumulate virtue. If one can extend the heart broadly and protect and nurture the multitudes, then those who dwell in wealth and nobility and love others will surely enrich their descendants, while those who dwell in poverty and lowliness and love others will surely attain prominence. Heaven blesses the good, the Emperor favors the virtuous—since ancient times, such blessings have been most abundant and swift. Therefore, to those who wish to understand the Dao of living in the world, I still urge: "Love others."

**On Medicine**
The Dao of medicine can either preserve a nation or sicken it; medicine in the world can either save lives or take them. One cannot be careless in this art. Within it lies principle, its study is inexhaustible, and its practice knows no end. Medicines are categorized as sovereign, minister, assistant, and courier; illnesses are distinguished as deficient or excessive, chronic or acute. While all physicians may speak of these, few truly understand them.

The sages’ learning was profound, yet their aspirations remained humble; their virtue was lofty, yet their hearts were modest. Those who practice the art of medicine should be the same. Do not underestimate yourself, do not mislead yourself, do not deceive yourself. To deceive yourself is to deceive others; to mislead yourself is to mislead others; to underestimate yourself is to underestimate others—such sins will be visited upon your own person.

Thus, in this path, achieving merit is easy, but incurring faults is also easy; accumulating blessings is difficult, but inviting misfortune is not. To seek merit without fault, blessings without misfortune, one must hold oneself in vigilant restraint. The subtleties of pulse and principle are profound—those with shallow learning cannot grasp them.

Now I exhort you, physicians: when you approach a patient’s bedside, first inquire about their history—do not experiment with medicine on them. Now I exhort you, patients: before the physician, first clarify the origins of your illness—do not gamble your life to test the physician. To gamble your life to test the physician is your own fault; to experiment with medicine on others is the physician’s fault.

Furthermore, when aiding those in critical condition, do not inflate your fees; when saving the destitute, do not calculate payment. If you can clearly discern the symptoms, proceed to rescue them; if you cannot, defer to those more skilled—this is the accumulation of steadfast and sincere goodness.

I further urge you, scholars of the Confucian tradition: study medical classics extensively, delve deeply into the principles of medicine, do not hoard knowledge nor act recklessly—benefit yourself and others. Fan Wenzheng and Lu Xuangong, as ministers of the state, devoted great attention to medicine. How can one neglect the Dao of medicine?

**On Physiognomy and Divination**
The superior person has a countenance, the inferior person has a countenance, but the mediocre person has no fixed countenance. The superior person has a fate, the inferior person has a fate, but the mediocre person has no fixed fate. Only the superior and inferior have natures that are difficult to change—this need not be discussed. Here, I speak only of you, the mediocre person, neither superior nor inferior, capable of rising or falling, sometimes rising, sometimes falling.

Neither rising nor falling is still falling; capable of rising or falling is still falling; sometimes rising, sometimes falling is still falling. Only by breaking free from the cycle of falling can one cease to be inferior. Countenance can be transformed by oneself, fate can be forged by oneself—this is no lie from the ancients.

Even those who practice physiognomy and divination can only read your appearance, not your heart; they can only calculate your fate, not your virtue. If they cannot read your heart, they cannot truly read your appearance; if they cannot calculate your virtue, they cannot truly calculate your fate.

Do not be deceived by physiognomists, for wisdom lies in understanding the heart behind the appearance. When the heart’s essence is upright, even a plain countenance is auspicious. Do not be haunted by diviners, for virtue transcends fate. When one’s moral nature is steadfast, even an ill-starred destiny becomes fortunate.

I urge you, people of the world, to read your own countenance and calculate your own fate. I urge you, physiognomists, to exhort others to cultivate the heart. I urge you, diviners, to exhort others to accumulate virtue. All discussions of bone and qi should be guided by the classics; all reckonings of fortune should be derived from canonical texts. When you speak of fate, speak also of virtue; when you discuss appearance, speak also of the heart. Embed moral transformation within the arts of physiognomy and divination, and the Three Patriarchs of the *Máyī* tradition and Master Zǐpíng will surely grant you sustenance.

---

**On Geomancy**

Heaven covers both good and evil; earth bears both good and evil; only the immortal masters conceal and store good and evil for heaven and earth. Heaven is impartial in its covering; earth is impartial in its bearing; the immortal masters are impartial in their grace. When people are swayed by selfish desires, their perception of principle becomes obscured.

Geomancy is the principle of heaven and earth. Where heavenly principle exists, human desire cannot intrude. Thus, this Dao can only be fully expounded by the sagely—those who are wise, enlightened, and upright. Yet today, people recklessly discuss fengshui, profaning the mountain spirits. They exhume the bones of their kin in pursuit of fortune and blessings, consulting geomancers to discern misfortune and auspiciousness. Some seek sites on behalf of others; some search for themselves. They swindle people of their wealth, demanding praise for their craft. With such hearts, how can they comprehend heavenly principle? It is no wonder that nine out of ten geomancers live in poverty!

When the immortal masters bestow a site, the virtuous receive virtue, and the wicked receive wickedness. The virtuous do not accept undeserved favor; the wicked do not bear unjust blame. This is the impartiality of principle, the clarity of the heart. When I have discussed geomancy with others, I have always coupled it with the law of retribution—this is the way it must be.

Those who govern the earth are immortal masters; their office is divine, not mundane. If people seek land from mortals, why not seek immortality from mortals as well?

---

**Admonitions for the World: On Guarding Against Lust**

The Dao of heaven is such that what goes forth must return—this principle is immutable, and its consequences are inevitable. Human beings, born between heaven and earth, are endowed with the finest essence of the Five Phases and possess the qi of uprightness. The proper union of husband and wife is the natural order of human relations. To transgress propriety and disrupt ethical norms is to descend to the level of beasts. Lewd and licentious conduct is something the virtuous must resolutely guard against.

Of all creatures in the world, none are more foolish than animals, yet the *suījiū* bird mates for life without confusion, and the solitary wild goose cries out but does not join the flock. How can humans, who bear the name of "human," be less enlightened than birds, failing to live up to their own nature?

Alas, these benighted masses do not understand that desire is emptiness, akin to an illusion or a bubble. They still covet the rosy cheeks and temples of beauty, indulging in entangling affections. Yet if they would but turn their gaze inward, they would awaken to the truth: all hearts are the same. When you lust after another’s wife or daughter, consider this—if your own wife or daughter were to consort with another, your heart would be pierced as with a thorn, your eyes would burn as with fire. You would strike out in fury, pursuing and slaying without hesitation. How then can you take pride in your own lust for others?

At such moments, heaven and earth, ghosts and spirits, stand above you, bearing witness at your side. Their eyes blaze with anger, their teeth gnash in wrath, plotting retribution. Disaster will strike without delay. Reflecting on this, how can one not shudder with dread?

Moreover, abandoning oneself to the blade of lust, one’s head may be shattered at the neighbor’s threshold before the dream of the *yángtái* is even over, and the gates of the netherworld will already be sealed. The green-tinged blood and pale gore—all are the work of the allure of rouge and powder. The beauty was but a tiger in cosmetics—how can this not be believed?

Even if one escapes such extremes, the strong may cry out to the authorities, while the weak harbor hidden resentment. Families bear inexplicable shame; husbands and wives sever bonds of a lifetime. Death or survival becomes uncertain; calamities multiply. Some secretly plot revenge; others inflict covert harm. As for the loss of one’s children, the stain on one’s reputation—it becomes a tale told for generations.

The cruelty of murder extends only to one person, but the poison of lust is no less than killing that person across multiple lifetimes. Those who indulge in lust are themselves unprincipled. With their soft hearts and seductive bones, they cannot control others but are inevitably controlled by them. Thus, they abandon filial piety and fraternal duty for private passions, casting aside parents and siblings as if they were mere bystanders. Beyond this one obsession, they are utterly oblivious.

As a result, wives, concubines, and children lack proper supervision, and the inner chambers descend into filth and chaos. Though retribution unfolds silently, they remain utterly oblivious. Furthermore, those who indulge in lust will see their children die young and their descendants dwindle. Why? Because one’s descendants are sown by one’s own spirit and essence. When one’s finite essence is squandered on the endless flowers and willows of desire, it is like felling a tree with an axe—once the sap is exhausted, the fruit must wither. The frailty of one’s offspring is inevitable.

Generation after generation grows thinner, weaker, until the lineage is severed entirely. This is the natural consequence. The severity of the calamity of lust—how can it be fully described?

Alas! How fleeting is human life—barely a hundred years, a mere instant. Even those who disregard reputation and squander their lives must still care for their descendants and ensure the continuity of their ancestral sacrifices. If they would but consider this, they would have no time for regret—how then could they still seek pleasure and indulge their desires?

As for those in the empty gate who maintain pure conduct, or widows with hearts as cold as ice, they are not to be compared with the alluring temptresses of the world. It is not merely a matter of personal integrity or the well-being of one’s family—such conduct is simply impermissible, and no further elaboration is needed.

For those of resolve, let purity of heart be the foundation, shame the instrument, perseverance the guard, and vigilance the aspiration. Hold fast without laxity; cultivate with clarity. Consign all licentious texts to the flames; sever ties with dissolute companions. Concentrate your spirit and energy to pursue what is truly beneficial. Then you will see every name established, every profit reaped. The five blessings will gather upon you. Is this not the immutable principle, the inevitable consequence?

Thus is the exhortation. This is the original work. It was once published by Sun Nianqu of Changzhou in *The Complete Human Measure*.

**Admonition Against Licentiousness**

Heaven and Earth give birth to humanity, endowing us with the finest essence of the Five Phases and the vital essence of the Two Great Forces. Husband and wife—such is the constant Way of human relations; wanton dalliance and fleeting passions—these are the crooked paths of depravity. Should one peer over walls or bore through holes, transgressing principle and confounding human ethics, it would be as the boar’s borrowed coupling, the dog’s indiscriminate congress, the wild mandarin ducks, the doves nesting in confusion. Thus, though born human, one would be ranked with beasts. Moreover, even the dullest creatures know their mates: the *guan* and *ju* birds take their proper places without disorder, the phoenixes soar a thousand flights yet remain ever paired. If humans fall short of birds, what claim to humanity remains?

Alas, how is it that the foolish masses, neglecting the bounds of ritual and propriety, repeatedly violate the precept against licentiousness? With rosy cheeks and raven locks, they entangle themselves in love’s snares, stealing jade and pilfering fragrance, their madness growing daily. Yet know this: all share the same heart, and thus the same principle; all share the same principle, and thus the same feelings. I urge those in the realm of desire: when tempted to seduce another’s wife or daughter, turn back and reflect deeply. Imagine if your own wife or daughter were enticed away, her pillowside whispers and tender embraces lavished upon another—if you stood by, witnessing such a scene, would your eyes not burn, your heart not seethe? Would you not clench your fists in rage, striking out without a moment’s hesitation?

Alas! All share the same feelings, and thus the same principle; all share the same principle, and thus the same heart. To defile one is to defile generations; to defile another is to defile oneself. The thought of lust must be swiftly eradicated. The retributions for licentiousness and the admonitions against it—ancient sages and former worthies have set forth countless examples. May those who turn back seek them out and study them.

**Reverence for Sun and Moon**

That Heaven and Earth possess sun and moon is like humans possessing two eyes.

The eye delights in purity and uprightness—all people are thus. Were someone to relieve themselves before your eyes, you would surely seethe with rage; were they to bathe before your eyes, you would surely flush with shame; were they to curse before your eyes, you would surely bristle with fury. Yet why, when the radiant sun and moon gaze down upon you, do you fail to show them reverence?

Only with the advent of sun and moon were yin and yang divided, day and night distinguished, and vision made clear. Thus, when the sun sinks in the west and daylight fades, those with eyes yet grope in darkness; when the moon sets in the west and the clear night darkens, those with eyes yet wander in blindness. How can one receive the illumination of sun and moon, borrow their luminous brilliance, yet remain ignorant of their supreme virtue?

Now I exhort you, people of the world: harbor awe and reverence, embody respect and veneration. Do not relieve yourselves before sun and moon, do not bathe before sun and moon, do not curse before sun and moon. Those who relieve themselves before sun and moon shall be pierced by the arrows of a hundred thousand wrathful spirits and suffer strange maladies; those who bathe before sun and moon shall have their bones pricked by a hundred thousand yin soldiers and contract chilling ailments; those who curse before sun and moon shall have their transgressions silently recorded by ten thousand investigating deities, who will then harass and oppress them, annihilating them utterly. Thus, sun and moon must be revered. People of the world, take heed and be warned!

**Exhortation to Repair Ancestral Graves**

A dwelling is the abode of the living, just as a grave is the home of the dead. When tiles leak and walls crumble, wind and rain assail, the living cannot rest in peace—how then can the dead find repose when earth collapses and coffins cave in, when ants burrow and worms bore through?

Now I exhort the people of the world: each tend to your ancestral graves. Those with means may undertake the task alone, and the blessings that follow shall be theirs to receive; those without resources may still contribute their strength, and the spirits’ repose shall bring them sheltering shade. Spare no expense, shirk no labor. Those whose families have long prospered must remember that today’s glory is but the legacy of their ancestors; those whose fortunes have newly risen must remember that today’s prosperity is but the fruit of their forebears’ labors—what merit is yours? What virtue have you established?

In life, they clothed and fed you—how can you ever repay their boundless kindness? In death, you honor them morning and night—how can you not cherish the ground where they rest? Tend to their graves generation after generation, and your descendants shall repay you in kind; repair them year after year, and the gods’ benevolent retribution shall grow ever more manifest. Those who disbelieve shall meet with early death, poverty, extinction, and lowly station; those who believe shall enjoy longevity, wealth, peace, health, and noble rank.

I have seen fine tombs fallen into desolation and known the descendants’ fortunes to wither in turn. When stone tablets lie beneath cold mist, how many clans have seen their heirs decline? When barren mounds bury rotting grass, how many families have seen their children fall into ruin? Who among us is without feeling? Who can escape this fate?

Here now is a matter of common sense—you ought to grasp its principle. Those who discourse on fengshui heap sand upon branches, for appearance’s sake alone they seek enclosure; those who repair tomb foundations build terraces and steps, for the earth’s veins must not be harmed. Even among ordinary folk, on the very day they inter their ancestors’ remains, they plant dense hedges on either side and diligently pile up earth and stone. How is it that what was so carefully tended in former days is suddenly abandoned by later generations?

I now instruct you all: let each person sweep and pay respects, adding good soil where needed; let every year’s visit include the uprooting of noxious trees. Thus the grave mound shall suffer no collapse or subsidence, and the qi of the veins shall rise and flourish; the fine tomb shall sprout lush grass, and the roots of trees shall settle firmly. With the ancestral spirits at peace, worthy descendants shall multiply. Should you defy this teaching, you shall surely incur divine punishment.

Looking up and down, sighing in sorrow, one feels the poignant beauty of a world cut off from its glory.

On Geomancy
The earth stands at the center of the Three Powers; to speak of geomancy is to speak of the resonance between heaven’s principle and man’s. When man seeks to assess the land, heaven likewise assesses man; when man seeks to choose the land, the land likewise chooses man. Though many in the world discuss the principles of land, do they also know the principles by which land is obtained?

The principles of discussing land are governed by man; the principles of obtaining land are governed by heaven, while the land itself conceals and reveals them. To know the difficulty of seeking land and thus abandon the search is wrong; yet to know the difficulty of seeking land and still forcefully pursue it is also impossible.

Master Ziping once said: “The teachings of geomancy did not originally arise for the sake of shielding descendants; rather, descendants use them to settle the ancestral spirits, and the ancestral spirits in turn bless the descendants—this is the Dao that runs through all.”

Now, land is of three ranks, and those who obtain land are likewise divided into three levels. The highest rank of land corresponds above to the stars, below to the map of the earth; it is formed by heaven and earth, its trigrams settled and stable, entirely the work of nature, with no human effort involved. Only sages, heroes, and those of great virtue and hidden merit can obtain such land.

The middle rank of land also possesses natural scenery, yet within it there are transformations: the eight trigrams interact, the five phases push and pull, a mass of true qi subtly swells and rises. Only those of steadfast loyalty and integrity, with some measure of virtue and hidden merit, can obtain such land.

The lowest rank of land presents itself in every mountain and stream, spread across the land—seen once every ten li, twice every hundred li, found everywhere, sought anywhere. Yet one must still understand the dragon’s origin, the mountain’s orientation, the soil’s color, skillfully selecting and arranging, aligning mountains and rivers with the luopan, not forcing the luopan to conform to mountains and rivers. Only when land and man are mutually suited is harmony achieved. This rank is attainable by any steadfast, loyal, and blameless person.

These are the great principles of the three ranks; those below them need not be discussed, for there is no auspicious land for the unvirtuous. How easily can one speak of the oxen-sleeping auspicious mounds!

Alas! Though man may be skilled in assessing land, heaven is also skilled in assessing man! Though man may be skilled in choosing land, the land is also skilled in choosing man! Can one not strive to be a virtuous person, so as to obtain ancient land?

I have seen many in the world seek land, and so I compose *On Geomancy* to awaken them.

From *The Complete Works of Master Zhang Sanfeng*, Volume Seven
Recompiled by Li Xiyue of Hanjia Changyishan
Respectfully inscribed by Zhang Daoyuanzi Shenshi

In the city of Langzhong, Zhu Daosheng, styled Wancheng, and his nephew Ying Chunchen, along with Zhu Zan, styled Suyuan, collated and proofread the text. His sons Huang Panxi and Doumu Yuanjun, the Supreme Nine Sovereigns’ True Scripture, offer this incense hymn:

Within the celestial Dipper, within the heart’s Dipper,
To revere the Dipper is first to revere the heart,
To revere the heart is also to revere the Dipper.
The heart’s tally: seven returns seven,
The numbers align: nine returns nine.
Precious censer burns incense, taking refuge in the Dipper Mother.
Thrice bathed, thrice perfumed, bowing deeply in reverence.

With sincere heart, we pay homage to:
The Primordial Divine Empress, the Sage of Tianzhu.
She governs the celestial pivot, traversing India.
Dwelling in the highest realm, she establishes the Great Central Heaven.
She commands the myriad spirits, roaming the Three Realms.
Her elixir refined in the nine tripods, her Dao succors all beings.
Great Compassion, Great Vow, Great Sage, Great Mercy—
The Qi of Brahmā, the Primordial Divine Empress, the Peerless Heavenly Dipper Mother.

With sincere heart, we pay homage to:
The Perfected Transmitter of the Dao, the Immortal Chosen by the Great Clarity.
Residing on Wudang, she inaugurated the teaching,
The true lineage of Wen Shi.
Like one entranced, she concealed her immortal traces in the splendor of spring;
Teaching filial piety and loyalty, she spread the mystic breeze across China.
She delivered the thirteen thousand from the Eastern Sea,
Husband and wife ascending together;
She continued the divine efficacy of the Dragon and Tiger,
Her Dao and methods both complete.
The precious raft of the ten directions, the master of the Three Teachings—
Great Compassion, Great Vow, Great Mercy, Great Benevolence,
Most Profound, Most Wondrous, Most Marvelous, Most Divine—
The Eastern August Minister, the Outer Minister of the Three Pure Ones,
The Thunder Spirit Officer, the Numinous Treasure Heavenly Master,
The Primordial Qi’s Founding Ancestor, the Dao-Pervading, Culture-Distant True Lord,
The Manifest and Transformative Heavenly Worthy.

With sincere heart, we pay homage to:
The Jade Clarity’s Inner Minister, the Immortal Chosen from the Golden Portal.
She manifested as the teacher of the Three Teachings,
Wielding the law and issuing the commands of the Five Thunders.
Awakening from the yellow millet dream, she forgot worldly fame and glory;
Her precious sword’s radiance severed the demons of the human realm.
For the four births and six destinies, she responds to all who call;
Across the Three Realms and ten directions, no request goes unanswered.
On Yellow Crane Tower, she left her wondrous traces;
In Purple Mushroom Grotto, she refined the numinous cinnabar.
She enshrined the sacred image on cloud-clad cliffs,
Revealed immortal traces in the jade firmament.
She spread the incense fire of the Dharma gate,
Providing the ladder and ferry for the mystic lineage—
Great Sage, Great Mercy, Great Benevolence, Great Filial Piety,
The Mountain-Opening, Teaching-Inaugurating, Mystic-Responsive Patriarch,
The Heavenly Thunder’s High Minister, the Numinous Treasure Perfected One,
The Pure Yang’s Manifestation of the Orthodox, the Awakening Transformation,
The Emperor Lord Who Protects and Assists, the Wondrous Dao’s Promulgator,
The Heavenly Worthy of Universal Salvation, the Perfectly Illumined, the Free and Unfettered,
The True Buddha of Culture and Wisdom.

**Mystic Essence Incantation of the Scripture’s Opening:**
The Qi’s womb is without limit,
Primordial before heaven and earth.
Embracing creation in empty profundity,
Reverently awaiting the divine luminaries.
The moon emits the white-rayed mark,
Clouds return to the vermilion gate.
The celestial river follows the turning of fortune,
The imperial carriage does not tarry.
Virtue harmonizes with the Three Origins’ principle,
Merit transmits the Nine Sons’ numinosity.
Majestic are the true parents,
Luxuriant is the ancient scripture’s text.
The supreme Dao encompasses the profound and wondrous,
The true person embodies utmost sincerity.
With devout heart, one may move and align,
For myriad ages, inscribing longevity.

**The Primordial Divine Empress, the Dipper Mother, the Supreme Dao’s Nine Sovereigns’ True Scripture**

At that time, the Primordial Dao Empress, the Dipper Mother, Supreme Sovereign, dwelled within the Dipper Pivot Palace of the Qi’s Brahmā Heaven, together with the Heavenly Dipper Father, the King Who Rules the Zhou. Together, they gazed down upon the world below, where there was a true person, surnamed Zhang, named Tong, with the Daoist name Kunyang, who was the incarnation of the Nine Sovereigns’ fifth, the Celestial Bird. He cultivated the Dao during the transition between the Northern Yuan and Southern Ming, dwelling on Mount Emei’s Fufuquan, reverently worshipping the Dipper and awaiting the imperial summons for ascension. The Dipper Mother, moved by his sincere heart, turned the jade pivot, and with a sudden sound, manifested her luminous and wondrous form. Riding a chariot drawn by seven boars, she descended into the true person’s Dipper-worshipping altar within the span of a single double-hour. She wove clouds of radiance and suspended a precious throne, whereupon she expounded this *Nine Sovereigns’ True Scripture*.

The true person bowed deeply, prostrating himself before the throne. Then the Dipper Mother addressed the true person, saying: “Rise, and I shall speak to you. I am Molizhitian, the Myriad Sunlit Vastness. Before the Heavenly Sovereign, I had already emerged; before the Earthly Sovereign, I dwelled in the Western Continent’s Tianzhu, wielding great divine efficacy and traversing India. Later, I saw the Zhou King of the Northern Continent, Yudan Yue, who was devoted to the stellar sacrifices, kind-hearted and fond of goodness. Thus, I went to assist him. Seeking pure land, I built walls and gates, holding the scriptures of the Wuji Palace, truly nurturing the golden womb’s chamber. A single mass of divine qi, thrice transcending, gave birth to nine sacred heirs. The eldest was Tianying, the Human Sovereign, who later ascended as the Jade Perfected Immortal; the second was Tianren, the third Tianzhu, the fourth Tianxin, the fifth Tianqin, the sixth Tianfu, the seventh Tianchong, the eighth Tianrui, and the ninth Tianpeng—jewel forests and jade blossoms, towering and resplendent. These are the Nine Sons, their royal title the Nine Sovereigns. The Human Sovereign and his brothers divided and ruled the nine provinces, known as the Fang Clan, their benevolent influence vast and far-reaching, universally benefiting all beings. The Nine Sovereigns ascended, mother and sons dwelling together. The Primordial Beginning named me the Primordial Dao Empress, commending my virtue of nurturing the Nine Sovereigns. The Great Equalizer is in my grasp, and I hold the Dipper’s pivot. The Nine Sovereigns ascend to illuminate the nine stars, and the nine stars encircle the single enclosure. Relying on the wondrousness of the single qi, I further transformed the Seven Primordials. The Nine Celestial Bodies may descend into the world, while the Seven Primordials alternate in their revolutions.”

The Dipper Mother said: “If in the world there are those who cultivate virtue and practice the Dao, who reverently inquire about the Nine Sovereigns’ governance and the Seven Primordials’ alternation, simply expound to them the Northern Dipper’s arrayed stars, and all they govern may be known. The Dipper is the celestial chariot, revolving at the center, overseeing the eight directions, harmonizing yin and yang. It establishes the four seasons, harmonizes the five phases, determines the various records, shifts the nodal measures—all depend upon the Dipper. The first is Tian Shu, governing yang virtue; the second is Tian Xuan, governing yin punishment; the third is Tian Ji, governing fortune and goodness; the fourth is Tian Quan, governing misfortune and evil; the fifth is Yu Heng, governing life and death; the sixth is Kai Yang, governing the hundred grains; the seventh is Yao Guang, governing the six armies. The eighth, to the left of Kai Yang, is named the Auxiliary Star; the ninth, to the right of Yao Guang, is named the Minister Star—both assist the Dipper in accomplishing its work.”

Thus, the titles of the Nine August Stellar Lords of the Great Sage Northern Dipper are proclaimed:

First, the Yang Virtue Star Lord Cānláng of the Great Sage Northern Dipper’s Nine August Ones;
Second, the Yin Punishment Star Lord Jùmén of the Great Sage Northern Dipper’s Nine August Ones;
Third, the Fortune-and-Goodness Star Lord Lùcún of the Great Sage Northern Dipper’s Nine August Ones;
Fourth, the Evil-Eradicating Star Lord Wénqǔ of the Great Sage Northern Dipper’s Nine August Ones;
Fifth, the Life-and-Death Star Lord Liánzhēn of the Great Sage Northern Dipper’s Nine August Ones;
Sixth, the Grain-Nurturing Star Lord Wǔqǔ of the Great Sage Northern Dipper’s Nine August Ones;
Seventh, the Armies-Commanding Star Lord Pòjūn of the Great Sage Northern Dipper’s Nine August Ones;
Eighth, the Left Auxiliary Star Lord Dòngmíng of the Great Sage Northern Dipper’s Nine August Ones;
Ninth, the Right Minister Star Lord Yǐnguāng of the Great Sage Northern Dipper’s Nine August Ones.

Such are the names and titles of these Stellar Lords, resplendent in celestial patterns. They hold the registers of life’s extension and death’s inscription, wielding authority over fortune, goodness, misfortune, and excess. Emperors and feudal lords, high ministers and common folk—all living beings belong to the Dipper’s palace.

Should any good man or good woman, afflicted by old age or illness, endure manifold sufferings, but repent their transgressions to dissolve faults, sincerely pay homage to the Dipper, recite these teachings of the Great Dao, and kindle the Nine August Divine Lamps to illuminate their life’s palace, they shall naturally turn misfortune into fortune, transform emolument into auspiciousness. The efficacies thereof are beyond full recounting.

The Dipper Mother declares: “The revolutions of the Northern Dipper depend upon the Seven Primes’ cycles of return. Its body is the Qian within Kun, its nature is firmness within softness. The Dao unfolds in the subtlety within subtlety, its qi derives from the yang within yang. At the end of the Qin, it manifested in the Western Han, appearing in person to expound the Dharma, converting the High Emperor.

Should any devotee seeking blessings wish to behold the august forms of the Seven Prime Golden Immortals, they must first sweep away worldly thoughts, purify the mind’s source, bow in reverence, and meditate with closed eyes. As celestial music floats in the void, the golden countenance shall appear of itself, the golden body shall reveal itself spontaneously—resembling the goddess Māgū, resembling the Lady of the Upper Prime. With the heroic qi of a woman, she compassionately delivers all beings. When the Seven Prime Lords ascend and descend in the central courtyard, all evil spirits retreat in haste, and a hundred blessings arrive in close succession.”

Thereupon, the *Incantation of the Northern Dipper’s Seven Primes for Resolving Calamities and Manifesting Efficacy* is proclaimed:

The Great Sage Northern Dipper’s Seven Prime Lords resolve the calamity of one’s person;
The Great Sage Northern Dipper’s Seven Prime Lords resolve the calamity of the two illnesses;
The Great Sage Northern Dipper’s Seven Prime Lords resolve the calamity of the three corpses;
The Great Sage Northern Dipper’s Seven Prime Lords resolve the calamity of the four slaughters;
The Great Sage Northern Dipper’s Seven Prime Lords resolve the calamity of the five thieves;
The Great Sage Northern Dipper’s Seven Prime Lords resolve the calamity of the six excesses;
The Great Sage Northern Dipper’s Seven Prime Lords resolve the calamity of the seven injuries;
The Great Sage Northern Dipper’s Seven Prime Lords resolve the calamity of the eight difficulties;
The Great Sage Northern Dipper’s Seven Prime Lords resolve the calamity of the nine perversities;
The Great Sage Northern Dipper’s Seven Prime Lords resolve the calamity of the ten demons.

August are the Seven Prime Lords! Blessings extend to the faithful and good.
All illnesses they resolve; impermanence dares not encroach.

Divine in healing sickness, responsive as echoes through the valley;
To behold the radiant image, burn incense and await the moon’s rising.

The Dipper Mother declares: “The Seven Primes cycle and return; again we await the Nine August Ones’ homecoming.
Those who reverence the Seven Primes may be enabled to repel death and prolong life;
Those who reverence the Nine August Ones may further attain immortality and Buddhahood.
Should there be virtuous men and women who first pay homage to the Seven Prime Lofty Perfected, then to the Nine August Great Sages,
their dwellings and abodes shall surely know sweet dew descending and nectarous springs arising—
scoop and drink thereof, and they shall return to youth from old age, golden light enveloping their bodies.
Again, before the altar of the Nine August Ones, a full cycle of offerings made, nine years of practice upheld,
merit perfected and conduct fulfilled, they shall mount the crane and ascend into the void.
Such are the blessed rewards of revering the Dipper.”

Thereupon, the *Incantation of the Northern Dipper’s Nine August Ones’ Efficacy* is proclaimed:

The Great Sage Northern Dipper’s Nine August Lords resolve all calamities;
The Great Sage Northern Dipper’s Nine August Lords resolve the calamity of the Two Luminaries;
The Great Sage Northern Dipper’s Nine August Lords resolve the calamity of the Three Disasters;
The Great Sage Northern Dipper’s Nine August Lords resolve the calamity of the Four Conditions;
The Great Sage Northern Dipper’s Nine August Lords resolve the calamity of the Five Aggregates;
The Great Sage Northern Dipper’s Nine August Lords resolve the calamity of the Six Dusts;
The Great Sage Northern Dipper’s Nine August Lords resolve the calamity of the Seven Slaughters;
The Great Sage Northern Dipper’s Nine August Lords resolve the calamity of the Eight Winds;
The Great Sage Northern Dipper’s Nine August Lords resolve the calamity of the Nine Dark Realms;
The Great Sage Northern Dipper’s Nine August Lords resolve the calamity of the Ten Entanglements.

August are the Nine August Lords! Their grace illumines the nine regions.
Bodies free of obstacles and misfortune, forms neither born nor extinguished,
They come and go diligently to deliver the world, traversing heaven and earth in spring’s universal bloom.
The Dao’s methods know no bounds; auspicious clouds shelter the Perfected Ones on high.

The Dipper Mother further addressed the Perfected One, saying:
“The Seven Primes and Nine August Lords all arise from the continuity of my primordial qi. In the movement and stillness of this single qi, the alternation of yin and yang, the waxing and waning of the moon, the succession of day and night, dawn and dusk—all take their lead from it. In the transformative power of this single qi, the Five Phases and Eight Trigrams, the numerology of the River Chart and Luo Writing, the Changes—all are encompassed within it. Years, months, days, and hours; Heavenly Stems and Earthly Branches; east, west, south, and north; mountains, rivers, seas, and peaks; birth from egg, womb, moisture, or transformation—none exist apart from the presence of this single qi. Vast, it embraces all; subtle, it penetrates all. Those who trust in it live; those who turn from it die. Those who follow it flourish; those who defy it perish. The great multitudes of the Three Teachings should all know this.

You were originally the Fifth Celestial Creature of the Nine August Lords, descended to the world below. Do not rely on past causes alone, but act in the present. If you cultivate now, past causes may be renewed. When the work of seven nines is complete, you will approach the sacred realm. Thus, I expound this scripture, entitled *The Primordial Qi Nine August Lords Perfected Scripture*. What I speak, you shall transmit—this is most intimate and direct.

Wherever this scripture resides, ten thousand spirits guard it, a thousand sages praise it, the Three Primes are outlined within it, and a single qi connects all. Those who study this scripture diligently will transcend life and death; those who study it diligently will comprehend the profound causes. Treasure and transmit it, but do not show it to the unworthy.”

As the Dipper Mother neared the end of her discourse, the celestial immortals and stellar hosts came to welcome her, returning to the Dipper Palace. Thereupon, the Perfected One, having received the wondrous Dharma, addressed the Dipper Mother, saying: “I now vow to propagate it widely, transmitting it to the virtuous. If there are men or women who receive, uphold, and recite it, I, together with the immortals and officials of the Dipper, shall protect them wherever they may be.”

Then, bowing again to the Dipper Mother, he offered this eulogy:

Where the *Scripture of the Nine Sovereigns* resides,
One’s natal star descends with true numen.
Where the *Scripture of the Nine Sovereigns* resides,
Parents are preserved in long life.
Where the *Scripture of the Nine Sovereigns* resides,
The seven ancestors all ascend in transcendence.
Where the *Scripture of the Nine Sovereigns* resides,
The nine lineages of descendants also attain perfection.
Where the *Scripture of the Nine Sovereigns* resides,
All malevolent forces dissolve into dust.
Where the *Scripture of the Nine Sovereigns* resides,
The ten thousand deviations naturally return to rectitude.
Where the *Scripture of the Nine Sovereigns* resides,
All evils forever vanish and clear.
Where the *Scripture of the Nine Sovereigns* resides,
The ten clans spontaneously flourish in glory.
Where the *Scripture of the Nine Sovereigns* resides,
One perpetually safeguards harmony, benefit, and integrity.

The Dipper Mother said: “Excellent, excellent! You may propagate the true teaching; its merit is boundless. Guide and lead later generations to cultivate together the fruits of the Dao.”

The Perfected One bowed his head in reverence, giving thanks, and received the teaching with faith, vowing to uphold and practice it.

The Primordial Divine Dipper Mother, Supreme Dao of the Nine Sovereign Perfected Ones

The Primordial Pure Yang Lord, the Protector Emperor, said: “Formerly, I expounded the *Chapter on Gazing at the Stars and Revering the Dipper* to the Three Great Assemblies of Han San, for the transmitted Dipper rituals of the world consist only of rites of veneration, lacking esoteric secrets. Now, beholding the *Scripture of the Nine Sovereigns* spoken by the Supreme Dipper Mother and the Perfected Lord of Kunyang, which unifies the great Dao of the Three Origins and illumines the numinous communion of the single qi, it is fully commensurate with the *Five Dipper Scriptures of the Most High*, preceding and following in equal measure. Superior practitioners who cultivate it will surely transcend the mundane and enter sagehood; middling practitioners who awaken to it will also perceive their nature and illumine their minds.”

May all beings across the Three Thousand Great Thousand Worlds, through a hundred generations and ten thousand ages, take refuge and revere this teaching—boundless shall be their merit and virtue.

Now, for those who perform the Dipper rites, I shall set forth the procedures in clear order. All who practice the *Scripture of the Nine Sovereigns* must first purify their ritual chamber, still their breath, and sever worldly attachments. Facing north, they bow in reverence, stand with hands clasped in auspicious reverence, as though the Celestial Countenance of the Dipper Mother has descended above, and as though a thousand perfected ones and ten thousand sages encircle them. Only then do they perform the Dipper veneration with utmost sincerity.

The body must be poised, the heart upright, the spirit settled, the mind discerning, the qi harmonious, and the voice even. Ascents and descents follow proper measure, advances and retreats observe refined form, movements and pauses adhere to ritual, and rises and prostrations maintain due proportion. First, they pay homage to the august titles; next, they recite the true scripture. Upon completing the recitation and rites, they then chant the two Dipper incantations.

Though I am not wise, I have privately examined the *Daoist Canon* and the *Buddhist Canon* and learned that the Sanskrit names of the Dipper Mother number over several dozen—too many for practitioners to recite in full. Here, I shall select the most concise and efficacious from the canon’s records and proclaim them for all virtuous adepts.

The *Dipper Mother’s Heart Mantra* states:

"Namo ratna-trayāya, tara yathā, tadyathā: akāṣa-maṣi, makā-maṣi, adū-maṣi, pūrvapāla-maṣi, mahā-pūrvapāla-maṣi, adanta, namo maṣi-māli, pūrya-maṣi. Namo suddhe, ra kṣa, ra kṣa svāhā, svā-satva-nandā svāhā, svā-tāra svāhā, svā-supūrṇa, vi-viyākṣa svāhā. Namo samanta, mudana, oṃ māli-je svāhā."

*Phonetic rendering:*
Namo laidan-na, dola-ye-ye, dani-yetuo, ajia-moxi, mojia-moxi, adu-moxi, bupolai-moxi, moha-bupolai-moxi. Adantuona, namoxi-moli, buyemo-xi, namo suidudi, laiqicha, laiqicha-mousa, wasadan-walanzuosuo, wadanlaisa, wasazibunala, feipiyao-sawaha. Namo sanmanda, muduonan, anmali-ji, mangsuohe.

Again, proclaim the *Northern Dipper Heart Mantra*:
"Oṃ, na, xī-xī-na, luó-luó-na, jié-dá-na, jié-na, na, na, oṃ, hūṃ, hūṃ, hūṃ, zhī-dì, shē-sū-zhà, ā-ruò-mì-zhà, wū-dū-zhà, shì-zhà, bō-tí-zhà, wēi-ruò-zhà, jù-luó-tí-zhà, shì-mó-zhà, sà svāhā."

*Phonetic rendering:*
Oṃ, goudina, jiji-na, luolou-na, xida-na, zhixi-na, batou-na, baye-na, oṃ, hūṃ, hūṃ, hūṃ-niàn-he, jùzhī-dì, shē-sū-zhā, ā-rě-mì-zhā, wū-dū-zhà, jù-qí-zhā, bō-lài-dì-zhā, yē-wēi-rě-zhā, jù-luó-dì-zhā, qí-mó-zhā, sà-pó-hē.

After the Pure Yang Imperial Lord proclaimed the Dipper incantations, the Perfected One bowed a hundred times and kowtowed, then offered this unifying eulogy:

"Atop Fortune Spring Peak, in the third watch of an autumn moon,
The vast sky stretches, deep blue, immaculate and dustless.
The Heavenly Mother’s compassionate heart
Responds and descends to the mountain pavilion.
Before the Dharma-expounding terrace, immortal blossoms gleam bright and fragrant—
In a flash, the moment arrives even now.
The Protector Imperial Lord
Recites the incantation to supplement the true scripture.
With great compassion and great vows,
The Heavenly Mother, too, rejoices."

To the Primordial Divine Marshal, Marīci Bodhisattva, Dipper Mother, Supreme Primordial Honored One—ninefold homage.
May this merit
Pervade all beings without exception.
Having now received and upheld it,
May its radiance be transmitted through ten thousand kalpas.

The *Three Sacred and Wondrous True Scriptures of the Former Three Teachings*—their three divisions—are penned in imitation of the *Huangting*. Their words fundamentally exhort one to revere the divine and sagely with utmost devotion, yet within them the Dao of the Golden Elixir is also fully contained. Both their form and meaning may be reverently upheld. Though I dared not presume to add even a single word of praise, having received them directly from my master’s hand and been commanded to annotate them forthwith, I withdrew and composed these notes.

**Preface to the Exegesis:**
*Former* refers to that which precedes the Great Ultimate. *Three Teachings* denotes the transmissions of *establishing life*, *completing life*, and *returning to life*. *Supreme Sages* is a metaphor for the highest-grade Golden Elixir. *Spiritual* compares to the primordial Yuan Spirit, most subtle and unfathomable. *Wondrous* encompasses the youngest maiden of the Dui trigram, who receives the yang radiance of the Zhen trigram’s youth. *True Scripture* is none other than true lead. Formerly, the Shangyang Perfected One annotated the *Most Wondrous Scripture of the Supreme Lord for the Salvation of All*, and composed a prefatory verse:

*"The Supreme Lord’s auspicious abode lies before the Great Ultimate,
Even prior to the time before parents gave birth.
To save others is to save oneself—this true scripture saves,
And if you ask what the true scripture is, it is gui, which is lead."*

I, too, offer this same verse for this preface.

**Eulogy to the Opening of the Scripture by the Protector Imperial Lord:**
The primordial ancestral qi,
Silent, profound.
The zither plucks Dharma tones,
The flute plays immortal melodies—
Incense and blossoms fill the chamber like a jade grove.
Within the inner sanctum, deep and still,
The three supreme honored ones descend in their sacred presence.

The primordial ancestral qi is the great medicine.
*Silent, profound* describes the time before division.
The *zither* symbolizes the attainment of harmony.
The *flute* symbolizes regulated breathing, and also the void.
The line on *incense and blossoms* compares to lead blossoms emerging from the crucible.
The final two lines truly indicate a state utterly unstained, where utmost sincerity moves the divine.

A single gatha reveals the essence of the entire scripture.

At that time, the Cavernous Mystery’s Perfected Immortal Zhang,
With a dragon-coiling brush, expounded the true scripture.
The scripture declares: The three teachings’ ancient sages,
Whose Dao towers above ten thousand generations, receive luminous offerings.

In the Eastern Zhou, the Unadorned King was born on Mount Ni—
On the full moon of winter’s month, in Changping,
When the Zhou calendar fixed the first month at *zi*,
Winter’s month belonging to *xu*—now corresponding to the fifteenth day of the ninth month.

In the West, the body of Siddhārtha Gautama—
On the eighth day of the fourth month, in the city of Wei,
When the Shang king fixed the first month at *chou*,
The fourth month belonging to *chen*—now corresponding to the eighth day of the third month.

The Supreme Lord of the ten directions and three realms—
On the fifteenth day of the second month, descending in Chengling,
When the Shang king fixed the first month at *chou*,
The second month belonging to *yin*—now corresponding to the fifteenth day of the first month.

For thousands and hundreds of kalpas, the great potter’s wheel turns,
And primordial qi abounds, casting forth sagely heroes.
In heaven above and earth below, these three honored ones,
Through boundless kalpas, are known to all.

At that time—*er shi*—"that" being the counterpart to "this," and "time" the moment when yang arises. The Great Dao of Former Heaven all emerges from this very moment, which is why true scriptures often begin with these words.

The Patriarch expounded the *Dongming Jing*, ranking it among the "Caverns and Mysteries." *Dong* means "pervading all without obstruction," and *xuan* means "penetrating its subtleties." Now he expounds this *Lingmiao Zhenjing*, which encompasses the Great Elixir of Golden Cinnabar. The *qiu* belongs to yin, the dragon to yang; when yin and yang converge beneath the brush, the Great Dao issues forth from the true scripture.

The scripture states that after the ancient sages emerged into the world and attained the Dao, they received offerings of bright sacrifice for ten thousand generations, exhorting later disciples to reverently bow before the sages and earnestly seek the Golden Elixir. Yet these three supreme sages were born on different days, which suggests that the medicine of Former Heaven and the *huozi* hour cannot be rigidly fixed.

The sages must wait for the great potter’s wheel to turn for thousands and hundreds of kalpas, until primordial *qi* is abundant, before their numinous spirits are nurtured—just as in the way of the Golden Elixir, one must surpass five thousand forty-eight days before the golden *qi* is full and the watery tide arises.

Above heaven and earth, only these three sages are most revered; within the body, only golden lead is most precious. Through boundless kalpas, their names are known to all, and after attaining the Elixir, one endures through eons without decay.

Now I expound these three sacred scriptures—water has its depths, trees have their roots. May people embody the grace of these three sages, and on their birthdays, express sincere devotion. No need for ritual vessels as in the court, no need for repentance assemblies with resounding conches. Only maintain fasting and solemnity, straighten your cap and sash, sweep the pure chamber clean of the slightest dust. In the empty, silent room, light a silver lamp; incense smoke spirals in a single wisp of clarity. Water, fruit, and tea flowers—pure and fragrant—bow humbly in reverence, awaiting the cloud chariot.

May the Primordial be preserved in its harmony and uprightness; may greed, delusion, desire, and anger be severed. May the five thousand characters of the *Daode* be studied; may the three teachings be practiced to wander in eternal spring. With a single thought of true inquiry, the mind is not scattered, and great blessings descend without delay.

The three sages govern the myriad spirits of the ten thousand scriptures—who can obstruct the bestowal of fortune and longevity upon me? The Patriarch, in reverence for the sages, expounds the true scriptures; thus, to honor the true scriptures is to honor the sages themselves.

The primordial unity of *qi* emerges from emptiness and nothingness, seemingly unfathomable in its source. Yet who knows that yang is born within *gui*, truly like water having its source and trees their roots? May people bear in mind the grace of this origin. When the true unity of *qi* arrives, they must express sincere devotion to welcome it, just as when encountering the sages’ birthdays.

The *Cantong Qi* says: *"With utmost sincerity and focused density, carefully await the celestial signs."* The noble person values this Dao, leaving ritual vessels and repentance assemblies to the keepers of such affairs—monks and Daoists. I only purify my heart, solemnize my spirit, enter the chamber, approach the furnace, straighten my cap and sash, and wait.

Take the Yellow Chamber as the pure abode, the Mysterious Pass as the empty room; sweep away every speck of dust, empty all thoughts. Golden and silver light appears, as if bright lamps. The silver lamp is a metaphor for the lead cauldron; a single wisp of clear incense is the first stirring of yang *qi*. Water, fruit, and tea flowers are metaphors for the medicinal substances of the Buddhist tradition.

At that time, the water’s source is utterly pure, the jade bud just blossoming—how could it not be pure and fragrant? The *Cantong Qi* says: *"The true person is most subtle, as if present, as if absent."* At that time, one must bow humbly, listen attentively, and watch closely; only then will the cloud chariot of the true person arrive. Await the true person as one awaits the sages.

*Ganyuan hengli zhen*—like the gathering of the five phases. Greed, delusion, desire, and anger must be utterly untethered. The five thousand words of the *Daode* expound this true and constant Dao. Weighing the teachings of the three traditions, one may then employ their great efficacy. Attaining it in an instant, one eternally preserves eternal spring—hence, *"a single thought of true inquiry, and great blessings descend."* "Without delay" means the Yang Elixir is formed in a moment.

The three families gather in the Central Palace, and the myriad spirits all heed their command—thus, *"governing the ten thousand scriptures."* Fortune and longevity depend entirely on the spirit of awareness within the primordial body—who dares obstruct it?

If you regard the true scripture as true gold, it surpasses worldly lead and silver. With utmost sincerity and focused density, cherish this rare treasure, and your household will surely not remain impoverished. It moistens the body and the house, enriching metal and wood; dwelling in peace and ease, joy knows no bounds. Not only does it reduce illness and prolong life, but it also establishes destiny and completes the horn.

In darkness, the black register of the netherworld is erased; in one’s steps, auspicious omens arise like mist. Before you, the great gate of destiny unfolds; after death, worthy jade-like descendants are nurtured. Accumulating merit and virtue harmonizes neighbors; virtue spreads through the village, transforming it into benevolence.

After a hundred years, the cicada sheds its shell to return to the Jade Capital; crimson clouds escort one to ascend the Heavenly Gate. The true scripture is true gold—the Patriarch here makes this clear. True gold is the treasure of long life; how can it be compared to common lead or silver?

Only with utmost sincerity and focused density, treasuring it as a rare jewel, will true gold return to the dwelling, filling the hall with yellow and white. How could one then lament poverty? Moistening the house and body, dwelling in peace and ease—all describe the coagulation of the Elixir’s head, the true *qi* embraced within.

Once the Yang Elixir is attained, it is not merely like refining the self and laying the foundation, merely reducing illness and prolonging life. It directly establishes destiny and completes the horn, ensuring long life and enduring vision. At that time, one’s name is inscribed in the immortal ranks, and the black register is erased—*"the dust of sin and the world is wiped away in a single stroke."*

In one’s steps, all is serene and tranquil; the great gate of destiny unfolds. The Elixir Furnace becomes the abode of immortals. Then, with the mother *qi* of the Yang Elixir subduing and the child *qi* of the Yin Elixir refined into the ninefold return of golden liquid, and further with the transmutation of the cauldron and the separation of the embryo, each golden brother and jade sibling will ride the crane.

Thus, concealing or revealing oneself among mortals, one accumulates merit and piles up virtuous deeds, first delivering oneself and then delivering others. When the celestial mandate arrives, one ascends in broad daylight—crimson clouds will gather in escort, and the gates of heaven open. Those of superior root and Dao-instrument must embody the scriptural principles and put them into practice to attain this. Do not suppose that merely reciting them with the mouth for a lifetime can lead to immortality.

Never meet a sacred birth with indifference, nor vent anger and spew harsh words. Indulgence in lust and licentiousness within the chamber will invite the celestial spirits to investigate and strip away what remains. In ordinary times, reverence for the sacred must be utmost and sincere; at this moment, one should be even more deeply cautious. If at this instant there is no inclination to prostrate in devotion, one may infer the habitual state of the heart.

When encountering a sacred birth, one must pay the utmost attention. At the time when Yang is born, one must concentrate the mind. If one still harbors anger, vents malice, or clings to lust for sensual pleasures, true *qi* will inevitably scatter. Not only does this harm oneself, but the celestial spirits, in their scrutiny, will also deprive one of years of life.

Awaiting the moment to refine the self requires utmost sincerity. When entering the chamber and approaching the Elixir Furnace, one must be even more deeply cautious. If one lacks solemn reverence in seeking Lead, then in ordinary refinement of the self, one may also infer a lack of purity.

This passage repeatedly admonishes, its meaning crystal clear. I wish for all to reverently uphold and follow it, purifying the heart and cleansing the mind until the solitary resolve is pure. Though unseen and unheard, the Three Sages ride the crimson clouds in solemn presence. The majestic demeanor of Confucius shines like the rising sun; the dharma-form of Śākyamuni is round like the autumn moon. The purple *qi* of the Pass streams forth in profusion, inspiring awe and vigilance in those who behold it. Gazing up at the lofty mountain with ever-deepening reverence, scholars and commoners alike are no longer of the mundane world.

Those who revere the sacred must express utmost devotion. Those who seek Lead must maintain profound stillness, purify the heart, cleanse the mind, and unify the resolve to observe its return. Purity and impurity stand in opposition; only with pure sincerity in seeking the Elixir can one succeed. Generally, when *qi* is settled and spirit is concentrated, purity arises; when emotions prevail, impurity follows. Seeking Lead in accordance with the proper timing is purity; acting recklessly out of season is impurity.

Moreover, the *qi* of prior heaven is deep and silent, without sound or shadow, unseen and unheard. Only by humbly restraining one’s seeing and hearing can one come to perceive and hear as if truly present. Beholding the sages riding the clouds is like witnessing the true person emerging from the cauldron. What the master calls *"a single red flower"* is the utmost truth.

Like the rising sun—newly manifested Yang light, the evening of the third day. Like the autumn moon—abundant Metal and Water, the night of the fifteenth. Like the purple *qi*—true *qi* surging, the fire of the Mysterious Pass igniting.

The Elixir school speaks of the third day and also of the fifteenth: the third symbolizes the newness of the *qi* of Metal and Water, the fifteenth its fullness. If the *qi* is insufficient, Water will not be born. The third and fifteenth must be viewed as one continuous moment, conceived as a single strand—one cannot calculate them by counting numbers. If one calculates by numbers, how can it be called the living *zi* hour?

Within the third is contained the fifteenth. On the third, the medicine is two parts tender; on the fifteenth, the Yang *qi* is pure and complete. As the *Huangting Jing* says: *"The three and five unite in harmony with the ninefold nodes."* At this time, when the fire is applied, there appears the image of purple *qi* entering the Pass. Otherwise, if even a moment is delayed, it falls into posterior heaven, and the Yang Elixir will be difficult to complete. Therefore, one must gaze vigilantly, never missing the moment of interaction.

Gazing up at the lofty mountain is what is meant by *"the mountain of form faces and welcomes the true person."* Those of the Elixir school who understand this, though they be scholars or commoners, transcend the mundane. The mechanism of entering sagehood lies in this single decisive effort—how can one not take this matter seriously?

The master’s oral instructions are fully revealed here for the benefit of fellow seekers.

In the Central Heaven, a rain of flowers pervades the cosmos; before the Dharma-throne, the atmosphere is renewed. Mountains, rivers, and the great earth radiate light; in the Lotus Society, flowers bloom in a spring of white snow. The Celestial Emperor, moved by compassion, expounds the true scripture and dispatches divine attendants to guard the *bing*-*ding*. On this day and night, the moon emerges in the *geng* direction; its clear radiance shines upon the empty and perilous stars. From the azure vault, the faint sound of flutes and reed pipes is heard; the incense-bearing devotee gazes into the void in welcome.

The scripture is honored as the host, the self as the guest. From this point on, through cultivation, one resolves inauspicious influences. The Central Heaven is likened to the realm of emptiness and nothingness. The rain of flowers symbolizes the birth of Metal and Water. The wondrous union of emptiness and nothingness with heaven and earth—within it lies the cauldron and furnace, the celestial stars and earthly tides, just as they pervade the cosmos.

The Dharma-throne is the place of Elixir refinement. What is the atmosphere before the throne? The *Niwan* says: *"Mountains, rivers, and the great earth burst into fierce fire."* Zhang Guo says: *"Upon opening the furnace, one already perceives the radiance."* Such is the atmosphere before the throne. The lotus society’s flowers bloom in a spring of white snow—the Lead flower appears as white as snowflakes.

The Celestial Emperor symbolizes the lord of the heart. Loving true gold, one employs the fire of spirit to refine it. As the *Wuzhen Pian* says: *"Further relying on Ding Gong’s forging."* On this day and evening, precisely when the moon emerges in the *geng* direction, though it marks the time of expounding the scripture, it also signifies the time of seeking gold. The clear light shines forth, illuminating the cavern of the empty and perilous stars; the flutes and reed pipes of the azure vault resemble the scene of Mercury welcoming Lead in joyous union. The incense-bearing devotee is none other than the cultivator of the Elixir. I visit their home, yet they become the host and I the guest—host and guest float and sink, self and other are inverted. This is the wondrous method of seeking the Elixir.

From this point on, through cultivation, one obtains the Elixir and enters the cauldron, where Yin diminishes and Yang flourishes, resolving inauspicious influences.

When heaven and earth are not in harmony, recite the true scripture, and wind, thunder, rain, and clearing will arrive in due season. When the solar terms are not in harmony, recite the true scripture, and spring, autumn, winter, and summer will be properly aligned. When the nation is not at peace, recite the true scripture, and the four directions will rejoice in prosperity. When the people and creatures are not at ease, recite the true scripture, and the mountains, corners, and watery marshes will all be joyful. When the nine dark realms and nine hells hear the true scripture, stagnant souls and departed spirits may be delivered.

In renowned mountains and sacred cloisters, the true scripture is concealed,
To guide Daoist adepts and lead eminent monks.

*Recitation* refers to cultivation.
Heaven and earth are likened to the body.
When the body’s movements are erratic,
Storms rage, winds howl, Kan and Li flee in chaos,
Thunder crashes, dew chills—men and women grow frantic.
To ensure the harmonious unfolding of wind, thunder, rain, and dew,
One must diligently cultivate the true scripture.

The *solar terms* denote the four seasons.
When the governance of the four seasons falters,
Spring’s *mao* and autumn’s *you* deviate from their baths,
Winter’s heat and summer’s frost invert Yin and Yang.
To align spring, summer, autumn, and winter in proper order,
One must diligently cultivate the true scripture.

The *nation* is likened to the foundation of the Elixir.
When the true scripture ensures safety,
The four directions—east, south, west, and north—rejoice together.
*People and creatures* also mirror the foundation of the Elixir.
When the true scripture brings tranquility,
Mountains, corners, and watery marshes all exult.
As for the dark realms and departed spirits—all Yin and perverse—
The true scripture causes Yin to retreat.

In mountain cloisters, where Daoists and monks embody half of Yang,
The true scripture enables them to attain full Yang.
The wondrous essence of the true scripture unfolds layer by layer,
And its foremost importance lies in the sacred birth.
Even a fleeting moment of faith brings glory—
How much more so if one preserves it to ascend the highest vehicle?
A thousand auspicious signs defy full enumeration,
Yet to fathom the jade casket is to draw near Penglai’s isles.

Solemnly expounded, the *Scripture of Numinous Wonders*,
By the Master of Cavernous Mystery, the Heavenly Master’s descendant.
Layer upon layer of wondrous essence,
Here synthesized from prior metaphors to conclude.
People, creatures, nations, solar terms, and heaven and earth—
All encompass the stages of laying the foundation, refining the self,
Gathering the medicine, and harmonizing the Elixir.
Yet this true scripture centers solely on the great matter of the Golden Elixir,
Thus it begins with the sacred birth, likening it to the primordial generation of the Golden Elixir.
By capturing the true Yin and true Yang—eightfold and of the same kind—
In a single moment, refining them into a single Yang Elixir,
Its transformation occurs in an instant.
If one can trust and embrace it even for a fleeting moment,
That moment will shine with brilliance.
How much more so if one preserves it without loss,
Combining the Yang Elixir with the Yin Elixir
To refine the ninefold return of golden liquid—
Would this not be ascending the highest vehicle?
Once the nine returns are accomplished, a thousand auspicious signs gather.
If one penetrates the jade casket’s depths,
The Isles of Penglai lie not far away.

Who but the Master of Cavernous Mystery could expound this scripture,
Revealing its numinous wonders?
And who is this Master?
The Heavenly Master’s descendant, Ancestor Zhang Sanfeng.
Only a true master can discourse on the true Dao—
How could this be lightly spoken?

Within the *True Scripture of the Three Teachings’ Great Sage, Numinous Response*,
The metaphor speaks of the work of external alchemy returning to internal nature,
Gold merging with essence.
The *Three Teachings* symbolize the paths of nurturing, perceiving, and restoring nature,
Unified in meaning with the prior three teachings.
The *Great Sage* signifies the great return.
*Numinous* refers to the single grain of the numinous Elixir.
*Response* signifies inner and outer resonance.
The *true scripture* is the golden liquid.

**Hymn of Opening the Scripture by Lord Fuyou**
Nectar pours upon the crown, rich and fragrant.
The dharma platform swept clean, flower rains fill the sky,
White clouds part to reveal the clear peaks.
A gentle breeze pervades the courtyard,
From afar, the three sacred visages appear.
The opening verse already reveals this scripture’s theme:
The great return of golden liquid—no further annotation is needed.

The Cavernous Mystery Perfected One, Immortal Zhang,
Transmitted the *Scripture of Numinous Response* beneath the azure heavens.
The Dao has three sages, centered in their positions,
First initiating, then following—teachings flourish in resonance.
One sage in Zouyi, east of Yanzhou,
One on Potala’s peak, where the tide’s sound falls,
One as Lord Guan, who inaugurated the mystic wind—
The Dao spread through China and the barbarian lands.

The three central sages descended from the celestial palace,
Their grace vast and flowing like a boundless tide.
Gathering righteousness to invigorate the spirit,
Who could mold such utter greatness and firmness?
Responding to cries with boundless compassion,
Saving the suffering, reviving the dust-veiled.
Master Wen Shi moves like a soaring dragon,
Leading the host of immortals in transformative work.

The three sages’ numinous radiance, infused with celestial qi,
Stems from years of learning and cultivation.
The great man upholds lofty aspirations, refining the Confucian demeanor,
Dwelling in benevolence, acting by righteousness—transcending the multitude.
Guanyin, embracing solitary devotion,
Endured ten trials and nine ordeals to attain perfect enlightenment.
On Stone Tower Mountain, wreathed in clouds and mist,
Through bitter resolve and diligent refinement, the Elixir glowed crimson.
Ascending with the entire household, soaring straight upward—
To this day, the bright moon illuminates the pine-clad vines.

The *Scripture of Numinous Response*, passed down by the ancestral master beneath the azure heavens,
Is no different from the descent of sweet dew.
Though the three sages differ, they share the same path of restoring nature,
The same principle of guarding the center—thus all occupy the central position.
The first three sages initiated, the latter three followed—
Like the Golden Elixir arising first, the golden liquid following after.
As the *Triplex Unity* states:
*“Suddenly attaining the golden blossom, it transforms in succession.
Turning into white liquid, it congeals into utmost firmness.”*
And again:
*“The golden blossom first initiates, then dissolves into water.”*
The golden blossom is merely the primordial qi.
At this stage of practice, the resonance of teachings grows ever more resplendent.

When the first three sages emerged, their paths diverged,
Yet all embodied the essence of pure gold, infused with celestial brilliance,
Descending from the celestial palace to bless the world.
This mirrors the Golden Elixir entering the cauldron,
After uniting with the pure, crossing the Magpie Bridge,
Ascending Kunlun, then transforming into a cup of nectar,
