Pouring upon the crown gate, descending the Magpie Bridge,
Returning to the yellow chamber to coalesce into the numinous Elixir.
Vast and flowing—truly the form of the wondrous liquid.
This Elixir, born of gathered righteousness (righteousness being metal),
Is utterly great and firm—heaven and earth cannot mold it.
It responds to cries, arriving like the return;
Saving the suffering, sweet dew showers the dust-veiled.
One day, breaking through the crown to emerge,
Agile as a soaring dragon, one may partake in the work of transformation.
Such numinous radiance arises solely from cultivation and nurturance.

The aspiration of the Second Sage, the Dao-refining of the Mercy Boat, and the Elixir-cultivation of Stone Tower—all are one with this. May all in the world uphold reverence, gazing upon merit and virtue as upon towering Mount Song. When the birthdays of the Three Sages coincide, tea’s fragrance fills the air and water-flowers bloom thickly. Silently reciting the true scripture, the breast is cleansed, as if bathed in sacred grace and beholding the true countenance. Solemnly entering the temple to harmonize the sheng and yong, solemnly entering the monastery to attune the drum and bell. Upon the pond, turtles rise to hear the bamboo struck; amid the clouds, phoenixes dance in time with the zither’s strings. The ritual chariot follows the green simurgh and white crane—where there is resonance, response comes manifold.

The arising of the Golden Liquid is what the Patriarchs wish people to honor. This birthday is the time when the Golden Liquid is born. The fragrance of tea and the lushness of water-flowers—this compares to its scent like ghee, its sweetness like honey. Only when the breast is cleansed may one partake of the Golden Liquid’s grace, coalescing into a numinous essence, as if beholding the golden radiance’s visage. Such Dao-flavor is not for ordinary people to taste.

Master Chenshangyang said: “When the knife-tip’s measure enters the mouth, circulate your true fire to nurture it.” In the midst of circulating the fire, one suddenly feels the true qi at the spine surging upward to the Mud Pill Palace, trickling with a sound, as if something touches the brain’s center. In an instant, like sparrow’s eggs, bead by bead from beneath the palate down the Tower of Nine Stories, it is cool as ice, rich as ghee, sweet beyond compare. When this state is felt, it confirms the Golden Liquid Returned Elixir—slowly swallow it back to the Cinnabar Field. Thereafter, it flows unceasingly. Closing the eyes to inwardly observe the viscera, each appears as if illuminated by candlelight, gradually enveloped in a golden radiance.

As for harmonizing with the sheng and yong, delighting with drum and bell—this is when the Golden Lord meets the Azure Maiden. Striking bamboo to summon the turtle, the turtle heeds the call; strumming the zither to beckon the phoenix, the phoenix answers the summons—this is the purport of the *Awakening to Reality*. The green simurgh symbolizes the dragon’s vigorous qi; the white crane, the tiger’s vigorous qi. When the dragon swallows the tiger, the inner and outer medicines congeal—where there is resonance, response comes, for sound and qi interflow.

This speaks of the Golden Liquid’s inner medicine, which must unite with the Golden Elixir’s outer medicine before success and felicity are achieved. Confucians revere it to open clarity and wisdom; monastics, to dispel delusion and deafness; Daoists, to rouse from stupor and darkness. Do not divide the Three Sages into three offices—the three teachings take different paths, yet their wonders are the same. Nurturing nature and preserving spirit, all under heaven harmonizes; perceiving nature and stabilizing spirit, the myriad dharmas are empty. The gate of mystery retreats, and many heroes emerge; refining nature and attuning spirit, they unite in one school.

Those who study the true Dao, regardless of the three teachings, need only honor the numinous medicine, coalescing it into the numinous Elixir. Then nurturing nature and preserving spirit, perceiving nature and stabilizing spirit, refining nature and attuning spirit—the three teachings all converge in one school.

The true scripture chants forth in resonant tones, like jade pendants and coral beads chiming exquisitely. As ink swells and recedes, the precious flame blazes—this is how the world should enshroud it in red gauze. It may be transmitted to caution merchants and laborers, displayed to exhort scholars and farmers, used to instruct the world and teach children, recited in every household and enshrined in every shrine, employed to guide toward fortune and avert misfortune—truly a jade resonance that perfects spring.

Carefully perusing the true scripture behind lowered blinds, one comes to know the Three Sages’ beginning and end. At times, it transforms things to flourish verdantly; sweet dew showers the heavens, hanging like hibiscus. The nine chapters’ literary force surges like the Yellow River—each word a precious raft ferrying people. The true scripture is likened to the Golden Liquid. Touching the Mud Pill Palace, it resounds—hence the resonant tones. When the Great Elixir coalesces, it shines like the Buddha’s garlands and the outer elixir’s coral, exquisitely interlaced. As ink swells and recedes, the precious flame blazes—this compares to adding lead and mercury. When the numinous elixir enters the cauldron, the hundred vessels return to their root, encircling and guarding the passes, moving in accord with the talisman’s wrapping—like red gauze enshrouding it. All beings who recognize this may enter the Dao.

The *Triple Concordance* says: “Concealing errors in the multitude of texts, transmitting them to confuse the world, thus causing officials to abandon office, farmers to neglect plowing, merchants to forsake goods, and scholars to suffer poverty—I grieve deeply for them.” The Patriarch shares the same compassion as Wei Boyang, hence the repeated exhortations to enlighten. If one carefully peruses the true scripture, the Three Sages’ beginning and end become known, and the Golden Elixir’s beginning and end also become known.

Mencius’ timely rain, the Great Earth’s sweet dew, Wen Shi’s word-source—all are like this. The Golden Liquid Great Elixir is truly the world’s precious raft. Whether one studies Confucianism, Buddhism, or follows the immortal’s path, without knowing the Three Sages’ wisdom, one remains ordinary. Amidst the teeming multitudes of heaven and earth, may people revere them without negligence or sloth.

The Three Sages’ books are like beans and greens—ready provisions for every household. The Three Sages’ Dao is like the vault of heaven—encompassing the eight directions and four extremes. Facing the scripture and contemplating the sages, one should be solemn and harmonious; let not the numinous terrace be disturbed by restless thoughts. Quietly nurturing the celestial mind like a young plant, the master’s bright moon remains dimly luminous. Moment by moment, guard against carelessness; gently and steadily, deepen your study.

The scripture hall’s four sides are warmed by cloud-like radiance—within, a single heart-flower holds purple down. Entering sagehood and transcending the ordinary rests with me. Those who do not know the Three Sages’ merit will surely fall into ordinariness; those who do not know the Golden Liquid’s Dao cannot become immortals. May people face the scripture and contemplate the sages; may people follow the scripture to refine the Elixir.

The method of refining the Elixir first requires sweeping clean the numinous terrace, allowing no thoughts to disturb it. After coalescing the Elixir, one must quietly nurture the infant, the heart like a bright moon—moment by moment, gently and steadily. This is the ten-month endeavor. The scripture hall symbolizes the Cinnabar Field. The warm cloud’s glow is as the *Awakening to Reality* says: “Within, there is the natural true fire, the furnace’s enduring red blaze.” When a single heart-flower coalesces, entering sagehood and transcending the ordinary rests with you.

Do not forget the lord and father, violating filial piety and loyalty; do not imitate the obstinate, flaunting Chan’s edge; do not follow heterodox paths, falling into confusion and descending into hell’s ghostly throngs.

The Three Sages in heaven shine with dazzling radiance, dispelling the dark and aiding the good to break through the gloom. The true scripture emerges with qi like a rainbow, its luminous brilliance surging toward the Dipper and Ox. Raising high the long sword, leaning upon Mount Kongtong, the celestial immortal and numinous sage is called Three Abundances.

Do not forget these four lines, which admonish one to establish the great foundation and seek the great Dao. The Three Sages in heaven, bright as the gleaming sun, silently protect the virtuous and good, sweeping away calamity and evil—this is like the Nine Returns achieved, the true Yang established and all yin dispersed. The scripture’s qi is like a rainbow, its light blazing and piercing the Dipper and Ox, just as the infant emerging from the womb, breaking through the crown and soaring into the heavens. Today, the long sword raised high, expounding the Dao while leaning upon Mount Kongtong, is none other than the one who attained the great Dao, ascending to the supreme rank—Immortal Master Three Abundances.

After the Three Teachings’ great sages’ numinous and wondrous true scripture—this refers to the completion of the Elixir. These Three Teachings share a common return. The great sages are the great Dao. Their numinous penetration is boundless transformation. The true scripture is the true sage.

*Where does the single Yang originate?*
The scripture’s cultivation is perfected, universally delivering good affinities. Incense congeals into precious talismans, golden lotuses surge from the earth, great Confucians, great Buddhas, great Perfected Immortals. Mounting the phoenix to ascend heaven, one again beholds the solemn three sacred forms. The true scripture’s cultivation is perfected—this means the great Dao is accomplished. Only then can one universally deliver good affinities, attaining the supreme rank. This passage’s intent is expressed in this verse.

The Cavernous Mystery Perfected Person Zhang Xuanyuan, embracing the true scripture, presented it to the world without reserve. Now he speaks again of the Three Sages’ chapter, three chapters completing the nine sages and nine Yangs. On the peak of Seven Curves, Wenchang the Literary Emperor, with Confucian learning, delved into the *Great Cavern*, becoming a divine sage—how could the worthies and sages not cultivate the Dao of immortality? The First Patriarch Bodhidharma, a single lotus stem, bore and protected the great vow-ship, branching into northern and southern lineages without end. The Three Sages’ numinous penetration pervades the eight directions, their cultivation of the body through ascetic practice spanning years. Filial piety, friendship, benevolence, and kindness—all virtues perfected—they broadly practiced the Three Teachings with sincere hearts. Crossing the river to face the wall, their resolve was steadfast, the Dao encompassing the Three Teachings, their spirits at ease. The ten trials on Zhongnan stood firm as mountains—great indeed, the Three Teachings’ shared burden.

People see the joy of non-action and naturalness, but who knows the effort that preceded it? The Patriarchs held the constant Dao, once more proclaiming it to the world, composing the third chapter to complete the number of nine Yangs, symbolizing the accomplishment of the Nine Returns. The three sacred persons all realized the great Dao, yet all arose from ascetic cultivation. As the *Awakening to Reality* says: *“Beginning with effort, none see it; only when non-action is reached do the multitudes know.”* This is the very meaning. Non-action symbolizes the facing-the-wall practice. If one speaks of numinous transformations manifesting, this is the sages’ compassion, yet it is also action in the world.

The Three Sages’ compassion fills the dusty realm, their transformative traces boundless and difficult to recount in detail. For seventeen generations, they served as ministers and nobles—*The Scripture on Hidden Virtue* often speaks of this—an eternal, vast grace worthy of song and praise, a blessing star shining brightly through the celestial palace. In the eastern and western lands, the Mahayana Chan is expounded; how could Shaolin Temple lack affinity? The monks of the Six Dynasties flourished—without the Master, who would have turned the raging tide? Girded with a sword, roaming the seas and skies, teaching the true essence to heroic men and women, inscribing extraordinary names upon mountains and rivers, their fame known even to women and children across the nine provinces.

This speaks figuratively of the Three Sages’ spiritual emanations and numinous transformations. It is hoped that later achievers of the true will also, like the Three Sages, compassionately instruct the world, transform the vulgar, cast out evil, and uphold the right, journeying to the Northern Marchmount in the morning and lodging in Cangwu by evening, universally delivering good affinities.

Now I proclaim this to the aspiring gentlemen ahead: the fruition of merit must be as perfect as the Three Sages’. To become a sage, a Buddha, or an immortal, one’s good heart and capacity must be vast and broad. Without cultivating virtue to nurture the root, one will constantly encounter demonic obstructions. When the Dao is accomplished, one may conceal one’s traces amidst the mortal world, ascending the immortal ranks in days to come.

This encourages later generations to aspire to the Three Sages, reverently pursuing merit, broadly cultivating virtue, and only then achieving the great Dao. The Three Sages’ hearts are like sweet springs, their abundant blessings flowing ceaselessly to aid later worthies. Had Qinghe forgotten the human world, why would he have manifested as a magistrate? Had Dharma concealed himself in nirvana, how would the five branches have spread to the western shore? Had Huiweng remained forever apart from the mundane, who would have delivered Kings He and Liu? The Three Sages’ hearts are most deeply entwined—who among later generations will follow in their footsteps?

This speaks of the Three Sages’ merits in reverse. Had the Three Sages, upon attaining the Dao, remained entirely concealed, how could there be such great compassion and such vast Dharma lineages? Though “who follows in their footsteps” seems the Patriarchs’ self-reference, it also exhorts later students.

Now I expound these words without fear of tedium, hoping others will diligently advance to exhaust the jade caskets. The Literary Patriarch’s true scripture unfolds the wondrous simurgh, annotated and interwoven with the *Great Cavern*, encompassing the numinous Elixir. The Enlightened Patriarch’s true scripture is seen in poetic seals, treasured within the abdomen to nurture the Mud Pill. As the Patriarch Bodhidharma’s verses say: *“Within the abdomen, the true scripture is circulated; the Mud Pill distinguishes host and guest.”* The Perfected Patriarch Lü’s true scripture is vast in scope, its poems, lyrics, songs, and discourses resounding with rhythm. Delivering ten thousand beings, ten thousand rejoice, his majestic precious carriage halts amidst the clouds.

This speaks figuratively of the Three Sages’ writings, all centered on the highest Elixir Dao. Wenchang the Literary Emperor, originally a Confucian, delved into the *Great Cavern* and became a divine sage—how could the worthies and sages not study the Dao of immortality? The First Patriarch Bodhidharma also likened Buddhism to the refinement of the golden Elixir, becoming a divine monk—how could true Buddhists not seek the Dao of immortality? As for Perfected Lü, that goes without saying. Delivering ten thousand beings, the Three Sages’ boundless hearts reveal the common source of the Three Teachings!

I wish all beings to prostrate with reverence, burning sandalwood incense on every auspicious birthday. Flowers, water, fruit, and lamps—pure and fresh—dust swept clean, the pine pass flung wide open.

Silently reciting the true scriptures, one beholds the sacred countenance—
a wheel of oceanic sun ascends three poles high,
crimson clouds spanning ten thousand miles illumine the great chiliocosm.

As if the deaf and mute were bearing the imperial carriage,
as if the flying tin-staff whirled midair,
once more red clouds rise from azure skies,
laughing to welcome the yellow cranes in dance.

Heavenly gods and marshals brandish thunder-whips,
the Three Sages ride the wind into purple mist.
This is but the symbolic manifestation of the Three Sages.
*Lingtong* (spiritual communion) illustrates the wondrous function of spirit-exit.
*Auspicious birth* compares to the moment of rebirth.
*Pine pass* compares to the upper cinnabar field.
Only when the dust of defilements is wholly shed does one return to emptiness.
*Beholding the sacred countenance* signifies seeing the dharmic image of one’s own body.
*The sun’s ascent and clouds’ radiance* symbolize the light of spirit.
The Three Sages’ *fajia* (dharma-chariot) is likened to the present *fajia*.
*The marshals’ thunder-whips*—these are the celestial guards in escort,
a single thunderclap beyond the heavens.

Do not say the planchette’s sand is hard to scale—
to this day, its teachings remain as vast as hills.
Do not claim the single sandal was left in the marketplace—
to this day, his disheveled locks still wander afar.
Do not suppose his true dwelling was confined to the Three Isles—
to this day, he often descends upon the altar of Mount Yue’s clouds.
This is but an illustration of the Three Sages’ *lingtong*.
Not only did they attain the Dao in their time and manifest in the world,
but even now, their teachings still enlighten the mortal realm,
their divine virtue unceasing.

The ode says:
*Nature’s capacity is perfect, the Dharma pervades the dust-mote realms.*
*Though the ten thousand conditions are stilled, the One True remains free.*
*Beholding all forms through myriad ages,*
*guiding the deluded multitudes, true cultivation never decays.*

How fine are these verses!

Alas! The Three Sages’ majestic grace spreads far—
may all people stand in awe before their solemnity.
To expound the true scriptures and compose commentaries,
one need not consult divination or pray for lots.
Only by accumulating virtue and nurturing purity
will divine blessings naturally descend in succession.
Wenchang’s brush-recordings are all false transmissions,
why study the barbarian monk’s staff-verses?
*The Numinous Treasure’s Perfect Methods* need not be pored over—
the true scriptures’ wondrous essence is like an acupuncture needle’s prick,
on the jade terrace, expounding the Dharma with beard raised in mirth.

This is but an illustration that those who partake of the Three Sages’ grace
must embody the Three Sages’ true Dao.
The Patriarch’s true scriptures are the grand vow memorial of cultivators.
Simply aspire to accumulate virtue and nurture integrity,
to perfect the great Dao—
no need to cast lots or seek divination slips.
After attaining the Dao, divine blessings will be bestowed in succession,
as if by repeated celestial decrees.
Those who falsely study brush-recordings,
seeking the Literary Emperor to awaken wisdom;
who idly discuss staff-verses,
claiming the Buddha’s Dharma was originally thus;
who practice *The Numinous Treasure* merely to ward off illness and prolong life—
all these are not the true transmission of the Three Sages.
The Patriarch composed three great scriptures, marking the great Dao,
justly serving as the world’s acupuncture needle.
An ancient immortal said:
*Why does this heart open the great Dao?*
*Only because it originally came from within the Dao.*
The Patriarch’s compassionate heart—
is it not the same as the Three Sages’!

The Master’s beard was most splendid.
In years past, wandering through Yunnan and Guizhou,
people called him “Zhang the Handsome-Bearded.”
Ascending the platform to expound the Dharma,
one could almost see him raise his beard in a smile.

*The Wondrous Dharma of Salvation: Precious Repentance to the Heavenly Worthies of the Highest True Scripture*
*Opening Verse*

Amidst the Great Harmony, a single qi turns the vast primordial chaos,
The teachings unfold in the mortal realm beneath the radiant moon’s glow.
Embracing the ten thousand phenomena, towering peaks stand in solemn array,
Compassion and literary grace adorn the brocade of his heart.

Forging the primordial Yellow and Mysterious qi,
Silently breathing the winds through the bellows and pipes.
The scripture serves as Heaven’s mouth, speaking to the lofty firmament.

At that time, the Most August Jade Emperor of the Golden Portal, Supreme Lord of the Highest Heaven, sat enthroned in the boundless expanse of his dominion, gazing down from the flaming heavens of Yama. Crimson clouds bore his throne, his body emanating thirty-two hues of sacred light, illuminating the world below. With sagely concern, he deigned to utter a jade decree, instructing the attendant ministers at his side, and addressed the assembly:

*"Now, as the seas and lands bask in the blessings of peace, many among the multitudes cultivate goodness. Yet one who practices virtue solely for oneself must also extend it to others; without such extension, even goodness is not truly good. Your vows are vast and profound—you must seize this moment to propagate the teachings, subtly aiding the flourishing dynasty. Let benevolent winds spread far, and nurturing rains fall ceaselessly. Surpass all others in compassion, and the ranks of immortals shall elevate you beyond sacred realms."*

Then, the Jade Void Preceptor, True Martial Sovereign of the Dark Warrior, bowed deeply and spoke: *"Your servant has nurtured the true Great Harmony since the time of the Yellow Emperor, attaining the supreme Dao and humbly serving in the Purple Empyrean for over four thousand years. Now, a single individual has emerged—descended from the Heavenly Master—styled Quanyi. He has amassed great merit and conduct, wielding profound spiritual powers, dispelling evil, expounding the true, and disseminating teachings to the enlightened and wise. At the Southern Culmen Assembly, he was enfeoffed as the Successor Martial Perfected, for his radiance illumines the Great Harmony, and his Daoist footsteps follow mine. The Most Supreme of the Jade Clarity bestowed the title 'Vast Compassion and Universal Salvation'; the Most Supreme of the Highest Clarity, 'Flying Dragon and Worldly Deliverance'; and the Most Supreme of the Grand Clarity, 'Perfected Lord of Literary Distinction.' The southwestern provinces have repeatedly received his boundless grace. I deem this Perfected One fully capable of great tasks, yet fear his rank may be too humble to widely propagate the teachings. If granted further favor, he will surely not betray your trust. Now, he has come to the August Heaven to respectfully present his petition."*

The Supreme Lord, upon hearing this, beamed with celestial joy and commanded that he be summoned to court without delay. The Perfected Lord then entered in full dignity, prostrating before the throne. His dark radiance enveloped his crown, and the sacred gaze upon him was filled with delight. The Emperor declared: *"Excellent! You, Perfected Lord Quanyi, deeply comprehend the great Dao. The Preceptor’s praise has already revealed your virtue. Indeed, you have extended your heart with boundless generosity, unfolding the mysterious scriptures. I now command the immortal historians of the Celestial Gardens to compose a precious proclamation on your behalf, bestowing upon you glory and honor. Henceforth, you, Perfected Lord Quanyi, shall be elevated to the rank of Sovereign Lord of the Cavernous Mystery, Right Minister of the Jade Void, and Assistant to the Heavenly Master in the Dharma. You shall oversee all directions without restraint, acting with full authority. Traverse the eight extremities above and below, and should you achieve merit without fault, further honors shall be bestowed."*

The jade decree descended, and the Perfected Lord received his mandate with reverence.

Having received the Perfected Lord’s obeisance, the Emperor withdrew to the Golden Palace and took his seat in the Vermilion Jade Hall. The Heavenly Master and his ministers then commanded the attendants of the Mysterious Heaven to escort the Sovereign Lord of the Cavernous Mystery on a tour of the Northern Culmen, where a three-day banquet was held in his honor. The assembled Perfected Ones and stellar hosts purified the rites and offered farewell libations. Thereafter, he roamed freely through the Three Clarities, where august instructions were graciously bestowed.

The Celestial Worthy of Primordial Beginning spoke:
*"Before Heaven and Earth were divided, vast and indistinct they hung in chaos. The Five dwelt within the Ten, the Mysterious Pivot at the Yellow Center. The myriad things took form in the womb, nurtured by the Three Powers. Stillness gave rise to movement, and the primal chaos first unfolded."*

He further expounded the supreme Dharma-teachings:
*"The qi of Great Harmony is sown in the Father of Qian. As the eldest son of Zhen, it is born of the Mother of Kun. Emerging as the sun and entering as the moon, it opens the gate and closes the door. Grasping yin and yang, it is the root and ancestor of the Dao. Should one encounter it, life shall extend for ten thousand ages."*

The Celestial Worthy of Numinous Treasure declared:
*"Following the Dao, one becomes human; reversing it, one refines the elixir. The method of elixir-craft lies in yielding and humility. Establishing the center generates correctness; in utter stillness, one ascends. Below, close the earthly gate; above, open the heavenly portal. Whoever beholds this shall preserve the Dao-qi eternally. Swiftly, swiftly, in accordance with the statutes and ordinances, guard my Dharma-body. The Fire Talisman dispels all demons; a single point enters the Yellow Court."*

In essential words, without prolixity, the Celestial Worthy of the Dao and Its Virtue said:
*"The essence of the Supreme Dao does not lie in verbose speech. Cast aside external distractions, and concentrate the spirit in the Cinnabar Field. The human heart forgets and forgets again; the celestial breath flows on, unbroken. Moving within the inner chamber, follow its spontaneity. Whether long or short, whether before or after, the generative qi surges like a turning wheel. Practice this with purity, and one may attain immortality."*

In essential words, without prolixity, the instructions of the heavens were concluded.

The August Celestial Envoy arrived, bestowing once more a jade-bound chapter, along with a precious scepter, a sacred seal, a divine sword, a ceremonial tablet, a Nine-Virtue Reclining Moon Crown, a Seven-Star Jade Hairpin, a mantle of plain silk and brocade clouds, a robe of purple silk and floral embroidery, a crimson skirt of feathered hues, an Eight-Treasure Weightless Robe, Jade Sandals of Primordial Radiance, a Golden Chariot of Flying Clouds, a canopy of jade wheels adorned with feathers, wielding the Nine-Radiance Staff and bearing the Ten-Perfection Banner. Before him soared twin phoenixes; behind followed eight simurghs. A thousand chariots and ten thousand riders illuminated the pure void.

Facing the celestial palace, he offered boundless gratitude. The Perfected Sovereign then bowed in farewell to the Celestial Worthies and Upper Saints, receiving their mandate to propagate the teachings. The Cavernous Mystery Perfected Sovereign descended to the Cloud-Wandering Pavilion, unfurling the vessel of deliverance for the world—this very sutra as its root and origin.

At that time, the Sky of Leaks had rained for days unending; the summer month congealed with cold. The people sighed in distress, their grain and millet submerged. As the Dharma assembly commenced, auspicious mists gathered thickly, propitious vapors descended in waves. A pure breeze scattered gently; bright stars mirrored the waters. At dawn, the sun emerged from the mountains, and he ascended the Wondrous Terrace to inaugurate the sacred instructions.

The Perfected Sovereign declared: *"How vast! The subtlety of the Supreme Dao is made luminous through words; the essence of the utmost encounter is rendered lucid through speech. The sutra may serve as Dharma—revere the sacred scriptures to model my Dharma. The sutra is the eternal Dao—revere the sacred scriptures to embody my Dao. It is neither possessed of dharma-form nor devoid of dharma-form; in daily practice and cultivation, dharma-form manifests. It is neither named as Dao nor unnamed as Dao; in the principles and norms of affairs, this is the name of Dao. Those who follow the sutra shall flourish; those who defy it shall perish. I proclaim the Dharma broadly across the seas, I expound the wonders of the Dao to distant lands, I guide the virtuous to the realm of immortals."*

He further said: *"Between heaven and humanity, there exist but two paths: blessing the good and calamity for the licentious. Thus, those who do good are granted a thousand auspices; those who do evil are visited by a hundred misfortunes. The cultivator who attains perfect goodness finds the heart settled, the six dusts unperturbed, the six roots thereby purified, the Three Corpses expelled, the Five Thieves eradicated. The Corpses and Thieves cannot unleash their poison; misfortune and harm cannot draw near. Within the accumulation of goodness lies the method to dispel calamity. It is not that after accumulating goodness does good fortune arise; rather, in the very moment of forsaking evil, evil retribution ceases. The Three Sagely Canons are boundless in their measure of goodness; the Three Sagely Sutras universally deliver through karmic affinity. Why do people not strive to practice them?"*

The Perfected Sovereign declared: "Now that the sacred scriptures are complete, all should revere and uphold them. The great assemblies of the ten directions and the multitudes of the six directions—when chanting these jade-like chapters, you must cherish their precious teachings. To read scriptures is to cultivate oneself; to expound sutras is first to deliver others. When compassion is widely bestowed, blessings and prosperity will ascend. Thus, I admonish you, faithful men and devout women: on every auspicious occasion, burn incense and prostrate in worship. Whether in secluded chambers or quiet pavilions, sweep the altar and open the texts, ever holding three great vows to amass boundless merit.

The first vow: may the sovereign be benevolent and sagely, and all people and creatures thrive.
The second vow: may parents enjoy robust health, and the clan flourish together.
The third vow: may lost souls and lingering spirits be delivered across the world to transcendence.

Hold these rare and measureless aspirations, aligning with the Three Non-Intentions. Without seeking fortune, fortune will descend of itself; without averting misfortune, misfortune will subside of itself. Wherever this scripture is chanted, gods and ghosts alike lend their ears. Let this decree be followed—all should revere and trust it."

The Perfected Sovereign declared: "The scriptural text is most weighty; reverent participation is supreme. The ancients said: utmost sincerity moves the divine, and the gods’ chariots descend from the void—people must offer utmost reverence. Do not boast of rare treasures from land and water, nor adorn the ritual feast with elaborate implements. Let the heart be pure, the chamber serene, and qi gather like fragrant mist. As if beholding the honored ranks of the sagely host—the Three Origins and Five Peaks, the grotto-heavens and blessed lands, the three isles of the sea—all divine spirits descend upon your crown, arrayed in devotion, palms joined in reverence."

With sincere devotion, recite the sacred names and bow in worship—one name, one prostration:
To the Jade Purity’s Sacred Realm, the Celestial Worthy of Primordial Beginning;
To the High Purity’s True Realm, the Celestial Worthy of Numinous Treasure.

To the Grand Purity’s Immortal Realm, the Celestial Worthy of the Dao and Its Virtue;
To the Jade Emperor, the Great Celestial Worthy, the August Supreme Sovereign of the Mysterious Heavens;
To the Heavenly Worthy of Universal Response and Thunder’s Resounding Transformation of the Nine Heavens;
To the Northern Culmen’s Unadorned King, the Mysterious Sage Dao Lord;
To the Southern Culmen’s Everlasting Life and Luminous Essence Great Emperor;
To the Eastern Florescence’s Lord of Wood, the Azure Yang Great Emperor;
To the Western Florescence’s Queen of Metal, the Primordial August Sovereign;
To the Central Florescence’s Yellow Elder, the Primordial August Sovereign;
To the Encompassing Wheel’s King, the Dipper Father Celestial Worthy;
To the Mother of the Dipper of the Mañjuśrī Heaven;
To all the Heavenly and Worldly Great Emperors, the Venerable Sacred Fathers;
To all the Heavenly and Worldly Primordial Ladies, the Venerable Sacred Mothers;
To the Palace of the Sun’s Great Yang Emperor Lord;
To the Palace of the Moon’s Great Yin August Lady;
To the Three Origins, Three Grades, and Three Officials Great Emperors;
To the Five Directions’ Upright Peaks and all the Venerable Great Emperors;
To all the Venerable Emperors of the Thirty-Six Heavens;

To the Jade Purity’s Internal Minister, the Lü Patriarch, the Fu You Emperor Lord;
To the Jade Purity’s Attendant Officer, the Han Patriarch, the Heng Yang Emperor Lord;
To the Universal Transformation’s Mysterious Awakening Zhang Patriarch, the Fei Yang Emperor Lord;
To the Grand Purity’s Prime Minister, the Cao Patriarch, the Hong Yang Emperor Lord;
To the Western Florescence’s Pure and Wondrous He Patriarch, the Yi Yang Emperor Lord;
To the High Purity’s True Governor, the Lan Patriarch, the Yang Su Emperor Lord;
To all the Perfected Lords of the Eight Perfected Lineages’ Expansive Dao;
To the Grand Purity’s Right Minister, the Liu Patriarch, the Hai Chan Emperor Lord;
To the High Purity’s Right Minister, the Wang Patriarch, the Chong Yang Emperor Lord;
To the Perfected Lord Qiu of Fu Yang;
To the Perfected Lord Zhang of Zi Yang;
To all the Perfected Lords of the Southern and Northern Lineages;
To the Orthodox Unity’s First Patriarch of the Dragon-Tiger Dharma, the Assisting Primordial and Transforming Teaching;
To all the Immortal Masters of the Dragon-Tiger Lineage’s Dharma;
To the Great Self-Saving and Transforming Azure Lotus Master, the Jade Purity’s Literary and Wondrous Perfected Lord;
To the Literary Upholder of the Dao, the Perfected Lord Su Shi, Duke of Wenchung;
To the Literary Assistant of the Dao, the Perfected Lord Su Che, Duke of Yingbin;
To all the Perfected Lords of the successive generations of literary scholars who attained the Dao;
To the High Purity’s Prime Minister, the Hidden Immortal and Transforming Dragon-like Second Patriarch, Master Wen Shi;
To the High Purity’s True Governor, the Hidden Immortal and Transforming Dragon-like Third Patriarch, Master Ma Yi;
To the Grand Purity’s Serene Governor, the Hidden Immortal and Transforming Dragon-like Fourth Patriarch, Master Xi Yi;
To the High Purity’s Right Minister, the Hidden Immortal and Transforming Dragon-like Wang Patriarch, Master Huo Long;

To all Patriarchal Masters who propagated the teachings and all Perfected Ones;
To all High Perfected of the Three Isles of the Eastern Sea;

To all Divine Protectors of the Nation who severed evil through the ages;
To all Gods of Great Loyalty and Righteousness through the ages;
To all Gods of Great Filial Piety and Chastity through the ages;
To Perfected Lord Sun, King of Medicines who transformed and saved lives;
To Perfected Lord Xu, King of Medicines who universally transformed and saved lives;

To all Perfected Lords who saved lives through the ages;

To all Sword Immortals and Masters of Immortality;

To the Stellar Lord of the Yearly Origin and Life-Destiny;
To the Three Hundred and Sixty Response-Evoking Heavenly Worthies;
To the Lord of the Nine Heavens’ Bureau of Destiny, Eastern Kitchen, and Determiner of Blessings;
To the Celestial and Terrestrial Daily Merit-Recording Immortal Officials;
To the Celestial and Terrestrial Daily Inspecting and Rectifying Generals of the Vast Expanse;
To the Twelve Heavenly Lords, Guardians of the Thunder Gate;
To the Five Hundred Spirit-Officials and all Responsive Heavenly Lords;
To the Esteemed Divine Lord of this Prefecture’s City God;
To the Assisting Divine Lord of this County’s City God;
To the Master of Epidemics of the Celestial Capital’s Plague Bureau;
To all Divine Lords who spread epidemics below;
To the Local Earth God and Community Deity;
To the Divine Messengers who transmit talismans, convey words, and present memorials;

To all the Great Compassionate Ones;
To the hosts of gods of the Ten Directions;
As auspicious clouds fill the empty sky,
This disciple now prostrates in reverence,
Wishing to uphold three great vows:
May they universally infuse the bodies of all people.
The evils of this disciple’s present life,
As well as those of past existences,
May all be caused to vanish,
That they may forever cultivate a heart of goodness.
With sincere devotion, this disciple bows in homage.

After thrice invoking and thrice bowing to the Divine Lord of the Cavernous Mystery, the Most High Emperor—

At that moment, the Heavenly Worthies and August Emperors gathered in the Heaven of Pure Tenuity, descending upon the Palace of Empty Luminosity. The Three Pure Ones took their high seats, while the ranks of sages arrayed themselves in the center. Then a lofty perfected one, the Lord Emperor of Sincere Protection, stepped forth from the assembly, bowed his head, and addressed the Heavenly Worthies:

*"This disciple now observes that in the world below, a field of good affinity has arisen from the southwest. The great scriptures of the Cavernous Mystery are being opened, delivering countless beings. In accordance with the teachings, virtue is being disseminated to renew the people. The grace of Heaven knows no bounds. Your servant humbly offers the* Hymn of Praise to the *Scriptures of the Cavernous Mystery:*"

Those who study the *Scriptures of the Cavernous Mystery*
Shall surely cultivate a heart of uprightness.

Those who study the *Scriptures of the Cavernous Mystery*
Shall surely cultivate a heart of compassion.

Those who study the *Scriptures of the Cavernous Mystery*
Shall surely cultivate a heart of purity.

Those who study the *Scriptures of the Cavernous Mystery*
Shall surely cultivate a heart of wisdom.

Those who study the *Scriptures of the Cavernous Mystery*
Shall surely cultivate a heart of transcendent awakening.

Those who study the *Scriptures of the Cavernous Mystery*
Shall surely cultivate the heart of immortals and buddhas.

We humbly submit:
The *Scriptures of the Cavernous Mystery* are the precious instructions of the Heavenly Worthies, the auspicious radiance of the Four Great Continents.
Wherever these scriptures reside, the ten thousand spirits all protect;
Wherever these scriptures reside, the ten thousand immortals lend their aid.

Thereupon, the *Great Repentance of the Cavernous Mystery* was recited, and thanks were offered for the grace of Heaven.

Those who pay homage to the *Repentance of the Cavernous Mystery*
Can resolve illness and suffering.

Those who pay homage to the *Repentance of the Cavernous Mystery*
Can resolve the calamity of strife.

Those who pay homage to the *Repentance of the Cavernous Mystery*
Can resolve the calamity of blades and warfare.

Those who pay homage to the *Repentance of the Cavernous Mystery*
Can resolve the calamity of water and fire.

Those who pay homage to the *Repentance of the Cavernous Mystery*
Can resolve the calamity of demonic and perverse forces.

Those who pay homage to the *Repentance of the Cavernous Mystery*
Can resolve the calamity of snares and nets.

Those who pay homage to the *Repentance of the Cavernous Mystery*
Can resolve the calamity of epidemics and miasmas.

Those who pay homage to the *Repentance of the Cavernous Mystery*
Can resolve the calamities within calamities.

Those who pay homage to the *Repentance of the Cavernous Mystery*
Can resolve the calamities beyond calamities.

When the Lord Emperor of Sincere Protection had finished reciting this hymn, he respectfully entreated the Divine Lord of the Cavernous Mystery to unfurl the jade case of the Golden Portal and to awaken the world with the thunderous voice of the Dao. The assembled perfected ones and ranks of sages all listened attentively.

Thereupon, the Divine Lord of the Cavernous Mystery began...

The August Heavenly Thearch’s precious instructions were proclaimed to the people below, saying: *"Compassion and purity form the heart of the Dao. Humility, harmony, sincerity, and silence form the conduct of the Dao. Loftiness, luminosity, breadth, and depth form the gate of the Dao. Nurturing the Three Wondrous Spirits forms the root of the Dao. The Dao values knowing death, for only then can one know life. It also values knowing life, for only then is the knowledge of death true. Without limit is death; the Supreme Ultimate is life. Its essence is profound and pure; its qi is vast and undifferentiated. Its spirit is empty and still. Its Dao is perfectly complete. Those who comprehend this ascend to the Azure Heavens."*

The Heavenly King of Dao and Virtue declared: *"The Three Teachings share a single source, one scripture for all ages. Assist my mysterious wind, propagate our true Dao. You, the assembled immortals, why not join in praise?"* Thereupon, the ranks of sages and perfected ones pressed their palms together, sang in response, and withdrew in harmonious voices.

Next, the Great Emperor of the Dark Heaven approached the throne of the Jade Void, entered the court of the Golden Portal, reverently presented the jade case, and earnestly entreated the bestowal of precious decrees. The decree proclaimed:

*"Prime Minister of the Jade Void, exalted perfected one of the Golden Portal. Your virtue flows between humans and spirits; your scriptures open the paths of the well and the dead. You have broadened the merit and conduct of the Three Thousand, awakening the myriad lost in delusion. Once you attained perfection on the Primordial Peak, now you succeed the Dark Heaven in unfolding transformation. Upholding the true teaching without bias or partiality, refuting heterodox paths with resounding clarity. You have executed the false practitioners of the cosmos, restoring the ancestral wind of Dao and virtue. Pointing to the prior heavens and facing the moon, summoning later disciples to ascend the clouds. The wondrous Dao is without fixed form; its mysteries are unfathomable. Utmost spirit, utmost sage, utmost great, utmost honored—your body harmonizes with nature, your spirit congeals in prajñā, the true sovereign of the Three Teachings, the qi of unified authority, the Dharma Heaven Master, Cavernous Mystery Emperor Lord, Dragon-like Six Patriarchs, concealed immortals dwelling in transformation, subtle and universal deliverance—Most High Heavenly Worthy."*

The Cavernous Mystery Emperor Lord bowed to receive the decree.

The myriad heavenly deities and sages then returned to their celestial palaces. Only radiant clouds drifted gently, and the resplendent sun shone brightly. The Emperor Lord returned to his original altar and expounded this scripture, addressing the world’s people thus:

May this merit extend through ten thousand generations,
And all sentient beings together attain the supreme Dao.

With devoted hearts, they bowed and chanted thrice the *Scripture of the Limitless Salvation of the Myriad Heavens* before withdrawing.

The *Cavernous Mystery Scripture* is the vessel for transcending the world. All within its teachings are the celestial instructions and Dharma words of the heavens. Our Master Three Peaks, following the scripture’s guidance, elucidated its profound mysteries and penetrated its subtle wonders. Thus was he enfeoffed as the Cavernous Mystery Emperor Lord and thus proclaimed this *True Scripture of the Cavernous Mystery*. Those who encounter it by karmic affinity must treasure and revere it.

Disciple Xiyue respectfully records this.

*The Scripture of Perfect Enlightenment in Bodhi*
A Verse:
Expounding the scripture, revealing wonders beyond the dust,
Three drumrolls of clouds ascend the Dharma throne.
The sun climbs the peak and swiftly passes,
Yet should return, crimson, to another mountain’s embrace.

The Bodhi declares: In times past, I dwelt in the Taihe Hermitage, diligently cultivating the Mysterious Teachings, inwardly embracing true suchness. Concealed or manifest, I delivered beings, appearing in myriad forms, employing myriad expedient means. I assiduously established merit and conduct, awaiting the celestial mandate. Though dust and grime covered my robes, I ever delighted in my tranquility.

Daily I sat beneath the Bodhi tree with my disciple Yuanqing and all the bhikṣu assembly, all of whom had attained perfection. Behold this wondrous seed of Bodhi—fragrance without fragrance, yet its fragrance is universally perceived; light without light, yet its light shines everywhere. Fragrance and light pervade all, yet all arises from no-mind.

I contemplated the supreme vehicle of the Buddha, wherein the original nature is complete, compassion universally protects, and natural quiescence illumines—all without contrivance. This is called Bodhi. The noble name of Bodhi truly originates here.

In former times, I journeyed in spirit to the Western Heaven, paying homage to the World-Honored One. I sought the Buddha’s intent and silently aligned with the Chan lineage. The World-Honored One rejoiced greatly and commanded its propagation, addressing the great assembly thus:

*"Divine light radiates brilliantly, the ocean of nature is limpid and clear.
Within the dust yet beyond it, concealed in the world yet delivering the world.
Manifesting as a healer to rescue the imperiled and relieve the distressed,
Advocating for the multitude to expound the Dao and transmit the scriptures.
Having realized the fruit of the Great Luo Golden Immortal,
Your Dao equals that of the Venerable Bodhidharma.
Great Benevolence, Great Vows, Great Compassion, Great Mercy—
Mysterious and Profound Ancestral Master, Savior from Calamities,
Heavenly Worthy of the Unkempt and Serene Light,
Buddha-Bodhisattva Mahāsattva!"*

The following day, I traveled to Potalaka in the Southern Sea, gazing upon the Venerable One. The sound of the tide was vast, the Buddha’s Dharma boundless. I sought the Buddha’s intent and attained the shared essence of the Śākya lineage. Thereupon, I recited the *Scripture of the Wondrous Bodhi*, extolling compassion. The King of Awakening, Avalokiteśvara, anointed me with sweet dew and bestowed a secret mantra to augment my merit.

Having made pilgrimage to both West and South, the fragrance and light flourished equally. The Dharma pervaded the dusty realms, the nature-body was perfectly replete, and the great vehicle of Śākya Buddha accorded entirely with my Dao. Now, with the burning of incense and the sounding of the drum, we recite the *Bodhi* aloud.

What is meant by "Śākya"?
The World-Honored One said: *"I favor Śākya, thus I established the teaching under Śākya, signifying the relinquishment of all entanglements."*

What is meant by "Buddha"?
The Compassionate Ferry said: *"I favor Buddha, thus I embodied the Buddha to establish the teaching, signifying the awakening of all beings."*

Thus have I heard: The Śākya Lord departs the world.
Thus have I heard: The Buddha Lord awakens the world.

Within Śākya, there is Buddha, yet no fragrance or light—yet fragrance and light arise spontaneously, like Bodhi.
Within Buddha, there is Śākya, with fragrance and light—yet originally no fragrance or light, also like Bodhi.

The scriptures of Śākya and the sūtras of Buddha serve but to transcend worldly defilement and awaken the deluded.

Therefore, the World-Honored One is pure, and the Compassionate Ferry is likewise pure. The World-Honored One encompasses purity, while the Compassionate Ferry universally purifies. There is no attachment to purity, no destruction of purity, no stinginess with purity—even to the point of no purity, non-purity, non-purity, yet also purity. This is the great purity, the perfect purity.

Those who chant the *Bodhi* shall attain a pure heart and a prajñā heart. Yet having attained prajñā, one forgets prajñā. To not forget prajñā is not prajñā; to be not prajñā is not called prajñā; to be not not-prajñā is true prajñā. Those who attain prajñā are called Śākya, may become Śākya, possess Śākya-Śākya, are Śākya yet not possess Śākya-Śākya, are Śākya yet inherently possess Śākya-Śākya.

They are called Buddha, may become Buddha, possess Buddha-Buddha, are Buddha yet not possess Buddha-Buddha, are Buddha yet inherently possess Buddha-Buddha.

Thus is the World-Honored One, thus is the Compassionate Ferry, and thus are the śramaṇa and bhikṣus.

Can one become Śākya without being thus?
No.

Can one become Buddha without being thus?
No.

Why is this so?

To be Śākya is Śākya; not to be Śākya is not Śākya.
To be Buddha is Buddha; not to be Buddha is not Buddha.
Why is this so?
Beyond Śākya there is no Śākya; to grasp Śākya is to be Śākya.
Beyond Buddha there is no Buddha; to grasp Buddha is to be Buddha.
Why is this so?
Śākya-Śākya-Śākya-intent—yet there is no Śākya-intent, only the intent of Śākya itself.
Buddha-Buddha-Buddha-thought—yet there is no Buddha-thought, only the true thought of Buddha.
To be not-Śākya yet Śākya is the supreme vehicle; to be not-Buddha yet Buddha is the great vehicle.
The scriptural treasury of Buddha and Śākya is thus the treasury of Śākya-Buddha, called the Treasury of the True Dharma Eye.

When the bodhisattva had spoken thus, at that moment blue phoenixes and white phoenixes intertwined, harmonizing in perfect celebration. All the bhikṣus and assembly rejoiced greatly, marveled at this rarity, bowed in reverence, and upheld the teaching. Then they recited the *Compassionate Ferry Mantra*, saying:

*"Bodhi truth, bodhi gate-truth,
Gate-bodhi truth, truth-gate-bodhi truth,
Bodhisattva truth, bodhi mahā-sattva."*

The *Bodhi Sutra* was obtained at West Lake’s Cijing Temple from the Venerable Ruzhan. The Venerable was a Dharma-grandson of Master Xu, a great monk of Jiangnan. From youth, he mastered Chan principles and devoted himself to the Mahāyāna. In later years, he presided over Cijing Temple and deeply revered this sutra. After his passing, Ruzhan treasured it for over twenty years. In the early Daoguang era, he traveled to Mount Emei. Fellow practitioners met with Ruzhan and found great affinity; thus, he revealed this sutra, saying that within the profound teachings lay this bodhi, yet people did not recognize it. At that time, Messrs. Liu and Yang were compiling the complete work and, having obtained this text, reverently transcribed and preserved it.

*Transmitted by the Buddha Lata Jingguang on behalf of the Great Compassionate One of Putuo: The Mind-Dharma Divine Mantra of Great Mercy*

The Bodhisattva Avalokiteśvara, from samādhi’s gaze, looked down upon the sea of suffering, sweeping away all unwholesome paths with the broom of Akṣobhya. Universally wishing that all beings in the three-thousandfold great-thousandfold world—whether koṭi, saṅkhyeya, or koti-koti—turn their hearts toward goodness, that their virtuous minds become as mighty as Nārāyaṇa, without distinction among all beings in the three-thousandfold great-thousandfold world—what are Pindola, what are Bharadvāja?—all may ascend to pāramitā, all may attain anuttarā-samyak-saṃbodhi.

Then was spoken the *Dhāraṇī True Words*:

*"Oṃ, thought after thought, thought after thought,
Avinivartanīya-tathatāya,
Mahā-bodhi, bodhisattva,
Kānta-hṛdaya, bodhi mahā-sattva."*

Homage to Avalokiteśvara,
who personally transmitted the *Great Compassion Mantra*.
May this merit awaken boundless multitudes.

Threefold homage to the Great Compassionate Lord, the Bodhisattva Avalokiteśvara Mahāsattva.

*Bell Verse Used in Temples and Abbeys of the Zhongji Hidden Immortal Lineage*

The ten directions are still; one, two, three—sound the bell’s toll.
Proclaim the numinous scripture of universal deliverance, expound the wondrous essence of pure emptiness.
We humbly pray that the sovereign be benevolent and sagely, all nations enjoy peace;
further entreat that parents be healthy and at ease, a thousand households harmonious and joyful.
Since ancient times, loyal ministers and steadfast martyrs have each won renown;
from this day forth, those afflicted by suffering and hardship shall all find blessing.
The nine dark realms, six paths, and four births return to the origin and revert to the root;
ancient tombs, desolate outskirts, and lonely burials deliver the po and guide the hun.
Broadly rescue those in the midst of blades, floods, miasmas, and untimely death, each spared from lamentation;
together bless the widowed, orphaned, solitary, and homeless wanderers, all returning to favorable circumstances.
Uniting yin and yang to preserve life and nature, transgressions and worldly dust are dissolved;
relying on virtue and conduct to establish heaven and earth, one may face the vastness of sky and distance of earth.
Whether Confucian or Buddhist, one may fulfill a lifespan of one hundred twenty thousand years;
aspiring to sagehood and truth, one shall not fall into the three thousand six hundred deviant paths.
Sweep away sorrow, fear, craving, desire, greed, and anger;
subdue the mind-horse and heart-ape, the tiger’s temperament and dragon’s nature.
Fortune and emolument come to fruition; heavenly immortals and immortals of the earth welcome and guide.
The mountain gate is pure; in the human realm, the Dao’s qi endures long.

With sincere devotion, we bow to the Primordial Unity Qi, the Three Pure Ones, the Daoist Ancestors, the Heavenly Worthies.

With sincere devotion, we bow to the August Jade Emperor of the Golden Gate of the Vast Heaven.

With sincere devotion, we bow to the Thunder Sovereign of the Nine Heavens, the Universally Transformative Heavenly Worthy.

With sincere devotion, we bow to the Heavenly Worthy of Great Unity, Savior from Suffering, Who Responds to Cries and Attends to Calls.

With sincere devotion, we bow to the Supreme Ancestral Masters of the Lineage of Transmitted Dao through the Ages.

With sincere devotion, we bow to the Supreme Sacred Masters Who Have Held the Dao Across Kalpas.

With sincere devotion, we bow to the Deities of All Heavens and Earths, the Sacred Peaks and River Spirits.

With sincere devotion, we bow to the Star Lords of the Northern Dipper and Southern Dipper, the Arrayed Constellations.

With sincere devotion, we bow to All the Responsive Spirits Throughout the Empty Void.

With sincere devotion, we bow to the *Sutra of Infinite Liberation from Distress*.

With sincere devotion, we bow to the *Sutra of Infinite Salvation of Beings*.

*Complete Works of Master Zhang Sanfeng, Volume Eight*
Recompiled by Li Xiyue of Hanjia, Mount Changyi
Respectfully inscribed by Zhang Daoyuanzi Shen
Engraved with reverence by Zhu Daosheng, Latecomer of Langzhong
Collated by nephew Ying Chuncheng and Zhu Zan Suyuan
Sons Huang Panxi and Shuishi Xiantan

*Idle Talks by the Water and Stone*

Master Zhang says: The world says one must read for ten years and cultivate qi for ten years. By separating reading and qi-cultivation into two distinct matters, they fail to grasp the learning of the sages and worthies. Reading is for investigating principle; cultivating qi is for refining one’s nature. The work of nature and principle lies precisely in the unobstructed simultaneity of reading and qi-cultivation. The Sage declared: *“Learn and practice it at due times.”* This alone suffices for the ceaseless refinement and unification of nature and principle.

Master Zhang says: Tao Yuanming reclined beneath his northern window, calling himself a man of the era of Fuxi. This reveals his lofty integrity and unyielding spirit, evoking the grandeur of a bygone dynasty—his words were merely too transcendent for others to perceive.

Master Zhang says: The Daoist hopes that scholars will swiftly fulfill their ambitions for fame and office, exhaust their human duties, and then promptly let go. One who retires after achieving success does so at the right moment. The danger lies in drowning in the pursuit of fame and fortune, clinging endlessly—such a person is a fool.

Master Zhang says: Within nurturing lies great learning; within harmony resides true nature. You must tolerate what others cannot tolerate, endure what others cannot endure. Then the mind grows ever more serene, and the nature ever more pure.

Master Zhang says: Fame and office, great or small, must be advanced or withdrawn in due time. How can one know the right time? Simply reflect calmly within the pursuit of fame and office: *“My fame and office will not exceed this.”* If you can rise to this, you have grasped the moment. Or if there seems no end, better to fall short than to overreach. Han Xin was not the equal of Zhang Liang; Yuan Zhen was not the equal of Bai Juyi—both were blinded by their insatiable ambition. Had Zhang Liang or Bai Juyi also harbored such desires, Zhang could easily have risen again to the highest offices, and Bai could have been promoted to prime minister. Yet how could one be certain they would not have met the same ignoble ends as Han Xin or Yuan Zhen? Thus, only those who know when to advance and when to retreat deserve to be called wise.

Master Zhang sighs deeply: The years drift by like shadows, and I see in the world those who chase fame and fortune—some seize high rank in an instant, others amass great wealth in a few years. Among thousands, barely a handful succeed. Even if they attain lofty titles and vast power, these cannot overawe the Lord of the Underworld; gold and jade cannot buy exemption from impermanence. Some may live long in wealth, or rest secure in nobility, yet in the end, all return to the poplar-shaded grave, where autumn winds wail and the chill pierces the heart. If their descendants are unworthy, the estate crumbles in the blink of an eye—what benefit was there? Moreover, those of sudden wealth or sudden rank often fear slander, curses, and malicious gossip. If they fail to do good, others’ curses may wither them on the spot or reduce them to poverty—everyone rejoices, each heart gladdened. Yet Heaven’s retribution is clear and unshaken, not swayed by human words. If one can see through this and let go, one will naturally cease to envy others’ wealth or status. Seek instead the principle of contentment with one’s lot, and uphold the Dao of self-cultivation. While others clamor noisily, I remain silent; while others fret in vexation, I abide in cool clarity. Why trouble oneself over others’ success or failure, wealth or poverty, or the world’s injustices?

Master Zhang says: Lifespan is fixed for those above, fixed for those below, but uncertain for those in between. The middling sort, neither wholly good nor wholly evil, cannot be prolonged by Heaven, nor can they be cut short—thus, they are left to live or die as fate decrees. Preservation depends on cultivation. Cultivate the body and accumulate merit through virtuous deeds to aspire to longevity and enduring vision. As for the lowest sort, burdened with many faults and evils, even cultivation cannot grant them long life. Their essence and qi are stripped away, and they are punished with death. The highest sort are different. If they cultivate longevity, they may attain it. Even if they choose not to pursue it, their upright qi sustains them among the ranks of divine beings. Otherwise, they may return to the human world, but will surely be born into a family of benevolence and goodness. Such is the principle of Heaven—what is difficult to understand?

Master Zhang says: Since ancient times, when men of loyalty, integrity, and heroic resolve sacrificed themselves to perfect their humanity, they manifested the vision of the sevenfold returning elixir. In that moment of undivided heart and unwavering resolve, their vast and upright qi arose within, and they regarded blades, saws, cauldrons, and boiling oil as mere illusions testing their resolve, remaining unmoved. They gathered and concentrated their righteous qi, solidifying it into indestructible firmness. At this stage of the alchemical fire, the radiance of the hero’s spirit endures for ten thousand years without fading. When Daoist adepts enter the chamber to tend the furnace, they must possess this same resolve.

Master Zhang says: While one’s parents are alive, one should fulfill filial duties in a timely manner. Otherwise, once their faces are gone, regret and sorrow over lost opportunities will be unspeakable.

Today, amidst the autumn mountains and forests, let those observing mourning rites heed my words:

*"Again the autumn winds sweep through the woods,
Beyond azure clouds, a heart yearns for kin.
Yellow reeds and white grass wither in the frost—
How deep the tears that wet the Yellow Springs!"*

Recite this poem, and who would not be stricken with sorrow?

Master Zhang says: In matters of filial piety, each must fully follow their innate conscience. Though methods may differ, they all converge in the single word "filial." To spare your family’s longing, you should return home to serve your parents; to seek honor and renown, you should dedicate yourself to the imperial path. If you wish to preserve your body as a form of filial devotion, you must curb desires and purify the heart—empty words are of no benefit. You disciples, though you may not yet have achieved distinction or returned home often, would do better to curb desires and purify the heart, embodying the teachings of the sages Zeng and Meng. If you do not purify the heart and curb desires, you will vainly chase fame without attaining it, pursue profit without success, and seek all things in vain. Your body and spirit will wither, and while your parents’ faces may yet show no signs of age, you, their child, will already bear the weariness of old age. You may speak of filial piety, but it will not endure long—only to bring your parents worry over your illness and anxiety over your distant travels. Should misfortune strike and you, their child, die, you would only add to their grief, forcing them to bury you. Reflecting on this, where is the filial piety? Would you not become a lifelong sinner?

The Dao takes purifying the heart and curbing desires as its foundation, for this is truly the way to preserve the body. Add to this a gentle countenance, respectful demeanor, and sincere intent, and you will attain filial piety.

Master Zhang says: After Confucian scholars achieve literary honors, many take up positions as private tutors. Know that accepting such posts to support one’s parents is also a convenient path for Confucians. Yet Confucius and Mencius bequeathed the *Book of Songs* and *Book of Documents* to later generations not to teach profit-seeking. In later times, when such remuneration became customary, using it to serve one’s parents is but a minor application with minor effect. Still, one must not be insatiably greedy, scheming for the ease of descendants and turning the classics into a den of profit—lest one become a sinner against the sages.

Master Zhang says: Those who wish to fulfill loyalty and filial piety and establish great integrity must first purify the heart and cultivate qi. Without a true heart and true qi, one cannot fully realize loyalty, filial piety, or great integrity. For loyalty arises from the true heart, and great integrity originates from true qi. To attain true heart and true qi, one must prioritize stillness, for only then can the true heart be preserved and true qi cultivated.

Master Zhang says: Seek inner joy, not outer joy. Confucius found joy within—this is inner joy. If you merely desire external things, you seek outer joy only to invite vexation.

Master Zhang says: Many Confucian scholars suffer from seminal loss, caused not only by impure heart-fire but also by staying up all night in conversation or reading, dissipating the qi of the *dantian* through ceaseless chatter, leaving essence without its companion and thus leading to seminal loss. Those who wisely preserve their bodies should speak less and read with moderation.

A young man once suffered from lethargy and weakness. Master Zhang said: "You should take advantage of these clear winter days. Move small stones to build a low wall, carry a mountain hoe to clear dead grass, and stop when you grow hungry. Do this daily, moving leisurely like a gardener, and your entire body’s qi and blood will flow freely without stagnation."

Master Zhang says: The heroic and outstanding do good deeds and act virtuously solely to follow what their hearts deem right, without harboring thoughts of seeking blessings through goodness. The luminous Lord on High has only the principle of blessing the good and punishing the licentious to govern ordinary people, not to reward the heroic. While the heroic may rightfully receive blessings for their goodness, this is not always the case. Yet their resounding deeds and virtuous actions endure through heaven and earth for a thousand years without decay. Their spirits feast on fragrant offerings in the unseen realm—how is this not the heavens’ reward for the heroic? I observe that throughout history, loyal ministers, filial children, righteous scholars, and benevolent people often meet untimely deaths or endure hardships, and I sigh in lament and sudden realization.

Master Zhang says: For Confucians, reading to establish character is an urgent task, and the way of preserving the body encompasses the establishment of character. To preserve the body, one must abandon arrogance, extravagance, dissipation, and excess, sweeping away depraved conduct—thus, preserving the body includes establishing character. The way of preserving the body was transmitted by Master Zeng and expanded by Mencius. Nurturing the heart and curbing desires, holding fast to one’s will and guarding one’s qi—these are the guiding principles of preserving the body. The Dao of self-cultivation takes this as its orthodox path. Yet people’s hearts are obscured: they dismiss preserving the body as commonplace and regard self-cultivation as strange. Thus, those who seek to understand self-cultivation and awaken to the Dao are already rare.

Master Zhang says: Without the teachings of Confucius and Mencius for a single day, the world would have no good people; without the teachings of Zhuangzi and Laozi for a single day, heroes would have no retreat.

The layman Wang once said that abstaining from meat removes its influence. Master Zhang replied: Meat and vegetables are not the same. Daoists abstain from the five pungent plants—medical texts list scallions, leeks, Chinese chives, garlic, and mustard greens. These five are acrid and foul-smelling, dispersing qi, hence the character for "pungent" (*xūn*) combines "grass" (*cǎo*) and "army" (*jūn*), as if to say they are "soldiers among the grasses," all possessing attacking properties. Those who cultivate qi avoid them. Buddhists emphasize vegetarianism to uphold the precept of not killing and to practice life-release, thus rejecting all meat from animals. Some people eat vegetarian meals on the first and fifteenth days of the lunar month but still crave rich flavors at other times—this is not true vegetarianism.

For those who adopt vegetarianism to abstain from meat, I say: better a virtuous heart than merely virtuous lips—follow the gentleman’s teaching to keep distant from the kitchen. Nurturing qi naturally nourishes the belly; observe the perfected one’s prohibition against strong flavors. Master Zhang addressed two Daoist priests, Renru and Shouru, saying: "All people must cultivate both inner and outer—refine the inner to purity and depth, and outer blessings will follow. Stealing a moment of leisure amid busyness grants a moment of nurturance; reading for a day in stillness brings a day’s benefit. If one only chases outward things, the root is lost, and one grows ever more shallow."

Master Zhang told Zhuo’an: "To preserve the body, focus on calming the heart and nourishing the kidneys. When the heart is calm, the fire of *li* does not flare outward; when the kidneys are nurtured, the water of *kan* does not spill outward. If fire does not flare, the spirit remains unshaken and the heart grows calmer; if water does not spill, there is no leakage of essence, and the kidneys grow clearer. When the kidneys are clear, the fire of life does not surge upward; when the heart is calm, the fire of spirit can shine downward. Spirit and essence congeal and intermingle, forming embryonic breathing—this can ward off illness and prolong life."

On the third day of the third month, the disciples bathed by the banks of the Brocade River, fanned themselves beneath the green woods, and listened to the cuckoos’ calls. Suddenly, a leaf fell to the ground, folded like a letter. Opening it, they found something like *zilan* orchid seeds wrapped inside. Asking a local, they were told: "These are *Duyu* pearls." When asked their use, the reply came: "What use do they have?"

They replied, "We do not know."

Just then, Master Zhang, wearing a bamboo hat, strolled over leisurely and addressed the disciples: "Do you wish to know the story of the *Duyu* pearls? After the King of Shu entered the mountains, his people longed for him, so the king commanded the cuckoo to bestow these pearls upon the people of Shu. The cuckoo was the king’s avian messenger, originally named *Xiebao*. The king said, ‘Go back to our land and console my people.’ Thus, *Xiebao* was also called *Xiebao* (‘repayment’), for King Duyu ordered it to repay the people’s gratitude. The pearls may be red, yellow, green, or purple—no single hue prevails. They can ward off malevolent spirits in households. When encountering such spirits, secretly raise the pearl and cast it toward them, and they will disperse. But none must perceive this; silently recite: ‘King of Shu, King of Shu, pearl’s radiance, pearl’s radiance, cast out the ghost, the ghost departs, slay the ghost, the ghost perishes. I wield the sacred pearl, its rays ever bright. Where yin lingers, it is consumed; when yin is spent, yang returns. By the command of the Nine Heavens’ Primordial Master, swiftly, swiftly, as the law decrees!’

It is also said that the number of pearls can divinely foretell a year’s harvest—whether bountiful or meager.

Master Zhang said: "One should cultivate the body in stillness, act within one’s station, and find contentment in circumstance. Then the heart and nature will be at peace, and the spirit and *qi* will be serene and unperturbed."

Master Zhang spoke of enduring humiliation: "If you teach the young, you must enforce strict discipline. Otherwise, if their nature and temper are corrupted, when they grow older, you will resent them—this is to cherish them only to abandon them."

Master Zhang, accompanied by Yunshi, Zhuo’an, and others, wandered through the wild mountains in the cold of winter when they heard ghostly whispers all around. They inquired of the local earth deity and learned these were the ancestral spirits and paternal souls of the dead. The yin energy was desolate and chilling; graves lay desolate, coffins crumbled, and the clothing, caps, and skeletal remains all suffered the cold’s intrusion. Could one feel no shudder of pity and sorrow? This is why the ancients had the custom of visiting graves and offering winter garments.

Master Zhang told the mountain dwellers: "In summer, one should rise early to practice, then seek a slightly cool place after sunrise to collect the mind in quiet sitting. Never sleep during the scorching midday heat. If sleep does not dull the senses, it may be tolerable, but if it does, essence and fluids transform into sweat and escape—what a pity, what a pity!"

Master Zhang said: "Yesterday, I traveled to Liangjie Mountain and saw an old woman sitting on a cliff, laughing and then weeping. I suspected a fox spirit, but soon she fell from the cliff and died. I hurried forward to look."

The lightning strike had slain it—a thousand-year-old fox spirit. I knew not its deeds, so I asked the Fire Cart Spirit-Official, who replied, "It had eaten humans, hence the strike." If such creatures lurk even in broad daylight on Liangjie Mountain, what might lurk in the depths of remote, desolate cliffs!

Master Zhang sighed and said: "People rush about day and night, always claiming they ‘have no choice.’ But what truly leaves them no choice? Only the mind’s insistence on ‘having no choice’—hence their constant refrain. Yet if one’s present lack of choice must one day cease, then old age and death will surely end it. That is the true cessation—what ‘lack of choice’ remains? Those among you with wisdom and foresight, cease from this day forward."

Master Zhang instructed those treating consumptive illness: "In healing, one must have a tranquil heart, an even heart, a patient heart—never seek swift results. If medicine does not worsen the illness, that is swift enough. Then, one day a slight improvement, two days a slight improvement, three days a gradual improvement—though slow, this is infinitely better than daily decline and imminent death."

Master Zhang, wandering above Yueyun Peak and lodging at the Pavilion of Whispering Winds, addressed his disciples: "Today, the mountains are clear, the people serene, the mind distant, the place secluded—truly a rare scene. Let each of you compose a new poem, then invite Hanxuzi to pluck the zither once more, to stir our poetic spirits. Is this not joyous?

Even if one cannot play the zither, one must learn to listen well, to dispel all turbid desires and muddled delusions. Listening to the zither’s sound is like wandering in the primordial age, where all clamor fades, the mind roams freely, transcending the mundane—cool and virtuous, profound and serene. One feels as though playing the zither oneself, forgetting worldly affairs, meeting Yu and Zhou of old, encountering Confucius and Mencius, with Boya and Ziqi to follow. Such is the refined recluse. Otherwise, one remains but a vulgar, shallow soul—unworthy of shared company!"

Master Zhang loved this autumn’s qi—so pure, so solemn. He mused: "How I long to carry a flask of wine, a zither, a flute, and ascend the highest peak! There, I would laugh and gaze upon the vast earth, rivers, and mountains—mist curling, clouds drifting, sunlight warming the village hamlets, waves rippling on the endless river. Then, the flute’s notes would rise from the treetops, the zither’s sound would issue from the rocks, and the wine’s fragrance would mingle among the crimson springs and jade peaks. Mountain birds would sing, emerald hues would scatter—what bliss! Do any of you share this delight?"

Master Zhang told an elderly Daoist: "At your age, you must settle your heart and ground yourself in practice. Let ‘Leave it be’ govern worldly affairs, and all desires will melt like ice. Every person has apertures within, and within those apertures, vital qi. Without this qi, how could the body be preserved? Yet qi arises constantly, and people fail to observe it in stillness.

Let me offer you eight idle words as your evening drum and morning bell:
*Grasp the aperture, know the moment,
Attend closely, nurture qi.
Then you will think deeply, see through illusions,
Act wisely, and fulfill your destiny.*
This is no deliberate teaching—yet it is precisely what you must study with all your heart.

Stillness is spirit; stability is the mind. Even with apertures, if the mind is not settled within them, how can one perceive the subtle?"

Master Zhang addressed the mountain-dwelling Daoist community: "Huiweng urged people toward the Dao with boundless compassion. Though success may seem distant, this is the shared affliction of millennia of seekers. Yet with soaring resolve, the Dao does not bar the heroic. Fear only weakness and lethargy—with spirit roused, even the patriarchs will silently aid you."

Master Zhang spoke to the mountain recluses: "To be called a recluse in the mountains, one must know the joy of mountain forests. Yet this joy does not lie in the mountains themselves, but in one who delights in them—only then do the mountains enhance that joy. To dwell in harmony with the mountains, in emptiness and stillness, in seclusion and elegance, in simplicity and tranquility—this is to truly know the joy of mountain forests."

Master Zhang said: "To become idle in an instant—that is mastery. To say, ‘Wait, let me set things aside for a few days, then slowly explore’—that is the tongue of the mediocre, the heart of the foolish."

Master Zhang told Yuanyangzi: "If you can sever worldly attachments and withdraw from the red dust, your life’s course is set from this day. Henceforth, you will wander freely, forever secure. What joy! Fine weather, beautiful mountains and waters, pavilions, good friends, splendid scenery—from this day, receive them, savor them, awaken to them."

Master Zhang said: "The geography of immortals must be understood alongside the Dao of alchemy. Take Yuanyangzi’s Yi Yun Mountain Villa, for instance: its dwelling sits between two mountains, neither swallowing nor spewing, now open, now closed. Using the method of reliance and adhesion, it forms a home of peace—truly the Great Central Ultimate below the Yellow Court and above the Pass of Origin. Who else knows such celestial secrets?"

Master Zhang said: "Silent mountains are perfect for discoursing on the supreme Dao; a clear heart loves the scent of fine incense—this is the wondrous scene before us." He casually offered these two lines and asked Yuanyang to continue them.

Master Zhang told the Daoist community: "One must leave home while at home, transcend the worldly while in the world, not cling to affairs, not covet things—only then is one a seed of the Dao. There is no need to be bound by inaction, nor mired in overthinking."

Master Zhang wore a cape of cool lotus leaves, roaming carefree beyond the clouds. One day, he heard the sound of stepping songs emerging from the mist. His disciples listened—it lamented the difficulty of transmitting the great Dao and how the yellow-crowned disciples squandered their days. The song went:

*"Time flies swiftly, yet learning the Dao lags behind.
Amid flowing waters and empty mountains, I walk alone in thought.
I fear only the fleeting scenes before my eyes—
in an instant, my throat’s breath may cease, lost in ignorance.
While alive, lost in ignorance;
upon waking, naught remains but walking corpses of flesh.
I fear most when impermanence arrives—
cold bones, how pitiful!
In that moment of endless rebirth,
one knows not the rain striking the flower branches."*

Master Zhang took up Han Xian’s fisherman’s drum, beating in rhythm to convey the emotion, and sang *The Desolate Song of the Dusty Sea*:

*"Flying Dragon Child, roaming the heavens,
never speaking but of loyalty and filial piety,
journeying always to Penglai’s isles.
Seeking to transmit the Dao, I seek men,
sighing that causes and conditions never align,
lamenting how few in life ever turn back.
A candle in the wind, a boat on the water—
