He journeyed to the capital and boldly discoursed on state affairs, but his counsel was ignored. He then retired to Fuchun Mountain, mingling with Buddhists and Daoists in reclusion. When Zhang Shicheng occupied Wu, he was appointed as a military aide. After Wu fell, he changed his name and fled to Hangzhou. He was the poet Yang Lianfu referred to as 'the iron-gated one.'" There was also a Zhang Silian from Suichang.

Residing at Shouguang Palace as a Daoist, he recited the *Supreme Scripture of Salvation* and gained enlightenment. Thereafter, he ceased speech and at times abstained from food. After more than forty years, he ascended as an immortal.

His name was Xuansu, as recorded in the *Preface to the Essential Writings*. His name was Xuanhua, as noted in the *Song of Returning the Elixir* within the *Essential Writings*. The Master himself stated that these two names matched those of the Jin dynasty physician Jiegu the Pure Elder, as well as those of Ge Yuan’s disciples. According to records, the Jin physician Zhang Jiegu of Mingzhou, also named Xuansu, failed the imperial examinations and transmitted his medical teachings instead. His courtesy name was Xuanxuan. The Master himself claimed this matched the sacred title of the Supreme Lord. As the *Old唐书* states, Laozi was styled the Mysterious Primordial Emperor, and Bai Juyi’s poem reads: *"The profoundly profound five thousand words of the* Daodejing." His courtesy names were Shanfeng and Sanfeng. The Master himself said these two names aligned with those of Puyangzi and the practitioners of *cai-zhan*. This has already been clarified in the *Rectification of Errors* within his collected works, and thus will not be repeated here. His courtesy name was Junshi. All biographies list this as his given name, but only Ziyuan’s *Random Notes* and his own biography correctly record it as his courtesy name. His courtesy names were Xuanyi, Quanyi, and Sanfeng. His sobriquet was Kunyang. As seen in his collected biography, the *Records of Grotto Heavens* state of the Master: *"From this day forward, he shall be named Quanyi, styled Sanfeng, and thus his name and sobriquet are firmly established."* Master Changyi notes: The Master’s names and sobriquets changed repeatedly yet often coincided. Later biographers should regard this statement as definitive.

**Legacy Sites**
Fuquan Mountain lies several *li* south of the prefectural city. The *Comprehensive Gazetteer* records it as *"the place where Zhang Sanfeng cultivated the Dao."* Formerly the site of Gaozhen Abbey, it later became the Ritual of the Dipper Pavilion. Before the pavilion lies the Immortal’s Bathing Pool, which neither overflows in summer nor dries in winter and can cure illnesses. According to the *Pingyue Prefecture Gazetteer*, the Chess-Stone at Fuquan Mountain, south of the prefectural city, is where later generations claim Zhang Sanfeng played *yi* with Marquis Longping Zhang Xin.

The Ritual of the Dipper Pavilion stands within Gaozhen Abbey, south of the prefectural city. Tradition holds that the immortal Zhang Sanfeng of the early Ming often performed the Dipper Ritual here. The *Seated Meditation Song* stele inscription within Fuquan Mountain’s Gaozhen Abbey was composed by the immortal Zhang Sanfeng, expounding on Daoist practice.

In Pingyue Prefecture, crossing the stone bridge at Shangmen Ferry and proceeding south along the street, one finds Gaozhen Abbey, the Daoist sanctuary of Master Zhang Sanfeng. Traveling northwest from there, one reaches Zhuobi Mountain, and ascending a slight incline to the west, Daoma Slope. Midway up the slope, a sheer cliff like a screen rises across the mountain, its thousand-*ren* precipice bearing the Master’s image: head crowned with a Huayang cap, staff in hand, walking sideways—clearly visible. Beside it, four large characters read *"Divine Trace Remains in the Cosmos,"* said to be the Master’s inscription, a numinous relic of the realm. The Sanfeng Shrine stands within Pingyue Prefecture’s city walls, containing a Ritual of the Dipper Pavilion. Before the pavilion lies a stone pool named the Immortal’s Bath, four to five *chi* deep, never drying in winter or summer. Nearby, a long-withered cassia tree revived when a Daoist, having bathed in the pool, hung his tattered robe upon it.

In the summer of the first year of the Tianqi era, Li Ruonan, the judicial commissioner stationed at Xintian, invited the *luán* spirit to descend. The brush wrote a *ci* poem: *"Ritual of the Dipper Pavilion, Ritual of the Dipper Pavilion—Zhang the Immortal borrowed this place to cultivate the Dao. Sun and moon hang overhead; wind and clouds pass like dust before the eyes. The Jasmine Sovereign, the Heavenly Sage of the *pū* Script, once tested my sincerity. Today, ranked among the immortals, manifesting numinous transformations, how dare I forget the traces entrusted to the Mystic Ford? Hearing my parents seek my name, I borrow these rustic words as a mirror."*

At Wu River in Zunyi Prefecture stands the site where Zhang Sanfeng observed the tide. Green mountains rise on the opposite bank, white waters flow before the gate, and to this day, his stone likeness remains. According to the *Guizhou Comprehensive Gazetteer*, two *li* east of Baoji County, springs scatter and flow down the mountainside, known as the Sal Tree Springs. The springs emerge from the summit of Jinbi Abbey, where the immortal Zhang Sanfeng once dwelled; his earthen cave still exists.

Master Sanfeng delighted in transcribing Tang poetry in a dragon-and-snake script. Those who obtained his works often carved them into stone as treasures for the world. The *Old Gazetteer of Chizhou* records: At Qingniu Abbey, a stele bears a regulated verse in an extraordinary calligraphic style, hailed as the Immortal’s Brush. The poem reads:
*"In immortal realms, idly seeking the herb-gathering elder,
A thatched hut retains our conversation this shared evening.
Behold the clouds’ depths below the mountain—
Truly, no human path leads through.
Springs draw lotus blossoms to the cave’s mouth;
The moon carries pine shadows east across the stream.
The heart set on fame finds leisure hard to dispel—
Tomorrow, hooves will tread the dust once more."*

This is a transcription of a Tang poem. During the Jiajing era, Grand Coordinator Liu Damu inscribed a colophon: *"This carving is like thunder, lightning, and spirits—unpredictably transformative, yet never straying from the Six Principles of Writing. Truly, none but an extraordinary person could achieve this. The Master of Nine Dragons should guard it well; if it were carried off by chariots or feathered carriages, would that not be a pity!"*

The *Records of Grotto Heavens* state: The immortal Sanfeng’s transcription of *"Idly Seeking in Immortal Realms"* bears the signature *"Written by the Jade Emperor’s Daoist Elder, the Grand Harmony Master."*

According to tradition, Immortal Zhang once secluded himself on the Great Harmony Mountain of Yuan Yue, hence his sobriquet "Master of Great Harmony." The common attribution of this calligraphy to Chen Tuan is mistaken. Lang Caoqiao claimed it was the work of some eccentric who had yet to enter officialdom, noting that it begins with *"Idly Seeking in Immortal Realms"* and ends with *"the heart set on fame."* How could an immortal utter such words? Yet he failed to grasp that the Master of Great Harmony simply admired Tang poetry and borrowed its lines to display his transcendent brushwork.

Today, the Two Immortals Temple in Chengdu Prefecture, Sichuan, also houses this stele—a re-engraved copy of the collapsed original. Elsewhere, on Mount Emei’s stone inscriptions, I have seen two other examples: *"Spring winds lean on the oars at Helü’s city; the Emperor’s son bids farewell to the vermilion phoenix gate,"* where each character twists like coiling dragons and serpents, the brushwork even more marvelous. The colophon reads *"Inscribed by Immortal Zhang,"* though these, too, are lines from Tang poetry. If judged by their content, one might again protest that *"The blue robe has now misled the scholar"* is hardly the language of immortals.

At Xiangfu Temple, the wall bears Zhang Sanfeng’s ink inscription of *"Soaring Fu Chan Cloister"*—substituting *"soaring"* for *"auspicious"*—its strokes writhing with the grace of coiled dragons in flight. This is the very calligraphy described in Tong Shan’s poem: *"Beside it, four characters large as fists, / split-bamboo script from Sanfeng’s own hand."*

*The Jinzhou Gazetteer* records that Bazhou County—now Bayue Mountain, fifteen *li* south of Tongliang—preserves Zhang Sanfeng’s fan, inkstone, and bamboo staff, still treasured by the temple monks.

*The Comprehensive Gazetteer of Sichuan* notes that a six-line poem in Sanfeng’s hand, brushed on silk, remains in the Zhuo family of Chengdu. It reads:
*"Vast qi surges through the cosmos,
Majestic and profound, with no other.
The white-jade-maned lion—
Originally, it dwells in my home."*
The characters surge with the force of celestial winds and oceanic waves, a relic of the late Ming.

*The Letters of Master Tong* describe the outer wall of the main hall on Gaobiao Mountain, where twenty characters of Meng Haoran’s poem are inscribed:
*"Spring slumber—dawn unnoticed,
Everywhere, birdsong.
Last night’s wind and rain—
How many blossoms fell?"*
The brushwork stretches and contracts, soaring and dancing with perfect control. Though much of the hall’s walls have crumbled and been replastered, this section alone remains unwhitewashed, its ink as fresh as the day it was laid down. Locals attribute it to Immortal Sanfeng’s brush.

*The Gazetteer of Leshan County* records that on Zhan Yun Peak of Jiuding Mountain, east of Jiazhou City, Zhang Sanfeng’s hand-carved inscription *"Dharma-Expounding Terrace"* is etched into the cliff. Above it stands the Clear Radiance Pavilion, where the immortal once discoursed with Prefect Wang.

The Lingyun Temple lies between Qiluan and Jifeng Peaks. Within it stands an ancient stele bearing an image of Immortal Feng seated on stone, reading. The inscription above, in clerical script, reads: *"Imperially Enfeoffed Flying Dragon, Salvation-of-the-World Perfected One, Penetrating-the-Mysterious Manifesting Transformation Celestial Worthy, Master Zhang Sanfeng."*

The former headquarters of the Jiannan Circuit now lie within the examination grounds of Jiading Prefecture. When Prefect Wang governed Jiannan, Master Zhang Sanfeng manifested himself there, prompting the construction of a pavilion at the foot of Gaobiao Mountain to honor him. The locals call it Sanfeng Tower. Before the tower stand several quiet chambers, their winding corridors and latticed railings opening onto wind pavilions and flower terraces—the very place where Prefect Wang once withdrew to cultivate stillness. Each evening, he would exit the rear gate of the headquarters and ascend the mountain by steps.

From the former site of Anle Garden, one brushes aside clouds and parts the trees to ascend, and upon reaching the tower’s front, must first burn incense and offer devout prayers to express a heart of purity and benevolence. The Immortal Elder, gazing down, acknowledges such sincerity. He then manifests his dharmakāya, engaging in discourse on scriptures and history, composing calligraphy and poetry—his transmitted secrets too numerous to recount.

In *Cao Shu of Seen and Heard* by Ruan Youtong

Several *li* southeast of Jiazhou, a solitary islet lies upon the river, near Wuyou and Ma’an, once recorded in old gazetteers as Qingyi’s Separate Isle. Master Zhang Sanfeng revealed his traces there, prompting local scholars and commoners to build pavilions and terraces in his honor. Within stand the Poetic Immortal Hall, Pure Yang Palace, Xuanran Terrace, Listening-to-the-Tides Pavilion, Bamboo-Embracing Studio, and two small pools named Moon-Imprinted and Sun-Encompassing. The Master left poems at each, a most refined affair.

In *Records of Grotto Heavens*

Within the mountains of Da County’s Heming, beneath the Welcoming Immortal Pavilion, stands a cypress planted by Zhang Sanfeng, its girth some fifty spans. Though now aged, only a withered stump remains, yet within it a young cypress has sprouted, nearly ten spans in girth.

In *Old Gazetteer of Sichuan*

Outside the Welcoming Immortal Pavilion on Heming Mountain, a stele bears Hu Ying’s poem in search of Zhang Sanfeng, its surface eroded by moss, leaving only the line *“A spirit of untrammeled brilliance, like jade concealed.”* The rest is blurred, yet it remains a treasured relic. The inscription’s colophon—*“Giving Secretary □ Ying”*—still bears three legible characters.

In *Old Gazetteer of Qiongzhou*

Within Heming Mountain stands the Eight Trigrams Pavilion, traditionally said to be where Master Zhang Sanfeng studied the *Yijing*. Its diagram places the Supreme Ultimate at its center, encircled by Fu Xi’s trigrams, illustrating the waxing and waning of yin and yang to clarify the advance and retreat of the elixir fire.

In *Records of Grotto Heavens*

When Emperor Hui perished in fire, rumors spread of his escape, with many former ministers following him. The Emperor grew suspicious. In the fifth year [of his reign], he dispatched Ying to distribute imperially composed books and seek the immortal Zhang Lǎotā, scouring every prefecture, county, and village. Secretly investigating the whereabouts of Emperor Jianwen, he returned only in the fourteenth year.

In *History of Ming: Biography of Hu Ying*

The Taizu Emperor commanded the Perfected Zhang Yuchu to seek Sanfeng, as recorded in a memorial by the Perfected One, preserved in the steles of Wudang. The Chengzu Emperor ordered the Giving Secretary Hu Ying to search the realm, leaving behind handwritten texts and poems, recorded in *Double Pagoda Annual Notes*.

In *Seven Revisions* (annotation)

During the Chengzu Emperor’s reign, Minister of War Hu Zhongduan was repeatedly dispatched to seek the Perfected Zhang Sanfeng, giving rise to the local saying in my hometown: *“Old Minister Hu chases Zhang Lǎotā.”*

In *Records of Pilgrimage in Bilin*

Old gazetteers record that Guiguzi, Yan Junping, Bai Yuchan, and Zhang Sanfeng all resided on Mount Emei. In *True Records of Divine Immortals*, it is said: Guigu was the teacher of Tai Xuan, dwelling on Qingcheng Mountain; Yan Junping remained on Emei, though his rank is unrecorded; Sanfeng, in the early Ming, befriended Guanghai, a monk of Kaiyuan Temple in Kuizhou. At their parting, he left a poem, a pair of straw sandals, and three pieces of aloeswood before departing. From this, it is certain that Sanfeng’s travels in Shu must have brought him to Emei. A thorough search of Bai’s collected works yields no mention of *“Emei,”* yet thirty *li* south of present-day Emei County lies Yuchan Bay. Along its cliffs, a path ascends to Yuchan Cave, capable of holding a thousand people. The cave’s walls shimmer like mica, faintly revealing the outline of a shoulder sash—traditionally said to be Yuchan’s place of liberation.

In *Supplementary Records of Emei* by Jiang Huchen

Within the city of Pingyue Prefecture, traces of Zhang Lǎotā’s Daoist cultivation remain at Gaozhen. During the Hongwu era, he wandered here, building a thatched pavilion. Secluding himself, he sat in silent meditation. Befriending Commander Zhang, he once drank and gambled with him, then pointed to the land of Yueshan Temple south of the city, saying, *“Buried here, one may be enfeoffed as a marquis.”* Zhang followed his advice and later earned the title Lord of Longping through military merit. Before the pavilion lies a pond that never dries, winter or summer, and beside it a cassia tree, also planted by his hand. Five *li* south of the prefecture stands Wu Sheng Pass. Across the stream, on sheer cliffs, remains an image of Sanfeng—wearing a Huayang cap, leaning on a staff as he walks, vivid as a painting. Beside it, Governor Guo Qingluo of the Ming inscribed four large characters: *“The Divine Lingers in the Cosmos.”* Below lies Night-Dripping Gold Bridge, where even on clear nights, droplets of rain fall. Further on is Sunset Glow, where slanting rays appear regardless of weather.

In *Travel Records* by Chen Ding of Jiangyin

Huang Gongwang, styled Zijiu, lived over ninety years, his eyes emerald-green, his cheeks crimson. One day at Tiger Dripping Temple in Wuling, standing on a rock with four companions, clouds and mist suddenly surged from the surrounding mountains, and in an instant, Zijiu vanished—presumed to have ascended as an immortal. I once suspected this tale was embellished by those enamored of his painting, but upon consulting the *Daoist Canon*’s *Jade Texts and Golden Writs*, I found that Gongwang had edited numerous works. His teacher was Jin Pengtou; his friends included Mo Yueding, Leng Qijing, and Zhang Sanfeng. Thus, it becomes clear that this elder originally hailed from the Ten Isles, and painting was but one of his cunning arts.

In *Miscellaneous Notes from the Purple Peach Studio*

Note: Gongwang’s paintings were unrivaled in his time. Zhang Zu and Leng Qian also gained fame as Northern School painters, their ink traces surely preserved in the homes of eminent scholars—hence the saying about their lingering traces.

*Addendum on Time and Place*
The people of Min.

The Error
*The Travels of Dian and Qian* states: "Sanfeng was a man of Min. During the Hongwu reign, he was conscripted under military registry to garrison Pingyue Prefecture, where he wandered the markets with disheveled hair and bare feet, begging—people called him the Slovenly Elder." ○ To claim the Patriarch was from Min may stem from his having once sojourned there. Yet the assertion that he was conscripted to garrison Pingyue Prefecture is utterly inexplicable. Could it be that when Shen Wansan was exiled to the frontier, the Patriarch was also banished to Guiyang? But then why did Emperor Taizu seek him out during the Hongwu era? [He was] a man of Baoji.

The Error
During the Ming, Du Mu traveled to Wangwu Mountain and recorded the Daoist Chen Xingchang, formerly of the Ziran Hermitage on Wudang, now eighty-eight years old, his spirit and qi still clear and flourishing, resembling one who has attained the Way. He had moved to this mountain twenty years prior, and his teachings were the true transmission of the immortal Zhang Sanfeng. He told me that Sanfeng’s given name was Yuanyuan, a native of Liaoyang, who styled himself the Retiring Elder of Sanfeng—few in the world knew his true name. He was still alive during the Zhengtong era, though his whereabouts became unknown. I asked: "People say he was from Baoji in Shaanxi—why is that?" Xingchang replied: "Baoji was merely a place he often stayed; he was not born there."

*Records of the Dao Altar*
An altar takes its name from the Dao, for the Dao is its root. Since divine immortals emerge from the Dao, those who invoke it must receive its descent through the Dao. Now, in setting up altars to summon immortals, scholar-officials often find this matter strange. Yet within it, some things are credible, others not. When the spirit-writing hand is upright, it is credible; when it is perverse, it is hard to believe. When the intent is sincere, it is credible; when it is false, it is hard to believe. When the style is pure and refined, it is credible; when it is vulgar and coarse, it is hard to believe. Moreover, the brush of an immortal must produce words of distinction. When a person speaks, they must establish their greatness. If the poetry and prose are crude, the principles shallow and careless, filled with monstrous and deceptive nonsense—how could these be the words of an immortal! Alas! Alack!

I have come to understand. The master said: *"What that lot does may be set aside and left undiscussed. I, with two or three of you, shall discourse on subtle principles, uphold purity and loftiness, and let the brush follow where inspiration leads. Then the hexagrams of the *River Chart* and *Luo Scripture*, the teachings of Dao and virtue, loyalty and filial piety, the maxims of former Confucians, the doctrines of Laozi, Zhuangzi, Yin Xi, and Lie Yukou, the essences of the *Triple Unification* and *Awakening to Reality*—all these may enrich our learning and give free rein to our words. How delightful this would be!"*

He also said: *"People seek immortality and liberation through divination of good and ill fortune, believing if it proves true and doubting if it does not. Yet you, my friends, should not indulge such foolish sentiments. Fortune and misfortune are decreed by Heaven—what benefit is there in knowing them? What harm in not knowing? Where principle abides, qi abides; where qi abides, fate abides. Principle is the master, qi is its flowing manifestation, and fate is the interplay of generation and restriction. Seek only where principle finds its peace, and even qi and fate will not oppose it."*

The disciples, suddenly enlightened, exclaimed: *"How grand your words! The teachings you impart to us are profound indeed."* Thereupon they recorded several passages of the *"Record of the Dao Altar"* to attest to its truth, that those who love the Dao might come to know the master.

The master then invited his disciples to ascend the clouds with wine, setting up an altar in the Eastern Slope Pavilion. There they expounded several chapters of the *Dao and Its Virtue*, each listening intently. He then commanded a lute-bearer to place the instrument upon the table, where fine incense was lit and ancient paintings unfurled. Together they descended, while their companions sipped tea in the front pavilion, joined by four or five mountain monks, laughing as they faced the river and hills. Suddenly, from the pavilion above, the sound of a lute arose—faint as a spring dawn in the grotto-heavens, vast as the clouds over the Xiao and Xiang rivers—yet no one was there. That day, all the disciples heard the master’s lute.

In early winter, with the cold biting and a light snow just clearing, the master descended from the mountains to discourse on the Dao and dispel the chill for his disciples. He said: *"Now I shall wander and chant among the snow—who among you will follow me?"* Soon after, a young novice reported: *"Before the gate stands a Daoist in a straw cloak, moving as swiftly as flight."* Hanxu, unable to catch up, later wrote a poem:

*"Few in the world knew the master’s worth,
I recognized him, yet my steps were slow.
Snow filled the bridge, no footprints left,
Clouds returned to sea and peaks, brimming with feeling.
Another wind has passed—how far it flew!
When will the crane-drawn carriage return?
Even chasing Han Yu was no easy task—
On the moonlit path home, I imagine his noble form."*

The master then entered Mount Qingcheng with his disciples, seeking a secluded place to build a thatched hut and cultivate stillness, lingering long without desire to leave. One day, upon the Flying Immortal Stone, he wrote: *"Now I shall reveal myself for you all to see."* Proceeding to the rear of the Supreme Clarity Palace, they suddenly saw a boy acting as if afraid of people, slipping into a great boulder. The disciples thought nothing of it. Later, leaning against a perilous cliff, they followed a narrow path, spiraling down to the Heavenly Master’s Cave, but saw nothing. Returning to the Supreme Clarity Palace, one disciple said: *"That boy today must have been the master—his vanishing into the stone was a lesson in retiring into profound concealment."*

The master kept his disciples in Mount Qingcheng for several days.

Gazing upon the marvels of Great Face Peak, where the azure void pierces the heavens; affirming the refined bond of shared hearts, as emptiness and purity arise in the courtyard. One day, he spoke to his disciples: *"Shall we return? General Yao’s snow has sealed the mountain."* Thereupon, they hastened their preparations and passed through Qiongzhou. Fifteen li beyond Taipingchang, they turned to look back at the famed mountain—already crimson clouds draped the ridges, and the snowy air filled the sky.

The master said to Panshanzi: *"If a scholar cannot rouse himself to serve in the court, he ought to withdraw into the hills and valleys, tending to his parents above and providing for his family below, content in a single hall. Devoting himself to the Dao through tilling the soil—this, too, is the learning of Yan and Min. But to rush through the clamor of cities, exchanging toasts and courtesies, wearying oneself in vain—how does this compare to the ease of a mulberry-picker?"* Hearing this, Panshanzi immediately moved his family into Pangu Valley, where he guarded his person and nurtured his body. His household affairs prospered, and he at last believed the master’s discourse on principle to be as responsive as drum to drumstick.

In the summer of the *jiawu* year, the *guoyi* bandits emerged from Dabao Fortress, burning and plundering villages. A girl of the Ding family, along with her younger brother, was captured. The bandits, taking pity on them, untied their bonds, intending to coerce them. The girl cursed them fiercely and refused to submit; seizing an opportunity, she threw herself into the river and perished. Earlier, when the bandits had first come, her father had drowned while fording the river, and her mother had also drowned—yet the girl had carried her mother’s corpse from the water. Her brother, held captive for three years, later escaped and returned to Lengqi, where he tearfully recounted the events. Prefect Xu Zhiyuan ordered the local gentry to publicize her story. The disciples in the mountains begged the master to compose an inscription, and he immediately wrote:

*"Ding Changying, a woman of heroic resolve,
When bandits from Dabao raided her village,
She held fast, refused dishonor, and drowned herself in the river,
Dying while clutching her mother’s corpse from the waters."*

After inscribing this, he added: *"This woman shall one day share eternal honor with the most steadfast of the chaste and loyal."*

Five years later, in Jiazhou, there was a woman of the Li-Wei clan. After her husband’s death, she maintained her chastity; then her mother-in-law passed away, followed by her father-in-law, who, impoverished, could not sustain himself. She returned to her natal family, the Weis, where she spun and wove to support her father while also caring for her father-in-law. She resolved to fulfill her duties of chastity and filial piety before becoming a Daoist nun. When her father fell gravely ill, fearing he would die at any moment and leave her with no refuge, he arranged through a matchmaker for her to remarry into the Song family. Upon hearing this, she wept bitterly and forced herself to say to her father: *"Tomorrow, I shall go to Li Lang’s grave to bid him farewell."* Her father consented. At dawn, she rode in a sedan chair beyond the western gate. Midway, she deceived the bearers: *"I am going to visit relatives behind the mountain. Here is a hairpin—take it back to my family, and you may exchange it for your fare."* Once she saw they were far off, she rushed to Guanyin Shoal and leapt into the river to preserve her chastity.

At the time, Magistrate Mao Huifeng of Leyi, hearing of this, prayed to the river deities to protect and preserve her body. The next day, her corpse was recovered at a Daoist abbey, her countenance as if still living. She was then buried alongside her husband’s son. Furthermore, a petition was made for official commendation, and a shrine was built, with the heroic Ding woman enshrined within. Only then did the disciples of Yun Tan believe that the master’s earlier inscription for Ding Changying had not been in vain.

---

**The Transmission of Master Sanfeng**

Sanfeng was a native of Yibei Liaoyang in Yizhou. His surname was Zhang, given name Junshi, courtesy name Xuanxuan, and sobriquet Sanfeng. He was enfeoffed as *"Permeating the Subtle, Manifesting Transformation Perfected Person."* He lived during the late Yuan dynasty.

The master’s father was named Zhang Chang, also called Zi’an. Sanfeng was his fifth son. In his youth, he suffered from an eye ailment that no medicine could cure. Thus, he was sent to Bile Palace, where he became a disciple of Zhang Yun’an, studying the Orthodox Unity teachings of the Complete Perfection tradition.

From birth, his master had possessed an extraordinary constitution—tortoise-shaped, crane-boned, with large ears, round eyes, and a beard like halberds. His topknot was bound into a single coil, and he sometimes wore a crescent moon cap. In his hand, he carried a bamboo staff, donning a single bamboo hat and a patched robe through winter and summer alike. Unconcerned with his appearance, people called him *"Zhang the Unkempt."* He could walk a thousand *li* in a day; when still, he would close his eyes in meditation. He might go ten days without eating, yet in a single morning consume a *sheng* or *dou* of grain, or abstain from food for days without discomfort. In truthful stillness, he was untouched by even a speck of worldly dust. Though he vowed to pursue the Great Dao, he did not achieve it. Instead, he wandered lakes and seas, eventually settling at Jintai Abbey in Baoji.

One day, he suddenly bid farewell to the world, leaving behind a verse before departing. His neighbor, Yang Guishan, prepared his coffin and completed the burial. As the coffin was being interred, a thunderous roar erupted from within. The crowd, terrified, opened it to find his complexion as if alive. Soon after, he revived. He endured hardships, traversing renowned mountains and vast marshes. By chance, in the Zhongnan Mountains of Yong, he encountered the Fire Dragon Master, who transmitted oral instructions, imparted secret wonders, and taught him to roam freely—blending his light, merging with the dust, seeking companions in Yue, and refining lead in Shen. Thus, his inner and outer elixirs were completed.

Thereafter, he journeyed through famous sites. On Wudang Mountain in Chu, he cultivated and refined himself, building a hut beneath an ancient grove before the Jade Void Palace. After nine cycles of the golden elixir, he attained the Great Dao. Fierce beasts did not startle him, and birds of prey did not snatch at him—people always marveled at this. He once told the locals: *"This mountain shall one day achieve great prominence."* After residing there for twenty-three years, he brushed his sleeves and departed.

He once entered Shu, where traces of immortals still lingered in its famous mountains. He was skilled at writing in "dragon-and-snake" cursive script, which the people of Shu treasured to this day. By the tenth year of the Yongle era, the emperor ordered Sun Biyun of the Orthodox Unity tradition to build palaces on Wudang Mountain and await his arrival. During the Tianshun era, he was posthumously honored as *"Permeating the Subtle, Manifesting Transformation Perfected Person."*

From then on, he appeared and vanished unpredictably, guiding countless souls, and none knew his ultimate fate. His writings, including *The Essential Chapters* and *Partridge Sky* lyrics, circulated in the world, expounding the applications of Daoism and the methods of attaining perfection.

The inner and outer alchemical classics—*Nei Wai Dan Jing*—are profoundly subtle in their phrasing. From ancient times, Wei Boyang’s *Triple Concordance*, Master Cui’s *Mirror for Entering the Medicine*, and Patriarch Lü’s *Knocking on the Hexagrams* have all embodied the ultimate principles of transcending the mundane and attaining sagehood. Yet their meanings are so refined and recondite that even after poring over ten thousand scrolls, one cannot grasp their essence. Only Master Ziyang’s *Awakening to Reality* elucidates the legacy of the ancestral masters in detail, yet even this cannot be swiftly comprehended. Alone among them, Master Sanfeng’s *Essential Chapters* is clear and precise, its oral instructions manifest, enabling later learners to achieve sudden enlightenment at a single glance.

It is this work that illuminates the true path of return and restoration, serves as the bridge and vessel for the mysterious lineage, clarifies the dual cultivation of nature and life, harmonizes the pairing of yin and yang, delivers the deluded masses, and bestows blessings upon all beings. It ensures the eternal transmission of the Supreme Dao without decline, reopening the gateway to the profound and wondrous—"mysterious and yet more mysterious, the gate of all subtleties"—in our present age. Moreover, it vigorously refutes heterodox schools and external paths, expunging falsehoods and upholding orthodoxy, guiding those of steadfast resolve and diligent practice away from straying onto errant paths, so they may attain swift results. Such is the compassion of the Perfected One, whose merit and virtue are beyond reckoning.

**Preface to the *Profound Essentials* Engraved at Xiangyun Cave Heaven by Wu Zhen:**
This book was transmitted by Ancestral Master Zhang Sanfeng. It extracts the profound mysteries of the Dao and distills its marrow, serving as the primordial secret and the true aim of Daoist cultivation for all ages. Some have mistakenly claimed it teaches the arts of "bedchamber techniques," a calumny most egregious. Yet one cannot fault them, for such slander arises from ignorance. During the Liu-Song dynasty, there was a certain Zhang Shanfeng who propagated the techniques of "bedchamber arts and essence absorption." Uncritical listeners conflated "Shanfeng" with "Sanfeng," thereby slandering the latter with such practices. This stems from careless minds and a penchant for idle speculation, failing to closely examine the book’s intent. Does not the *Discourse on the Golden Elixir* within it state: *"Those who take this for bedchamber arts are like one who dons hemp to fight fire or a moth that hurls itself into a flame"*? Upon careful review, such misguided criticism is readily refuted.

Through years of arduous study, we—Lingji and Lingmi—have painstakingly explored and collated these texts. Though we dare not claim to have plumbed their deepest recesses, we have, with no small delight, grasped two or three of their fundamental principles and sequences. We have traversed the fence but dare not grow complacent or idle; rather, we remain earnest and humble, seeking guidance from many quarters. The secrets of external alchemy, however, remain elusive.

This book has long lacked a printed edition, and hand-copied versions are rife with errors—transpositions of characters, decay, and illegibility. Thus, we now commit it to the engraver’s block to ensure its enduring transmission. May those of aspiration not lose their way, and may the wish of Ancestral Master Ziyang—*"ten thousand people, one character; ten thousand people, one character"*—be fulfilled, even if only in part. The spirit of the Ancestral Master in heaven must surely be guiding us in silence.

*Respectfully inscribed by Daoist disciples Zhang Lingji and Deng Lingmi after ritual ablutions.*

**Preface by Yueyun Altar**
Master Zhang Zi Qiong of Kunyang was one of boundless compassion, universally delivering all beings. When he encountered Confucians, he spoke of Confucianism; with Buddhists, he spoke of Buddhism; with Daoists, he spoke of the Dao. In matters of the Dao, he taught celestial immortality to those of great capacity, terrestrial immortality to those of middling capacity, and human immortality to those of lesser capacity. In matters of humanity, he expounded the practice of the Dao to the superior, karmic retribution to the average, and moral consequences to the inferior. His teachings were undifferentiated in form, yet he tailored his instruction to each individual’s aptitude. His aspiration was to guide every being in the world toward fulfillment—how vast was his vow to perpetuate the ancestral legacy!

**Collected Works of Master Zhang Sanfeng, Volume Nine**
*Recompiled by Li Xiyue of Hanjia, Mount Changyi*
*Respectfully transcribed by Zhang Daoyuan, styled Zishi*

**Published by Wan-Cheng’s Late Disciple Zhu Daosheng, styled Zijing**
**Collated by Nephew Ying Chuncheng and Zhu Zan, styled Suyuan**

**Preface to the Annotated *Lyrics of the Rootless Tree***

The *Awakening to Reality* of Tiantai elucidates the great matter of the return and restoration of the inner and outer elixirs. Yet in its time, those of shallow understanding and ignorance mistook it for a text on furnace-fire or sexual arts. Ye Wenshu, failing to grasp the principle of return, further appended superficial discourses on purity and stillness, riding its fame into circulation. Weng Baoguang, upon reading it, laughed and said, *"This is one who knows nothing of the Golden Elixir."* He then composed annotations to correct its errors. Lu Ziye and Chen Shangyang subsequently expanded upon it, and with the emergence of the *Three Commentaries on Awakening to Reality*, Ye’s notes faded into obscurity.

Master Zhang Sanfeng of Liaoyang was a celestial immortal. During his time in Wudang, he composed *Twenty-Four Daoist Songs of the Rootless Tree*, a work peerless with Zhang Boduan’s *Awakening to Reality*, though the world likewise misconstrued it as pertaining to sexual or furnace-fire practices. Hanxu sighed and said, *"The Dao does not spread because the Dao is not understood."* He longed to compose an exegesis to clarify it but lamented the absence of like-minded alchemical companions.

Liu Wuyuan of Qiyun, endowed with vast and penetrating eloquence, authored dozens of works transmitted to the world. Among them was his *Annotations on the Rootless Tree*. Hanxu obtained and examined it, finding its diction expansive and its principles perfectly comprehensive. Overjoyed, he exclaimed, *"He has anticipated what my heart already affirmed!"* Where Liu’s work left some matters unexhausted, Hanxu supplemented them, revealing in full the inner and outer medicines, the fire-phases of return, and the sequence of furnaces and crucibles. Thus, the *Two Exegeses on the Rootless Tree* stand as the *Three Commentaries on Awakening to Reality* do. Upon completing the work, he asked me to write a preface. Though unworthy, I record here the depth of his devotion.

*Respectfully inscribed by Qingxia Cave Master, with fellow disciple He Xifu, on the day of the Beginning of Autumn in the year Dingwei*

**Two Lyrics on the *Rootless Tree* (To the Tune of *Partridge Sky*)**

The transmission of the Dao’s methods knows true and deviant paths;
Those who stray from the true and embrace the deviant wander the earth.
Rarely seen is the phoenix soaring through the clouds,
While many, sunk in delusion, become frogs at the bottom of a well.
It is no difficult task to distinguish the clamor of chaos—
They mistake red earth for cinnabar.
To know the authentic path that penetrates the mysteries,
Study closely the blossoms beneath the *Rootless Tree*.

**Selling Flowers’ Cry**
Beneath the *Rootless Tree*, the eternal constant is expounded;
The six realms of sentient beings share a single light.
When you comprehend the affairs before and after *Vairocana’s* voice,
You see that fundamentally there is no coming or going—your bearing is majestic.

In the year *Jiazi* of the *Hongwu* reign’s seventeenth year, on the *Zhonghe* Festival, the remnant elder of the Great Yuan, Zhang Sanfeng, recorded this at the thatched hut of Mount Wudang’s Heavenly Pillar Peak.

**Lineage of the Perfected Zhang Sanfeng**
The Perfected was a native of Yizhou in Liaodong, surnamed Zhang, given name Junshi, style Yuanyuan, sobriquet Sanfengzi, also known as Kunyang. Some say his surname was Zhang, given name Zheng, style Junbao, sobriquet Yuanyuanzi. He lived at the end of the Song dynasty. Born with extraordinary qualities, his form resembled a tortoise, his bones those of a crane; he had large ears and round eyes. Standing over seven feet tall, his beard was long and bristling like a halberd, his topknot bound into a single coil, and he often wore a crescent-shaped cap. Clad in a single bamboo hat and patched robe, he endured both cold and heat without change. Neglecting his appearance, people called him "Zhang the Slovenly." He could consume a *sheng* or *dou* of food at a meal, yet at times would abstain from grain for months, remaining at ease.

During the Yanyou era, at the age of sixty-seven, he entered the southern reaches of Mount Song and encountered Lü Chunyang and Zheng Huolong, from whom he received the essential teachings of the Golden Elixir and cultivated the Dao to fruition. Some say he entered Mount Zhongnan and received transmission from the Fire Dragon Perfected, through which he cultivated the Dao to completion.

A fisherman of the Qinhuai, Shen Wanshan—also known as Wan San—was fond of virtue and delighted in almsgiving, yet constrained by poverty, he could not fulfill his aspirations. The Perfected One transmitted to him the art of transmuting stone into gold, thereby realizing his wishes. Wan San styled himself the "Daoist of Three Mountains," and his elixir chamber bore a couplet: *"Eight hundred fire-oxen plow the moonlit night; / Three thousand beauties laugh in the spring breeze."* The world called him the "Basin of Gathered Treasures," and Three Mountains Street in the southwest of the city was his former residence.

At the end of the Yuan dynasty, the Perfected One resided at Jintai Abbey in Baoji. In the ninth month of the *bingwu* year of the Zhizheng era, on the twentieth day, he declared his departure from the world, left a verse, and passed away. The scholar and commoner Yang Guishan prepared a coffin and completed the encoffining, but as the burial was about to commence, he revived—by then, he was one hundred and thirty years old.

Thereafter, he entered Shu and arrived at Mount Taihe, where he built a thatched hut at Jade Void Hermitage. Before the hermitage stood five ancient trees, beneath which he often perched. Fierce beasts did no harm, and birds of prey did not strike; all who witnessed this were astonished.

When asked about immortal arts, he would never answer; when asked about classics, he would discourse tirelessly. Once, he said to the villagers of Wudang, "This mountain shall one day achieve great renown." Later, during the Yongle era, the emperor ordered the restoration of Wudang. The Perfected One concealed himself among the laborers, toiling diligently, yet none recognized him—only Sun Biyun, the Perfected One of Azure Clouds, knew him well. At the time, Biyun served as the abbot of Wudang Mountain, and through their exchanges, he received much benefit from the Perfected One. The Perfected One’s name had reached the celestial court, and though the emperor repeatedly sent envoys to summon him, he never complied, only entrusting poems and lyrics to Biyun to present on his behalf. Later, he transmitted the Dao to the Daoist Yuan Jing and vanished without a trace.

**The Yongle Emperor’s Letter in Reverence of [Zhang] Sanfeng**

With utmost reverence, the Emperor addresses the True Immortal, Master Zhang Sanfeng:

For long have I admired the True Immortal, yearning to personally receive your guidance and example. I have dispatched envoys bearing incense and letters, earnestly inviting you from every renowned mountain. The True Immortal’s virtue and power are lofty, transcending all existence, harmonizing with nature, and attaining unfathomable mystery. Though my talents are meager and my virtue shallow, my sincere desire to meet you has never waned, day or night. With profound respect, I once more send envoys, bearing incense and this letter, humbly awaiting the arrival of your dragon carriage and phoenix chariot. May you graciously come, fulfilling my earnest and unwavering admiration.

Respectfully presented.

**Zhang Sanfeng’s Poetic Reply Entrusted to Sun Biyun for Presentation**

The sacred master’s oral instructions,
A luminous method bequeathed for ages.
Passed to the people of this world,
How many truly comprehend?

When clothes tear, patch them with cloth;
When trees wither, nourish them with earth.
When a person declines, what can restore them?
The mechanism of yin and yang’s creation.

Draw forth the treasure from Kan’s depths,
A golden flower reveals a single branch.
Auspicious clouds unfold across the heavens,
Propitious light fills the realm of death.

Returning, one is dull and silent,
Like one drunk or lost in stupor.
The Great Elixir, like a grain of millet,
Sheds its husk to realize non-action.

Roaming freely through heaven and earth’s expanse,
All phenomena become a pearl in the palm.
Whoever consumes this medicine
Shall live as long as heaven and earth.
If it fails to extend life,
Then all my words are false.

The Golden Elixir weighs one *jin*,
Close your eyes and silently preserve the spirit.
It is found within your own home—
Why seek it elsewhere?

Refine the mercury of the Departing Maiden,
Consume the essence of the Kan Man.
The Golden Elixir and the firing times,
Each word is the primordial sound.

---

**Annotations on the Venerable Master Zhang Sanfeng’s *Lyrics of the Rootless Tree***

**Liu Wuyuan of Yunqi Mountain, notes**
**Li Hanxu of Changyi Mountain, expanded explanations**

**[Liu’s Notes]**
*The Rootless Tree* is the title of these lyrics. All trees require roots to grow; without roots, they cannot endure. Human life in this world—birth, aging, illness, death—appears and vanishes in an instant. A century passes like a spark or lightning flash, much like a rootless tree. The Immortal Elder’s twenty-four lyrics, titled *The Rootless Tree*, awaken the world, urging people to see through the illusory dream of floating life and swiftly cultivate their nature and destiny.

**[Li’s Explanations]**
*The Rootless Tree* refers to the *qi* of the human body. All the body’s meridians arise from *qi*, which itself emerges from the realm of emptiness and nothingness—hence, "rootless." The alchemist nurtures roots within this empty realm, where both pre-heavenly and post-heavenly *qi* arise from nothingness. Thus, the rootless is the origin of the rooted. Those refining the post-heavenly must enter nothingness to seek being, then merge being into nothingness; those refining the pre-heavenly must merge being into nothingness, then return from nothingness to being. Such is the cultivation of the root’s cause. However, the *qi* of the human body differs in youth, prime, and old age, just as the *qi* of refinement varies in the early, middle, and late stages. The twenty-four chapters correspond to the year’s seasons, all urging one to observe the flowers beneath the rootless tree in due time—this is the perfection of the Dao’s sentiment.

---

**1.**
**[Liu’s Note]** Lamenting the world.
**[Li’s Note]** Urging people to nurture the hidden flower.

The rootless tree,
Its flowers deeply secluded—
Who would cease their craving for glory and splendor?
The affairs of floating life,
A boat upon the sea of suffering,
Tossed to and fro without freedom.
No shore, no bounds, no place to moor,
Ever drifting through perilous waters of fish and dragons.
If one turns their head,
There lies the shore—
Do not wait for the storm to wreck your boat.

**[Wu Yuan’s Note]** "I do not know to what tune this belongs."
**[Hanxu’s Note]** "Those who sing *Daoist sentiments* call it *Pulling Back the Black Clouds*."

**[Liu’s Notes]**
Flowers are the radiant essence of the tree.

The human body is like a tree, and the human true spirit is like the tree’s flower. All trees have roots, thus they can grow and bloom. Only the human body has no root—life and death are impermanent, wholly dependent on the movement of that single point of true spirit’s qi. When the true spirit flourishes, the body endures and lives; when the true spirit decays, the body perishes and dies. Human survival or demise, life or death, rests entirely on the flourishing or decay of this true spirit. Though it is the flower of the human tree, it is in truth the root of the human tree.

Master Yuyang called this true spirit the "Yellow Sprout"; Master Boyang called it the "Golden Flower"; Master Chunyang called it the "Spiritual Root"; Master Ziyang called it "True Gold"; Yaofu called it the "Heavenly Root"; the Immortal Elder called it "Golden Essence." The various alchemical classics also refer to this true spirit as the "Primordial Unity Qi." Though its names are manifold, they all describe this one thing.

This thing is born of the Primordial, concealed within the Later Heaven. It positions Heaven and Earth, governs yin and yang, moves the Five Phases, and nurtures the myriad things. Vast, it has no exterior; minute, it has no interior. Released, it fills the Six Directions; gathered, it retreats into secrecy.

In terms of its essence: in Confucianism, it is called the Supreme Ultimate; in Daoism, the Golden Elixir; in Buddhism, Perfect Enlightenment. In terms of its function: in Confucianism, it is called Illustrious Virtue, the Heart-Mind of Heaven and Earth; in Daoism, the Numinous Treasure, the Mysterious Pearl of Millet; in Buddhism, the Treasury of the True Dharma Eye, the Wondrous Heart of Nirvana.

The human true spirit is originally round and complete, radiant and luminous, pure and bare, unadorned and free—neither born nor destroyed, neither form nor emptiness. In the sage, it does not increase; in the ordinary person, it does not diminish. Yet through interaction with the Later Heaven, the common people lose it, while the noble person preserves it—thus arises the distinction between sage and ordinary.

The common people lose it by forsaking this true spirit and pursuing the false spirit. The noble person preserves it by retaining this true spirit and not chasing the false spirit. Because the common people cling to the false spirit, the true spirit becomes dim and obscure. Following their desires, they crave glory and splendor, vie for fame and profit, never ceasing. Mistaking the false for the true, a hundred worries disturb their hearts, ten thousand affairs weary their forms—like a boat upon the sea of suffering, tossed to and fro, ever drifting through the perilous waters of fish and dragons.

If one can suddenly awaken and turn back, they instantly transcend to the other shore. Do not wait for the storm to wreck your boat and lose your life. Once the human form is lost, escape is impossible for ten thousand kalpas.

**Li’s Exegesis**

For years, this mountain dweller has secluded himself beneath the *Rootless Tree*, ever desiring to expound its profound mysteries and summon those of like kind. One day, strolling through the mountain garden, I beheld the serene seclusion of flowers and trees, their natural abundance overflowing—suddenly grasping that this character *you* (幽, "seclusion") is the wellspring from which the twenty-four chapters of the *Rootless Tree* arise. *You* means depth, the realm of emptiness and nothingness. All such realms of emptiness are the sacred precincts where Daoists cultivate flowers and trees. Thus, my mountain teacher inscribed upon the *Bamboo-Embracing Studio*:

*"Three paths of secluded blossoms, fragrance at ease,*
*Four gardens of cultivated bamboo, shadows intertwined."*

How wondrous these words, harmonizing perfectly with this truth! Without deep seclusion, flowers cannot exude their fragrance freely; amidst the red dust of worldly affairs, peace is unattainable day or night. As for *"shadows intertwined"*—this is the hollow heart and tranquil *qi* depending upon one another, whereby one’s *qi* nourishes the heart, and the heart nourishes the *qi*. When *qi* flourishes and principle abounds, the heart is at peace and the spirit whole, preserving one’s true nature and containing one’s numinous essence.

Wu Yuan was right to take *"true spirit"* as the root and flower of the human tree. The *true spirit* is true knowing and numinous knowing. Numinous knowing pertains to *yin* nature, true knowing to *yang* emotion. When nature and emotion remain uncorrupted, the true spirit is complete. Yet alas, the seven emotions and six desires erode and deplete it, inwardly damaging one’s nature and outwardly harming one’s emotions—until the true spirit vanishes. With the true spirit gone, the tree has no flower, no root.

Wu Yuan’s essential meaning is thus. Yet I have more to say: flowers grow from the tree, the tree from the root, the root from nothingness. The essence of the true spirit is indeed conceived within the womb of emptiness—hence the phrase *"the flower is truly secluded."* This conception within emptiness is none other than humanity’s primordial wisdom, the *empty numinosity* within each person—formless and traceless, yet containing all principles and responding to all affairs. Sages and worthies employ it with abundance, immortals and buddhas cultivate it to perfection, but it must never be entangled with emotions and desires. Once entangled, one daily extracts *being* from *non-being* to meet worldly needs, and in daily extracting *being*, one daily loses *non-being*. In daily losing *non-being*, one daily loses the root; losing the root, one loses the tree; losing the tree, one loses the flower. The common saying goes: *"When people grow old, they go senile; when trees grow old, their hearts hollow."* Wisdom is exhausted, empty numinosity scattered—where then is the true spirit?

All this comes from clinging to glory and splendor, refusing to rest, daily engaging in the affairs of fleeting life. They never consider that a hundred years pass in an instant, that upon death all matters are abandoned, and the body sits in the boat upon the sea of suffering. Nor do they consider that when impermanence strikes, the nature sinks with the capsized boat—boundless and shore-less, mooring and anchorage lost. Drifting and wandering through the perilous waters of fish and dragons, they rush about in endless toil, vainly wounding their wisdom and shackling their empty numinosity. What benefit is there in this?

The Immortal Master, moved by profound compassion, steers the compassionate vessel to ferry them, saying: The reason worldly people sink deeply into the sea of suffering and struggle to escape is simply that they refuse to turn back and do not recognize the shore. If they would but turn back, that is the shore. The shore is the path of awakening. Those who ascend this path find wisdom restored, empty numinosity enduring, past errors amendable, and future truths still attainable. Though spirit and *qi* may have declined, there is still a way to return. Do not wait until the storm’s surging waves shatter your boat—only then may the boat and its passenger be preserved, serving as provisions for the other shore and aid in emerging from the abyss.

**Liu’s Note:** Exhort the diligent learner.
**Li’s Note:** Urge people to graft and cultivate.

*The Rootless Tree, its flower now faint,*
*The aged tree must graft fresh branches anew.*
*Plum on willow, mulberry on pear—*
*Pass this on as a model for those who cultivate the truth.*
*Since ancient times, immortals have had their grafting methods;*
*When people grow old, there is medicine to heal them.*
*Seek a wise teacher, inquire of the method—*
*Begin swiftly, for even then it may be too late.*

Wu Yuan’s annotated edition renders *wei* (微) as *wei* (危, "perilous"), which also aligns with the sense of decline. **Liu’s Commentary:** Many doubt that when old age arrives and vitality wanes, the spirit is limited—like a tree’s flower withering in peril, unable to return to its origin or restore its root. Thus, they abandon themselves to despair, awaiting death. Yet observe how in the world, old trees grafted with tender branches flourish anew—plum on willow, mulberry on pear. These are inanimate things, yet they can revive. How much more so for humans, the most numinous of all beings, endowed with heaven and earth’s upright *qi*? Can the old truly lack medicine to heal them? What is this healing medicine? It is the method of grafting in old age. To know this method, hasten to seek a wise teacher and inquire of the true formula. Once obtained, begin swiftly—for even then it may be too late.

**Li’s Exegesis:** *Wei* means decline. When people grow old, their primordial *qi* declines, and they must urgently graft and replenish. Observe the examples of plum on willow and mulberry on pear—these serve as models. *Ji* ("to lodge") corresponds to the alchemical method of dwelling in the *dui* trigram’s gate or lodging in the western neighbor’s body; *jie* ("to graft") corresponds to the alchemical method of joining nature with life or oneself with another. Thus, plum on willow and mulberry on pear are precisely the models for modern truth-cultivators and the grafting methods of ancient immortals. Grafting is the medicine for old age.

The method of grafting trees has its fine techniques. Speaking of plum, willow, mulberry, and pear, these are of the same kind. When grafting, split the old branch, insert the tender shoot, bind and secure it, pack it with good soil, and let *yin* and *yang* interlock—this is the method of grafting trees. The medicine for old age must likewise employ like with like, blending with wondrous soil, only then can one return to youth and restore the origin. This method is known to wise teachers—it remains for people to seek them out.

Swift cultivation may still be too slow, for time waits for no one—impermanence arrives in an instant, and if one’s nature remains unenlightened while life remains unestablished, one strays into the vast and desolate realm of ghosts. Immortal He the Maiden said: *"In the Gardens of Lang, peach trees bear drooping willow branches; on Fusang’s boughs, intertwined pears take form—this is the alchemical method revealed by the Eastern King and the Queen Mother of the West."* The words of Zhang Sanfeng are not without foundation.

Further, as Liu observes, the work of refining the self. As Li notes, the marvel of flowers and willows. *"The rootless tree, its blossoms fresh and green—flower-wine immortals from ancient times to now. In the brothel’s den, the meat-and-wine grove, one neither shuns flesh nor transgresses lust. To transgress lust is to lose the treasure of long life; meat and wine pass through the gut, yet the Dao abides in the heart. Open the gate and I shall tell you: without flowers and wine, the Dao cannot be achieved."*

In Wu Yuan’s annotated edition, *"green"* is rendered as *"pure,"* yet *"green"* signifies the freshness of new growth, akin to purity untainted. Liu comments: The path of the Golden Elixir takes absolute purity—utterly free of dross—as its destination. Yet to attain such purity, one must first emerge from the depths of turbidity. Only by remaining unstained amid the deepest murk does true purity arise. Thus it is said: *"The rootless tree, its blossoms pure—flower-wine immortals from ancient times to now."*

How can one see that flowers and wine may forge immortality? The brothel’s den and the meat-and-wine grove are the very snares that beguile mortals. Yet if one can perceive color without being ensnared by it, resisting the allure of sensual pleasures, and if one can wander through the grove of wine and meat without being burdened by them—neither abstaining from flesh nor indulging in lust—then the appetites of food and desire are transformed. The heart of the Dao remains constant, the human heart fades away, the true spirit suffers no harm, and the great Dao may be attained.

When it says *"not abstaining from flesh,"* it does not mean clinging to it, but rather letting meat and wine pass through the body while the heart remains untroubled. To refrain from lust is to have no brothel in the heart; to consume meat and wine is to have no wine or meat in the heart. Without the brothel in the heart, the immortal blossom of long life naturally blooms; without wine and meat in the heart, the wine of extended life naturally flows. With the immortal blossom and immortal wine, one arrives at the realm of pure truth. Those in the world who shun brothels and avoid meat and wine—how could they know that immortals emerge from the midst of mortal flowers and wine? How could they know that without flowers and wine, the Dao cannot be achieved?

The *"Song of Knocking on the Hexagrams"* says: *"Wine is a good friend, flowers a companion; seek the true person in the willow lanes and flower streets—the true person is found only in the play of flowers."* This harmonizes with the marvel of *"blossoms pure."*

Li explains: The appetites for food and desire weigh heaviest upon mortals. Immortal Zhang Sanfeng used flowers and wine as metaphors. Many crave flowers and wine, but who knows of the flower-wine immortals? The primordial *qi* within the body is fresh and verdant. If one can consume it, harness it, drink it, and adorn oneself with it, the spirit becomes clear and the *qi* invigorated—this is the flower-wine immortal, present from ancient times to now. Yet this is not the brothel’s den or the meat-and-wine grove of the world.

Brothels and wine-meat dull the spirit; the *qi* of meat and wine is turbid, and brothels stir lust. Both are harmful, but lust is the greater danger. Those who refine themselves well eat when they encounter food, without seeking more, so they do not abstain from flesh yet forget it entirely. They see color as no-color, do not cling to beauty, and thus do not transgress lust, for lust is extinguished. Otherwise, essence scatters and fluids leak, causing no small harm. As the *Yellow Court Classic* says: *"Leaves fall, the tree withers, losing its verdant hue; only by sealing and guarding the light can one attain lasting peace."* Thus, to transgress lust is to lose the treasure of long life.

Meat and wine pass through the gut, yet the Dao remains in the heart—how could flowers and wine delude one? It is people who delude themselves with flowers and wine! Seek not mortal flowers and wine, and you will find immortal blossoms and wine. Immortal blossoms and wine aid the attainment of the Dao—they are the fresh, verdant flowers on the rootless tree, rich in flavor and vibrant in hue, most nourishing.

The immortal master opens the gate of the primordial and tells you: without such flowers and wine, the Dao is difficult to achieve.

Further, as Liu says, severing the side doors. As Li laments, solitary cultivation. *"The rootless tree, its blossoms solitary—pray tell, does yin and yang find their kind? The hen’s egg, though laid, cannot hatch a chick, for it has turned its back on the furnace of yin-yang transformation. A woman without a husband is a resentful maiden; a man without a wife is a widowed bachelor. Alas for the deluded, so utterly confused—sitting in stillness, cultivating alone, their qi withers away."*

Liu comments: The path of cultivating truth requires yin and yang to find their kind, only then can the treasure of the true spirit be perfected. If there is yin without yang, or yang without yin, this is a solitary blossom without its counterpart—the true spirit cannot form, just as the hen’s egg cannot hatch a chick. For it has turned its back on the furnace of yin-yang union and transformation. Likewise, a woman without a husband or a man without a wife—how can they bear offspring?

Those blind fools of the world, who do not fathom the principles of yin and yang or trace the source of transformation, muddle through their practice—some contemplating emptiness, some regulating breath, some visualizing spirits, some guarding cavities, some circulating *qi*—all are solitary cultivation in stillness, yin without yang. Not only do they fail to benefit nature and life, but they harm them, growing ever more desiccated with each passing day.

Li explains: *"Solitary"* refers to inner cultivation. Cultivating nature alone cannot establish life, for it is solitary and without a counterpart, failing to give rise to the treasure of life. It is like a hen without a rooster—though it may lay eggs, it cannot hatch chicks. Those today who cultivate nature to nurture *qi* do not realize their *qi* is but solitary yin.

To avoid desiccation, one must pair true yang with true yin—only then are they of the same kind. I ask those who cultivate the Dao: have you attained this pairing? Now, true yang is *yi* (righteousness), and true yin is the Dao. When *yi* and the Dao are paired, they are no longer solitary.

Yet within this lies three layered stages: first, true yin generates true yang; next, true yang pairs with true yin; then, from the intercourse of yin and yang, the true numinous *qi* of vastness is born. How could this be like the hen’s egg, difficult to hatch? Those who cannot hatch the chick have turned their backs on the principle of yin and yang and the furnace of creation.

Yin and yang are husband and wife. The Dao of the sages begins with husband and wife, and through them, the myriad things are transformed and born. The same holds for the men and women of the world. If a woman has no husband, she is solitary yin that cannot give life and becomes a resentful maiden. If a man has no wife, he is solitary yang that cannot be nurtured and becomes a widowed bachelor. This principle is clear and easy to understand, yet the deluded disciples of the world remain utterly confused. They believe that solitary cultivation in stillness can clarify the mind, reveal the nature, and allow one to ascend directly—all while neglecting the pairing of yin and yang. I fear that with each day of sitting and cultivating, they wander the halls of empty nothingness and play in the sea of extinction, until their *qi* grows ever more withered.

**Liu’s Note:** The pairing of yin and yang.
**Li’s Note:** The inversion of yin and yang.

The rootless tree, its flowers askew—
Departed from yin and yang, the Dao is incomplete.
Gold parted from wood, mercury parted from lead,
Yang widowed, yin solitary, each to one side.

In the world, yin and yang—man paired with woman—
Bear sons and grandsons, generation after generation.
Following the sequence makes one mortal; reversing it, immortal—
The difference lies solely in this inversion.

**Liu’s Commentary:**
The *Book of Changes* states: *"The alternation of yin and yang is called the Dao."* The *True Sayings of Awakening* says: *"When yin and yang find their kind, they unite in intercourse; when the two eights correspond, they naturally join in kinship."* If yin and yang are each askew—if yang stirs but yin does not respond, if yin seeks but yang does not beckon, if yang exceeds and yin falls short, or if yang flourishes while yin is deficient—then the flower of true numinosity is askew, neither centered nor upright, and the Dao remains incomplete.

A person’s true passion is like gold, true knowing like lead—both are firm. Numinous nature is like wood, numinous knowing like mercury—both are yielding. True passion and true knowing, firm yet prone to sinking; numinous nature and numinous knowing, yielding yet prone to floating. If nature seeks passion and passion returns to nature, if the true governs the numinous and the numinous returns to the true, then firm and yielding respond, yin and yang harmonize, and they transform into a single *qi*, with life’s mechanism enduring unceasingly.

But if passion does not return to nature, if the numinous does not return to the true, this is what is meant by *"gold parted from wood, mercury parted from lead, yang widowed, yin solitary, each to one side."* How then can one return to the root and revert to the origin, coalescing the elixir of true numinosity? Observe the world: when man and woman pair, they bear sons and grandsons, generation after generation, perpetuating the lineage. Thus, in the Dao of cultivating the true, when yin and yang unite, they give birth to immortals and sages, also perpetuating the lineage without end. The difference lies only in whether one follows the sequence or reverses it—mortals follow, immortals reverse. The distinction rests solely in this inversion.

This *"middle"* is profound in principle and most subtle in practice. It is not the middle between inner and outer, nor the middle of the body’s upper and lower. It is the middle of yin and yang’s intercourse, formless and imageless, called the root of heaven and earth, the cavity of yin and yang, the abode of life and death, the Gate of the Mysterious Female. Birth and death occur here; sagehood and worthiness are determined here; whether one becomes human or beast depends on this. If cultivators can plant their feet firmly here and reverse the flow, then in the space of inversion, calamity transforms into fortune, punishment into virtue. This is what is meant by *"the elixir is completed in a single hour."*

Alas! The *"middle"* is not easily known, and the *"inversion"* is also difficult to comprehend. The sexual arts take the place of man and woman’s union as the *"middle"* and the man’s absorption of the woman’s essence as *"inversion."* The circulation schools take the Yellow Court as the *"middle"* and the ascent of *qi* and descent of blood as *"inversion."* All these are but the beginnings of error—how could they fathom the meaning of the *"middle"* and *"inversion"* in the Dao of immortals? Diligent learners should discern this early.

**Li’s Explanation:**
*"Askew"* refers to yin and yang being parted, unable to complete the elixir. When yin and yang unite in the middle, the knife and spoon congeal, and the Dao’s arts are fully realized. Gold and wood, lead and mercury—these are yin and yang. The essence of wood and the nature of mercury belong to yin; the *qi* of gold and the passion of lead belong to yang. Essence and *qi* depend on each other, nature and passion unite in intercourse. Gold cherishes wood’s benevolence, wood loves gold’s righteousness; mercury goes forth to welcome lead, lead comes to join mercury. Only then is there no illness of separation, and the great medicine’s true body is born.

If yin is solitary and yang widowed, each to one side, then yin and yang do not pair, remaining askew and incomplete. How can they transform and give life to the utmost reality, perpetuating it for ten thousand generations? The method of pairing is similar for immortals and mortals—only mortals use the sequence, while immortals use the reverse.

Master Wu Yuan said that the *"middle"* and *"inversion"* are beyond people’s understanding; I say that even the *"reverse"* is unknown to them. To grasp the *"middle"* and *"inversion,"* one must first know the wondrous use of *"reverse."* If one knows *"reverse,"* then gold, wood, lead, and mercury are all within it, yin and yang, *qian* and *kun* are entirely inverted, and all events revolve within the *"reverse."* The medicine is obtained, the elixir returned—success may be expected in an instant.

**Liu’s Note:** When the medicine is born.
**Li’s Note:** The principle of *kun* and *shen.*

The rootless tree, its flowers renewed,
Born in the *kun* direction—*kun* is the person.

Pluck the flower and wear it, gather the flower’s heart,
Layer upon layer, its pistils glow with spring’s radiance.
The world does not fathom the principle within the flower—
A single secret of heaven’s mechanism is worth ten thousand gold.

Borrow the flower’s name, embody the flower’s form,
Each line of the *"Knocking on Hexagrams"* speaks truly.

**Liu’s Note:** *"New"* refers to the original substance long buried, suddenly reappearing. When the flower is renewed, its brilliance revives. Like the moon emerging in the southwest *kun* direction, beneath pure yin, a speck of subtle yang unfurls—akin to emptiness giving birth to light, the true spirit revealed, the original face restored. This original face is the undying true person within me. With this person, one is human; without it, one is not. It is what I receive from heaven to be human. Yet this true person rarely appears, not to be seen at will. Only in utter emptiness and profound stillness, when all conditions are stilled, does a fleeting image arise. Utter emptiness and profound stillness are the image of pure yin in *kun*, hence *"born in the kun direction—kun is the person."* This person has long been buried beneath dust and grime, leaving no trace. Once its image appears, it is the new flower—timing must not be missed. One must swiftly act, plucking and gathering it for oneself. *"Pluck the flower and wear it"* means to pluck the flower of this true person. *"Gather the flower’s heart"* means to gather the heart of this true person. Gradually plucking and gathering, from little to much, accumulating depth and radiating light, the true spirit remains undimmed. Then the flower’s pistils unfold layer by layer, all principles become luminous, following the heart’s intent wherever it leads, every step the Dao. Its splendor is like spring, yang qi spreading across the earth, flowers blooming everywhere. Yet this flower is possessed by all, seen by all, yet none comprehend it. Most let it slip by before their eyes. If one does grasp it, transcending the mundane to enter sagehood happens in an instant—hence *"a single secret of heaven’s mechanism is worth ten thousand gold."* The immortal elder, in compassion, borrows the flower’s name and embodies its form, now tangible, now intangible. Each line of *"Knocking on Hexagrams"* expounds the subtleties of the primordial, wishing for all to attain the Dao and each to become an immortal. Alas, the world does not fathom the principle within the flower, and some still wildly speculate with misguided practices like *"guiding the woman"* or *"chamber elixirs."* Even the immortal elder can do nothing about this—how lamentable!

**Li’s Explanation:** Master Wu Yuan speaks of the *"person"* as the original face, having once glimpsed this person, his words flow at length and his heart bears deep compassion, seeking to awaken both self and others. Yet the *"is"* in *"kun is the person"* remains obscure. The flower is likened to the person, and the person borrows the flower as metaphor. *"The flower is renewed"* is like a person returning to the root, cultivating emptiness and stillness, observing the solitary yang’s return—unawares, spring’s colors renew. This flower appears in the *kun* direction, meaning *kun* sees the flower, the flower sees the person, where the flower is born is where the person is born—hence *"kun is the person."* In elixir methods, lead is planted in the metal village, mercury sown in the fire land. Metal and fire reside in the southwest; the southwest gains its companion. Where metal and fire unite is precisely above the *kun* direction. This person is a golden body and fiery form, a mass of pure yang—our true qi, also called true emotion. Vague yet distinct, within it lies an image, hot as fire, radiant as a flower. The flower’s fragrance intoxicates like wine—obtaining it is like being drunk. At this moment, one must pluck and wear it without delay. One must further gather its heart, swallowing it whole. From flower to pistil, penetrating layer upon layer, truly it is a spring palace of splendor. The world knows only the exterior, not the interior, and thus cannot grasp the wondrous principle within the flower. The wondrous principle within the flower is pure heavenly mechanism. When the heavenly mechanism flows forth, a single secret is worth ten thousand gold. The fourth, fifth, sixth, and seventh lines here are all from Lü Zu’s *"Knocking on Hexagrams Song."* Master Feng said: *"Lü Zu borrows the flower’s name for the human body and the flower’s form for the person’s form. Each line I use from 'Knocking on Hexagrams' speaks with utmost truth and savor."* **Liu’s Note:** Seize the moment to gather it.

**Li’s Note:** Before the furnace, settle into stillness.

The rootless tree blooms in full profusion,
Fair features and delicate charm outshine powdered faces.
Guard against the monkey and horse, stubborn and unruly—
Raise the iron mask your mother bore.
Draw forth the true treasure-sword of the Azure Dragon,
Pluck every fresh blossom from the wall’s edge.
Catch the wind’s sail, return fully laden—
How could one pass the mountain of treasure empty-handed?

*"Wall’s edge"* may be rendered *"jade blossoms,"* and *"jade blossoms"* as *"wall’s edge"*—I have seen both. This annotation takes *"wall’s edge"* as more evocative, so I follow it.

**Liu’s Annotation:** When the primordial true spirit shines forth, one root branches into ten thousand forms. Gazing upon images in their season, nothing exists that is not a flower in full bloom. At the height of its flourishing, its splendor is fully revealed, its essence spent outwardly, easily drawn into rivalry and vanity, flaunting its allure. Hence it is said: *"Fair features and delicate charm outshine powdered faces."* At such a time, one must guard against peril and contemplate danger, firmly tether the monkey and horse, raise the iron mask your mother bore, and grasp the treasure-sword of the Azure Dragon. In the face of phenomena, forget emotion, pluck every fresh blossom from the wall’s edge, allowing not the slightest attachment to form or dissipation of true qi.

The *"iron mask your mother bore"* is the unfeeling, unknowing iron visage. The *"treasure-sword of the Azure Dragon"* is the true nature, unstained and unattached. The iron mask your mother bore is the treasure-sword of the Azure Dragon—both emerge from the same source but bear different names. In terms of essence, it is the iron mask your mother bore; in terms of function, it is the treasure-sword of the Azure Dragon. The iron mask is the settled body; the treasure-sword is the instrument of wisdom. Settling gives rise to wisdom; wisdom perfects settling. Settling and wisdom depend on each other, essence and function never parted.

The primordial true spirit is form yet emptiness, ever-responsive yet ever-still, without leakage or loss. This is what is meant by *"pluck every fresh blossom from the wall’s edge."* The blossoms at the wall’s edge have just emerged but not yet left the wall, when true qi has not yet dispersed. Plucking them at this moment leaves no dross, pure as heaven’s truth. Gradually they grow, gradually they are gathered; gradually they are plucked, gradually they are reaped—one must pluck until nothing remains to be plucked.

Alas! The great medicine is hard to encounter; the great method is hard to meet. Fortunate to have met it, the moment must not be missed. Catch the wind’s sail, swiftly gather the fresh blossoms, return fully laden—how could one pass the mountain of treasure empty-handed, only to regret it later?

**[Li’s Exegesis]**
"Abundance" refers to the moment of fullness. The beauty of a fair face and delicate features is likened to the primordial unity of qi—just as the Immortal Elder’s *Five Watches’ Daoist Ballad* says: *"When the host of yin is spent, the radiant yang season arrives, / A branch of spring’s hue, golden blossoms resplendent."* The "powdered-cluster contest" marks the birth of the medicine, the very hour when the Flower Demon vies in beauty. Ancient immortals warned: *"When the primordial appears, the Medicine Demon easily arises."* Without refining the self to utter purity—seeing beauty yet unmoved—who could seize the golden blossom in but half an instant?
